<p>Activation of T cells requires (1) binding of antigen/MHC complex and (2) an additional 2nd signal.
C. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>helper T-cell activation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Extracellular antigen (e.g., foreign protein) is phagocytosed, processed, and presented on MHC class II, which is expressed by antigen presenting cells (APCs).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>B7 on APC binds CD28 on <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>helper T cells providing 2nd activation signal.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Activated <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>helper T cells secrete cytokines that "help" inflammation and are divided into two subsets.
i. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}} 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">H</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> subset secretes IFN- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span> (activates macrophage, promotes B-cell class switching from IgM to IgG, promotes <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}} 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">H</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> phenotype and inhibits <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}} 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">H</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span> phenotype).
ii. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}} 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">H</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span> subset secretes IL-4 (facilitates B-cell class switching to IgE), IL-5 (eosinophil chemotaxis and activation, and class switching to IgA), and IL-13 (function similar to IL-4).
D. CD8 <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>cytotoxic T-cell activation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Intracellular antigen (derived from proteins in the cytoplasm) is processed and presented on MHC class I, which is expressed by all nucleated cells and platelets.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>IL-2 from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+}{ }^{+} \mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}} 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.9946em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">H</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> cell provides 2 nd activation signal.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cytotoxic T cells are activated for killing.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Killing occurs via
i. Secretion of perforin and granzyme; perforin creates pores that allow granzyme to enter the target cell, activating apoptosis.
ii. Expression of FasL, which binds Fas on target cells, activating apoptosis</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-b-lymphocytes">III. B LYMPHOCYTES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-b-lymphocytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Immature B cells are produced in the bone marrow and undergo immunoglobulin rearrangements to become naïve B cells that express surface IgM and IgD.
B. B-cell activation occurs via</p>
<ol>
<li>Antigen binding by surface IgM or IgD; results in maturation to IgM- or IgDsecreting plasma cells</li>
<li>B-cell antigen presentation to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>helper T cells via MHC class II.
i. CD40 receptor on B cell binds CD40L on helper T cell, providing 2nd activation signal.
ii. Helper T cell then secretes IL-4 and IL-5 (mediate B-cell isotype switching, hypermutation, and maturation to plasma cells).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-granulomatous-inflammation">IV. GRANULOMATOUS INFLAMMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-granulomatous-inflammation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Subtype of chronic inflammation
B. Characterized by granuloma, which is a collection of epithelioid histiocytes (macrophages with abundant pink cytoplasm), usually surrounded by giant cells and a rim of lymphocytes
C. Divided into noncaseating and caseating subtypes</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Noncaseating granulomas lack central necrosis (Fig. 2.2A). Common etiologies include reaction to foreign material, sarcoidosis, beryllium exposure, Crohn disease, and cat scratch disease.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Caseating granulomas exhibit central necrosis and are characteristic of tuberculosis and fungal infections (Fig. 2.2B).
D. Steps involved in granuloma formation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Macrophages process and present antigen via MHC class II to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>helper T cells.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Interaction leads macrophages to secrete IL-12, inducing <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>helper T cells to differentiate into <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}} 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">H</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> subtype.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}} 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">H</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> cells secrete IFN- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>γ</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\gamma</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05556em;">γ</span></span></span></span></span>, which converts macrophages to epithelioid histiocytes and giant cells.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="primary-immunodeficiency">PRIMARY IMMUNODEFICIENCY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#primary-immunodeficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-digeorge-syndrome">I. DIGEORGE SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-digeorge-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Developmental failure of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches</p>
<ol>
<li>Due to 22 q 11 microdeletion
B. Presents with T-cell deficiency (lack of thymus); hypocalcemia (lack of parathyroids); and abnormalities of heart, great vessels, and face</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-severe-combined-immunodeficiency-scid">II. SEVERE COMBINED IMMUNODEFICIENCY (SCID)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-severe-combined-immunodeficiency-scid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Defective cell-mediated and humoral immunity
B. Etiologies include</p>
<ol>
<li>Cytokine receptor defects-Cytokine signaling is necessary for proliferation and maturation of B and T cells.</li>
<li>Adenosine deaminase (ADA) deficiency-ADA is necessary to deaminate adenosine and deoxyadenosine for excretion as waste products; buildup of adenosine and deoxyadenosine is toxic to lymphocytes.</li>
<li>MHC class II deficiency-MHC class II is necessary for <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>helper T cell activation and cytokine production.
C. Characterized by susceptibility to fungal, viral, bacterial, and protozoal infections, including opportunistic infections and live vaccines
D. Treatment is sterile isolation ('bubble baby') and stem cell transplantation.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-x-linked-agammaglobulinemia">III. X-LINKED AGAMMAGLOBULINEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-x-linked-agammaglobulinemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Complete lack of immunoglobulin due to disordered B-cell maturation</p>
<ol>
<li>Pre- and pro-B cells cannot mature.
B. Due to mutated Bruton tyrosine kinase; X-linked
C. Presents after 6 months of life with recurrent bacterial, enterovirus (e.g., polio and coxsackievirus), and Giardia lamblia infections; maternal antibodies present during the first 6 months of life are protective.
D. Live vaccines (e.g., polio) must be avoided.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-common-variable-immunodeficiency-cvid">IV. COMMON VARIABLE IMMUNODEFICIENCY (CVID)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-common-variable-immunodeficiency-cvid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Low immunoglobulin due to B-cell or helper T-cell defects
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6f1eeb68.jpeg" alt="img-14.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 2.2 Granuloma. A, Noncaseating. B, Caseating.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-38ada159.jpeg" alt="img-15.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 2.3 Angioedema. (Courtesy of James Heilman, MD, Wikipedia)</p>
<p>B. Increased risk for bacterial, enterovirus, and Giardia lamblia infections, usually in late childhood
C. Increased risk for autoimmune disease and lymphoma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="v-iga-deficiency">V. IgA DEFICIENCY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-iga-deficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Low serum and mucosal IgA; most common immunoglobulin deficiency
B. Increased risk for mucosal infection, especially viral; however, most patients are asymptomatic.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-hyper-igm-syndrome">VI. HYPER-IgM SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-hyper-igm-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Characterized by elevated IgM
B. Due to mutated CD40L (on helper T cells) or CD40 receptor (on B cells)</p>
<ol>
<li>Second signal cannot be delivered to helper T cells during B-cell activation.</li>
<li>Consequently, cytokines necessary for immunoglobulin class switching are not produced.
C. Low IgA, IgG, and IgE result in recurrent pyogenic infections (due to poor opsonization), especially at mucosal sites.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-wiskott-aldrich-syndrome">VII. WISKOTT-ALDRICH SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-wiskott-aldrich-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections (defective humoral and cellular immunity); bleeding is a major cause of death
B. Due to mutation in the WASP gene; X-linked</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-complement-deficiencies">VIII.COMPLEMENT DEFICIENCIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-complement-deficiencies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. C5-C9 deficiencies-increased risk for Neisseria infection ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span> gonorrhoeae and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>N</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">N</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">N</span></span></span></span></span> meningitidis)
B. Cl inhibitor deficiency-results in hereditary angioedema, which is characterized by edema of the skin (especially periorbital, Fig. 2.3) and mucosal surfaces</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="autoimmune-disorders">AUTOIMMUNE DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#autoimmune-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Characterized by immune-mediated damage of self tissues</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>US prevalence is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \%-2 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">2%</span></span></span></span></span>.
B. Involves loss of self-tolerance</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Self-reactive lymphocytes are regularly generated but develop central (thymus and bone marrow) or peripheral tolerance.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Central tolerance in thymus leads to T-cell (thymocyte) apoptosis or generation of regulatory T cells.
i. AIRE mutations result in autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Central tolerance in bone marrow leads to receptor editing or B-cell apoptosis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Peripheral tolerance leads to anergy or apoptosis of T and B cells.
i. Fas apoptosis pathway mutations result in autoimmune lymphoproliferative syndrome (ALPS).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Regulatory T cells suppress autoimmunity by blocking T-cell activation and producing anti-inflammatory cytokines (IL-10 and TGF- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> ).
i. CD25 polymorphisms are associated with autoimmunity (MS and type 1 DM).
ii. FOXP3 mutations lead to IPEX syndrome (Immune dysregulation, Polyendocrinopathy, Enteropathy, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="bold-italic">X</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\boldsymbol{X}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6861em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord boldsymbol" style="margin-right: 0.07778em;">X</span></span></span></span></span></span></span>-linked).
C. More common in women; classically affects women of childbearing age</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Estrogen may reduce apoptosis of self-reactive B cells.
D. Etiology is likely an environmental trigger in genetically-susceptible individuals.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased incidence in twins</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Association with certain HLA types (e.g., HLA-B27) and PTPN22 polymorphisms</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Environmental triggers lead to bystander activation or molecular mimicry.
E. Autoimmune disorders are clinically progressive with relapses and remissions and often show overlapping features; partially explained by epitope spreading</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-systemic-lupus-erythematosus">II. SYSTEMIC LUPUS ERYTHEMATOSUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-systemic-lupus-erythematosus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Chronic, systemic autoimmune disease</p>
<ol>
<li>Flares and remissions are common.
B. Classically arises in middle-aged females, especially African American and Hispanic women</li>
<li>May also arise in children and older adults (less dramatic gender bias)
C. Antigen-antibody complexes damage multiple tissues (type III HSR).</li>
<li>Poorly-cleared apoptotic debris (e.g., from UV damage) activates self-reactive lymphocytes, which then produce antibodies to host nuclear antigens.</li>
<li>Antigen-antibody complexes are generated at low levels and taken up by dendritic cells.</li>
<li>DNA antigens activate TLRs, amplifying immune response (IFN- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> ).</li>
<li>Antigen-antibody complexes are subsequently generated at higher levels and deposit in multiple tissues causing disease.</li>
<li>Deficiency of early complement proteins (C1q, C4, and C2) is associated with SLE.
D. Almost any tissue can be involved. Classic findings include</li>
<li>Fever, weight loss, fatigue, lymphadenopathy, and Raynaud phenomenon</li>
<li>Malar 'butterfly' rash (Fig. 2.4A) or discoid rash (Fig. 2.4B), especially upon exposure to sunlight</li>
<li>Oral or nasopharyngeal ulcers (usually painless)</li>
<li>Arthritis (usually involving <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>≥</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\geq 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7719em; vertical-align: -0.136em;"></span><span class="mrel">≥</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span> joints)</li>
<li>Serositis (pleuritis and pericarditis)</li>
<li>Psychosis or seizures</li>
<li>Renal damage
i. Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis is the most common and most severe form of injury.
ii. Other patterns of injury (e.g., membranous glomerulonephritis) also occur.</li>
<li>Anemia, thrombocytopenia, or leukopenia (type II HSR)</li>
<li>Libman-Sacks endocarditis</li>
<li>Antinuclear antibody (ANA; sensitive, but not specific)</li>
<li>Anti-dsDNA or anti-Sm antibodies (highly specific)
E. Antiphospholipid antibody is associated with SLE (one-third of patients).</li>
<li>Autoantibody directed against proteins bound to phospholipids
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-43d0cc7a.jpeg" alt="img-16.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 2.4A Malar 'butterfly' rash, SLE.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-4a604665.jpeg" alt="img-17.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 2.4B Discoid rash, SLE.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Important antiphospholipid antibodies include anticardiolipin (false-positive VDRL and RPR syphilis screening tests), anti- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>β</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0528em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>-glycoprotein I, and lupus anticoagulant (falsely-elevated PTT).
F. Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is characterized by hypercoagulable state due to antiphospholipid antibodies (especially lupus anticoagulant).</li>
<li>Results in arterial and venous thrombosis including deep venous, hepatic vein, placental (recurrent pregnancy loss), and cerebral (stroke) thrombosis</li>
<li>Requires lifelong anticoagulation</li>
<li>Associated with SLE; however, more commonly occurs as a primary disorder
G. Antihistone antibody is characteristic of drug-induced lupus.</li>
<li>Procainamide, hydralazine, and isoniazid are common causes.</li>
<li>ANA is positive by definition.</li>
<li>CNS and renal involvement are rare.</li>
<li>Removal of drug usually results in remission.
H. First-line treatment includes avoiding exposure to direct sunlight and glucocorticoids for flares; other immunosuppressive agents are useful in severe or refractory disease.
I. 5-year survival is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span>; renal failure, infection, and accelerated coronary atherosclerosis (occurs late) are common causes of death.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="e1a80ad6">III. SJÖGREN SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e1a80ad6" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Autoimmune destruction of lacrimal and salivary glands</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Lymphocyte-mediated damage (type IV HSR) with fibrosis
B. Classically presents as dry eyes (keratoconjunctivitis sicca), dry mouth (xerostomia), and recurrent dental caries in an older woman (50-60 years)-"Can't chew a cracker, dirt in my eyes"</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>May progress to ulceration of corneal epithelium and oral mucosa
C. Can be primary (sicca syndrome) or associated with another autoimmune disorder, especially rheumatoid arthritis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Rheumatoid factor is often present even when rheumatoid arthritis is absent.
D. Characterized by ANA and anti-ribonucleoprotein antibodies (anti-SSA/Ro and anti-SSB/La)</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anti-SSA and anti-SSB are associated with extraglandular manifestations (e.g., neuropathy).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pregnant women with anti-SSA are at risk for delivering babies with neonatal lupus and congenital heart block.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anti-SSA and anti-SSB are also seen in a subset of patients with SLE (screen pregnant patients)
E. Lymphocytic sialadenitis on lip biopsy (minor salivary glands) is an additional diagnostic criterion (Fig. 2.4C).
F. Increased risk for B-cell (marginal zone) lymphoma, which presents as unilateral enlargement of the parotid gland late in disease course</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-systemic-sclerosis-scleroderma">IV. SYSTEMIC SCLEROSIS (SCLERODERMA)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-systemic-sclerosis-scleroderma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Autoimmune disorder characterized by sclerosis of skin and visceral organs</p>
<ol>
<li>Classically presents in middle-aged females ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>30</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>50</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">30-50</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">30</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span></span></span></span></span> years)
B. Fibroblast activation leads to deposition of collagen.</li>
<li>Autoimmune damage to mesenchyme is possible initiating event.</li>
<li>Endothelial dysfunction leads to inflammation (increased adhesion molecules), vasoconstriction (increased endothelin and decreased NO), and secretion of growth factors (TGF- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> and PDGF).</li>
<li>Fibrosis, initially perivascular, progresses and causes organ damage.</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Limited type-Skin involvement is limited (hands and face) with late visceral involvement.</p>
<ol>
<li>Prototype is CREST syndrome: Calcinosis/anti-Centromere antibodies, Raynaud phenomenon, Esophageal dysmotility, Sclerodactyly (Fig. 2.4D), and Telangiectasias of the skin.
D. Diffuse type-Skin involvement is diffuse with early visceral involvement.</li>
<li>Any organ can be involved.</li>
<li>Commonly involved organs include
i. Vessels (Raynaud phenomenon)
ii. GI tract (esophageal dysmotility and reflux)
iii. Lungs (interstitial fibrosis and pulmonary hypertension)
iv. Kidneys (scleroderma renal crisis)</li>
<li>Highly associated with antibodies to DNA topoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="v-mixed-connective-tissue-disease">V. MIXED CONNECTIVE TISSUE DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-mixed-connective-tissue-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Autoimmune-mediated tissue damage with mixed features of SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis
B. Characterized by ANA along with serum antibodies to U1 ribonucleoprotein</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="wound-healing">WOUND HEALING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#wound-healing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Healing is initiated when inflammation begins.
B. Occurs via a combination of regeneration and repair</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-regeneration">II. REGENERATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-regeneration" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Replacement of damaged tissue with native tissue; dependent on regenerative capacity of tissue
B. Tissues are divided into three types based on regenerative capacity: labile, stable, and permanent.
C. Labile tissues possess stem cells that continuously cycle to regenerate the tissue.</p>
<ol>
<li>Small and large bowel (stem cells in mucosal crypts, Fig. 2.5)</li>
<li>Skin (stem cells in basal layer, Fig. 2.6)</li>
<li>Bone marrow (hematopoietic stem cells)
D. Stable tissues are comprised of cells that are quiescent <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi></msub><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{n}}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">G</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.1514em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">n</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>, but can reenter the cell cycle to regenerate tissue when necessary.</li>
<li>Classic example is regeneration of liver by compensatory hyperplasia after partial resection. Each hepatocyte produces additional cells and then reenters quiescence.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6999f6c4.jpeg" alt="img-18.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 2.4C Lymphocytic sialadenitis, Sjögren syndrome.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5cbe60bc.jpeg" alt="img-19.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 2.4D Sclerodactyly, scleroderma.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-8af2bc0c.jpeg" alt="img-20.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 2.5 Intestinal crypts.</p>
<p>E. Permanent tissues lack significant regenerative potential (e.g., myocardium, skeletal muscle, and neurons).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-repair">III. REPAIR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-repair" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Replacement of damaged tissue with fibrous scar
B. Occurs when regenerative stem cells are lost (e.g., deep skin cut) or when a tissue lacks regenerative capacity (e.g., healing after a myocardial infarction, Fig. 2.7)
C. Granulation tissue formation is the initial phase of repair (Fig. 2.8).</p>
<ol>
<li>Consists of fibroblasts (deposit type III collagen), capillaries (provide nutrients), and myofibroblasts (contract wound)
D. Eventually results in scar formation, in which type III collagen is replaced with type I collagen</li>
<li>Type III collagen is pliable and present in granulation tissue, embryonic tissue, uterus, and keloids.</li>
<li>Type I collagen has high tensile strength and is present in skin, bone, tendons, and most organs.</li>
<li>Collagenase removes type III collagen and requires zinc as a cofactor.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-mechanisms-of-tissue-regeneration-and-repair">IV. MECHANISMS OF TISSUE REGENERATION AND REPAIR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-mechanisms-of-tissue-regeneration-and-repair" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Mediated by paracrine signaling via growth factors (e.g., macrophages secrete growth factors that target fibroblasts)
B. Interaction of growth factors with receptors (e.g., epidermal growth factor with growth factor receptor) results in gene expression and cellular growth.
C. Examples of mediators include</p>
<ol>
<li>TGF- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>-epithelial and fibroblast growth factor</li>
<li>TGF- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-important fibroblast growth factor; also inhibits inflammation</li>
<li>Platelet-derived growth factor-growth factor for endothelium, smooth muscle, and fibroblasts</li>
<li>Fibroblast growth factor-important for angiogenesis; also mediates skeletal development</li>
<li>Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF)-important for angiogenesis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-normal-and-aberrant-wound-healing">V. NORMAL AND ABERRANT WOUND HEALING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-normal-and-aberrant-wound-healing" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Cutaneous healing occurs via primary or secondary intention.</p>
<ol>
<li>Primary intention-Wound edges are brought together (e.g., suturing of a surgical incision); leads to minimal scar formation</li>
<li>Secondary intention-Edges are not approximated. Granulation tissue fills the defect; myofibroblasts then contract the wound, forming a scar.
B. Delayed wound healing occurs in</li>
<li>Infection (most common cause; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span></span> aureus is the most common offender)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-63a3cd65.jpeg" alt="img-21.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 2.6 Basal layer of skin.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5b28de03.jpeg" alt="img-22.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 2.7 Myocardial scarring. (Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6c734d88.jpeg" alt="img-23.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 2.8 Granulation tissue.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Vitamin C, copper, or zinc deficiency
i. Vitamin C is an important cofactor in the hydroxylation of proline and lysine procollagen residues; hydroxylation is necessary for eventual collagen cross-linking.
ii. Copper is a cofactor for lysyl oxidase, which cross-links lysine and hydroxylysine to form stable collagen.
iii. Zinc is a cofactor for collagenase, which replaces the type III collagen of granulation tissue with stronger type I collagen.</li>
<li>Other causes include foreign body, ischemia, diabetes, and malnutrition.
C. Dehiscence is rupture of a wound; most commonly seen after abdominal surgery
D. Hypertrophic scar is excess production of scar tissue that is localized to the wound (Fig. 2.9).
E. Keloid is excess production of scar tissue that is out of proportion to the wound (Fig. 2.10).</li>
<li>Characterized by excess type III collagen</li>
<li>Genetic predisposition (more common in African Americans)</li>
<li>Classically affects earlobes, face, and upper extremities
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-9b090b79.jpeg" alt="img-24.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 2.9 Hypertrophic scar. (Reprinted with permission, <a href="http://emedicine.medscape.com/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">http://emedicine.medscape.com/</a> article/1128404-overview)
Fig. 2.10 Keloid.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="principles-of-neoplasia">Principles of Neoplasia<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#principles-of-neoplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="neoplasia">NEOPLASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neoplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplasia is new tissue growth that is unregulated, irreversible, and monoclonal; these features distinguish it from hyperplasia and repair.
B. Monoclonal means that the neoplastic cells are derived from a single mother cell.
C. Clonality was historically determined by glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) enzyme isoforms.</p>
<ol>
<li>Multiple isoforms (e.g., <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mi>A</mi></msub><mo separator="true">,</mo><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mi>B</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{G}_{6} \mathrm{PD}_{A}, \mathrm{G}_{6} \mathrm{PD}_{B}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">G</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">A</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">G</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mi>C</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{G}_{6} \mathrm{PD}_{C}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">G</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ) exist; only one isoform is inherited from each parent.</li>
<li>In females, one isoform is randomly inactivated in each cell by lyonization (G6PD is present on the X chromosome).</li>
<li>Normal ratio of active isoforms in cells of any tissue is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>:</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1: 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> (e.g., <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> of cells have <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mi>A</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{G}_{6} \mathrm{PD}_{A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">G</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">A</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> of cells have <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mn>6</mn></msub><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mi>B</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{G}_{6} \mathrm{PD}_{B}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">G</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">6</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ).</li>
<li>1:1 ratio is maintained in hyperplasia, which is polyclonal (cells are derived from multiple cells).</li>
<li>Only one isoform is present in neoplasia, which is monoclonal.</li>
<li>Clonality can also be determined by androgen receptor isoforms, which are also present on the X chromosome.
D. Clonality of B lymphocytes is determined by immunoglobulin (Ig) light chain phenotype.</li>
<li>Ig is comprised of heavy and light chains.</li>
<li>Each B cell expresses light chain that is either kappa or lambda.</li>
<li>Normal kappa to lambda light chain ratio is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>:</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">3: 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>This ratio is maintained in hyperplasia, which is polyclonal.</li>
<li>Ratio increases to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>:</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;6: 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> or is inverted (e.g., kappa to lambda ratio <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>:</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">=1: 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span></span></span></span></span> ) in lymphoma, which is monoclonal.
E. Neoplastic tumors are benign or malignant.</li>
<li>Benign tumors remain localized and do not metastasize.</li>
<li>Malignant tumors (cancer) invade locally and have the potential to metastasize.
F. Tumor nomenclature is based on lineage of differentiation (type of tissue produced) and whether the tumor is benign or malignant (Table 3.1).</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 3.1: Examples of Tumor Nomenclature</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">LINEAGE OF &lt;br&gt; DIFFERENTIATION</th><th style="text-align: left;">BENIGN</th><th style="text-align: left;">MALIGNANT &lt;br&gt; (CANCER)</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Epithelium</td><td style="text-align: left;">Adenoma</td><td style="text-align: left;">Adenocarcinoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;"></td><td style="text-align: left;">Papilloma</td><td style="text-align: left;">Papillary carcinoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Mesenchyme</td><td style="text-align: left;">Lipoma</td><td style="text-align: left;">Liposarcoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Lymphocyte</td><td style="text-align: left;">(Does not exist)</td><td style="text-align: left;">Lymphoma/Leukemia</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Melanocyte</td><td style="text-align: left;">Nevus (mole)</td><td style="text-align: left;">Melanoma</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-epidemiology">II. EPIDEMIOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-epidemiology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Cancer is the 2nd leading cause of death in both adults and children.</p>
<ol>
<li>The leading causes of death in adults are (1) cardiovascular disease, (2) cancer, and (3) chronic respiratory disease.</li>
