<li>The leading causes of death in children are (1) accidents, (2) cancer, and (3) congenital defects.
B. The most common cancers by incidence in adults are (1) breast/prostate, (2) lung, and (3) colorectal.
C. The most common causes of cancer mortality in adults are (1) lung, (2) breast/ prostate, and (3) colorectal.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-role-of-screening">III. ROLE OF SCREENING<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-role-of-screening" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Cancer begins as a single mutated cell.
B. Approximately 30 divisions occur before the earliest clinical symptoms arise.
C. Each division (doubling time) results in increased mutations.</p>
<ol>
<li>Cancers that do not produce symptoms until late in disease will have undergone additional divisions and, hence, additional mutations.</li>
<li>Cancers that are detected late tend to have a poor prognosis.</li>
<li>Screening seeks to catch dysplasia (precancerous change) before it becomes carcinoma or carcinoma before clinical symptoms arise; efficacy of screening, however, requires a decrease in cancer-specific mortality.
D. Common screening methods include</li>
<li>Pap smear-detects cervical dysplasia (CIN) before it becomes carcinoma</li>
<li>Mammography-detects in situ breast cancer (e.g., DCIS) before it invades or invasive carcinoma before it becomes clinically palpable</li>
<li>Prostate specific antigen (PSA) and digital rectal exam-detects prostate carcinoma before it spreads</li>
<li>Hemoccult test (for occult blood in stool) and colonoscopy-detect colonic adenoma before it becomes colonic carcinoma or carcinoma before it spreads</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="carcinogenesis">CARCINOGENESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#carcinogenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Cancer formation is initiated by damage to DNA of stem cells. The damage overcomes DNA repair mechanisms, but is not lethal.</p>
<ol>
<li>Carcinogens are agents that damage DNA, increasing the risk for cancer. Important carcinogens include chemicals, oncogenic viruses, and radiation (Table 3.2).
B. DNA mutations eventually disrupt key regulatory systems, allowing for tumor promotion (growth) and progression (spread).</li>
<li>Disrupted systems include proto-oncogenes, tumor suppressor genes, and regulators of apoptosis.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-oncogenes">II. ONCOGENES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-oncogenes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Proto-oncogenes are essential for cell growth and differentiation; mutations of proto-oncogenes form oncogenes that lead to unregulated cellular growth.
B. Categories of oncogenes include growth factors, growth factor receptors, signal transducers, nuclear regulators, and cell cycle regulators (Table 3.3).</p>
<ol>
<li>Growth factors induce cellular growth (e.g., PDGFB in astrocytoma).</li>
<li>Growth factor receptors mediate signals from growth factors (e.g., ERBB2 [HER2/neu] in breast cancer).</li>
<li>Signal transducers relay receptor activation to the nucleus (e.g., ras).</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 3.2: Important Carcinogens and Associated Cancers</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">CARCINOGENIC AGENT</th><th style="text-align: center;">ASSOCIATED CANCER</th><th style="text-align: center;">COMMENTS</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">CHEMICALS</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Aflatoxins</td><td style="text-align: center;">Hepatocellular carcinoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Derived from Aspergillus, which can contaminate stored rice and grains</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Alkylating agents</td><td style="text-align: center;">Leukemia/lymphoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Side effect of chemotherapy</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Alcohol</td><td style="text-align: center;">Squamous cell carcinoma of oropharynx and upper esophagus, and hepatocellular carcinoma</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Arsenic</td><td style="text-align: center;">Squamous cell carcinoma of skin, lung cancer, and angiosarcoma of liver</td><td style="text-align: center;">Arsenic is present in cigarette smoke.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Asbestos</td><td style="text-align: center;">Lung carcinoma and mesothelioma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Exposure to asbestos is more likely to lead to lung cancer than mesothelioma.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Cigarette smoke</td><td style="text-align: center;">Carcinoma of oropharynx, esophagus, lung, kidney, bladder, and pancreas</td><td style="text-align: center;">Most common carcinogen worldwide; polycyclic hydrocarbons are particularly carcinogenic.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Nitrosamines</td><td style="text-align: center;">Stomach carcinoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Found in smoked foods; responsible for high rate of stomach carcinoma in Japan</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Naphthylamine</td><td style="text-align: center;">Urothelial carcinoma of bladder</td><td style="text-align: center;">Derived from cigarette smoke</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Vinyl chloride</td><td style="text-align: center;">Angiosarcoma of liver</td><td style="text-align: center;">Occupational exposure; used to make polyvinyl chloride (PVC) for use in pipes</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Nickel, chromium, beryllium, or silica</td><td style="text-align: center;">Lung carcinoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Occupational exposure</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">ONCOGENIC VIRUSES</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">EBV</td><td style="text-align: center;">Nasopharyngeal carcinoma, Burkitt lymphoma, and CNS lymphoma in AIDS</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">HHV-8</td><td style="text-align: center;">Kaposi sarcoma</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">HBV and HCV</td><td style="text-align: center;">Hepatocellular carcinoma</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">HTLV-1</td><td style="text-align: center;">Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">High-risk HPV (e.g., subtypes <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>16</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>18</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>31</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>33</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">16,18,31,33</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">16</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">18</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">31</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">33</span></span></span></span></span> )</td><td style="text-align: center;">Squamous cell carcinoma of vulva, vagina, anus, and cervix; adenocarcinoma of cervix</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">RADIATION</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Ionizing (nuclear reactor accidents and radiotherapy)</td><td style="text-align: center;">AML, CML, and papillary carcinoma of the thyroid</td><td style="text-align: center;">Generates hydroxyl free radicals</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Nonionizing (UVB sunlight is most common source)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Basal cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, and melanoma of skin</td><td style="text-align: center;">Results in formation of pyrimidine dimers in DNA, which are normally excised by restriction endonuclease</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>i. Ras is associated with growth factor receptors in an inactive GDP-bound state.
ii. Receptor binding causes GDP to be replaced with GTP, activating ras.
iii. Activated ras sends growth signals to the nucleus.
iv. Ras inactivates itself by cleaving GTP to GDP; this is augmented by GTPase activating protein.
v. Mutated ras inhibits the activity of GTPase activating protein. This prolongs the activated state of ras, resulting in increased growth signals.
4. Cell cycle regulators mediate progression through the cell cycle (e.g., cyclin and cyclin-dependent kinase).
i. Cyclins and cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) form a complex which phosphorylates proteins that drive the cell through the cell cycle.
ii. For example, the cyclinD/CDK4 complex phosphorylates the retinoblastoma protein, which promotes progression through the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{i}} / \mathrm{S}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">G</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3175em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">i</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathrm">S</span></span></span></span></span> checkpoint.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-tumor-suppressor-genes">III. TUMOR SUPPRESSOR GENES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-tumor-suppressor-genes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Regulate cell growth and, hence, decrease ("suppress") the risk of tumor formation; p53 and Rb (retinoblastoma) are classic examples.
B. p53 regulates progression of the cell cycle from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{G}_{\mathrm{i}}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">G</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3175em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">i</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> to S phase.</p>
<p>Table 3.3: Important Oncogenes and Associated Tumors</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;"></th><th style="text-align: center;">FUNCTION</th><th style="text-align: center;">MECHANISM</th><th style="text-align: center;">ASSOCIATED TUMOR</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">GROWTH FACTOR</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">PDGFB</td><td style="text-align: center;">Platelet-derived growth factor</td><td style="text-align: center;">Overexpression, autocrine loop</td><td style="text-align: center;">Astrocytoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">GROWTH FACTOR RECEPTORS</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">ERBB2 [HER2/ neu]</td><td style="text-align: center;">Epidermal growth factor receptor</td><td style="text-align: center;">Amplification</td><td style="text-align: center;">Subset of breast carcinomas</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">RET</td><td style="text-align: center;">Neural growth factor receptor</td><td style="text-align: center;">Point mutation</td><td style="text-align: center;">MEN 2A, MEN 2B and sporadic medullary carcinoma of thyroid</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">KIT</td><td style="text-align: center;">Stem cell growth factor receptor</td><td style="text-align: center;">Point mutation</td><td style="text-align: center;">Gastrointestinal stromal tumor</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">SIGNAL TRANSDUCERS</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">RAS gene family</td><td style="text-align: center;">GTP-binding protein</td><td style="text-align: center;">Point mutation</td><td style="text-align: center;">Carcinomas, melanoma, and lymphoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">ABL</td><td style="text-align: center;">Tyrosine kinase</td><td style="text-align: center;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>22</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{t}(9 ; 22)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">t</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">22</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> with BCR</td><td style="text-align: center;">CML and some types of ALL</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">NUCLEAR REGULATORS</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">c-MYC</td><td style="text-align: center;">Transcription factor</td><td style="text-align: center;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>14</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{t}(8 ; 14)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">t</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">8</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">14</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> involving <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">IgH</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\operatorname{IgH}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mop"><span class="mord mathrm">IgH</span></span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align: center;">Burkitt lymphoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">N-MYC</td><td style="text-align: center;">Transcription factor</td><td style="text-align: center;">Amplification</td><td style="text-align: center;">Neuroblastoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">L-MYC</td><td style="text-align: center;">Transcription factor</td><td style="text-align: center;">Amplification</td><td style="text-align: center;">Lung carcinoma (small cell)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">CELL CYCLE REGULATORS</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">CCND1 (cyclin &lt;br&gt; D1)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Cyclin</td><td style="text-align: center;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>11</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>14</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{t}(11 ; 14)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">t</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">11</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">14</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> involving <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">IgH</mi><mo>⁡</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\operatorname{IgH}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mop"><span class="mord mathrm">IgH</span></span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align: center;">Mantle cell lymphoma</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">CDK4</td><td style="text-align: center;">Cyclin-dependent kinase</td><td style="text-align: center;">Amplification</td><td style="text-align: center;">Melanoma</td></tr></tbody></table>
<ol>
<li>In response to DNA damage, p53 slows the cell cycle and upregulates DNA repair enzymes.</li>
<li>If DNA repair is not possible, p53 induces apoptosis.
i. p53 upregulates BAX, which disrupts Bcl2.
ii. Cytochrome <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> leaks from the mitochondria activating apoptosis.</li>
<li>Both copies of the p53 gene must be knocked out for tumor formation (Knudson two-hit hypothesis).
i. Loss is seen in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> of cancers.
ii. Germline mutation results in Li-Fraumeni syndrome (2nd hit is somatic), characterized by the propensity to develop multiple types of carcinomas and sarcomas.
C. Rb also regulates progression from <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{G}_{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">G</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span></span> phase.</li>
<li>Rb "holds" the E2F transcription factor, which is necessary for transition to the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span></span> phase.</li>
<li>E2F is released when <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>R</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">R B</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">RB</span></span></span></span></span> is phosphorylated by the cyclinD/cyclin-dependent kinase 4 (CDK4) complex.</li>
<li>Rb mutation results in constitutively free E2F, allowing progression through the cell cycle and uncontrolled growth of cells.</li>
<li>Both copies of Rb gene must be knocked out for tumor formation (Knudson twohit hypothesis).
i. Sporadic mutation (both hits are somatic) is characterized by unilateral retinoblastoma (Fig. 3.1).
ii. Germline mutation results in familial retinoblastoma (2nd hit is somatic), characterized by bilateral retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-regulators-of-apoptosis">IV. REGULATORS OF APOPTOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-regulators-of-apoptosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Prevent apoptosis in normal cells, but promote apoptosis in mutated cells whose DNA cannot be repaired (e.g., Bcl2)</p>
<ol>
<li>Bcl2 normally stabilizes the mitochondrial membrane, blocking release of cytochrome <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>Disruption of Bcl2 allows cytochrome <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span></span></span></span></span> to leave the mitochondria and activate apoptosis.
B. Bcl2 is overexpressed in follicular lymphoma.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>14</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>18</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{t}(14 ; 18)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">t</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">14</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">18</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> moves Bcl 2 (chromosome 18) to the Ig heavy chain locus (chromosome 14), resulting in increased Bcl 2 .</li>
<li>Mitochondrial membrane is further stabilized, prohibiting apoptosis.</li>
<li>B cells that would normally undergo apoptosis during somatic hypermutation in the lymph node germinal center accumulate, leading to lymphoma.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-75b0b6cf.jpeg" alt="img-25.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 3.1 Retinoblastoma. (Courtesy of Jerome Taxy, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-ee79401d.jpeg" alt="img-26.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 3.2 Carcinoma involving lymph node.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-05fa4d8c.jpeg" alt="img-27.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 3.3 Seeding of the omentum by carcinoma. (Courtesy of Jerome Taxy, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="v-other-important-features-of-tumor-development">V. OTHER IMPORTANT FEATURES OF TUMOR DEVELOPMENT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-other-important-features-of-tumor-development" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Telomerase is necessary for cell immortality.</p>
<ol>
<li>Normally, telomeres shorten with serial cell divisions, eventually resulting in cellular senescence.</li>
<li>Cancers often have upregulated telomerase, which preserves telomeres.
B. Angiogenesis (production of new blood vessels) is necessary for tumor survival and growth.</li>
<li>FGF and VEGF (angiogenic factors) are commonly produced by tumor cells.
C. Avoiding immune surveillance is necessary for tumor survival.</li>
<li>Mutations often result in production of abnormal proteins, which are expressed on MHC class I.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+} \mathrm{T}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">T</span></span></span></span></span> cells detect and destroy such mutated cells.</li>
<li>Tumor cells can evade immune surveillance by downregulating expression of MHC class I.</li>
<li>Immunodeficiency (both primary and secondary) increases risk for cancer.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="tumor-progression">TUMOR PROGRESSION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#tumor-progression" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-tumor-invasion-and-spread">I. TUMOR INVASION AND SPREAD<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-tumor-invasion-and-spread" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Accumulation of mutations eventually results in tumor invasion and spread.</p>
<ol>
<li>Epithelial tumor cells are normally attached to one another by cellular adhesion molecules (e.g., E-cadherin).</li>
<li>Downregulation of E-cadherin leads to dissociation of attached cells.</li>
<li>Cells attach to laminin and destroy basement membrane (collagen type IV) via collagenase.</li>
<li>Cells attach to fibronectin in the extracellular matrix and spread locally.</li>
<li>Entrance into vascular or lymphatic spaces allows for metastasis (distant spread).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-routes-of-metastasis">II. ROUTES OF METASTASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-routes-of-metastasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Lymphatic spread is characteristic of carcinomas.</p>
<ol>
<li>Initial spread is to regional draining lymph nodes (Fig. 3.2).
B. Hematogenous spread is characteristic of sarcomas and some carcinomas.</li>
<li>Renal cell carcinoma (often invades renal vein)</li>
<li>Hepatocellular carcinoma (often invades hepatic vein)</li>
<li>Follicular carcinoma of the thyroid</li>
<li>Choriocarcinoma
C. Seeding of body cavities is characteristic of ovarian carcinoma, which often involves the peritoneum ('omental caking', Fig. 3.3).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1bca74c3.jpeg" alt="img-28.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 3.4 Histologic features of neoplasia. A, Well differentiated, follicular adenoma of thyroid. B, Poorly differentiated, anaplastic carcinoma of thyroid.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-8e26e390.jpeg" alt="img-29.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 3.5 Immunohistochemical stain for keratin marking epithelial cells (in brown).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="clinical-characteristics">CLINICAL CHARACTERISTICS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#clinical-characteristics" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-clinical-features">I. CLINICAL FEATURES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-clinical-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign tumors tend to be slow growing, well circumscribed, distinct, and mobile.
B. Malignant tumors are usually rapid growing, poorly circumscribed, infiltrative, and fixed to surrounding tissues and local structures.
C. Biopsy or excision is generally required before a tumor can be classified as benign or malignant with certainty.</p>
<ol>
<li>Some benign tumors can grow in a malignant-like fashion, and some malignant tumors can grow in a benign-like fashion.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-histologic-features">II. HISTOLOGIC FEATURES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-histologic-features" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign tumors are usually well differentiated (Fig. 3.4A). Characteristics include</p>
<ol>
<li>Organized growth</li>
<li>Uniform nuclei</li>
<li>Low nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio</li>
<li>Minimal mitotic activity</li>
<li>Lack of invasion (of basement membrane or local tissue)</li>
<li>No metastatic potential
B. Malignant tumors are classically poorly differentiated (anaplastic, Fig. 3.4B). Characteristics include</li>
<li>Disorganized growth (loss of polarity)</li>
<li>Nuclear pleomorphism and hyperchromasia</li>
<li>High nuclear to cytoplasmic ratio</li>
<li>High mitotic activity with atypical mitosis</li>
<li>Invasion (through basement membrane or into local tissue)
C. Metastatic potential is the hallmark of malignancy-benign tumors never metastasize.</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 3.4: Common Immunohistochemical Stains and Target Cell Types</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">IMMUNOHISTOCHEMICAL STAIN</th><th style="text-align: left;">TISSUE TYPE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">INTERMEDIATE FILAMENTS</td><td style="text-align: left;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Keratin</td><td style="text-align: left;">Epithelium</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Vimentin</td><td style="text-align: left;">Mesenchyme</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Desmin</td><td style="text-align: left;">Muscle</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">GFAP</td><td style="text-align: left;">Neuroglia</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Neurofilament</td><td style="text-align: left;">Neurons</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>OTHERS</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">PSA</th><th style="text-align: left;">Prostatic epithelium</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">ER</td><td style="text-align: left;">Breast epithelium</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Thyroglobulin</td><td style="text-align: left;">Thyroid follicular cells</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Chromogranin</td><td style="text-align: left;">Neuroendocrine cells (e.g., small cell &lt;br&gt; carcinoma of lung and carcinoid tumors)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">S-100</td><td style="text-align: left;">Melanoma, Schwannoma and Langerhans cell &lt;br&gt; histiocytosis</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>D. Immunohistochemistry is used to characterize tumors that are difficult to classify on histology (Fig. 3.5, Table 3.4).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-serum-tumor-markers">III. SERUM TUMOR MARKERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-serum-tumor-markers" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Proteins released by tumor into serum (e.g., PSA)
B. Useful for screening, monitoring response to treatment, and monitoring recurrence
C. Elevated levels require tissue biopsy for diagnosis of carcinoma (e.g., biopsy of prostate with elevated PSA).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-grading-of-cancer">IV. GRADING OF CANCER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-grading-of-cancer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Microscopic assessment of differentiation (i.e., how much a cancer resembles the tissue in which it grows); takes into account architectural and nuclear features</p>
<ol>
<li>Well differentiated (low grade)-resembles normal parent tissue</li>
<li>Poorly differentiated (high grade)-does not resemble parent tissue
B. Important for determining prognosis; well-differentiated cancers have better prognosis than poorly-differentiated cancers.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-staging-of-cancer">V. STAGING OF CANCER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-staging-of-cancer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Assessment of size and spread of a cancer
B. Key prognostic factor; more important than grade
C. Determined after final surgical resection of the tumor
D. Utilizes TNM staging system</p>
<ol>
<li>T-tumor (size and/or depth of invasion)</li>
<li>N-spread to regional lymph nodes; second most important prognostic factor</li>
<li>M-metastasis; single most important prognostic factor</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hemostasis-and-related-disorders">Hemostasis and Related Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hemostasis-and-related-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-hemostasis">I. HEMOSTASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-hemostasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Integrity of the blood vessel is necessary to carry blood to tissues.</p>
<ol>
<li>Damage to the wall is repaired by hemostasis, which involves formation of a thrombus (clot) at the site of vessel injury.
B. Hemostasis occurs in two stages: primary and secondary.</li>
<li>Primary hemostasis forms a weak platelet plug and is mediated by interaction between platelets and the vessel wall.</li>
<li>Secondary hemostasis stabilizes the platelet plug and is mediated by the coagulation cascade.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="primary-hemostasis-and-related-bleeding-disorders">PRIMARY HEMOSTASIS AND RELATED BLEEDING DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#primary-hemostasis-and-related-bleeding-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. PRIMARY HEMOSTASIS
A. Step 1-Transient vasoconstriction of damaged vessel</p>
<ol>
<li>Mediated by reflex neural stimulation and endothelin release from endothelial cells
B. Step 2-Platelet adhesion to the surface of disrupted vessel</li>
<li>Von Willebrand factor (vWF) binds exposed subendothelial collagen.</li>
<li>Platelets bind vWF using the GPIb receptor.</li>
<li>vWF is derived from the Weibel-Palade bodies of endothelial cells and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>-granules of platelets.
C. Step 3-Platelet degranulation</li>
<li>Adhesion induces shape change in platelets and degranulation with release of multiple mediators.
i. ADP is released from platelet dense granules; promotes exposure of GPIIb/ IIIa receptor on platelets.
ii. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{TXA}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">TXA</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is synthesized by platelet cyclooxygenase (COX) and released; promotes platelet aggregation
D. Step 4-Platelet aggregation</li>
<li>Platelets aggregate at the site of injury via GPIIb/IIIa using fibrinogen (from plasma) as a linking molecule; results in formation of platelet plug</li>
<li>Platelet plug is weak; coagulation cascade (secondary hemostasis) stabilizes it.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-disorders-of-primary-hemostasis">II. DISORDERS OF PRIMARY HEMOSTASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-disorders-of-primary-hemostasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Usually due to abnormalities in platelets; divided into quantitative or qualitative disorders
B. Clinical features include mucosal and skin bleeding.</p>
<ol>
<li>Symptoms of mucosal bleeding include epistaxis (most common overall symptom), hemoptysis, GI bleeding, hematuria, and menorrhagia. Intracranial bleeding occurs with severe thrombocytopenia.</li>
<li>Symptoms of skin bleeding include petechiae ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>2</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1-2 \mathrm{~mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>, Fig. 4.1), purpura ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>3</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;3 \mathrm{~mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> ), ecchymoses ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>1</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;1 \mathrm{~cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> ), and easy bruising; petechiae are a sign of thrombocytopenia and are not usually seen with qualitative disorders.</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Useful laboratory studies include</p>
<ol>
<li>Platelet count—normal <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>150</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>400</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mo separator="true">;</mo><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>50</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">150-400 \mathrm{~K} / \mu \mathrm{L} ;&lt;50 \mathrm{~K} / \mu \mathrm{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">150</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">400</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">K</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">K</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span></span></span></span> leads to symptoms.</li>
<li>Bleeding time-normal <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>7</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2-7</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span></span></span></span></span> minutes; prolonged with quantitative and qualitative platelet disorders</li>
<li>Blood smear-used to assess number and size of platelets</li>
<li>Bone marrow biopsy-used to assess megakaryocytes, which produce platelets</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-immune-thrombocytopenic-purpura-itp">III. IMMUNE THROMBOCYTOPENIC PURPURA (ITP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-immune-thrombocytopenic-purpura-itp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Autoimmune production of IgG against platelet antigens (e.g., GPIIb/IIIa)</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common cause of thrombocytopenia in children and adults
B. Autoantibodies are produced by plasma cells in the spleen.
C. Antibody-bound platelets are consumed by splenic macrophages, resulting in thrombocytopenia.
D. Divided into acute and chronic forms</li>
<li>Acute form arises in children weeks after a viral infection or immunization; selflimited, usually resolving within weeks of presentation</li>
<li>Chronic form arises in adults, usually women of childbearing age. May be primary or secondary (e.g., SLE). May cause short-lived thrombocytopenia in offspring since antiplatelet IgG can cross the placenta.
E. Laboratory findings include</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> platelet count, often <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>50</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;50 \mathrm{~K} / \mu \mathrm{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">K</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>Normal PT/PTT-Coagulation factors are not affected.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> megakaryocytes on bone marrow biopsy
F. Initial treatment is corticosteroids. Children respond well; adults may show early response, but often relapse.</li>
<li>IVIG is used to raise the platelet count in symptomatic bleeding, but its effect is short-lived.</li>
<li>Splenectomy eliminates the primary source of antibody and the site of platelet destruction (performed in refractory cases).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-microangiopathic-hemolytic-anemia">IV. MICROANGIOPATHIC HEMOLYTIC ANEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-microangiopathic-hemolytic-anemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Pathologic formation of platelet microthrombi in small vessels</p>
<ol>
<li>Platelets are consumed in the formation of microthrombi.</li>
<li>RBCs are "sheared" as they cross microthrombi, resulting in hemolytic anemia with schistocytes (Fig. 4.2).
B. Seen in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) and hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS)
C. TTP is due to decreased ADAMTS13, an enzyme that normally cleaves vWF multimers into smaller monomers for eventual degradation.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-a244de28.jpeg" alt="img-30.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 4.1 Petechiae involving skin.
Fig. 4.2 Schistocyte.</p>
<ol>
<li>Large, uncleaved multimers lead to abnormal platelet adhesion, resulting in microthrombi.</li>
<li>Decreased ADAMTS13 is usually due to an acquired autoantibody; most commonly seen in adult females
D. HUS is due to endothelial damage by drugs or infection.</li>
<li>Classically seen in children with E coli O157:H7 dysentery, which results from exposure to undercooked beef</li>
<li>E coli verotoxin damages endothelial cells resulting in platelet microthrombi.
E. Clinical findings (HUS and TTP) include</li>
<li>Skin and mucosal bleeding</li>
<li>Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia</li>
<li>Fever</li>
<li>Renal insufficiency (more common in HUS)-Thrombi involve vessels of the kidney.</li>
<li>CNS abnormalities (more common in TTP)-Thrombi involve vessels of the CNS.
F. Laboratory findings include</li>
<li>Thrombocytopenia with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> bleeding time</li>
<li>Normal PT/PTT (coagulation cascade is not activated)</li>
<li>Anemia with schistocytes</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> megakaryocytes on bone marrow biopsy
G. Treatment involves plasmapheresis and corticosteroids, particularly in TTP.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="v-qualitative-platelet-disorders">V. QUALITATIVE PLATELET DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-qualitative-platelet-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Bernard-Soulier syndrome is due to a genetic GPIb deficiency; platelet adhesion is impaired.</p>
<ol>
<li>Blood smear shows mild thrombocytopenia with enlarged platelets.
B. Glanzmann thrombasthenia is due to a genetic GPIIb/IIIa deficiency; platelet aggregation is impaired.
C. Aspirin irreversibly inactivates cyclooxygenase; lack of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">X</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{TXA}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">TXA</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> impairs aggregation.
D. Uremia disrupts platelet function; both adhesion and aggregation are impaired.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="secondary-hemostasis-and-related-disorders">SECONDARY HEMOSTASIS AND RELATED DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#secondary-hemostasis-and-related-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. SECONDARY HEMOSTASIS
A. Stabilizes the weak platelet plug via the coagulation cascade</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Coagulation cascade generates thrombin, which converts fibrinogen in the platelet plug to fibrin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrin is then cross-linked, yielding a stable platelet-fibrin thrombus.
B. Factors of the coagulation cascade are produced by the liver in an inactive state. Activation requires</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Exposure to an activating substance
i. Tissue thromboplastin activates factor VII (extrinsic pathway).
ii. Subendothelial collagen activates factor XII (intrinsic pathway).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Phospholipid surface of platelets</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Calcium (derived from platelet dense granules)
II. DISORDERS OF SECONDARY HEMOSTASIS
A. Usually due to factor abnormalities
B. Clinical features include deep tissue bleeding into muscles and joints (hemarthrosis) and rebleeding after surgical procedures (e.g., circumcision and wisdom tooth extraction).
C. Laboratory studies include</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Prothrombin time (PT)—measures extrinsic (factor VII) and common (factors II, V, X, and fibrinogen) pathways of the coagulation cascade</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Partial thromboplastin time (PTT)—measures intrinsic (factors XII, XI, IX, VIII) and common (factors II, V, X, and fibrinogen) pathways of the coagulation cascade</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-hemophilia-a">III. HEMOPHILIA A<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-hemophilia-a" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Genetic factor VIII (FVIII) deficiency</p>
<ol>
<li>X-linked recessive (predominantly affects males)</li>
<li>Can arise from a new mutation (de novo) without any family history
B. Presents with deep tissue, joint, and postsurgical bleeding</li>
<li>Clinical severity depends on the degree of deficiency.
C. Laboratory findings include</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> PTT; normal PT</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> FVIII</li>
<li>Normal platelet count and bleeding time
D. Treatment involves recombinant FVIII.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-hemophilia-b-christmas-disease">IV. HEMOPHILIA B (CHRISTMAS DISEASE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-hemophilia-b-christmas-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Genetic factor IX deficiency</p>
<ol>
<li>Resembles hemophilia A, except FIX levels are decreased instead of FVIII</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-coagulation-factor-inhibitor">V. COAGULATION FACTOR INHIBITOR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-coagulation-factor-inhibitor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Acquired antibody against a coagulation factor resulting in impaired factor function; anti-FVIII is most common.</p>
<ol>
<li>Clinical and lab findings are similar to hemophilia A.</li>
<li>PTT does not correct upon mixing normal plasma with patient's plasma (mixing study) due to inhibitor; PTT does correct in hemophilia A.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-von-willebrand-disease">VI. VON WILLEBRAND DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-von-willebrand-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Genetic vWF deficiency</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common inherited coagulation disorder
B. Multiple subtypes exist, causing quantitative and qualitative defects; the most common type is autosomal dominant with decreased vWF levels.
C. Presents with mild mucosal and skin bleeding; low vWF impairs platelet adhesion.
D. Laboratory findings include</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> bleeding time</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> PTT; normal PT—Decreased FVIII half-life (vWF normally stabilizes FVIII); however, deep tissue, joint, and postsurgical bleeding are usually not seen.</li>
<li>Abnormal ristocetin test-Ristocetin induces platelet agglutination by causing vWF to bind platelet GPIb; lack of vWF <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> impaired agglutination <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> abnormal test.
E. Treatment is desmopressin (ADH analog), which increases vWF release from Weibel-Palade bodies of endothelial cells.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-vitamin-k-deficiency">VII. VITAMIN K DEFICIENCY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-vitamin-k-deficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Disrupts function of multiple coagulation factors</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Vitamin K is activated by epoxide reductase in the liver.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Activated vitamin K gamma carboxylates factors II, VII, IX, X, and proteins C and S; gamma carboxylation is necessary for factor function.
B. Deficiency occurs in</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Newborns-due to lack of GI colonization by bacteria that normally synthesize vitamin K; vitamin K injection is given prophylactically to all newborns at birth to prevent hemorrhagic disease of the newborn.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Long-term antibiotic therapy-disrupts vitamin K-producing bacteria in the GI tract</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Malabsorption-leads to deficiency of fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamin K</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="viii-other-causes-of-abnormal-secondary-hemostasis">VIII.OTHER CAUSES OF ABNORMAL SECONDARY HEMOSTASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-other-causes-of-abnormal-secondary-hemostasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Liver failure-decreased production of coagulation factors and decreased activation of vitamin K by epoxide reductase; effect of liver failure on coagulation is followed using PT.
B. Large-volume transfusion-dilutes coagulation factors, resulting in a relative deficiency</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="other-disorders-of-hemostasis">OTHER DISORDERS OF HEMOSTASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#other-disorders-of-hemostasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. HEPARIN-INDUCED THROMBOCYTOPENIA
A. Platelet destruction that arises secondary to heparin therapy
B. Fragments of destroyed platelets may activate remaining platelets, leading to thrombosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-disseminated-intravascular-coagulation">II. DISSEMINATED INTRAVASCULAR COAGULATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-disseminated-intravascular-coagulation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Pathologic activation of the coagulation cascade</p>
<ol>
<li>Widespread microthrombi result in ischemia and infarction.</li>
<li>Consumption of platelets and factors results in bleeding, especially from IV sites and mucosal surfaces (bleeding from body orifices).
B. Almost always secondary to another disease process</li>
<li>Obstetric complications-Tissue thromboplastin in the amniotic fluid activates coagulation.</li>
