<li>Sepsis (especially with E Coli or N meningitidis)-Endotoxins from the bacterial wall and cytokines (e.g., TNF and IL-1) induce endothelial cells to make tissue factor.</li>
<li>Adenocarcinoma-Mucin activates coagulation.</li>
<li>Acute promyelocytic leukemia-Primary granules activate coagulation.</li>
<li>Rattlesnake bite-Venom activates coagulation.
C. Laboratory findings include</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> platelet count</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> PT/PTT</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> fibrinogen</li>
<li>Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia</li>
<li>Elevated fibrin split products, particularly D-dimer
i. Elevated D-dimer is the best screening test for DIC.
ii. Derived from splitting of cross-linked fibrin; D-dimer is not produced from splitting of fibrinogen.
D. Treatment involves addressing the underlying cause and transfusing blood products and cryoprecipitate (contains coagulation factors), as necessary.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-disorders-of-fibrinolysis">III. DISORDERS OF FIBRINOLYSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-disorders-of-fibrinolysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Normal fibrinolysis removes thrombus after damaged vessel heals.</p>
<ol>
<li>Tissue plasminogen activator (tPA) converts plasminogen to plasmin.</li>
<li>Plasmin cleaves fibrin and serum fibrinogen, destroys coagulation factors, and blocks platelet aggregation.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span>-antiplasmin inactivates plasmin.</li>
</ol>
<p>B. Disorders of fibrinolysis are due to plasmin overactivity resulting in excessive cleavage of serum fibrinogen. Examples include</p>
<ol>
<li>Radical prostatectomy-Release of urokinase activates plasmin.</li>
<li>Cirrhosis of liver-reduced production of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span>-antiplasmin
C. Presents with increased bleeding (resembles DIC)
D. Laboratory findings include</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> PT/PTT—Plasmin destroys coagulation factors.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> bleeding time with normal platelet count-Plasmin blocks platelet aggregation.</li>
<li>Increased fibrinogen split products without D-dimers-Serum fibrinogen is lysed; however, D-dimers are not formed because fibrin thrombi are absent.
E. Treatment is aminocaproic acid, which blocks activation of plasminogen.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="thrombosis">THROMBOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#thrombosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Pathologic formation of an intravascular blood clot (thrombus)</p>
<ol>
<li>Can occur in an artery or vein</li>
<li>Most common location is the deep veins (DVT) of the leg below the knee.
B. Characterized by (1) lines of Zahn (alternating layers of platelets/fibrin and RBCs, Fig. 4.3) and (2) attachment to vessel wall</li>
<li>Both features distinguish thrombus from postmortem clot.
C. Three major risk factors for thrombosis are disruption in blood flow, endothelial cell damage, and hypercoagulable state (Virchow triad).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-disruption-in-normal-blood-flow">II. DISRUPTION IN NORMAL BLOOD FLOW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-disruption-in-normal-blood-flow" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Stasis and turbulence of blood flow increases risk for thrombosis.</p>
<ol>
<li>Blood flow is normally continuous and laminar; keeps platelets and factors dispersed and inactivated
B. Examples include</li>
<li>Immobilization-increased risk for deep venous thrombosis</li>
<li>Cardiac wall dysfunction (e.g., arrhythmia or myocardial infarction)</li>
<li>Aneurysm</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-endothelial-cell-damage">III. ENDOTHELIAL CELL DAMAGE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-endothelial-cell-damage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Endothelial damage disrupts the protective function of endothelial cells, increasing the risk for thrombosis.
B. Endothelial cells prevent thrombosis by several mechanisms.</p>
<ol>
<li>Block exposure to subendothelial collagen and underlying tissue factor</li>
<li>Produce prostacyclin <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{PGI}_{2}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PGI</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span> and NO -vasodilation and inhibition of platelet aggregation
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-9ed8fa5f.jpeg" alt="img-31.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 4.3 Lines of Zahn characterized by alternating layers of platelets/fibrin and RBCs.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Secrete heparin-like molecules-augment antithrombin III (ATIII), which inactivates thrombin and coagulation factors</li>
<li>Secrete tissue plasminogen activator (tPA)—converts plasminogen to plasmin, which (1) cleaves fibrin and serum fibrinogen, (2) destroys coagulation factors, and (3) blocks platelet aggregation</li>
<li>Secrete thrombomodulin—redirects thrombin to activate protein C, which inactivates factors V and VIII
C. Causes of endothelial cell damage include atherosclerosis, vasculitis, and high levels of homocysteine.</li>
<li>Vitamin B12 and folate deficiency result in mildly elevated homocysteine levels, increasing the risk for thrombosis.
i. Folic acid (tetrahydrofolate, THF) circulates as methyl-THF in the serum.
ii. Methyl is transferred to cobalamin (vitamin B12), allowing THF to participate in the synthesis of DNA precursors.
iii. Cobalamin transfers methyl to homocysteine resulting in methionine.
iv. Lack of vitamin B12 or folate leads to decreased conversion of homocysteine to methionine resulting in buildup of homocysteine.</li>
<li>Cystathionine beta synthase (CBS) deficiency results in high homocysteine levels with homocystinuria.
i. CBS converts homocysteine to cystathionine; enzyme deficiency leads to homocysteine buildup.
ii. Characterized by vessel thrombosis, mental retardation, lens dislocation, and long slender fingers.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-hypercoagulable-state">IV. HYPERCOAGULABLE STATE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-hypercoagulable-state" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Due to excessive procoagulant proteins or defective anticoagulant proteins; may be inherited or acquired
B. Classic presentation is recurrent DVTs or DVT at a young age.</p>
<ol>
<li>Usually occurs in the deep veins of the leg; other sites include hepatic and cerebral veins.
C. Protein C or S deficiency (autosomal dominant) decreases negative feedback on the coagulation cascade.</li>
<li>Proteins C and S normally inactivate factors V and VIII.</li>
<li>Increased risk for warfarin skin necrosis
i. Initial stage of warfarin therapy results in a temporary deficiency of proteins C and S (due to shorter half-life) relative to factors II, VII, IX, and X
ii. In preexisting C or S deficiency, a severe deficiency is seen at the onset of warfarin therapy increasing risk for thrombosis, especially in the skin.
D. Factor V Leiden is a mutated form of factor V that lacks the cleavage site for deactivation by proteins C and S .</li>
<li>Most common inherited cause of hypercoagulable state
E. Prothrombin 20210A is an inherited point mutation in prothrombin that results in increased gene expression.</li>
<li>Increased prothrombin results in increased thrombin, promoting thrombus formation.
F. ATIII deficiency decreases the protective effect of heparin-like molecules produced by the endothelium, increasing the risk for thrombus.</li>
<li>Heparin-like molecules normally activate ATIII, which inactivates thrombin and coagulation factors.</li>
<li>In ATIII deficiency, PTT does not rise with standard heparin dosing.
i. Pharmacologic heparin works by binding and activating ATIII.
ii. High doses of heparin activate limited ATIII; coumadin is then given to maintain an anticoagulated state.</li>
</ol>
<p>G. Oral contraceptives are associated with a hypercoagulable state.</p>
<ol>
<li>Estrogen induces increased production of coagulation factors, thereby increasing the risk for thrombosis.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="embolism">EMBOLISM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Intravascular mass that travels and occludes downstream vessels; symptoms depend on the vessel involved.
B. Thromboembolus is due to a thrombus that dislodges; most common type of embolus ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>95</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;95 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">95%</span></span></span></span></span> )
C. Atherosclerotic embolus is due to an atherosclerotic plaque that dislodges.</p>
<ol>
<li>Characterized by the presence of cholesterol clefts in the embolus (Fig. 4.4A)
D. Fat embolus is associated with bone fractures, particularly long bones, and soft tissue trauma.</li>
<li>Develops while fracture is still present or shortly after repair</li>
<li>Characterized by dyspnea (fat, often with bone marrow elements, is seen in pulmonary vessels, Fig. 4.4B) and petechiae on the skin overlying the chest
E. Gas embolus is classically seen in decompression sickness.</li>
<li>Nitrogen gas precipitates out of blood due to rapid ascent by a diver.</li>
<li>Presents with joint and muscle pain ('bends') and respiratory symptoms ('chokes').</li>
<li>Chronic form (Caisson disease) is characterized by multifocal ischemic necrosis of bone.</li>
<li>Gas embolus may also occur during laparoscopic surgery (air is pumped into the abdomen).
F. Amniotic fluid embolus enters maternal circulation during labor or delivery</li>
<li>Presents with shortness of breath, neurologic symptoms, and DIC (due to the thrombogenic nature of amniotic fluid)</li>
<li>Characterized by squamous cells and keratin debris, from fetal skin, in embolus (Fig. 4.4C)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-pulmonary-embolism-pe">II. PULMONARY EMBOLISM (PE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-pulmonary-embolism-pe" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Usually due to thromboembolus; the most common source is deep venous thrombus (DVT) of the lower extremity, usually involving the femoral, iliac, or popliteal veins.
B. Most often clinically silent because (1) the lung has a dual blood supply (via pulmonary and bronchial arteries) and (2) the embolus is usually small (selfresolves)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-2b523b25.jpeg" alt="img-32.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 4.4 Emboli. A, Atherosclerotic embolus characterized by cholesterol clefts. B, Fat embolus with bone marrow elements. C, Amniotic fluid embolus with squamous cells and keratin debris from fetal skin. (A, Courtesy of Professor A. Garfia. C, Courtesy of Shakuntala Teas, MD)</p>
<p>C. Pulmonary infarction occurs if a large- or medium-sized artery is obstructed in patients with pre-existing cardiopulmonary compromise; only <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of PEs cause infarction.</p>
<ol>
<li>Presents with shortness of breath, hemoptysis, pleuritic chest pain, and pleural effusion</li>
<li>V/Q lung scan shows mismatch; perfusion is abnormal.</li>
<li>Spiral CT shows a vascular filling defect in the lung.</li>
<li>Lower extremity Doppler ultrasound is useful to detect DVT.</li>
<li>D-dimer is elevated.</li>
<li>Gross examination reveals a hemorrhagic, wedge-shaped infarct.
D. Sudden death occurs with a large saddle embolus that blocks both left and right pulmonary arteries or with significant occlusion of a large pulmonary artery (Fig. 4.5); death is due to electromechanical dissociation.
E. Pulmonary hypertension may arise with chronic emboli that are reorganized over time.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-systemic-embolism">III. SYSTEMIC EMBOLISM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-systemic-embolism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Usually due to thromboembolus
B. Most commonly arise in the left heart
C. Travel down systemic circulation to occlude flow to organs, most commonly the lower extremities
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-067cae6e.jpeg" alt="img-33.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 4.5 Saddle embolus involving pulmonary artery. (Courtesy of Yale Rosen, MD)</p>
<p>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="red-blood-cell-disorders">Red Blood Cell Disorders<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#red-blood-cell-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anemia">ANEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. BASIC PRINCIPLES
A. Reduction in circulating red blood cell (RBC) mass
B. Presents with signs and symptoms of hypoxia</p>
<ol>
<li>Weakness, fatigue, and dyspnea</li>
<li>Pale conjunctiva and skin</li>
<li>Headache and lightheadedness</li>
<li>Angina, especially with preexisting coronary artery disease
C. Hemoglobin ( Hb ), hematocrit ( Hct ), and RBC count are used as surrogates for RBC mass, which is difficult to measure.</li>
<li>Anemia is defined as <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi></mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>13.5</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Hb}&lt;13.5 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{dL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7335em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Hb</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">13.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">dL</span></span></span></span></span></span> in males and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>12.5</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;12.5 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{dL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">12.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">dL</span></span></span></span></span></span> in females (normal Hb is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>13.5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>17.5</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">13.5-17.5 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{dL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">13.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">17.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">dL</span></span></span></span></span></span> in males and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>12.5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>16.0</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">12.5-16.0 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{dL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">12.5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">16.0</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">dL</span></span></span></span></span></span> in females).
D. Based on mean corpuscular volume (MCV), anemia can be classified as microcytic ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>80</mn><mi>μ</mi><msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{MCV}&lt;80 \mu \mathrm{~m}^{3}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7224em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">MCV</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0085em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ), normocytic ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>100</mn><mi>μ</mi><msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{MCV}=80-100 \mu \mathrm{~m}^{3}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">MCV</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0085em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ), or macrocytic ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>100</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{MCV}&gt;100</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7224em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">MCV</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span></span></span></span></span> <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>μ</mi><msup><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mn>3</mn></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left.\mu \mathrm{m}^{3}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.2em; vertical-align: -0.35em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen nulldelimiter"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">m</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;"><span class="delimsizing size1">)</span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="microcytic-anemias">MICROCYTIC ANEMIAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#microcytic-anemias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. BASIC PRINCIPLES
A. Anemia with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>80</mn><mi>μ</mi><msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{MCV}&lt;80 \mu \mathrm{~m}^{3}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7224em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">MCV</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0085em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>
B. Microcytic anemias are due to decreased production of hemoglobin.</p>
<ol>
<li>RBC progenitor cells in the bone marrow are large and normally divide multiple times to produce smaller mature cells ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>100</mn><mi>μ</mi><msup><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{MCV}=80-100 \mu \mathrm{~m}^{3}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">MCV</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">=</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">80</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0085em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">m</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8141em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ).</li>
<li>Microcytosis is due to an "extra" division which occurs to maintain hemoglobin concentration.
C. Hemoglobin is made of heme and globin; heme is composed of iron and protoporphyrin. A decrease in any of these components leads to microcytic anemia.
D. Microcytic anemias include (1) iron deficiency anemia, (2) anemia of chronic disease, (3) sideroblastic anemia, and (4) thalassemia.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-iron-deficiency-anemia">II. IRON DEFICIENCY ANEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-iron-deficiency-anemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Due to decreased levels of iron</p>
<ol>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> iron <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span> heme <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span> hemoglobin <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> microcytic anemia
B. Most common type of anemia</li>
<li>Lack of iron is the most common nutritional deficiency in the world, affecting roughly <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/3</span></span></span></span></span> of world's population.
C. Iron is consumed in heme (meat-derived) and non-heme (vegetable-derived) forms.</li>
<li>Absorption occurs in the duodenum. Enterocytes have heme and non-heme (DMT1) transporters; the heme form is more readily absorbed.</li>
<li>Enterocytes transport iron across the cell membrane into blood via ferroportin.</li>
<li>Transferrin transports iron in the blood and delivers it to liver and bone marrow macrophages for storage.</li>
<li>Stored intracellular iron is bound to ferritin, which prevents iron from forming free radicals via the Fenton reaction.</li>
</ol>
<p>D. Laboratory measurements of iron status</p>
<ol>
<li>Serum iron-measure of iron in the blood</li>
<li>Total iron-binding capacity (TIBC)—measure of transferrin molecules in the blood</li>
<li>% saturation—percentage of transferrin molecules that are bound by iron (normal is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>33</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">33 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">33%</span></span></span></span></span> )</li>
<li>Serum ferritin-reflects iron stores in macrophages and the liver
E. Iron deficiency is usually caused by dietary lack or blood loss.</li>
<li>Infants-breast-feeding (human milk is low in iron)</li>
<li>Children-poor diet</li>
<li>Adults (20-50 years)—peptic ulcer disease in males and menorrhagia or pregnancy in females</li>
<li>Elderly-colon polyps/carcinoma in the Western world; hookworm (Ancylostoma duodenale and Necator americanus) in the developing world</li>
<li>Other causes include malnutrition, malabsorption, and gastrectomy (acid aids iron absorption by maintaining the <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Fe}^{2+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8873em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Fe</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8873em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> state, which is more readily absorbed than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">e</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>+</mo></mrow></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Fe}^{3+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8873em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Fe</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8873em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ).
F. Stages of iron deficiency</li>
<li>Storage iron is depleted <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> ferritin; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> TIBC</li>
<li>Serum iron is depleted <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>−</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">-\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> serum iron; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">%</span></span></span></span></span> saturation</li>
<li>Normocytic anemia-Bone marrow makes fewer, but normal-sized, RBCs.</li>
<li>Microcytic, hypochromic anemia-Bone marrow makes smaller and fewer RBCs.
G. Clinical features of iron deficiency include anemia, koilonychia, and pica.
H. Laboratory findings include</li>
<li>Microcytic, hypochromic RBCs with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> red cell distribution width (RDW, Fig. 5.1)</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> ferritin; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> TIBC; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> serum iron; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">%</span></span></span></span></span> saturation</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> Free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP)
I. Treatment involves supplemental iron (ferrous sulfate).
J. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is iron deficiency anemia with esophageal web and atrophic glossitis; presents as anemia, dysphagia, and beefy-red tongue</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-anemia-of-chronic-disease">III. ANEMIA OF CHRONIC DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-anemia-of-chronic-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Anemia associated with chronic inflammation (e.g., endocarditis or autoimmune conditions) or cancer; most common type of anemia in hospitalized patients
B. Chronic disease results in production of acute phase reactants from the liver, including hepcidin.</p>
<ol>
<li>Hepcidin sequesters iron in storage sites by (1) limiting iron transfer from macrophages to erythroid precursors and (2) suppressing erythropoietin (EPO)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5c4e8825.jpeg" alt="img-34.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 5.1 Microcytic, hypochromic RBCs of iron deficiency anemia.</p>
<p>Fig. 5.2 Ringed sideroblasts (Prussian blue stain).</p>
<p>production; aim is to prevent bacteria from accessing iron, which is necessary for their survival.
2. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> available iron <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span> heme <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span> hemoglobin <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> microcytic anemia
C. Laboratory findings include</p>
<ol>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> ferritin, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> TIBC, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> serum iron, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">%</span></span></span></span></span> saturation</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> Free erythrocyte protoporphyrin (FEP)
D. Treatment involves addressing the underlying cause.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-sideroblastic-anemia">IV. SIDEROBLASTIC ANEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-sideroblastic-anemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Anemia due to defective protoporphyrin synthesis</p>
<ol>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> protoporphyrin <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span> heme <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span> hemoglobin <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> microcytic anemia
B. Protoporphyrin is synthesized via a series of reactions.</li>
<li>Aminolevulinic acid synthetase (ALAS) converts succinyl CoA to aminolevulinic acid (ALA) using vitamin B6 as a cofactor (rate-limiting step).</li>
<li>Aminolevulinic acid dehydratase (ALAD) converts ALA to porphobilinogen.</li>
<li>Additional reactions convert porphobilinogen to protoporphyrin.</li>
<li>Ferrochelatase attaches protoporphyrin to iron to make heme (final reaction; occurs in the mitochondria).
C. Iron is transferred to erythroid precursors and enters the mitochondria to form heme. If protoporphyrin is deficient, iron remains trapped in mitochondria.</li>
<li>Iron-laden mitochondria form a ring around the nucleus of erythroid precursors; these cells are called ringed sideroblasts (hence, the term sideroblastic anemia, Fig. 5.2).
D. Sideroblastic anemia can be congenital or acquired.</li>
<li>Congenital defect most commonly involves ALAS (rate-limiting enzyme).</li>
<li>Acquired causes include
i. Alcoholism-mitochondrial poison
ii. Lead poisoning-inhibits ALAD and ferrochelatase
iii. Vitamin B6 deficiency-required cofactor for ALAS; most commonly seen as a side effect of isoniazid treatment for tuberculosis
E. Laboratory findings include <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> ferritin, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> TIBC, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> serum iron, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">%</span></span></span></span></span> saturation (iron-overloaded state).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-thalassemia">V. THALASSEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-thalassemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Anemia due to decreased synthesis of the globin chains of hemoglobin</p>
<ol>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> globin <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">→↓</span></span></span></span></span> hemoglobin <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>→</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\rightarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.3669em;"></span><span class="mrel">→</span></span></span></span></span> microcytic anemia
B. Inherited mutation; carriers are protected against Plasmodium falciparum malaria.
C. Divided into <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span> - and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-thalassemia based on decreased production of alpha or beta globin chains.</li>
<li>Normal types of hemoglobin are <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi></mrow><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><mo separator="true">,</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>β</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{HbF}\left(\alpha_{2} \mathrm{Y}_{2}\right), \mathrm{HbA}\left(\alpha_{2} \beta_{2}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HbF</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0037em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.025em;">Y</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.025em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HbA</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0037em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0528em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><msub><mi>δ</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{HbA}_{2}\left(\alpha_{2} \delta_{2}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HbA</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0037em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.03785em;">δ</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0379em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 5.1: Laboratory Findings in Microcytic Anemia</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">STATE</th><th style="text-align: left;">FERRITIN</th><th style="text-align: left;">TIBC</th><th style="text-align: left;">SERUM IRON</th><th style="text-align: left;">% SATURATION</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Normal</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>300</mn><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">300 \mu \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{dL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">300</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">dL</span></span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>100</mn><mi>μ</mi><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">100 \mu \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{dL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">100</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">dL</span></span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>33</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">33 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">33%</span></span></span></span></span></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Iron Deficiency Anemia</td><td style="text-align: left;">Low</td><td style="text-align: left;">High</td><td style="text-align: left;">Low</td><td style="text-align: left;">Low</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Anemia of Chronic Disease</td><td style="text-align: left;">High</td><td style="text-align: left;">Low</td><td style="text-align: left;">Low</td><td style="text-align: left;">Low</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Sideroblastic Anemia</td><td style="text-align: left;">High</td><td style="text-align: left;">Low</td><td style="text-align: left;">High</td><td style="text-align: left;">High</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Pregnancy and oral contraceptives</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td><td style="text-align: left;">High</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td><td style="text-align: left;">Low</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>D. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>-Thalassemia is usually due to gene deletion; normally, 4 alpha genes are present on chromosome 16.</p>
<ol>
<li>One gene deleted-asymptomatic</li>
<li>Two genes deleted-mild anemia with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> RBC count; cis deletion is associated with an increased risk of severe thalassemia in offspring.
i. Cis deletion is when both deletions occur on the same chromosome; seen in Asians
ii. Trans deletion is when one deletion occurs on each chromosome; seen in Africans, including African Americans</li>
