BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Hematopoiesis occurs via a stepwise maturation of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><msup><mn>34</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD} 34^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>hematopoietic stem cells (Fig. 6.1).
B. Cells mature and are released from the bone marrow into the blood.
C. A normal white blood cell (WBC) count is approximately <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mi>μ</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5-10 \mathrm{~K} / \mu \mathrm{L}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">K</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord mathnormal">μ</span><span class="mord mathrm">L</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<ol>
<li>A low WBC count <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>5</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(&lt;5 \mathrm{~K})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">K</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> is called leukopenia.</li>
<li>A high WBC count ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>10</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;10 \mathrm{~K}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">K</span></span></span></span></span></span> ) is called leukocytosis.</li>
<li>A low or high WBC count is usually due to a decrease or increase in one particular cell lineage.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-leukopenia">II. LEUKOPENIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-leukopenia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neutropenia refers to a decreased number of circulating neutrophils. Causes include</p>
<ol>
<li>Drug toxicity (e.g., chemotherapy with alkylating agents)-Damage to stem cells results in decreased production of WBCs, especially neutrophils.</li>
<li>Severe infection (e.g., gram-negative sepsis)-Increased movement of neutrophils into tissues results in decreased circulating neutrophils.</li>
<li>As a treatment, GM-CSF or G-CSF may be used to boost granulocyte production, thereby decreasing risk of infection in neutropenic patients.
B. Lymphopenia refers to a decreased number of circulating lymphocytes. Causes include</li>
<li>Immunodeficiency (e.g., DiGeorge syndrome or HIV)</li>
<li>High cortisol state (e.g., exogenous corticosteroids or Cushing syndrome)induces apoptosis of lymphocytes</li>
<li>Autoimmune destruction (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus)</li>
<li>Whole body radiation-Lymphocytes are highly sensitive to radiation; lymphopenia is the earliest change to emerge after whole body radiation.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-leukocytosis">III. LEUKOCYTOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-leukocytosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neutrophilic leukocytosis refers to increased circulating neutrophils. Causes include</p>
<ol>
<li>Bacterial infection or tissue necrosis-induces release of marginated pool and bone marrow neutrophils, including immature forms (left shift); immature cells are characterized by decreased Fc receptors (CD16).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-0e8f351c.jpeg" alt="img-42.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 6.1 Hematopoiesis.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>High cortisol state-impairs leukocyte adhesion, leading to release of marginated pool of neutrophils
B. Monocytosis refers to increased circulating monocytes. Causes include chronic inflammatory states (e.g., autoimmune and infectious) and malignancy.
C. Eosinophilia refers to increased circulating eosinophils. Causes include allergic reactions (type I hypersensitivity), parasitic infections, and Hodgkin lymphoma. Eosinophilia is driven by increased eosinophil chemotactic factor.
D. Basophilia refers to increased circulating basophils; classically seen in chronic myeloid leukemia
E. Lymphocytic leukocytosis refers to increased circulating lymphocytes. Causes include</li>
<li>Viral infections-T lymphocytes undergo hyperplasia in response to virally infected cells.</li>
<li>Bordetella pertussis infection-Bacteria produce lymphocytosis-promoting factor, which blocks circulating lymphocytes from leaving the blood to enter the lymph node.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-infectious-mononucleosis-im">IV. INFECTIOUS MONONUCLEOSIS (IM)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-infectious-mononucleosis-im" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. EBV infection that results in a lymphocytic leukocytosis comprised of reactive <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> T cells; CMV is a less common cause.</p>
<ol>
<li>EBV is transmitted by saliva ("kissing disease"); classically affects teenagers
B. EBV primarily infects</li>
<li>Oropharynx, resulting in pharyngitis</li>
<li>Liver, resulting in hepatitis with hepatomegaly and elevated liver enzymes</li>
<li>B cells
C. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>T-cell response leads to</li>
<li>Generalized lymphadenopathy (LAD) due to T-cell hyperplasia in the lymph node paracortex</li>
<li>Splenomegaly due to T-cell hyperplasia in the periarterial lymphatic sheath (PALS)</li>
<li>High WBC count with atypical lymphocytes (reactive <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+}{ }^{+} \mathrm{T}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">T</span></span></span></span></span> cells) in the blood (Fig. 6.2)
D. The monospot test is used for screening.</li>
<li>Detects IgM antibodies that cross-react with horse or sheep red blood cells (heterophile antibodies)</li>
<li>Usually turns positive within 1 week after infection</li>
<li>A negative monospot test suggests CMV as a possible cause of IM.</li>
<li>Definitive diagnosis is made by serologic testing for the EBV viral capsid antigen.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-88ef16e3.jpeg" alt="img-43.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 6.2 Atypical lymphocyte, infectious mononucleosis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-a8fca33b.jpeg" alt="img-44.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 6.3 Splenic rupture. (Courtesy of K.V. Santosh, MD)</p>
<p>E. Complications</p>
<ol>
<li>Increased risk for splenic rupture (Fig. 6.3); patients are generally advised to avoid contact sports for one month.</li>
<li>Rash if exposed to ampicillin</li>
<li>Dormancy of virus in B cells leads to increased risk for both recurrence and B-cell lymphoma, especially if immunodeficiency (e.g., HIV) develops.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="acute-leukemia">ACUTE LEUKEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-leukemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of blasts; defined as the accumulation of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;20 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">20%</span></span></span></span></span> blasts in the bone marrow.
B. Increased blasts "crowd-out" normal hematopoiesis, resulting in an "acute" presentation with anemia (fatigue), thrombocytopenia (bleeding), or neutropenia (infection).
C. Blasts usually enter the blood stream, resulting in a high WBC count.</p>
<ol>
<li>Blasts are large, immature cells, often with punched out nucleoli (Fig. 6.4).
D. Acute leukemia is subdivided into acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) or acute myelogenous leukemia (AML) based on the phenotype of the blasts.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-acute-lymphoblastic-leukemia">II. ACUTE LYMPHOBLASTIC LEUKEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-acute-lymphoblastic-leukemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic accumulation of lymphoblasts ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;20 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">20%</span></span></span></span></span> ) in the bone marrow</p>
<ol>
<li>Lymphoblasts are characterized by positive nuclear staining for TdT, a DNA polymerase.</li>
<li>TdT is absent in myeloid blasts and mature lymphocytes.
B. Most commonly arises in children; associated with Down syndrome (usually arises after the age of 5 years)
C. Subclassified into B-ALL and T-ALL based on surface markers
D. B-ALL is the most common type of ALL.</li>
<li>Usually characterized by lymphoblasts ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{TdT}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8557em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">TdT</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8557em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>) that express CD10, CD19, and CD20.</li>
<li>Excellent response to chemotherapy; requires prophylaxis to scrotum and CSF (Fig. 6.5)</li>
<li>Prognosis is based on cytogenetic abnormalities.
i. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>12</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>21</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{t}(12 ; 21)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">t</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">12</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">21</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> has a good prognosis; more commonly seen in children
ii. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>22</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t(9 ; 22)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">22</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> has a poor prognosis; more commonly seen in adults (Philadelphia <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> ALL)
E. T-ALL is characterized by lymphoblasts ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{TdT}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8557em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">TdT</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8557em;"><span style="top: -3.1473em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>) that express markers ranging from CD2 to CD8 (e.g., CD3, CD4, CD7). The blasts do not express CD10.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-59b693e6.jpeg" alt="img-45.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 6.4 Blasts of acute leukemia.
Fig. 6.5 Acute lymphoblastic leukemia involving meninges.</p>
<ol>
<li>Usually presents in teenagers as a mediastinal (thymic) mass (called acute lymphoblastic lymphoma because the malignant cells form a mass)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-acute-myeloid-leukemia">III. ACUTE MYELOID LEUKEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-acute-myeloid-leukemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic accumulation of immature myeloid cells ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;20 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">20%</span></span></span></span></span> ) in the bone marrow
B. Myeloblasts are usually characterized by positive cytoplasmic staining for myeloperoxidase (MPO).</p>
<ol>
<li>Crystal aggregates of MPO may be seen as Auer rods (Fig. 6.6).
C. Most commonly arises in older adults (average age is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>60</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50-60</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span></span></span></span></span> years)
D. Subclassification based on cytogenetic abnormalities, lineage of immature myeloid cells, and surface markers. High-yield subtypes include</li>
<li>Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL)
i. Characterized by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>15</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>17</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t(15 ; 17)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">15</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">17</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>, which involves translocation of the retinoic acid receptor (RAR) on chromosome 17 to chromosome 15; RAR disruption blocks maturation and promyelocytes (blasts) accumulate.
ii. Abnormal promyelocytes contain numerous primary granules that increase the risk for DIC.
iii. Treatment is with all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA, a vitamin A derivative), which binds the altered receptor and causes the blasts to mature (and eventually die).</li>
<li>Acute monocytic leukemia
i. Proliferation of monoblasts; usually lack MPO
ii. Blasts characteristically infiltrate gums (Fig. 6.7).</li>
<li>Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia
i. Proliferation of megakaryoblasts; lack MPO
ii. Associated with Down syndrome (usually arises before the age of 5)
E. AML may also arise from pre-existing dysplasia (myelodysplastic syndromes), especially with prior exposure to alkylating agents or radiotherapy.</li>
<li>Myelodysplastic syndromes usually present with cytopenias, hypercellular bone marrow, abnormal maturation of cells, and increased blasts (&lt;20%).</li>
<li>Most patients die from infection or bleeding, though some progress to acute leukemia.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-leukemia">CHRONIC LEUKEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-leukemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of mature circulating lymphocytes; characterized by a high WBC count
B. Usually insidious in onset and seen in older adults
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-37cab479.jpeg" alt="img-46.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 6.6 Acute myelogenous leukemia with Auer rod. (Courtesy of Paulo Mourao, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-d48a17ea.jpeg" alt="img-47.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 6.7 Acute monocytic leukemia. (Courtesy of Drs. H. Fred and H. van Dijk, Images of Memorable Cases)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-00e8239c.jpeg" alt="img-48.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 6.8 Chronic lymphocytic leukemia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-chronic-lymphocytic-leukemia-cll">II. CHRONIC LYMPHOCYTIC LEUKEMIA (CLL)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-chronic-lymphocytic-leukemia-cll" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of naïve B cells that co-express CD5 and CD20; most common leukemia overall
B. Increased lymphocytes and smudge cells are seen on blood smear (Fig. 6.8).
C. Involvement of lymph nodes leads to generalized lymphadenopathy and is called small lymphocytic lymphoma.
D. Complications include</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypogammaglobulinemia-Infection is the most common cause of death in CLL.</li>
<li>Autoimmune hemolytic anemia</li>
<li>Transformation to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (Richter transformation)marked clinically by an enlarging lymph node or spleen</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-hairy-cell-leukemia">III. HAIRY CELL LEUKEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-hairy-cell-leukemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of mature B cells characterized by hairy cytoplasmic processes (Fig. 6.9)
B. Cells are positive for tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP).
C. Clinical features include splenomegaly (due to accumulation of hairy cells in red pulp) and "dry tap" on bone marrow aspiration (due to marrow fibrosis). Lymphadenopathy is usually absent.
D. Excellent response to 2-CDA (cladribine), an adenosine deaminase inhibitor; adenosine accumulates to toxic levels in neoplastic B cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-adult-t-cell-leukemia-lymphoma-atll">IV. ADULT T-CELL LEUKEMIA/LYMPHOMA (ATLL)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-adult-t-cell-leukemia-lymphoma-atll" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of mature <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><msup><mn>4</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD} 4^{+} \mathrm{T}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">T</span></span></span></span></span> cells
B. Associated with HTLV-1; most commonly seen in Japan and the Caribbean
C. Clinical features include rash (skin infiltration), generalized lymphadenopathy with hepatosplenomegaly, and lytic (punched-out) bone lesions with hypercalcemia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-mycosis-fungoides">V. MYCOSIS FUNGOIDES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-mycosis-fungoides" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of mature <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><msup><mn>4</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD} 4^{+} \mathrm{T}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">T</span></span></span></span></span> cells that infiltrate the skin, producing localized skin rash, plaques, and nodules. Aggregates of neoplastic cells in the epidermis are called Pautrier microabscesses.
B. Cells can spread to involve the blood, producing Sezary syndrome.</p>
<ol>
<li>Characteristic lymphocytes with cerebriform nuclei (Sezary cells) are seen on blood smear (Fig. 6.10).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-f80a99cf.jpeg" alt="img-49.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 6.9 Hairy cell leukemia. (Courtesy of Paulo Mourao, MD)
Fig. 6.10 Sezary cells. (Courtesy of Paulo Mourao, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="myeloproliferative-disorders-mpd">MYELOPROLIFERATIVE DISORDERS (MPD)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#myeloproliferative-disorders-mpd" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of mature cells of myeloid lineage; disease of late adulthood (average age is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>60</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50-60</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span></span></span></span></span> years)
B. Results in high WBC count with hypercellular bone marrow</p>
<ol>
<li>Cells of all myeloid lineages are increased; classified based on the dominant myeloid cell produced
C. Complications include</li>
<li>Increased risk for hyperuricemia and gout due to high turnover of cells</li>
<li>Progression to marrow fibrosis or transformation to acute leukemia</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-chronic-myeloid-leukemia-cml">II. CHRONIC MYELOID LEUKEMIA (CML)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-chronic-myeloid-leukemia-cml" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially granulocytes and their precursors; basophils are characteristically increased (Fig. 6.11).
B. Driven by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>22</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t(9 ; 22)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">22</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> (Philadelphia chromosome) which generates a BCR-ABL fusion protein with increased tyrosine kinase activity.</p>
<ol>
<li>First line treatment is imatinib, which blocks tyrosine kinase activity.
C. Splenomegaly is common. Enlarging spleen suggests progression to accelerated phase of disease; transformation to acute leukemia usually follows shortly thereafter.</li>
<li>Can transform to AML ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2/3</span></span></span></span></span> of cases) or ALL ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/3</span></span></span></span></span> of cases) since mutation is in a pluripotent stem cell.
D. CML is distinguished from a leukemoid reaction (reactive neutrophilic leukocytosis) by</li>
<li>Negative leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) stain (granulocytes in a leukemoid reaction are LAP positive)</li>
<li>Increased basophils (absent with leukemoid reaction)</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>9</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>22</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t(9 ; 22)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">9</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">22</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> (absent in leukemoid reaction)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-polycythemia-vera-pv">III. POLYCYTHEMIA VERA (PV)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-polycythemia-vera-pv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially RBCs</p>
<ol>
<li>Granulocytes and platelets are also increased.
B. Associated with JAK2 kinase mutation
C. Clinical symptoms are mostly due to hyperviscosity of blood.</li>
<li>Blurry vision and headache</li>
<li>Increased risk of venous thrombosis (e.g., hepatic vein, portal vein, and dural sinus)</li>
<li>Flushed face due to congestion (plethora)</li>
<li>Itching, especially after bathing (due to histamine release from increased mast cells)
D. Treatment is phlebotomy; second-line therapy is hydroxyurea.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-a55c29dc.jpeg" alt="img-50.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 6.11 Chronic myelogenous leukemia.
Fig. 6.12 Essential thrombocythemia.</p>
<ol>
<li>Without treatment, death usually occurs within one year.
E. PV must be distinguished from reactive polycythemia.</li>
<li>In PV, erythropoietin (EPO) levels are decreased, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Sao}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Sao</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is normal.</li>
<li>In reactive polycythemia due to high altitude or lung disease, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Sao}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Sao</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is low, and EPO is increased.</li>
<li>In reactive polycythemia due to ectopic EPO production from renal cell carcinoma, EPO is high, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{Sao}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Sao</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> is normal.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-essential-thrombocythemia-et">IV. ESSENTIAL THROMBOCYTHEMIA (ET)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-essential-thrombocythemia-et" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially platelets (Fig. 6.12)</p>
<ol>
<li>RBCs and granulocytes are also increased.
B. Associated with JAK2 kinase mutation
C. Symptoms are related to an increased risk of bleeding and/or thrombosis.</li>
<li>Rarely progresses to marrow fibrosis or acute leukemia</li>
<li>No significant risk for hyperuricemia or gout</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-myelofibrosis">V. MYELOFIBROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-myelofibrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of mature myeloid cells, especially megakaryocytes</p>
<ol>
<li>Associated with JAK2 kinase mutation ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases)
B. Megakaryocytes produce excess platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) causing marrow fibrosis (Fig. 6.13).
C. Clinical features include</li>
<li>Splenomegaly due to extramedullary hematopoiesis</li>
<li>Leukoerythroblastic smear (tear-drop RBCs, nucleated RBCs, and immature granulocytes, Fig. 6.14)</li>
<li>Increased risk of infection, thrombosis, and bleeding</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lymphadenopathy-lad">LYMPHADENOPATHY (LAD)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymphadenopathy-lad" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. LAD refers to enlarged lymph nodes.</p>
<ol>
<li>Painful LAD is usually seen in lymph nodes that are draining a region of acute infection (acute lymphadenitis).</li>
<li>Painless LAD can be seen with chronic inflammation (chronic lymphadenitis), metastatic carcinoma, or lymphoma.
B. In inflammation, lymph node enlargement is due to hyperplasia of particular regions of the lymph node (Fig. 6.15).</li>
<li>Follicular hyperplasia (B-cell region) is seen with rheumatoid arthritis and early stages of HIV infection, for example.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1d3f2039.jpeg" alt="img-51.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 6.13 Myelofibrosis.
Fig. 6.14 Tear-drop RBC.
Fig. 6.15 Normal lymph node.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Paracortex hyperplasia (T-cell region) is seen with viral infections (e.g., infectious mononucleosis).</li>
<li>Hyperplasia of sinus histiocytes is seen in lymph nodes that are draining a tissue with cancer.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lymphoma">LYMPHOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lymphoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of lymphoid cells that forms a mass; may arise in a lymph node or in extranodal tissue
B. Divided into non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL, 60%) and Hodgkin lymphoma (HL, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">40%</span></span></span></span></span> ) (Table 6.1)
C. NHL is further classified based on cell type (e.g., B versus T), cell size, pattern of cell growth, expression of surface markers, and cytogenetic translocations.</p>
<ol>
<li>Small B cells-follicular lymphoma, mantle cell lymphoma, marginal zone lymphoma, and small lymphocytic lymphoma (i.e., CLL cells that involve tissue)</li>
<li>Intermediate-sized B cells-Burkitt lymphoma</li>
<li>Large B cells-diffuse large B-cell lymphoma</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 6.1: Differences Between Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma and Hodgkin Lymphoma</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;"></th><th style="text-align: left;">NON-HODGKIN LYMPHOMA</th><th style="text-align: left;">HODGKIN LYMPHOMA</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Overall frequency</td><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">60%</span></span></span></span></span></td><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">40%</span></span></span></span></span></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Malignant cells</td><td style="text-align: left;">Lymphoid cells</td><td style="text-align: left;">Reed-Sternberg cells</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Composition of mass</td><td style="text-align: left;">Lymphoid cells</td><td style="text-align: left;">Predominantly reactive cells &lt;br&gt; (inflammatory cells and fibrosis)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Clinical</td><td style="text-align: left;">Painless lymphadenopathy, usually arises &lt;br&gt; in late adulthood</td><td style="text-align: left;">Painless lymphadenopathy occasionally &lt;br&gt; with 'B' symptoms, usually arises in young &lt;br&gt; adults</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Spread</td><td style="text-align: left;">Diffuse; often extranodal</td><td style="text-align: left;">Contiguous; rarely extranodal</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Staging</td><td style="text-align: left;">Limited importance</td><td style="text-align: left;">Guides therapy; radiation is the mainstay &lt;br&gt; of treatment.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Leukemic phase</td><td style="text-align: left;">Occurs</td><td style="text-align: left;">Does not occur</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251213-f832c47c.jpeg" alt="img-52.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 6.16 Follicular lymphoma. A, Disruption of normal lymph node architecture by neoplastic follicles. B, Neoplastic follicles lacking tingible body macrophages. C, Reactive follicular hyperplasia with tingible body macrophages for comparison.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-follicular-lymphoma">II. FOLLICULAR LYMPHOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-follicular-lymphoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of small B cells (CD20 <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>) that form follicle-like nodules (Fig. 6.16A)
B. Presents in late adulthood with painless lymphadenopathy
C. Driven by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>14</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>18</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t(14 ; 18)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">14</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">18</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<ol>
<li>BCL2 on chromosome 18 translocates to the Ig heavy chain locus on chromosome 14.</li>
<li>Results in overexpression of Bcl 2 , which inhibits apoptosis
D. Treatment is reserved for patients who are symptomatic and involves low-dose chemotherapy or rituximab (anti-CD20 antibody).
E. Progression to diffuse large B-cell lymphoma is an important complication; presents as an enlarging lymph node
F. Follicular lymphoma is distinguished from reactive follicular hyperplasia by</li>
<li>Disruption of normal lymph node architecture (maintained in follicular hyperplasia)</li>
<li>Lack of tingible body macrophages in germinal centers (tingible body macrophages are present in follicular hyperplasia, Fig. 6.16B,C)</li>
<li>Bcl2 expression in follicles (not expressed in follicular hyperplasia)</li>
<li>Monoclonality (follicular hyperplasia is polyclonal)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-mantle-cell-lymphoma">III. MANTLE CELL LYMPHOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-mantle-cell-lymphoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of small B cells (CD20 <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>) that expands the mantle zone
B. Presents in late adulthood with painless lymphadenopathy
C. Driven by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>11</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>14</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">t(11 ; 14)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">t</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">11</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">14</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></p>
<ol>
<li>Cyclin D1 gene on chromosome 11 translocates to Ig heavy chain locus on chromosome 14.</li>
<li>Overexpression of cyclin D1 promotes G1/S transition in the cell cycle, facilitating neoplastic proliferation.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-marginal-zone-lymphoma">IV. MARGINAL ZONE LYMPHOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-marginal-zone-lymphoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of small B cells (CD20 <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>) that expands the marginal zone
B. Associated with chronic inflammatory states such as Hashimoto thyroiditis, Sjögren syndrome, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span></span></span></span></span> pylori gastritis</p>
<ol>
<li>The marginal zone is formed by post-germinal center B cells.
C. MALToma is marginal zone lymphoma in mucosal sites.</li>
<li>Gastric MALToma may regress with treatment of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span></span></span></span></span> Pylori.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-burkitt-lymphoma">V. BURKITT LYMPHOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-burkitt-lymphoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of intermediate-sized B cells (CD20 <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>); associated with EBV
B. Classically presents as an extranodal mass in a child or young adult
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-0b400534.jpeg" alt="img-53.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 6.17 Burkitt lymphoma. A, Involvement of jaw. B, 'Starry-sky' appearance. (A, Courtesy Mike Blyth)</p>
<ol>
<li>African form usually involves the jaw (Fig. 6.17A).</li>
<li>Sporadic form usually involves the abdomen.
C. Driven by translocations of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>y</mi><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c-m y c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">m</span><span class="mord mathnormal">yc</span></span></span></span></span> (chromosome 8)</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">t</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>14</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{t}(8 ; 14)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">t</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">8</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">14</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> is most common, resulting in translocation of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>y</mi><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c-m y c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">m</span><span class="mord mathnormal">yc</span></span></span></span></span> to the Ig heavy chain locus on chromosome 14.</li>
<li>Overexpression of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>c</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>y</mi><mi>c</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">c-m y c</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">c</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.625em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">m</span><span class="mord mathnormal">yc</span></span></span></span></span> oncogene promotes cell growth.
D. Characterized by high mitotic index and 'starry-sky' appearance on microscopy (Fig. 6.17B)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vi-diffuse-large-b-cell-lymphoma">VI. DIFFUSE LARGE B-CELL LYMPHOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-diffuse-large-b-cell-lymphoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Neoplastic proliferation of large B cells (CD20 <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>) that grow diffusely in sheets</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common form of NHL</li>
<li>Clinically aggressive (high-grade)
B. Arises sporadically or from transformation of a low-grade lymphoma (e.g., follicular lymphoma)</li>
<li>Presents in late adulthood as an enlarging lymph node or an extranodal mass</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="hodgkin-lymphoma-hl">HODGKIN LYMPHOMA (HL)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hodgkin-lymphoma-hl" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. BASIC PRINCIPLES
A. Neoplastic proliferation of Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells, which are large B cells with multilobed nuclei and prominent nucleoli ('owl-eyed nuclei', Fig. 6.18); classically positive for CD15 and CD30
B. RS cells secrete cytokines.</p>
<ol>
<li>Occasionally results in 'B' symptoms (fever, chills, weight loss, and night sweats)</li>
<li>Attract reactive lymphocytes, plasma cells, macrophages, and eosinophils</li>
<li>May lead to fibrosis
C. Reactive inflammatory cells make up a bulk of the tumor and form the basis for classification of HL. Subtypes include</li>
<li>Nodular sclerosis</li>
<li>Lymphocyte-rich</li>
<li>Mixed cellularity</li>
<li>Lymphocyte-depleted
D. Nodular sclerosis is the most common subtype of HL ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">70%</span></span></span></span></span> of all cases).</li>
<li>Classic presentation is an enlarging cervical or mediastinal lymph node in a young adult, usually female.</li>
<li>Lymph node is divided by bands of sclerosis (Fig. 6.19A); RS cells are present in lake-like spaces (lacunar cells, Fig. 6.19B).
E. Important considerations regarding other subtypes of HL</li>
<li>Lymphocyte-rich has the best prognosis of all types.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-0c9b106f.jpeg" alt="img-54.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 6.19 Hodgkin lymphoma, nodular sclerosis type. A, Sclerosis of lymph node. B, Reed-Sternberg cells in lacunar spaces.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Mixed cellularity is often associated with abundant eosinophils (RS cells produce IL-5).</li>
<li>Lymphocyte-depleted is the most aggressive of all types; usually seen in the elderly and HIV-positive individuals</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="plasma-cell-disorders-dyscrasias">PLASMA CELL DISORDERS (DYSCRASIAS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#plasma-cell-disorders-dyscrasias" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-multiple-myeloma">I.
