MULTIPLE MYELOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-multiple-myeloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of plasma cells in the bone marrow</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common primary malignancy of bone; metastatic cancer, however, is the most common malignant lesion of bone overall.</li>
<li>High serum IL-6 may be present; stimulates plasma cell growth and immunoglobulin production
B. Clinical features include</li>
<li>Bone pain with hypercalcemia-Neoplastic plasma cells activate the RANK receptor on osteoclasts, leading to bone destruction. Lytic, 'punched-out' skeletal lesions are seen on x-ray (Fig. 6.20A), especially in the vertebrae and skull; increased risk for fracture</li>
<li>Elevated serum protein-Neoplastic plasma cells produce immunoglobulin; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">M</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.10903em;">M</span></span></span></span></span> spike is present on serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP), most commonly due to monoclonal IgG or IgA.</li>
<li>Increased risk of infection-Monoclonal antibody lacks antigenic diversity; infection is the most common cause of death in multiple myeloma.</li>
<li>Rouleaux formation of RBCs on blood smear-Increased serum protein decreases charge between RBCs (Fig. 6.20B).</li>
<li>Primary AL amyloidosis-Free light chains circulate in serum and deposit in tissues.</li>
<li>Proteinuria-Free light chain is excreted in the urine as Bence Jones protein; deposition in kidney tubules leads to risk for renal failure (myeloma kidney).
II. MONOCLONAL GAMMOPATHY OF UNDETERMINED SIGNIFICANCE (MGUS)
A. Increased serum protein with M spike on SPEP; other features of multiple myeloma are absent (e.g., no lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, AL amyloid, or Bence Jones proteinuria).
B. Common in elderly (seen in 5% of 70 -year-old individuals); <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span></span></span></span></span> of patients with MGUS develop multiple myeloma each year.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="d4e58da8">III. WALDENSTRÖM MACROGLOBULINEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#d4e58da8" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. B-cell lymphoma with monoclonal IgM production
B. Clinical features include
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-8130ac1c.jpeg" alt="img-55.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 6.20 Multiple myeloma. A, 'Punched-out' lesions involving skull, x-ray. B, Rouleaux formation of RBCs.</p>
<p>Fig. 6.21 Birbeck granule, electron microscopy. (Courtesy of humpath.com)</p>
<ol>
<li>Generalized lymphadenopathy; lytic bone lesions are absent.</li>
<li>Increased serum protein with M spike (comprised of IgM)</li>
<li>Visual and neurologic deficits (e.g., retinal hemorrhage or stroke)-IgM (large pentamer) causes serum hyperviscosity.</li>
<li>Bleeding-Viscous serum results in defective platelet aggregation.
C. Acute complications are treated with plasmapheresis, which removes IgM from the serum.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="langerhans-cell-histiocytosis">LANGERHANS CELL HISTIOCYTOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#langerhans-cell-histiocytosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Langerhans cells are specialized dendritic cells found predominantly in the skin.</p>
<ol>
<li>Derived from bone marrow monocytes</li>
<li>Present antigen to naïve T cells
B. Langerhans cell histiocytosis is a neoplastic proliferation of Langerhans cells.</li>
<li>Characteristic Birbeck (tennis racket) granules are seen on electron microscopy (Fig. 6.21); cells are CD1a <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>and S-100 <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>by immunohistochemistry.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-letterer-siwe-disease">II. LETTERER-SIWE DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-letterer-siwe-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of Langerhans cells
B. Classic presentation is skin rash and cystic skeletal defects in an infant ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span> years old).
C. Multiple organs may be involved; rapidly fatal</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-eosinophilic-granuloma">III. EOSINOPHILIC GRANULOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-eosinophilic-granuloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign proliferation of Langerhans cells in bone
B. Classic presentation is pathologic fracture in an adolescent; skin is not involved.
C. Biopsy shows Langerhans cells with mixed inflammatory cells, including numerous eosinophils.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="684b47f3">IV. HAND-SCHÜLLER-CHRISTIAN DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#684b47f3" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of Langerhans cells
B. Classic presentation is scalp rash, lytic skull defects, diabetes insipidus, and exophthalmos in a child.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vascular-pathology">Vascular Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vascular-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vasculitis">VASCULITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vasculitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inflammation of the blood vessel wall</p>
<ol>
<li>Arterial wall is comprised of three layers: endothelial intima, smooth muscle media, and connective tissue adventitia (Fig. 7.1).
B. Etiology is usually unknown; most cases are not infectious.
C. Clinical features include</li>
<li>Nonspecific symptoms of inflammation (e.g., fever, fatigue, weight loss, and myalgias)</li>
<li>Symptoms of organ ischemia-due to luminal narrowing or thrombosis of the inflamed vessels
D. Divided into large-, medium-, and small-vessel vasculitides</li>
<li>Large-vessel vasculitis involves the aorta and its major branches.</li>
<li>Medium-vessel vasculitis involves muscular arteries that supply organs.</li>
<li>Small-vessel vasculitis involves arterioles, capillaries, and venules.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-large-vessel-vasculitis">II. LARGE-VESSEL VASCULITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-large-vessel-vasculitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Temporal (Giant Cell) Arteritis</p>
<ol>
<li>Granulomatous vasculitis that classically involves branches of the carotid artery</li>
<li>Most common form of vasculitis in older adults ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>50</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;50</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span></span></span></span></span> years); usually affects females</li>
<li>Presents as headache (temporal artery involvement), visual disturbances (ophthalmic artery involvement), and jaw claudication. Flu-like symptoms with joint and muscle pain (polymyalgia rheumatica) are often present. ESR is elevated.</li>
<li>Biopsy reveals inflamed vessel wall with giant cells and intimal fibrosis (Fig. 7.2). i. Lesions are segmental; diagnosis requires biopsy of a long segment of vessel, and a negative biopsy does not exclude disease.</li>
<li>Treatment is corticosteroids; high risk of blindness without treatment
B. Takayasu Arteritis</li>
<li>Granulomatous vasculitis that classically involves the aortic arch at branch points</li>
<li>Presents in adults <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>50</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;50</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span></span></span></span></span> years old (classically, young Asian females) as visual and neurologic symptoms with a weak or absent pulse in the upper extremity ('pulseless disease'). ESR is elevated.</li>
<li>Treatment is corticosteroids.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-medium-vessel-vasculitis">III. MEDIUM-VESSEL VASCULITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-medium-vessel-vasculitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Polyarteritis Nodosa</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Necrotizing vasculitis involving multiple organs; lungs are spared.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Classically presents in young adults as hypertension (renal artery involvement), abdominal pain with melena (mesenteric artery involvement), neurologic disturbances, and skin lesions. Associated with serum HBsAg</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Lesions of varying stages are present. Early lesion consists of transmural inflammation with fibrinoid necrosis (Fig. 7.3); eventually heals with fibrosis, producing a 'string-of-pearls' appearance on imaging</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatment is corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide; fatal if not treated
B. Kawasaki Disease</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Classically affects Asian children <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span></span></span></span></span> years old</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Presents with nonspecific signs including fever, conjunctivitis, erythematous rash of palms and soles, and enlarged cervical lymph nodes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Coronary artery involvement is common and leads to risk for (1) thrombosis with myocardial infarction and (2) aneurysm with rupture.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Treatment is aspirin and IVIG; disease is self-limited.
C. Buerger Disease</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Necrotizing vasculitis involving digits</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Presents with ulceration, gangrene, and autoamputation of fingers and toes; Raynaud phenomenon is often present.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Highly associated with heavy smoking; treatment is smoking cessation.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-small-vessel-vasculitis">IV. SMALL-VESSEL VASCULITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-small-vessel-vasculitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Wegener Granulomatosis</p>
<ol>
<li>Necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis involving nasopharynx, lungs, and kidneys</li>
<li>Classic presentation is a middle-aged male with sinusitis or nasopharyngeal ulceration, hemoptysis with bilateral nodular lung infiltrates, and hematuria due to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.</li>
<li>Serum c-ANCA levels correlate with disease activity.</li>
<li>Biopsy reveals large necrotizing granulomas with adjacent necrotizing vasculitis (Fig. 7.4).</li>
<li>Treatment is cyclophosphamide and steroids; relapses are common.
B. Microscopic Polyangiitis</li>
<li>Necrotizing vasculitis involving multiple organs, especially lung and kidney</li>
<li>Presentation is similar to Wegener granulomatosis, but nasopharyngeal involvement and granulomas are absent.</li>
<li>Serum p-ANCA levels correlate with disease activity.</li>
<li>Treatment is corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide; relapses are common.
C. Churg-Strauss Syndrome</li>
<li>Necrotizing granulomatous inflammation with eosinophils involving multiple organs, especially lungs and heart</li>
<li>Asthma and peripheral eosinophilia are often present.</li>
<li>Serum p-ANCA levels correlate with disease activity.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-3a3f67f5.jpeg" alt="img-56.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 7.1 Normal muscular artery.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-aefbcb6f.jpeg" alt="img-57.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 7.2 Temporal (giant cell) arteritis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-73cd4d26.jpeg" alt="img-58.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 7.3 Fibrinoid necrosis, polyarteritis nodosa.</p>
<p>D. Henoch-Schönlein Purpura</p>
<ol>
<li>Vasculitis due to IgA immune complex deposition; most common vasculitis in children</li>
<li>Presents with palpable purpura on buttocks and legs, GI pain and bleeding, and hematuria (IgA nephropathy); usually occurs following an upper respiratory tract infection</li>
<li>Disease is self-limited, but may recur; treated with steroids, if severe</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="hypertension-htn">HYPERTENSION (HTN)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#hypertension-htn" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Increased blood pressure; may involve pulmonary (see chapter 9) or systemic circulation
B. Systemic HTN is defined as pressure <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>≥</mo><mn>140</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>90</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\geq 140 / 90 \mathrm{~mm} \mathrm{Hg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7719em; vertical-align: -0.136em;"></span><span class="mrel">≥</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">140/90</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Hg</span></span></span></span></span></span> (normal <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>≤</mo><mn>120</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>80</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\leq 120 / 80 \mathrm{~mm} \mathrm{Hg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7719em; vertical-align: -0.136em;"></span><span class="mrel">≤</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">120/80</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Hg</span></span></span></span></span></span> ); divided into primary or secondary types based on etiology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-primary-htn">II. PRIMARY HTN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-primary-htn" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. HTN of unknown etiology ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>95</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">95 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">95%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases)
B. Risk factors include age, race (increased risk in African Americans, decreased risk in Asians), obesity, stress, lack of physical activity, and high-salt diet.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-secondary-htn">III. SECONDARY HTN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-secondary-htn" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. HTN due to an identifiable etiology ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">5%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases)
B. Renal artery stenosis is a common cause (renovascular hypertension).</p>
<ol>
<li>Stenosis decreases blood flow to glomerulus.</li>
<li>Juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA) responds by secreting renin, which converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin I.</li>
<li>Angiotensin I is converted to angiotensin II (ATII) by angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE).</li>
<li>ATII raises blood pressure by (1) contracting arteriolar smooth muscle, increasing total peripheral resistance and (2) promoting adrenal release of aldosterone, which increases resorption of sodium in the distal convoluted tubule (expanding plasma volume).</li>
<li>Leads to HTN with increased plasma renin and unilateral atrophy (due to low blood flow) of the affected kidney; neither feature is seen in primary hypertension.
C. Important causes of stenosis include atherosclerosis (elderly males) and fibromuscular dysplasia (young females).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-d230afe1.jpeg" alt="img-59.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 7.4 Wegener granulomatosis. A, Necrotizing granuloma. B, Giant cells at edge of granuloma.
Fig. 7.5 Atherosclerosis.</p>
<ol>
<li>Fibromuscular dysplasia is a developmental defect of the blood vessel wall, resulting in irregular thickening of large- and medium-sized arteries, especially the renal artery.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-benign-and-malignant-htn">IV. BENIGN AND MALIGNANT HTN<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-benign-and-malignant-htn" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. HTN can also be classified as benign or malignant.
B. Benign HTN is a mild or moderate elevation in blood pressure; most cases of HTN are benign.</p>
<ol>
<li>Clinically silent; vessels and organs are damaged slowly over time.
C. Malignant HTN is severe elevation in blood pressure ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>180</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>120</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;180 / 120 \mathrm{~mm} \mathrm{Hg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">180/120</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Hg</span></span></span></span></span></span> ); comprises <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;5 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">5%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases</li>
<li>May arise from preexisting benign HTN or de novo</li>
<li>Presents with acute end-organ damage (e.g., acute renal failure, headache, and papilledema) and is a medical emergency</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="arteriosclerosis">ARTERIOSCLEROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#arteriosclerosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Literally, "hard arteries;" due to thickening of the blood vessel wall
B. Three pathologic patterns-atherosclerosis, arteriolosclerosis, and Mönckeberg medial calcific sclerosis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-atherosclerosis">II. ATHEROSCLEROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-atherosclerosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Intimal plaque that obstructs blood flow</p>
<ol>
<li>Consists of a necrotic lipid core (mostly cholesterol) with a fibromuscular cap (Fig. 7.5); often undergoes dystrophic calcification
B. Involves large- and medium-sized arteries; abdominal aorta, coronary artery, popliteal artery, and internal carotid artery are commonly affected.
C. Risk factors for atherosclerosis are divided into modifiable and nonmodifiable.</li>
<li>Modifiable risk factors include hypertension, hypercholesterolemia (LDL increases risk; HDL decreases risk), smoking, and diabetes.</li>
<li>Nonmodifiable risk factors include age (number and severity of lesions increase with age), gender (increased risk in males and postmenopausal females; estrogen is protective), and genetics (multifactorial, but family history is highly predictive of risk).
D. Pathogenesis</li>
<li>Damage to endothelium allows lipids to leak into the intima.</li>
<li>Lipids are oxidized and then consumed by macrophages via scavenger receptors, resulting in foam cells.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-53a031d0.jpeg" alt="img-60.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 7.6 Atherosclerotic embolus. (Courtesy of Professor A. Garfia)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5410b875.jpeg" alt="img-61.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 7.7 Hyaline arteriolosclerosis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-ee8a637a.jpeg" alt="img-62.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 7.8 Arteriolonephrosclerosis. (Courtesy of Jerome Taxy, MD)</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Inflammation and healing leads to deposition of extracellular matrix and proliferation of smooth muscle.
E. Morphologic stages</li>
<li>Begins as fatty streaks (flat yellow lesions of the intima consisting of lipid-laden macrophages); arise early in life (present in most teenagers)</li>
<li>Progresses to atherosclerotic plaque
F. Complications of atherosclerosis account for <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> of disease in Western countries.</li>
<li>Stenosis of medium-sized vessels results in impaired blood flow and ischemia leading to
i. Peripheral vascular disease (lower extremity arteries, e.g., popliteal)
ii. Angina (coronary arteries)
iii. Ischemic bowel disease (mesenteric arteries)</li>
<li>Plaque rupture with thrombosis results in myocardial infarction (coronary arteries) and stroke (e.g., middle cerebral artery).</li>
<li>Plaque rupture with embolization results in atherosclerotic emboli, characterized by cholesterol crystals within the embolus (Fig. 7.6).</li>
<li>Weakening of vessel wall results in aneurysm (e.g., abdominal aorta).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-arteriolosclerosis">III. ARTERIOLOSCLEROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-arteriolosclerosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Narrowing of small arterioles; divided into hyaline and hyperplastic types
B. Hyaline arteriolosclerosis is caused by proteins leaking into the vessel wall, producing vascular thickening; proteins are seen as pink hyaline on microscopy (Fig. 7.7).</p>
<ol>
<li>Consequence of long-standing benign hypertension or diabetes</li>
<li>Results in reduced vessel caliber with end-organ ischemia; classically produces glomerular scarring (arteriolonephrosclerosis, Fig. 7.8) that slowly progresses to chronic renal failure
C. Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis involves thickening of vessel wall by hyperplasia of smooth muscle ('onion-skin' appearance, Fig. 7.9).</li>
<li>Consequence of malignant hypertension</li>
<li>Results in reduced vessel caliber with end-organ ischemia</li>
<li>May lead to fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall with hemorrhage; classically causes acute renal failure with a characteristic 'flea-bitten' appearance</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="e4c4346b">IV. MÖNCKEBERG MEDIAL CALCIFIC SCLEROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#e4c4346b" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Calcification of the media of muscular (medium-sized) arteries; nonobstructive (Fig. 7.10A)
B. Not clinically significant; seen as an incidental finding on x-ray or mammography (Fig. 7.10B)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-05a0d44b.jpeg" alt="img-63.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 7.9 Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis.
Fig. 7.10 Mönckeberg medial calcific sclerosis. A, Microscopic appearance. B, Mammogram.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="aortic-dissection-and-aneurysm">AORTIC DISSECTION AND ANEURYSM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#aortic-dissection-and-aneurysm" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-aortic-dissection">I. AORTIC DISSECTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-aortic-dissection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Intimal tear with dissection of blood through media of the aortic wall (Fig. 7.11)
B. Occurs in the proximal 10 cm of the aorta (high stress region) with preexisting weakness of the media
C. Most common cause is hypertension (older adults); also associated with inherited defects of connective tissue (younger individuals)</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypertension results in hyaline arteriolosclerosis of the vasa vasorum; decreased flow causes atrophy of the media.</li>
<li>Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome classically lead to weakness of the connective tissue in the media (cystic medial necrosis).
D. Presents as sharp, tearing chest pain that radiates to the back
E. Complications include pericardial tamponade (most common cause of death), rupture with fatal hemorrhage, and obstruction of branching arteries (e.g., coronary or renal) with resultant end-organ ischemia.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-thoracic-aneurysm">II. THORACIC ANEURYSM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-thoracic-aneurysm" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Balloon-like dilation of the thoracic aorta
B. Due to weakness in the aortic wall. Classically seen in tertiary syphilis; endarteritis of the vasa vasorum results in luminal narrowing, decreased flow, and atrophy of the vessel wall. Results in a 'tree-bark' appearance of the aorta (Fig. 7.12)
C. Major complication is dilation of the aortic valve root, resulting in aortic valve insufficiency.</p>
<ol>
<li>Other complications include compression of mediastinal structures (e.g., airway or esophagus) and thrombosis/embolism.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-abdominal-aortic-aneurysm">III. ABDOMINAL AORTIC ANEURYSM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-abdominal-aortic-aneurysm" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Balloon-like dilation of the abdominal aorta; usually arises below the renal arteries, but above the aortic bifurcation (Fig. 7.13)
B. Primarily due to atherosclerosis; classically seen in male smokers <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>60</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;60</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span></span></span></span></span> years old with hypertension</p>
<ol>
<li>Atherosclerosis increases the diffusion barrier to the media, resulting in atrophy and weakness of the vessel wall.
C. Presents as a pulsatile abdominal mass that grows with time
D. Major complication is rupture, especially when <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>5</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;5 \mathrm{~cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> in diameter; presents with triad of hypotension, pulsatile abdominal mass, and flank pain</li>
<li>Other complications include compression of local structures (e.g., ureter) and thrombosis/embolism.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-f52ab030.jpeg" alt="img-64.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 7.11 Aortic dissection. (Courtesy of humpath. com)
Fig. 7.12 'Tree-bark' appearance of aorta due to syphilis. (Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-db2ed2c4.jpeg" alt="img-65.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 7.13 Abdominal aortic aneurysm. (Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vascular-tumors">VASCULAR TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vascular-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-hemangioma">I. HEMANGIOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-hemangioma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign tumor comprised of blood vessels (Fig. 7.14)
B. Commonly present at birth; often regresses during childhood
C. Most often involves skin and liver</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-angiosarcoma">II. ANGIOSARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-angiosarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of endothelial cells; highly aggressive
B. Common sites include skin, breast, and liver.</p>
<ol>
<li>Liver angiosarcoma is associated with exposure to polyvinyl chloride, arsenic, and Thorotrast.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-kaposi-sarcoma">III. KAPOSI SARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-kaposi-sarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Low-grade malignant proliferation of endothelial cells; associated with HHV-8
B. Presents as purple patches, plaques, and nodules on the skin (Fig. 7.15); may also involve visceral organs
C. Classically seen in</p>
<ol>
<li>Older Eastern European males-tumor remains localized to skin; treatment involves surgical removal.</li>
<li>AIDS-tumor spreads early; treatment is antiretroviral agents (to boost immune system).</li>
<li>Transplant recipients-tumor spreads early; treatment involves decreasing immunosuppression.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-721e3f92.jpeg" alt="img-66.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 7.14 Hemangioma.
Fig. 7.15 Kaposi sarcoma.</p>
<p>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cardiac-pathology">Cardiac Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiac-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ischemic-heart-disease-ihd">ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE (IHD)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ischemic-heart-disease-ihd" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Group of syndromes related to myocardial ischemia; IHD is the leading cause of death in the US.
B. Usually due to atherosclerosis of coronary arteries, which decreases blood flow to the myocardium</p>
<ol>
<li>Risk factors for IHD are similar to those of atherosclerosis; incidence increases with age.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-angina">II. ANGINA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-angina" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Stable angina is chest pain that arises with exertion or emotional stress.</p>
<ol>
<li>Due to atherosclerosis of coronary arteries with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>70</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;70 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">70%</span></span></span></span></span> stenosis; decreased blood flow is not able to meet the metabolic demands of the myocardium during exertion.</li>
<li>Represents reversible injury to myocytes (no necrosis)</li>
<li>Presents as chest pain (lasting <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;20</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span></span></span></span></span> minutes) that radiates to the left arm or jaw, diaphoresis, and shortness of breath</li>
<li>EKG shows ST-segment depression due to subendocardial ischemia.</li>
<li>Relieved by rest or nitroglycerin
B. Unstable angina is chest pain that occurs at rest.</li>
<li>Usually due to rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque with thrombosis and incomplete occlusion of a coronary artery (Fig. 8.1A).</li>
<li>Represents reversible injury to myocytes (no necrosis)</li>
<li>EKG shows ST-segment depression due to subendocardial ischemia.</li>
<li>Relieved by nitroglycerin</li>
<li>High risk of progression to myocardial infarction
C. Prinzmetal angina is episodic chest pain unrelated to exertion.</li>
<li>Due to coronary artery vasospasm</li>
<li>Represents reversible injury to myocytes (no necrosis)</li>
<li>EKG shows ST-segment elevation due to transmural ischemia.</li>
<li>Relieved by nitroglycerin or calcium channel blockers</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-myocardial-infarction">III. MYOCARDIAL INFARCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-myocardial-infarction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Necrosis of cardiac myocytes
B. Usually due to rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque with thrombosis and complete occlusion of a coronary artery (Fig. 8.1B)</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Other causes include coronary artery vasospasm (due to Prinzmetal angina or cocaine use), emboli, and vasculitis (e.g., Kawasaki disease).
C. Clinical features include severe, crushing chest pain (lasting <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;20</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span></span></span></span></span> minutes) that radiates to the left arm or jaw, diaphoresis, and dyspnea; symptoms are not relieved by nitroglycerin.
D. Infarction usually involves the left ventricle (LV); right ventricle (RV) and both atria are generally spared.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Occlusion of left anterior descending artery (LAD) leads to infarction of the anterior wall and anterior septum of the LV; LAD is the most commonly involved artery in MI ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>45</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">45 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">45%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Occlusion of right coronary artery (RCA) leads to infarction of the posterior wall, posterior septum, and papillary muscles of the LV; RCA is the 2nd most commonly involved artery in MI.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Occlusion of left circumflex artery leads to infarction of lateral wall of the LV.
E. Initial phase of infarction leads to subendocardial necrosis involving <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> of the myocardial thickness (subendocardial infarction, Fig. 8.2); EKG shows ST-segment depression.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Continued or severe ischemia leads to transmural necrosis involving most of the myocardial wall (transmural infarction); EKG shows ST-segment elevation.
F. Laboratory tests detect elevated cardiac enzymes.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Troponin I is the most sensitive and specific marker (gold standard) for MI. Levels rise 2-4 hours after infarction, peak at 24 hours, and return to normal by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>7</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">7-10</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">7</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span></span></span></span></span> days.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>CK-MB is useful for detecting reinfarction that occurs days after an initial MI; creatine kinase MB (CK-MB) levels rise 4-6 hours after infarction, peak at 24 hours, and return to normal by 72 hours.
G. Treatment includes</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Aspirin and/or heparin-limits thrombosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Supplemental <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{O}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>-minimizes ischemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nitrates-vasodilate veins and coronary arteries</p>
</li>
<li>
<p><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-blocker-slows heart rate, decreasing <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{O}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">O</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> demand and risk for arrhythmia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>ACE inhibitor-decreases LV dilation</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Fibrinolysis or angioplasty-opens blocked vessel
i. Reperfusion of irreversibly-damaged cells results in calcium influx, leading to hypercontraction of myofibrils (contraction band necrosis, Fig. 8.3).
ii. Return of oxygen and inflammatory cells may lead to free radical generation, further damaging myocytes (reperfusion injury).
H. Complications of myocardial infarction are closely related to gross and microscopic changes (Table 8.1).</p>
</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 8.1: Morphologic Changes in Myocardial Infarction</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">TIME FROM &lt;br&gt; INFARCTION</th><th style="text-align: center;">GROSS CHANGES</th><th style="text-align: center;">MICROSCOPIC CHANGES</th><th style="text-align: center;">COMPLICATIONS</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">4</span></span></span></span></span> hours</td><td style="text-align: center;">None</td><td style="text-align: center;">None</td><td style="text-align: center;">Cardiogenic shock (massive infarction), congestive heart failure, and arrhythmia</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">4-24 hours</td><td style="text-align: center;">Dark discoloration</td><td style="text-align: center;">Coagulative necrosis (Fig. 8.4 A )</td><td style="text-align: center;">Arrhythmia</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">1-3 days</td><td style="text-align: center;">Yellow pallor</td><td style="text-align: center;">Neutrophils (Fig. 8.4B)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Fibrinous pericarditis (Fig. 8.5A); presents as chest pain with friction rub</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">4-7 days</td><td style="text-align: center;">Yellow pallor</td><td style="text-align: center;">Macrophages</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rupture of ventricular free wall (Fig. 8.5B; leads to cardiac tamponade), interventricular septum (leads to shunt), or papillary muscle (Fig. 8.5C; leads to mitral insufficiency)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">1-3 weeks</td><td style="text-align: center;">Red border emerges as granulation tissue enters from edge of infarct.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Granulation tissue with plump fibroblasts, collagen, and blood vessels</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Months</td><td style="text-align: center;">White scar (Fig. 8.6A)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Fibrosis (Fig. 8.6B)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Aneurysm (Fig. 8.7), mural thrombus, or Dressler syndrome</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251213-63d1d42f.jpeg" alt="img-67.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.1 Thrombosis of coronary artery. A, Incomplete occlusion. B, Complete occlusion. (Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6c6a8279.jpeg" alt="img-68.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.2 Early infarction ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> day old), predominantly subendocardial. (Courtesy of Jerome Taxy, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1a50dcf4.jpeg" alt="img-69.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.3 Contraction band necrosis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5f358ba3.jpeg" alt="img-70.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.4 Myocardial infarction. A, Coagulative necrosis of myocardium. B, Neutrophilic infiltrate.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-2c393bc5.jpeg" alt="img-71.jpeg">

<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-022974ca.jpeg" alt="img-73.jpeg"></p>

<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-3628226f.jpeg" alt="img-74.jpeg"></p>

<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-f55516b7.jpeg" alt="img-75.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.7 Ventricular aneurysm.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-sudden-cardiac-death">IV. SUDDEN CARDIAC DEATH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-sudden-cardiac-death" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Unexpected death due to cardiac disease; occurs without symptoms or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> hour after symptoms arise</p>
<ol>
<li>Usually due to fatal ventricular arrhythmia
B. Most common etiology is acute ischemia; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of patients have preexisting severe atherosclerosis.</li>
<li>Less common causes include mitral valve prolapse, cardiomyopathy, and cocaine abuse.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-chronic-ischemic-heart-disease">V. CHRONIC ISCHEMIC HEART DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-chronic-ischemic-heart-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Poor myocardial function due to chronic ischemic damage (with or without infarction); progresses to congestive heart failure (CHF)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="congestive-heart-failure-chf">CONGESTIVE HEART FAILURE (CHF)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#congestive-heart-failure-chf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Pump failure; divided into right- and left-sided failure</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-left-sided-heart-failure">II. LEFT-SIDED HEART FAILURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-left-sided-heart-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Causes include ischemia, hypertension, dilated cardiomyopathy, myocardial infarction, and restrictive cardiomyopathy.
B. Clinical features are due to decreased forward perfusion and pulmonary congestion.</p>
<ol>
<li>Pulmonary congestion leads to pulmonary edema.
i. Results in dyspnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (due to increased venous return when lying flat), orthopnea, and crackles
ii. Small, congested capillaries may burst, leading to intraalveolar hemorrhage; marked by hemosiderin-laden macrophages ('heart-failure' cells, Fig. 8.8)</li>
<li>Decreased flow to kidneys leads to activation of renin-angiotensin system.
i. Fluid retention exacerbates CHF.
C. Mainstay of treatment is ACE inhibitor.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-right-sided-heart-failure">III. RIGHT-SIDED HEART FAILURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-right-sided-heart-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Most commonly due to left-sided heart failure; other important causes include left-to-right shunt and chronic lung disease (cor pulmonale).
B. Clinical features are due to congestion.</p>
<ol>
<li>Jugular venous distension</li>
<li>Painful hepatosplenomegaly with characteristic 'nutmeg' liver (Fig. 8.9); may lead to cardiac cirrhosis</li>
<li>Dependent pitting edema (due to increased hydrostatic pressure)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-4f856f7b.jpeg" alt="img-76.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 8.8 Hemosiderin-laden macrophages ('heart Fig. 8.9 'Nutmeg' liver, congestive heart failure. failure' cells).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-92245d24.jpeg" alt="img-77.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.10 'Boot-shaped' heart, tetralogy of Fallot.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="congenital-defects">CONGENITAL DEFECTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#congenital-defects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Arise during embryogenesis (usually weeks 3 through 8); seen in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span></span></span></span></span> of live births 1. Most defects are sporadic.
B. Often result in shunting between left (systemic) and right (pulmonary) circulations.
C. Defects with left-to-right shunting may be relatively asymptomatic at birth, but the shunt can eventually reverse.</p>
<ol>
<li>Increased flow through the pulmonary circulation results in hypertrophy of pulmonary vessels and pulmonary hypertension.</li>
<li>Increased pulmonary resistance eventually results in reversal of shunt, leading to late cyanosis (Eisenmenger syndrome) with right ventricular hypertrophy, polycythemia, and clubbing.
D. Defects with right-to-left shunting usually present as cyanosis shortly after birth.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-ventricular-septal-defect-vsd">II. VENTRICULAR SEPTAL DEFECT (VSD)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-ventricular-septal-defect-vsd" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
