<p>A. Defect in the septum that divides the right and left ventricles</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common congenital heart defect</li>
<li>Associated with fetal alcohol syndrome
B. Results in left-to-right shunt; size of defect determines extent of shunting and age at presentation. Small defects are often asymptomatic; large defects can lead to Eisenmenger syndrome.
C. Treatment involves surgical closure; small defects may close spontaneously.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-atrial-septal-defect-asd">III. ATRIAL SEPTAL DEFECT (ASD)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-atrial-septal-defect-asd" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Defect in the septum that divides right and left atria; most common type is ostium secundum ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases).
B. Ostium primum type is associated with Down syndrome.
C. Results in left-to-right shunt and split <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>S</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0576em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> on auscultation (increased blood in right heart delays closure of pulmonary valve)
D. Paradoxical emboli are an important complication.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-patent-ductus-arteriosus-pda">IV. PATENT DUCTUS ARTERIOSUS (PDA)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-patent-ductus-arteriosus-pda" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Failure of ductus arteriosus to close; associated with congenital rubella
B. Results in left-to-right shunt between the aorta and the pulmonary artery</p>
<ol>
<li>During development, the ductus arteriosus normally shunts blood from the pulmonary artery to the aorta, bypassing the lungs.
C. Asymptomatic at birth with continuous 'machine-like' murmur; may lead to Eisenmenger syndrome, resulting in lower extremity cyanosis
D. Treatment involves indomethacin, which decreases PGE, resulting in PDA closure (PGE maintains patency of the ductus arteriosus).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-tetralogy-of-fallot">V. TETRALOGY OF FALLOT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-tetralogy-of-fallot" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Characterized by (1) stenosis of the right ventricular outflow tract, (2) right ventricular hypertrophy, (3) VSD, and (4) an aorta that overrides the VSD
B. Right-to-left shunt leads to early cyanosis; degree of stenosis determines the extent of shunting and cyanosis.
C. Patients learn to squat in response to a cyanotic spell; increased arterial resistance decreases shunting and allows more blood to reach the lungs.
D. 'Boot-shaped' heart on x-ray (Fig. 8.10)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-transposition-of-the-great-vessels">VI. TRANSPOSITION OF THE GREAT VESSELS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-transposition-of-the-great-vessels" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Characterized by pulmonary artery arising from the left ventricle and aorta arising from the right ventricle</p>
<p>B. Associated with maternal diabetes
C. Presents with early cyanosis; pulmonary and systemic circuits do not mix.</p>
<ol>
<li>Creation of shunt (allowing blood to mix) after birth is required for survival.</li>
<li>PGE can be administered to maintain a PDA until definitive surgical repair is performed.
D. Results in hypertrophy of the right ventricle and atrophy of the left ventricle</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vii-truncus-arteriosus">VII. TRUNCUS ARTERIOSUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-truncus-arteriosus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Characterized by a single large vessel arising from both ventricles</p>
<ol>
<li>Truncus fails to divide.
B. Presents with early cyanosis; deoxygenated blood from right ventricle mixes with oxygenated blood from left ventricle before pulmonary and aortic circulations separate.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-tricuspid-atresia">VIII.TRICUSPID ATRESIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-tricuspid-atresia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Tricuspid valve orifice fails to develop; right ventricle is hypoplastic.
B. Often associated with ASD, resulting in a right-to-left shunt; presents with early cyanosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ix-coarctation-of-the-aorta">IX. COARCTATION OF THE AORTA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ix-coarctation-of-the-aorta" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Narrowing of the aorta (Fig. 8.11A); classically divided into infantile and adult forms
B. Infantile form is associated with a PDA; coarctation lies after (distal to) the aortic arch, but before (proximal to) the PDA.</p>
<ol>
<li>Presents as lower extremity cyanosis in infants, often at birth</li>
<li>Associated with Turner syndrome
C. Adult form is not associated with a PDA; coarctation lies after (distal to) the aortic arch.</li>
<li>Presents as hypertension in the upper extremities and hypotension with weak pulses in the lower extremities; classically discovered in adulthood</li>
<li>Collateral circulation develops across the intercostal arteries; engorged arteries cause 'notching' of ribs on x-ray (Fig. 8.11B),</li>
<li>Associated with bicuspid aortic valve</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="valvular-disorders">VALVULAR DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#valvular-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. The heart has four valves (tricuspid, pulmonary, mitral, and aortic) that prevent backflow.
B. Valvular lesions generally result in stenosis (decreased caliber of the valve orifice) or regurgitation (backflow).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6817ca8a.jpeg" alt="img-78.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.11 Coarctation of the aorta. A, Gross specimen. B, 'Notching of ribs' on x-ray. (A, Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD. B, Courtesy of Images Paediatr Cardiol 2009;38:7-9)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-acute-rheumatic-fever">II. ACUTE RHEUMATIC FEVER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-acute-rheumatic-fever" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Systemic complication of pharyngitis due to group A <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hemolytic streptococci; affects children 2-3 weeks after an episode of streptococcal pharyngitis ("strep throat")
B. Caused by molecular mimicry; bacterial M protein resembles proteins in human tissue.
C. Diagnosis is based on Jones criteria.</p>
<ol>
<li>Evidence of prior group A <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hemolytic streptococcal infection (e.g., elevated ASO or anti-DNase B titers) with the presence of major and minor criteria</li>
<li>Minor criteria are nonspecific and include fever and elevated ESR.</li>
<li>Major criteria
i. Migratory polyarthritis-swelling and pain in a large joint (e.g., wrist, knees, ankles) that resolves within days and "migrates" to involve another large joint
ii. Pancarditis
a. Endocarditis-Mitral valve is involved more commonly than the aortic valve. Characterized by small vegetations along lines of closure that lead to regurgitation (Fig. 8.12A)
b. Myocarditis with Aschoff bodies that are characterized by foci of chronic inflammation, reactive histiocytes with slender, wavy nuclei (Anitschkow cells), giant cells, and fibrinoid material (Fig. 8.12B,C); myocarditis is the most common cause of death during the acute phase.
c. Pericarditis-leads to friction rub and chest pain
iii. Subcutaneous nodules
iv. Erythema marginatum-annular, nonpruritic rash with erythematous borders, commonly involving trunk and limbs
v. Sydenham chorea (rapid, involuntary muscle movements)
D. Acute attack usually resolves, but may progress to chronic rheumatic heart disease; repeat exposure to group <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{A} \beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">A</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hemolytic streptococci results in relapse of the acute phase and increases risk for chronic disease.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-chronic-rheumatic-heart-disease">III. CHRONIC RHEUMATIC HEART DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-chronic-rheumatic-heart-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Valve scarring that arises as a consequence of rheumatic fever
B. Results in stenosis with a classic 'fish-mouth' appearance</p>
<ol>
<li>Almost always involves the mitral valve; leads to thickening of chordae tendineae and cusps</li>
<li>Occasionally involves the aortic valve; leads to fusion of the commissures (Fig. 8.13)</li>
<li>Other valves are less commonly involved.
C. Complications include infectious endocarditis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-4153da85.jpeg" alt="img-79.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 8.12 Acute rheumatic heart disease. A, Mitral valve vegetations. B, Aschoff body involving myocardium. C, Anitschkow cells. (A, Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD. B, Courtesy of Ed Uthman, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-aortic-stenosis">IV. AORTIC STENOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-aortic-stenosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Narrowing of the aortic valve orifice (Fig. 8.14)
B. Usually due to fibrosis and calcification from "wear and tear"</p>
<ol>
<li>Presents in late adulthood (&gt; 60 years)</li>
<li>Bicuspid aortic valve increases risk and hastens disease onset. A normal aortic valve has three cusps; fewer cusps results in increased "wear and tear" on each cusp.
C. May also arise as a consequence of chronic rheumatic valve disease; coexisting mitral stenosis and fusion of the aortic valve commissures distinguish rheumatic disease from "wear and tear."
D. Cardiac compensation leads to a prolonged asymptomatic stage during which a systolic ejection click followed by a crescendo-decrescendo murmur is heard.
E. Complications include</li>
<li>Concentric left ventricular hypertrophy-may progress to cardiac failure</li>
<li>Angina and syncope with exercise-Limited ability to increase blood flow across the stenotic valve leads to decreased perfusion of the myocardium and brain.</li>
<li>Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia-RBCs are damaged (producing schistocytes) while crossing the calcified valve.
F. Treatment is valve replacement after onset of complications.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-aortic-regurgitation">V. AORTIC REGURGITATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-aortic-regurgitation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole
B. Arises due to aortic root dilation (e.g., syphilitic aneurysm and aortic dissection) or valve damage (e.g., infectious endocarditis); most common cause is isolated root dilation
C. Clinical features include</p>
<ol>
<li>Early, blowing diastolic murmur</li>
<li>Hyperdynamic circulation due to increased pulse pressure
i. Pulse pressure is the difference between systolic and diastolic pressures.
ii. Diastolic pressure decreases due to regurgitation, while systolic pressure increases due to increased stroke volume.
iii. Presents with bounding pulse (water-hammer pulse), pulsating nail bed (Quincke pulse), and head bobbing</li>
<li>Results in LV dilation and eccentric hypertrophy (due to volume overload)
D. Treatment is valve replacement once LV dysfunction develops.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-mitral-valve-prolapse">VI. MITRAL VALVE PROLAPSE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-mitral-valve-prolapse" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Ballooning of mitral valve into left atrium during systole</p>
<ol>
<li>Seen in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2-3 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">3%</span></span></span></span></span> of US adults
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-54773dfa.jpeg" alt="img-80.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 8.13 Fusion of aortic valve commissures, chronic rheumatic heart disease. (Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD)
Fig. 8.14 Aortic stenosis. (Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-f6f3a367.jpeg" alt="img-81.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.15 Mitral valve prolapse. (Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD)</p>
<p>B. Due to myxoid degeneration (accumulation of ground substance) of the valve, making it floppy (Fig. 8.15)</p>
<ol>
<li>Etiology is unknown; may be seen in Marfan syndrome or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
C. Presents with an incidental mid-systolic click followed by a regurgitation murmur; usually asymptomatic</li>
<li>Click and murmur become softer with squatting (increased systemic resistance decreases left ventricular emptying).
D. Complications are rare, but include infectious endocarditis, arrhythmia, and severe mitral regurgitation.
E. Treatment is valve replacement.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vii-mitral-regurgitation">VII. MITRAL REGURGITATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-mitral-regurgitation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Reflux of blood from the left ventricle into the left atrium during systole
B. Usually arises as a complication of mitral valve prolapse; other causes include LV dilatation (e.g., left-sided cardiac failure), infective endocarditis, acute rheumatic heart disease, and papillary muscle rupture after a myocardial infarction.
C. Clinical features</p>
<ol>
<li>Holosystolic "blowing" murmur; louder with squatting (increased systemic resistance decreases left ventricular emptying) and expiration (increased return to left atrium)</li>
<li>Results in volume overload and left-sided heart failure</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-mitral-stenosis">VIII.MITRAL STENOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-mitral-stenosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Narrowing of the mitral valve orifice</p>
<ol>
<li>Usually due to chronic rheumatic valve disease
B. Clinical features</li>
<li>Opening snap followed by diastolic rumble</li>
<li>Volume overload leads to dilatation of the left atrium, resulting in
i. Pulmonary congestion with edema and alveolar hemorrhage
ii. Pulmonary hypertension and eventual right-sided heart failure
iii. Atrial fibrillation with associated risk for mural thrombi (Fig. 8.16)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="endocarditis">ENDOCARDITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endocarditis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inflammation of endocardium that lines the surface of cardiac valves; usually due to bacterial infection
B. Streptococcus viridans is the most common overall cause. It is a low-virulence organism that infects previously damaged valves (e.g., chronic rheumatic heart
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-a01445f6.jpeg" alt="img-82.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.16 Mural thrombus involving left atrium. (Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD)</p>
<p>Fig. 8.17A Large vegetations involving tricuspid valve. (Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD)</p>
<p>Fig. 8.17B Janeway lesions.</p>
<p>disease and mitral valve prolapse). Results in small vegetations that do not destroy the valve (subacute endocarditis)</p>
<ol>
<li>Damaged endocardial surface develops thrombotic vegetations (platelets and fibrin).</li>
<li>Transient bacteremia leads to trapping of bacteria in the vegetations; prophylactic antibiotics decrease risk of endocarditis.
C. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause in IV drug abusers.</li>
<li>High-virulence organism that infects normal valves, most commonly the tricuspid.</li>
<li>Results in large vegetations that destroy the valve (acute endocarditis, Fig. 8.17A)
D. Staphylococcus epidermidis is associated with endocarditis of prosthetic valves.
E. Streptococcus bovis is associated with endocarditis in patients with underlying colorectal carcinoma.
F. HACEK organisms (Haemophilus, Actinobacillus, Cardiobacterium, Eikenella, Kingella) are associated with endocarditis with negative blood cultures.
G. Clinical features of bacterial endocarditis include</li>
<li>Fever-due to bacteremia</li>
<li>Murmur-due to vegetations on heart valve</li>
<li>Janeway lesions (erythematous nontender lesions on palms and soles, Fig. 8.17B), Osler nodes (tender lesions on fingers or toes), splinter hemorrhages in nail bed (Fig. 8.17C) and Roth spots (Fig. 8.17D)—due to embolization of septic vegetations</li>
<li>Anemia of chronic disease-due to chronic inflammation
H. Laboratory findings</li>
<li>Positive blood cultures</li>
<li>Anemia of chronic disease ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">b</mi></mrow><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo>↓</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mo separator="true">;</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow \mathrm{Hb}, \downarrow \mathrm{MCV} ; \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">Hb</span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">MCV</span></span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> ferritin, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> TIBC, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> serum iron, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">%</span></span></span></span></span> saturation)</li>
<li>Transesophageal echocardiogram is useful for detecting lesions on valves.
I. Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis is due to sterile vegetations that arise in association with a hypercoagulable state or underlying adenocarcinoma. Vegetations arise on the mitral valve along lines of closure and result in mitral regurgitation.
J. Libman-Sacks endocarditis is due to sterile vegetations that arise in association with SLE. Vegetations are present on the surface and undersurface of the mitral valve and result in mitral regurgitation.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cardiomyopathy">CARDIOMYOPATHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiomyopathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Group of myocardial diseases that result in cardiac dysfunction
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-8e4fbd27.jpeg" alt="img-83.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.17C Splinter hemorrhages.</p>
<p>Fig. 8.17D Roth spots.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-ae0dc44f.jpeg" alt="img-84.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.18 Dilated cardiomyopathy. (Courtesy of Jamie Steinmetz, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-dilated-cardiomyopathy">II. DILATED CARDIOMYOPATHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-dilated-cardiomyopathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Dilation of all four chambers of the heart (Fig. 8.18); most common form of cardiomyopathy
B. Results in systolic dysfunction (ventricles cannot pump), leading to biventricular CHF; complications include mitral and tricuspid valve regurgitation and arrhythmia.
C. Most commonly idiopathic; other causes include</p>
<ol>
<li>Genetic mutation (usually autosomal dominant)</li>
<li>Myocarditis (usually due to coxsackie A or B) -characterized by a lymphocytic infiltrate in the myocardium (Fig. 8.19); results in chest pain, arrhythmia with sudden death, or heart failure. Dilated cardiomyopathy is a late complication.</li>
<li>Alcohol abuse</li>
<li>Drugs (e.g., doxorubicin)</li>
<li>Pregnancy-seen during late pregnancy or soon (weeks to months) after childbirth</li>
<li>Hemochromatosis
D. Treatment is heart transplant.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-hypertrophic-cardiomyopathy">III. HYPERTROPHIC CARDIOMYOPATHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-hypertrophic-cardiomyopathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Massive hypertrophy of the left ventricle
B. Usually due to genetic mutations in sarcomere proteins; most common form is autosomal dominant.
C. Clinical features include</p>
<ol>
<li>Decreased cardiac output-Left ventricular hypertrophy leads to diastolic dysfunction (ventricle cannot fill).</li>
<li>Sudden death due to ventricular arrhythmias; hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a common cause of sudden death in young athletes.</li>
<li>Syncope with exercise-Subaortic hypertrophy of the ventricular septum results in functional aortic stenosis.
D. Biopsy shows myofiber hypertrophy with disarray (Fig. 8.20).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-restrictive-cardiomyopathy">IV. RESTRICTIVE CARDIOMYOPATHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-restrictive-cardiomyopathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Decreased compliance of the ventricular endomyocardium that restricts filling during diastole
B. Causes include amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, endocardial fibroelastosis (children, Fig. 8.21), and Loeffler syndrome (endomyocardial fibrosis with an eosinophilic infiltrate and eosinophilia).
C. Presents as congestive heart failure; classic finding is low-voltage EKG with diminished QRS amplitude.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-7d5ac9f4.jpeg" alt="img-85.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.19 Myocarditis.
Fig. 8.20 Myofiber disarray, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-7222b5fe.jpeg" alt="img-86.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 8.21 Endocardial fibroelastosis. (Courtesy of humpath.com)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cardiac-tumors">CARDIAC TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cardiac-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I. MYXOMA
A. Benign mesenchymal tumor with a gelatinous appearance and abundant ground substance on histology</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common primary cardiac tumor in adults
B. Usually forms a pedunculated mass in the left atrium that causes syncope due to obstruction of the mitral valve
II. RHABDOMYOMA
A. Benign hamartoma of cardiac muscle</li>
<li>Most common primary cardiac tumor in children; associated with tuberous sclerosis
B. Usually arises in the ventricle
III. METASTASIS
A. Metastatic tumors are more common in the heart than primary tumors.</li>
<li>Common metastases to the heart include breast and lung carcinoma, melanoma, and lymphoma.
B. Most commonly involve the pericardium, resulting in a pericardial effusion</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="respiratory-tract-pathology">Respiratory Tract Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiratory-tract-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nasopharynx">NASOPHARYNX<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nasopharynx" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-rhinitis">I. RHINITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-rhinitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inflammation of the nasal mucosa; rhinovirus is the most common cause.
B. Presents with sneezing, congestion, and runny nose (common cold)
C. Allergic rhinitis is a subtype of rhinitis due to a type I hypersensitivity reaction (e.g., to pollen)</p>
<ol>
<li>Characterized by an inflammatory infiltrate with eosinophils</li>
<li>Associated with asthma and eczema</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-nasal-polyp">II. NASAL POLYP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-nasal-polyp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Protrusion of edematous, inflamed nasal mucosa
B. Usually secondary to repeated bouts of rhinitis; also occurs in cystic fibrosis and aspirin-intolerant asthma</p>
<ol>
<li>Aspirin-intolerant asthma is characterized by the triad of asthma, aspirininduced bronchospasms, and nasal polyps; seen in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of asthmatic adults</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-angiofibroma">III. ANGIOFIBROMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-angiofibroma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign tumor of nasal mucosa composed of large blood vessels and fibrous tissue; classically seen in adolescent males
B. Presents with profuse epistaxis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-nasopharyngeal-carcinoma">IV. NASOPHARYNGEAL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-nasopharyngeal-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant tumor of nasopharyngeal epithelium
B. Associated with EBV; classically seen in African children and Chinese adults
C. Biopsy usually reveals pleomorphic keratin-positive epithelial cells (poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma) in a background of lymphocytes.
D. Often presents with involvement of cervical lymph nodes</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="larynx">LARYNX<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#larynx" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. ACUTE EPIGLOTTITIS
A. Inflammation of the epiglottis (Fig. 9.1); H influenzae type b is the most common cause, especially in nonimmunized children.
B. Presents with high fever, sore throat, drooling with dysphagia, muffled voice, and inspiratory stridor; risk of airway obstruction</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-laryngotracheobronchitis-croup">II. LARYNGOTRACHEOBRONCHITIS (CROUP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-laryngotracheobronchitis-croup" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inflammation of the upper airway; parainfluenza virus is the most common cause.
B. Presents with a hoarse, "barking" cough and inspiratory stridor</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-vocal-cord-nodule-singer-s-nodule">III. VOCAL CORD NODULE (SINGER'S NODULE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-vocal-cord-nodule-singer-s-nodule" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Nodule that arises on the true vocal cord
B. Due to excessive use of vocal cords; usually bilateral (Fig. 9.2A)</p>
<ol>
<li>Composed of degenerative (myxoid) connective tissue (Fig. 9.2B)</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Presents with hoarseness; resolves with resting of voice</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-laryngeal-papilloma">IV. LARYNGEAL PAPILLOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-laryngeal-papilloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Benign papillary tumor of the vocal cord
B. Due to HPV 6 and 11; papillomas are usually single in adults and multiple in children.
C. Presents with hoarseness</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-laryngeal-carcinoma">V. LARYNGEAL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-laryngeal-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Squamous cell carcinoma usually arising from the epithelial lining of the vocal cord
B. Risk factors are alcohol and tobacco; can rarely arise from a laryngeal papilloma
C. Presents with hoarseness; other signs include cough and stridor.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulmonary-infections">PULMONARY INFECTIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-infections" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-pneumonia">I. PNEUMONIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-pneumonia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Infection of the lung parenchyma
B. Occurs when normal defenses are impaired (e.g., impaired cough reflex, damage to mucociliary escalator, or mucus plugging) or organism is highly virulent.
C. Clinical features include fever and chills, productive cough with yellow-green (pus) or rusty (bloody) sputum, tachypnea with pleuritic chest pain, decreased breath sounds, crackles, dullness to percussion, and elevated WBC count.
D. Diagnosis is made by chest x-ray, sputum gram stain and culture, and blood cultures.
E. Three patterns are classically seen on chest x-ray: lobar pneumonia, bronchopneumonia, and interstitial pneumonia.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-e25ffebd.jpeg" alt="img-87.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.1 Acute epiglottitis. (Courtesy of Stephanie Rozell, MD)</p>
<p>Fig. 9.2 Vocal cord nodules. A, Gross appearance. B, Microscopic appearance. (B, Reproduced from wikipedia.org, CCBY-SA 3.0)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5ca76a27.jpeg" alt="img-88.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.3 Lobar pneumonia. A, X-ray appearance. B, Red hepatization. C, Acute inflammation involving alveolar sacs. (A, Courtesy of James Heilman, MD, Wikipedia. B, Courtesy of Yale Rosen, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-lobar-pneumonia">II. LOBAR PNEUMONIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-lobar-pneumonia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Characterized by consolidation of an entire lobe of the lung (Fig. 9.3A)
B. Usually bacterial; most common causes are Streptococcus pneumoniae (95%) and Klebsiella pneumoniae (Table 9.1)
C. Classic gross phases of lobar pneumonia</p>
<ol>
<li>Congestion-due to congested vessels and edema</li>
<li>Red hepatization-due to exudate, neutrophils, and hemorrhage filling the alveolar air spaces, giving the normally spongy lung a solid consistency (Fig. 9.3B,C)</li>
<li>Gray hepatization-due to degradation of red cells within the exudate</li>
<li>Resolution</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-bronchopneumonia">III. BRONCHOPNEUMONIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-bronchopneumonia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Characterized by scattered patchy consolidation centered around bronchioles; often multifocal and bilateral (Fig. 9.4)
B. Caused by a variety of bacterial organisms (Table 9.2)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-interstitial-atypical-pneumonia">IV. INTERSTITIAL (ATYPICAL) PNEUMONIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-interstitial-atypical-pneumonia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Characterized by diffuse interstitial infiltrates (Fig. 9.5)
B. Presents with relatively mild upper respiratory symptoms (minimal sputum and low fever); 'atypical' presentation
C. Caused by bacteria or viruses (Table 9.3)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-aspiration-pneumonia">V. ASPIRATION PNEUMONIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-aspiration-pneumonia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Seen in patients at risk for aspiration (e.g., alcoholics and comatose patients)
B. Most often due to anaerobic bacteria in the oropharynx (e.g., Bacteroides, Fusobacterium, and Peptococcus)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-0e3a850a.jpeg" alt="img-89.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.4 Bronchopneumonia. A, X-ray appearance. B, Gross appearance. (B, Courtesy of Yale Rosen, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-f130a818.jpeg" alt="img-90.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.5 Interstitial pneumonia. A, X-ray appearance. B, Inflammatory infiltrate involving interstitium.</p>
<p>Table 9.1: Causes of Lobar Pneumonia</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">ORGANISM</th><th style="text-align: left;">HIGH-YIELD ASSOCIATIONS</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Streptococcus pneumoniae</td><td style="text-align: left;">Most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia and secondary &lt;br&gt; pneumonia (bacterial pneumonia superimposed on a viral upper respiratory tract &lt;br&gt; infection); usually seen in middle-aged adults and elderly</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Klebsiella pneumoniae</td><td style="text-align: left;">Enteric flora that is aspirated; affects malnourished and debilitated individuals, &lt;br&gt; especially elderly in nursing homes, alcoholics, and diabetics. Thick mucoid &lt;br&gt; capsule results in gelatinous sputum (currant jelly); often complicated by abscess</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Table 9.2: Causes of Bronchopneumonia</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">ORGANISM</th><th style="text-align: left;">HIGH-YIELD ASSOCIATIONS</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Staphylococcus aureus</td><td style="text-align: left;">2nd most common cause of secondary pneumonia; often complicated by abscess &lt;br&gt; or empyema</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Haemophilus influenzae</td><td style="text-align: left;">Common cause of secondary pneumonia and pneumonia superimposed on COPD &lt;br&gt; (leads to exacerbation of COPD)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Pseudomonas aeruginosa</td><td style="text-align: left;">Pneumonia in cystic fibrosis patients</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Moraxella catarrhalis</td><td style="text-align: left;">Community-acquired pneumonia and pneumonia superimposed on COPD (leads &lt;br&gt; to exacerbation of COPD)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Legionella pneumophila</td><td style="text-align: left;">Community-acquired pneumonia, pneumonia superimposed on COPD, or &lt;br&gt; pneumonia in immunocompromised states; transmitted from water source &lt;br&gt; Intracellular organism that is best visualized by silver stain</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Table 9.3: Causes of Interstitial (Atypical) Pneumonia</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">ORGANISM</th><th style="text-align: center;">HIGH-YIELD ASSOCIATIONS</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Mycoplasma pneumoniae</td><td style="text-align: center;">Most common cause of atypical pneumonia, usually affects young adults (classically, military recruits or college students living in a dormitory). Complications include autoimmune hemolytic anemia (IgM against I antigen on RBCs causes cold hemolytic anemia) and erythema multiforme. Not visible on gram stain due to lack of cell wall</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Chlamydia pneumoniae</td><td style="text-align: center;">Second most common cause of atypical pneumonia in young adults</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Most common cause of atypical pneumonia in infants</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Cytomegalovirus (CMV)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Atypical pneumonia with posttransplant immunosuppression or chemotherapy</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Influenza virus</td><td style="text-align: center;">Atypical pneumonia in the elderly, immunocompromised, and those with preexisting lung disease. Also increases the risk for superimposed <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span></span> aureus or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span></span></span></span></span> influenzae bacterial pneumonia</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Coxiella burnetii</td><td style="text-align: center;">Atypical pneumonia with high fever (Q fever); seen in farmers and veterinarians (Coxiella spores are deposited on cattle by ticks or are present in cattle placentas). Coxiella is a rickettsial organism, but it is distinct from most rickettsiae because it (1) causes pneumonia, (2) does not require arthropod vector for transmission (survives as highly heat-resistant endospores), and (3) does not produce a skin rash.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>C. Classically results in a right lower lobe abscess</p>
<ol>
<li>Anatomically, the right main stem bronchus branches at a less acute angle than the left.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vi-tuberculosis-tb">VI. TUBERCULOSIS (TB)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-tuberculosis-tb" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Due to inhalation of aerosolized Mycobacterium tuberculosis
B. Primary TB arises with initial exposure.</p>
<ol>
<li>Results in focal, caseating necrosis in the lower lobe of the lung and hilar lymph nodes that undergoes fibrosis and calcification, forming a Ghon complex (Fig. 9.6A)</li>
<li>Primary TB is generally asymptomatic, but leads to a positive PPD.
C. Secondary TB arises with reactivation of Mycobacterium tuberculosis.</li>
<li>Reactivation is commonly due to AIDS; may also be seen with aging</li>
<li>Occurs at apex of lung (relatively poor lymphatic drainage and high oxygen tension)</li>
<li>Forms cavitary foci of caseous necrosis; may also lead to miliary pulmonary TB or tuberculous bronchopneumonia</li>
<li>Clinical features include fevers and night sweats, cough with hemoptysis, and weight loss.</li>
<li>Biopsy reveals caseating granulomas; AFB stain reveals acid-fast bacilli (Fig. 9.6B,C).</li>
<li>Systemic spread often occurs and can involve any tissue; common sites include meninges (meningitis), cervical lymph nodes, kidneys (sterile pyuria), and lumbar vertebrae (Pott disease).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-obstructive-pulmonary-disease">CHRONIC OBSTRUCTIVE PULMONARY DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-obstructive-pulmonary-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Group of diseases characterized by airway obstruction; lung does not empty, and air is trapped.</p>
<ol>
<li>Volume of air that can be forcefully expired is decreased ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> FVC), especially during the first second of expiration <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><mo>↓</mo><mo>↓</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mn>1</mn></msub><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\downarrow \downarrow \mathrm{FEV}_{1}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mrel">↓↓</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">FEV</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>; results in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>:</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow \mathrm{FEV}_{1}: \mathrm{FVC}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">FEV</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">FVC</span></span></span></span></span></span> ratio</li>
<li>Total lung capacity (TLC) is usually increased due to air trapping.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-chronic-bronchitis">II. CHRONIC BRONCHITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-chronic-bronchitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Chronic productive cough lasting at least 3 months over a minimum of 2 years; highly associated with smoking
B. Characterized by hypertrophy of bronchial mucous glands (Fig. 9.7)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-e45d9b4a.jpeg" alt="img-91.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.6 Tuberculosis. A, Ghon focus. B, Caseating granuloma. C, AFB staining of M tuberculosis. (A, Courtesy of Yale Rosen, MD)</p>
<ol>
<li>Leads to increased thickness of mucus glands relative to bronchial wall thickness (Reid index increases to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span>; normal is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>40</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;40 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">40%</span></span></span></span></span> ).
C. Clinical features</li>
<li>Productive cough due to excessive mucus production</li>
<li>Cyanosis ('blue bloaters')—Mucus plugs trap carbon dioxide; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \mathrm{PaCO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PaCO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow \mathrm{PaO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PaO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>Increased risk of infection and cor pulmonale</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-emphysema">III. EMPHYSEMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-emphysema" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Destruction of alveolar air sacs (Fig. 9.8)</p>
<ol>
<li>Loss of elastic recoil and collapse of airways during exhalation results in obstruction and air trapping.
B. Due to imbalance of proteases and antiproteases</li>
<li>Inflammation in the lung normally leads to release of proteases by neutrophils and macrophages.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha_{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5806em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0037em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>-antitrypsin (A1AT) neutralizes proteases.</li>
<li>Excessive inflammation or lack of A1AT leads to destruction of the alveolar air sacs.
C. Smoking is the most common cause of emphysema.</li>
<li>Pollutants in smoke lead to excessive inflammation and protease-mediated damage.</li>
<li>Results in centriacinar emphysema that is most severe in the upper lobes
D. A1AT deficiency is a rare cause of emphysema.</li>
<li>Lack of antiprotease leaves the air sacs vulnerable to protease-mediated damage.</li>
<li>Results in panacinar emphysema that is most severe in the lower lobes</li>
<li>Liver cirrhosis may also be present.
i. A1AT deficiency is due to misfolding of the mutated protein.
ii. Mutant A1AT accumulates in the endoplasmic reticulum of hepatocytes, resulting in liver damage.
iii. Biopsy reveals pink, PAS-positive globules in hepatocytes (Fig. 9.9).</li>
<li>Disease severity is based on the degree of A1AT deficiency.
i. PiM is the normal allele; two copies are usually expressed (PiMM).
ii. PiZ is the most common clinically relevant mutation; results in significantly low levels of circulating A1AT
iii. PiMZ heterozygotes are usually asymptomatic with decreased circulating levels of A1AT; however, significant risk for emphysema with smoking exists.
iv. PiZZ homozygotes are at significant risk for panacinar emphysema and cirrhosis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-ffe87e81.jpeg" alt="img-92.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 9.7 Chronic bronchitis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5f716d6c.jpeg" alt="img-93.jpeg">
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-734e4641.jpeg" alt="img-94.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.8 Emphysema. A, Gross appearance. B, Microscopic appearance. (A, Courtesy of Yale Rosen, MD)</p>
<p>E. Clinical features of emphysema include</p>
<ol>
<li>Dyspnea and cough with minimal sputum</li>
<li>Prolonged expiration with pursed lips ('pink-puffer')</li>
<li>Weight loss</li>
<li>Increased anterior-posterior diameter of chest ('barrel-chest,' Fig. 9.10)</li>
<li>Hypoxemia (due to destruction of capillaries in the alveolar sac) and cor pulmonale are late complications.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-asthma">IV. ASTHMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-asthma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Reversible airway bronchoconstriction, most often due to allergic stimuli (atopic asthma)
B. Presents in childhood; often associated with allergic rhinitis, eczema, and a family history of atopy
C. Pathogenesis (type I hypersensitivity)</p>
<ol>
<li>Allergens induce <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}} 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em;
