margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">H</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span> phenotype in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><msup><mn>4</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD} 4^{+} \mathrm{T}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">T</span></span></span></span></span> cells of genetically susceptible individuals.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}} 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">H</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span> cells secrete IL-4 (mediates class switch to IgE), IL-5 (attracts eosinophils), and IL-10 (stimulates <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}} 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">H</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span> cells and inhibits <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi></msub><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{T}_{\mathrm{H}} 1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">T</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: 0em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">H</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> ).</li>
<li>Reexposure to allergen leads to IgE-mediated activation of mast cells.
i. Release of preformed histamine granules and generation of leukotrienes C 4 , D4, and E4 lead to bronchoconstriction, inflammation, and edema (earlyphase reaction).
ii. Inflammation, especially major basic protein derived from eosinophils, damages cells and perpetuates bronchoconstriction (late-phase reaction).
D. Clinical features are episodic and related to allergen exposure.</li>
<li>Dyspnea and wheezing</li>
<li>Productive cough, classically with spiral-shaped mucus plugs (Curschmann spirals) and eosinophil-derived crystals (Charcot-Leyden crystals, Fig. 9.11).</li>
<li>Severe, unrelenting attack can result in status asthmaticus and death.
E. Asthma may also arise from nonallergic causes (non-atopic asthma) such as exercise, viral infection, aspirin (e.g., aspirin intolerant asthma), and occupational exposures.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-bronchiectasis">V. BRONCHIECTASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-bronchiectasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Permanent dilatation of bronchi (Fig. 9.12); loss of airway tone results in air trapping.
B. Due to severe inflammation with damage to airway walls. Causes include</p>
<ol>
<li>Cystic fibrosis</li>
<li>Primary ciliary dyskinesia-inherited defect of the dynein arm, which is necessary for ciliary movement. Associated with sinusitis, infertility (poor motility of sperm), and situs inversus (position of major organs is reversed, e.g., heart is on right side of thorax), which is called Kartagener syndrome
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-9a7a9230.jpeg" alt="img-95.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 9.9 A1AT accumulation in hepatocytes.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-550b372a.jpeg" alt="img-96.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.10 Increased AP diameter, emphysema. (Courtesy of James Heilman, MD, Wikipedia)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5f26a236.jpeg" alt="img-97.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.11 Charcot-Leyden crystals, asthma.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Tumor or foreign body (localized bronchiectasis)</li>
<li>Necrotizing infection (localized bronchiectasis)</li>
<li>Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis-Hypersensitivity reaction to Aspergillus leads to chronic inflammatory damage; usually seen in individuals with asthma or cystic fibrosis
C. Clinical features</li>
<li>Cough, dyspnea, and foul-smelling sputum</li>
<li>Complications include hypoxemia with cor pulmonale and secondary (AA) amyloidosis.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="restrictive-diseases">RESTRICTIVE DISEASES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#restrictive-diseases" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Characterized by restricted filling of the lung; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> TLC, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow \mathrm{FEV}_{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">FEV</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo><mo>↓</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow \downarrow \mathrm{FVC}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓↓</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">FVC</span></span></span></span></span></span>; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>:</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{FEV}_{1}: \mathrm{FVC}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">FEV</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">FVC</span></span></span></span></span></span> ratio is increased.
B. Most commonly due to interstitial diseases of the lung; may also arise with chest wall abnormalities (e.g., massive obesity)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-idiopathic-pulmonary-fibrosis">II. IDIOPATHIC PULMONARY FIBROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-idiopathic-pulmonary-fibrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Fibrosis of lung interstitium (Fig. 9.13)
B. Etiology is unknown. Likely related to cyclical lung injury; TGF- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> from injured pneumocytes induces fibrosis.</p>
<ol>
<li>Secondary causes of interstitial fibrosis such as drugs (e.g., bleomycin and amiodarone) and radiation therapy must be excluded.
C. Clinical features</li>
<li>Progressive dyspnea and cough</li>
<li>Bilateral fibrosis on lung CT; initially seen in subpleural patches, but eventually results in extensive fibrosis with end-stage 'honeycomb' lung</li>
<li>Anti-fibrogenic drugs slow disease progression</li>
<li>Definitive treatment is lung transplantation.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-pneumoconioses">III. PNEUMOCONIOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-pneumoconioses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Interstitial fibrosis due to occupational exposure; requires chronic exposure to small particles that are fibrogenic (Table 9.4)</p>
<ol>
<li>Alveolar macrophages engulf foreign particles and induce fibrosis.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-sarcoidosis">IV. SARCOIDOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-sarcoidosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Systemic disease characterized by noncaseating granulomas in multiple organs; classically seen in African American females
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1a7eea48.jpeg" alt="img-98.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.12 Bronchiectasis. (Courtesy of Yale Rosen, MD)
Fig. 9.13 Interstitial fibrosis, idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.</p>
<p>Table 9.4: Summary of Pneumoconioses</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">ENTITY</th><th style="text-align: center;">EXPOSURE</th><th style="text-align: center;">PATHOLOGIC FINDINGS</th><th style="text-align: center;">COMMENTS</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Coal Workers' &lt;br&gt; Pneumoconiosis</td><td style="text-align: center;">Carbon dust; seen in coal miners</td><td style="text-align: center;">Massive exposure leads to diffuse fibrosis ('black lung'); associated with rheumatoid arthritis (Caplan syndrome)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Mild exposure to carbon (e.g., pollution) results in anthracosis (collections of carbon-laden macrophages); not clinically significant</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Silicosis</td><td style="text-align: center;">Silica; seen in sandblasters and silica miners</td><td style="text-align: center;">Fibrotic nodules in upper lobes of the lung</td><td style="text-align: center;">Increased risk for TB; silica impairs phagolysosome formation by macrophages.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Berylliosis</td><td style="text-align: center;">Beryllium; seen in beryllium miners and workers in the aerospace industry</td><td style="text-align: center;">Noncaseating granulomas in the lung, hilar lymph nodes, and systemic organs</td><td style="text-align: center;">Increased risk for lung cancer</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Asbestosis</td><td style="text-align: center;">Asbestos fibers; seen in construction workers, plumbers, and shipyard workers</td><td style="text-align: center;">Fibrosis of lung and pleura (plaques) with increased risk for lung carcinoma and mesothelioma; lung carcinoma is more common than mesothelioma in exposed individuals.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Lesions may contain long, goldenbrown fibers with associated iron (asbestos bodies, Fig. 9.14), which confirm exposure to asbestos</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>B. Etiology is unknown; likely due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>helper T-cell response to an unknown antigen
C. Granulomas most commonly involve the hilar lymph nodes and lung (Fig. 9.15A), leading to restrictive lung disease.</p>
<ol>
<li>Characteristic stellate inclusions ('asteroid bodies') are often seen within giant cells of the granulomas (Fig. 9.15B).
D. Other commonly involved tissues include the uvea (uveitis), skin (cutaneous nodules or erythema nodosum), and salivary and lacrimal glands (mimics Sjögren syndrome); almost any tissue can be involved.
E. Clinical features</li>
<li>Dyspnea or cough (most common presenting symptom)</li>
<li>Elevated serum ACE</li>
<li>Hypercalcemia (1-alpha hydroxylase activity of epithelioid histiocytes converts vitamin D to its active form)</li>
<li>Treatment is immunosuppression; often resolves spontaneously without treatment.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-9c2fd8cc.jpeg" alt="img-99.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 9.14 Asbestos bodies. (Courtesy of Nephron, GNU-FDL v1.3)</p>
<p>Fig. 9.15 Sarcoidosis. A, Noncaseating granuloma involving lung. B, Asteroid body.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="v-hypersensitivity-pneumonitis">V. HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-hypersensitivity-pneumonitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Granulomatous reaction to inhaled organic antigens (e.g., pigeon breeder's lung)
B. Presents with fever, cough, and dyspnea hours after exposure; resolves with removal of the exposure
C. Chronic exposure leads to interstitial fibrosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="pulmonary-hypertension">PULMONARY HYPERTENSION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pulmonary-hypertension" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. High pressure in the pulmonary circuit (mean arterial pressure <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>25</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;25 \mathrm{~mm} \mathrm{Hg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8778em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">25</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">Hg</span></span></span></span></span></span>; normal is 10 mm Hg )
B. Characterized by atherosclerosis of the pulmonary trunk, smooth muscle hypertrophy of pulmonary arteries, and intimal fibrosis; plexiform lesions are seen with severe, long-standing disease (Fig. 9.16).
C. Leads to right ventricular hypertrophy with eventual cor pulmonale
D. Presents with exertional dyspnea or right-sided heart failure
E. Subclassified as primary or secondary based on etiology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-primary-pulmonary-hypertension">II. PRIMARY PULMONARY HYPERTENSION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-primary-pulmonary-hypertension" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Classically seen in young adult females
B. Etiology is unknown; some familial forms are related to inactivating mutations of BMPR2, leading to proliferation of vascular smooth muscle.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-secondary-pulmonary-hypertension">III. SECONDARY PULMONARY HYPERTENSION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-secondary-pulmonary-hypertension" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Due to hypoxemia (e.g., COPD and interstitial lung disease) or increased volume in the pulmonary circuit (e.g., congenital heart disease); may also arise with recurrent pulmonary embolism</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="respiratory-distress-syndromes">RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROMES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#respiratory-distress-syndromes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-acute-respiratory-distress-syndrome">I. ACUTE RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-acute-respiratory-distress-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Diffuse damage to the alveolar-capillary interface (diffuse alveolar damage)
B. Leakage of protein-rich fluid leads to edema that combines with necrotic epithelial cells to form hyaline membranes lining alveoli (Fig. 9.17A).
C. Clinical features</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypoxemia and cyanosis with respiratory distress-due to thickened diffusion barrier and collapse of air sacs (increased surface tension)</li>
<li>'White-out' on chest x-ray (Fig. 9.17B)
D. Secondary to a variety of disease processes including sepsis, infection, shock, trauma, aspiration, pancreatitis, DIC, hypersensitivity reactions, and drugs.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-ca62f732.jpeg" alt="img-100.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 9.16 Plexiform lesion, primary pulmonary hypertension.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-fdedad73.jpeg" alt="img-101.jpeg">
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-4c298606.jpeg" alt="img-102.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.17 ARDS. A, Hyaline membranes. B, 'White-out' of lung on x-ray. (B, Courtesy of Samir, GNUFDL v1.2)</p>
<ol>
<li>Activation of neutrophils induces protease- and free radical-mediated damage of type I and II pneumocytes.
E. Treatment</li>
<li>Address underlying cause</li>
<li>Ventilation with positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP)
F. Recovery may be complicated by interstitial fibrosis; damage and loss of type II pneumocytes leads to scarring and fibrosis.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-neonatal-respiratory-distress-syndrome">II. NEONATAL RESPIRATORY DISTRESS SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-neonatal-respiratory-distress-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Respiratory distress due to inadequate surfactant levels</p>
<ol>
<li>Surfactant is made by type II pneumocytes; phosphatidylcholine (lecithin) is the major component.</li>
<li>Surfactant decreases surface tension in the lung, preventing collapse of alveolar air sacs after expiration.</li>
<li>Lack of surfactant leads to collapse of air sacs and formation of hyaline membranes.
B. Associated with</li>
<li>Prematurity-Surfactant production begins at 28 weeks; adequate levels are not reached until 34 weeks.
i. Amniotic fluid lecithin to sphingomyelin ratio is used to screen for lung maturity.
ii. Phosphatidylcholine (lecithin) levels increase as surfactant is produced; sphingomyelin remains constant.
iii. A ratio <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span> indicates adequate surfactant production.</li>
<li>Caesarian section delivery-due to lack of stress-induced steroids; steroids increase synthesis of surfactant.</li>
<li>Maternal diabetes-Insulin decreases surfactant production.
C. Clinical features</li>
<li>Increasing respiratory effort after birth, tachypnea with use of accessory muscles, and grunting</li>
<li>Hypoxemia with cyanosis</li>
<li>Diffuse granularity of the lung ('ground-glass' appearance) on x-ray (Fig. 9.18)
D. Complications</li>
<li>Hypoxemia increases the risk for persistence of patent ductus arteriosus and necrotizing enterocolitis.</li>
<li>Supplemental oxygen increases the risk for free radical injury. Retinal injury leads to blindness; lung damage leads to bronchopulmonary dysplasia.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="lung-cancer">LUNG CANCER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lung-cancer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Most common cause of cancer mortality in the US; average age at presentation is 60 years.
B. Key risk factors are cigarette smoke, radon, and asbestos.</p>
<ol>
<li>Cigarette smoke contains over 60 carcinogens; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>85</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">85 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">85%</span></span></span></span></span> of lung cancer occurs in smokers.
i. Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons and arsenic are particularly mutagenic.
ii. Cancer risk is directly related to the duration and amount of smoking ('packyears').</li>
<li>Radon is formed by radioactive decay of uranium, which is present in soil.
i. Accumulates in closed spaces such as basements
ii. Responsible for most of the public exposure to ionizing radiation; <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mn>2</mn><mtext>nd&nbsp;</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2^{\text {nd }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8491em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">2</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8491em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">nd&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> most frequent cause of lung carcinoma in US</li>
</ol>
<p>iii. Increased risk of lung cancer is also seen in uranium miners.
3. Environmental toxins include asbestos, coal fueled stoves, and metals (arsenic, chromium, and nickel)
C. Presenting symptoms are nonspecific (e.g., cough, hemoptysis, dyspnea, weight loss, and post-obstructive pneumonia).
D. Imaging usually reveals a large, spiculated mass; however, a solitary nodule ('coinlesion') can be seen. Biopsy is necessary for a diagnosis of cancer.</p>
<ol>
<li>Benign lesions may also produce a 'coin-lesion,' especially in younger patients. Examples include
i. Granuloma-often due to TB or fungus (especially Histoplasma in the Midwest)
ii. Bronchial hamartoma-benign tumor composed of lung tissue and cartilage; often calcified on imaging
E. Lung carcinoma is classically divided into 2 categories (Table 9.5).</li>
<li>Small cell carcinoma (15%)—usually not amenable to surgical resection (treated with chemotherapy and radiation)</li>
<li>Non-small cell carcinoma (85%)
i. Usually amenable to surgical resection
ii. Major subtypes include adenocarcinoma (50%), squamous cell carcinoma (30%), large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma (5%), and carcinoid tumor (5%).</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 9.5: Cancers of the Lung</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">CANCER</th><th style="text-align: center;">CHARACTERISTIC HISTOLOGY</th><th style="text-align: center;">ASSOCIATION</th><th style="text-align: center;">LOCATION</th><th style="text-align: center;">COMMENT</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Small cell carcinoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Poorly differentiated small cells (Fig. 9.19) with neuroendocrine differentiation, chromogranin positive</td><td style="text-align: center;">Male smokers</td><td style="text-align: center;">Central</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rapid growth and early metastasis; may produce endocrine (e.g., ADH or ACTH) or nervous system (e.g., Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome) paraneoplastic syndromes</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Adenocarcinoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Glands, mucin (Fig. 9.20A), or TTF1 expression by immunohistochemistry (IHC)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Most common tumor in nonsmokers and female smokers</td><td style="text-align: center;">Peripheral (Fig. 9.20B)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Adenocarcinoma in-situ exhibits columnar cells that grow along preexisting bronchioles and alveoli (Fig. 9.21); may present as pneumonia-like consolidation on imaging</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Squamous cell carcinoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Keratin pearls, intercellular bridges (Fig. 9.22A,B), or p40 expression by IHC</td><td style="text-align: center;">Most common tumor in male smokers</td><td style="text-align: center;">Central (Fig. 9.22C)</td><td style="text-align: center;">May produce PTHrP</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Poorly differentiated large cells (no glands, mucin, TTF-1, keratin pearls, intercellular bridges, or p40)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Smoking</td><td style="text-align: center;">Central or peripheral</td><td style="text-align: center;">Diagnosis of exclusion</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Carcinoid tumor</td><td style="text-align: center;">Well differentiated neuroendocrine cells (nests); chromogranin positive (Fig. 9.23A,B)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Not significantly related to smoking</td><td style="text-align: center;">Central or peripheral; when central, classically forms a polyp-like mass in the bronchus (Fig. 9.23C)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Low-grade malignancy; rarely, can cause carcinoid syndrome</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Metastasis to lung</td><td style="text-align: center;">Most common sources are breast and colon carcinoma.</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">Multiple 'cannonball' nodules on imaging</td><td style="text-align: center;">More common than primary tumors</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251213-546fdd0d.jpeg" alt="img-103.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.18 Granularity of lung, neonatal respiratory
Fig. 9.19 Small cell carcinoma. distress syndrome. (Published with permission from LearningRadiology.com)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6dc2f3e1.jpeg" alt="img-104.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.20 Adenocarcinoma. A, Gland formation and mucin production. B, Peripheral location. (B, Courtesy of Thomas Krausz, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-275e55b0.jpeg" alt="img-105.jpeg">
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-02bf9078.jpeg" alt="img-106.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.21 Adenocarcinoma in-situ.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1edae0a8.jpeg" alt="img-107.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.22 Squamous cell carcinoma. A, Keratin pearls. B, Intercellular bridges. C, Central location. (B, Courtesy Thomas Krausz, MD. C, Courtesy of Yale Rosen, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-0da2024a.jpeg" alt="img-108.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.23 Carcinoid tumor. A, Microscopic appearance. B, Chromogranin expression by immunohistochemistry. C, Polyp-like growth in the bronchus. (C, Courtesy of Yale Rosen, MD)</p>
<p>F. TNM staging</p>
<ol>
<li>T-Tumor size and local extension
i. Obstruction of SVC leads to distended head and neck veins with edema and blue discoloration of arms and face (superior vena cava syndrome).
ii. Involvement of recurrent laryngeal (hoarseness) or phrenic (diaphragmatic paralysis) nerve
iii. Involvement of the sympathetic chain (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis; Horner syndrome) and brachial plexus (shoulder pain and hand weakness) is seen with apical tumors involving the superior sulcus (Pancoast tumor)</li>
<li>N-spread to regional lymph nodes (hilar and mediastinal)</li>
<li>M-a unique site of distant metastasis is the adrenal gland.</li>
<li>Overall, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> 5-year survival; lung carcinoma often presents late
i. Screening by low-dose CT recommended for patients with long smoking history</li>
<li>Testing for 'driver mutations' guides systemic therapy in advanced disease
i. EGFR mutations (erlotinib) or ALK translocation (crizotinib) may be present in adenocarcinoma; EGFR is especially common in Asian females who are non-smokers.</li>
<li>Testing for PD-L1 expression (pembrolizumab) guides immunotherapy in advanced disease; PD-L1 may be present in any non-small cell carcinoma.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="pleura">PLEURA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#pleura" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-pneumothorax">I. PNEUMOTHORAX<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-pneumothorax" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Accumulation of air in the pleural space
B. Spontaneous pneumothorax is due to rupture of an emphysematous bleb; seen in young adults</p>
<ol>
<li>Results in collapse of a portion of the lung (Fig. 9.24); trachea shifts to the side of collapse.
C. Tension pneumothorax arises with penetrating chest wall injury.</li>
<li>Air enters the pleural space, but cannot exit; trachea is pushed opposite to the side of injury.</li>
<li>Medical emergency; treated with insertion of a chest tube</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-mesothelioma">II. MESOTHELIOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-mesothelioma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant neoplasm of mesothelial cells; highly associated with occupational exposure to asbestos
B. Presents with recurrent pleural effusions, dyspnea, and chest pain; tumor encases the lung (Fig. 9.25).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1f335009.jpeg" alt="img-109.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 9.24 Spontaneous pneumothorax. (Courtesy of James Heilman, MD, Wikipedia.)
Fig. 9.25 Mesothelioma. (Courtesy of Jamie Steinmetz, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="gastrointestinal-pathology">Gastrointestinal Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gastrointestinal-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="oral-cavity">ORAL CAVITY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#oral-cavity" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-cleft-lip-and-palate">I. CLEFT LIP AND PALATE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-cleft-lip-and-palate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Full-thickness defect of lip or palate (Fig. 10.1)
B. Due to failure of facial prominences to fuse</p>
<ol>
<li>During early pregnancy, facial prominences (one from superior, two from the sides, and two from inferior) grow and fuse together to form the face.
C. Cleft lip and palate usually occur together; isolated cleft lip or palate is less common.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-aphthous-ulcer">II. APHTHOUS ULCER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-aphthous-ulcer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Painful, superficial ulceration of the oral mucosa (Fig. 10.2)
B. Arises in relation to stress and resolves spontaneously, but often recurs
C. Characterized by a grayish base surrounded by erythema</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bd7cddde">III. BEHÇET SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bd7cddde" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Recurrent aphthous ulcers, genital ulcers, and uveitis
B. Due to immune complex vasculitis involving small vessels
C. Can be seen after viral infection, but etiology is unknown</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-oral-herpes">IV. ORAL HERPES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-oral-herpes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Vesicles involving oral mucosa that rupture, resulting in shallow, painful, red ulcers
B. Usually due to HSV-1
C. Primary infection occurs in childhood; lesions heal, but virus remains dormant in ganglia of the trigeminal nerve.
D. Stress and sunlight cause reactivation of the virus, leading to vesicles that often arise on the lips (cold sore, Fig. 10.3).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-squamous-cell-carcinoma">V. SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-squamous-cell-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant neoplasm of squamous cells lining the oral mucosa
B. Tobacco and alcohol are major risk factors.
C. Floor of mouth is the most common location.
D. Oral leukoplakia and erythroplakia are precursor lesions.</p>
<ol>
<li>Leukoplakia is a white plaque that cannot be scraped away; often represents squamous cell dysplasia</li>
<li>Leukoplakia is distinct from oral candidiasis (thrush) and hairy leukoplakia.
i. Oral candidiasis is a white deposit on the tongue, which is easily scraped away (Fig. 10.4); usually seen in immunocompromised states
ii. Hairy leukoplakia is a white, rough ('hairy') patch that arises on the lateral tongue. It is usually seen in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., AIDS) and is due to EBV-induced squamous cell hyperplasia; not pre-malignant</li>
<li>Erythroplakia (red plaque) represents vascularized leukoplakia and is highly suggestive of squamous cell dysplasia.</li>
<li>Erythroplakia and leukoplakia are often biopsied to rule out carcinoma.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="salivary-gland">SALIVARY GLAND<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#salivary-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Salivary glands are exocrine glands that secrete saliva.
B. Divided into major (parotid, submandibular, and sublingual glands) and minor glands (hundreds of microscopic glands distributed throughout the oral mucosa)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-mumps">II. MUMPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-mumps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Infection with mumps virus resulting in bilateral inflamed parotid glands
B. Orchitis, pancreatitis, and aseptic meningitis may also be present.</p>
<ol>
<li>Serum amylase is increased due to salivary gland or pancreatic involvement.</li>
<li>Orchitis carries risk of sterility, especially in teenagers.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-sialadenitis">III. SIALADENITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-sialadenitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inflammation of the salivary gland
B. Most commonly due to an obstructing stone (sialolithiasis) leading to Staphylococcus aureus infection; usually unilateral</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-pleomorphic-adenoma">IV. PLEOMORPHIC ADENOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-pleomorphic-adenoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign tumor composed of stromal (e.g., cartilage) and epithelial tissue; most common tumor of the salivary gland
B. Usually arises in parotid; presents as a mobile, painless, circumscribed mass at the angle of the jaw
C. High rate of recurrence; extension of small islands of tumor through tumor capsule often leads to incomplete resection (Fig. 10.5).
D. Rarely may transform into carcinoma, which presents with signs of facial nerve damage (facial nerve runs through parotid gland)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-warthin-tumor">V. WARTHIN TUMOR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-warthin-tumor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign cystic tumor with abundant lymphocytes and germinal centers (lymph node-like stroma); 2nd most common tumor of the salivary gland
B. Almost always arises in the parotid</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-mucoepidermoid-carcinoma">VI. MUCOEPIDERMOID CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-mucoepidermoid-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant tumor composed of mucinous and squamous cells; most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland
B. Usually arises in the parotid; commonly involves the facial nerve
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-aaa2d297.jpeg" alt="img-110.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 10.1 Cleft lip and palate. (Courtesy of James Heilman, MD, Wikipedia)</p>
<p>Fig. 10.2 Aphthous ulcer. (Reproduced from wikipedia.org, CCBY-SA 3.0)</p>
<p>Fig. 10.3 Cold sore. (Courtesy of Dr. Herrmann, CDC)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="esophagus">ESOPHAGUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#esophagus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-tracheoesophageal-fistula">I. TRACHEOESOPHAGEAL FISTULA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-tracheoesophageal-fistula" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Congenital defect resulting in a connection between the esophagus and trachea
B. Most common variant consists of proximal esophageal atresia with the distal esophagus arising from the trachea (Fig. 10.6).</p>
<ol>
<li>Presents with vomiting, polyhydramnios, abdominal distension, and aspiration</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-esophageal-web">II. ESOPHAGEAL WEB<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-esophageal-web" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Thin protrusion of esophageal mucosa, most often in the upper esophagus
B. Presents with dysphagia for poorly chewed food
C. Increased risk for esophageal squamous cell carcinoma
D. Plummer-Vinson syndrome is characterized by severe iron deficiency anemia, esophageal web, and beefy-red tongue due to atrophic glossitis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-zenker-diverticulum">III. ZENKER DIVERTICULUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-zenker-diverticulum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Outpouching of pharyngeal mucosa through an acquired defect in the muscular wall (false diverticulum)
B. Arises above the upper esophageal sphincter at the junction of the esophagus and pharynx
C. Presents with dysphagia, obstruction, and halitosis (bad breath)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-mallory-weiss-syndrome">IV. MALLORY-WEISS SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-mallory-weiss-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Longitudinal laceration of mucosa at the gastroesophageal (GE) junction
B. Caused by severe vomiting, usually due to alcoholism or bulimia
C. Presents with painful hematemesis
D. Risk of Boerhaave syndrome-rupture of esophagus leading to air in the mediastinum and subcutaneous emphysema</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-esophageal-varices">V. ESOPHAGEAL VARICES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-esophageal-varices" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Dilated submucosal veins in the lower esophagus
B. Arise secondary to portal hypertension</p>
<ol>
<li>Distal esophageal vein normally drains into the portal vein via the left gastric vein.</li>
<li>In portal hypertension, the left gastric vein backs up into the esophageal vein, resulting in dilation (varices).
C. Asymptomatic, but risk of rupture exists</li>
<li>Presents with painless hematemesis</li>
<li>Most common cause of death in cirrhosis
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-b51e9de4.jpeg" alt="img-111.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 10.4 Oral candidiasis. (Courtesy of James Hellman, MD, Wikipedia)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-acb1dd29.jpeg" alt="img-112.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 10.5 Pleomorphic adenoma. (Courtesy of Bulent Celasun, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-3683e2eb.jpeg" alt="img-113.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 10.6 Tracheoesophageal fistula. (Courtesy of humpath.com)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vi-achalasia">VI. ACHALASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-achalasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Disordered esophageal motility with inability to relax the lower esophageal sphincter (LES)
B. Due to damaged ganglion cells in the myenteric plexus</p>
<ol>
<li>Ganglion cells of myenteric plexus are located between the inner circular and outer longitudinal layers of the muscularis propria and are important for regulating bowel motility and relaxing the LES.</li>
<li>Damage to ganglion cells can be idiopathic or secondary to a known insult (e.g., Trypanosoma cruzi infection in Chagas disease).
C. Clinical features</li>
<li>Dysphagia for solids and liquids</li>
<li>Putrid breath</li>
<li>High LES pressure on esophageal manometry</li>
<li>'Bird-beak' sign on barium swallow study (Fig. 10.7)</li>
<li>Increased risk for esophageal squamous cell carcinoma</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-gastroesophageal-reflux-disease-gerd">VII. GASTROESOPHAGEAL REFLUX DISEASE (GERD)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-gastroesophageal-reflux-disease-gerd" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Reflux of acid from the stomach due to reduced LES tone
B. Risk factors include alcohol, tobacco, obesity, fat-rich diet, caffeine, and hiatal hernia.
C. Clinical features</p>
<ol>
<li>Heartburn (mimics cardiac chest pain)</li>
<li>Asthma (adult-onset) and cough</li>
<li>Damage to enamel of teeth</li>
<li>Ulceration with stricture and Barrett esophagus are late complications.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-barrett-esophagus">VIII.BARRETT ESOPHAGUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-barrett-esophagus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Metaplasia of the lower esophageal mucosa from stratified squamous epithelium to nonciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells (Fig. 10.8); seen in 10% of patients with GERD</p>
<ol>
<li>Response of lower esophageal stem cells to acidic stress
B. May progress to dysplasia and adenocarcinoma</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ix-esophageal-carcinoma">IX. ESOPHAGEAL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ix-esophageal-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Subclassified as adenocarcinoma or squamous cell carcinoma
B. Adenocarcinoma is a malignant proliferation of glands; most common type of esophageal carcinoma in the West</p>
<ol>
<li>Arises from preexisting Barrett esophagus; usually involves the lower one-third of the esophagus
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-05c0a9f0.jpeg" alt="img-114.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 10.7 'Bird-beak' sign, achalasia. (Courtesy of F. Farrokhi, MD and M. Vaezi, MD)
Fig. 10.8 Barrett esophagus.</p>
<p>C. Squamous cell carcinoma is a malignant proliferation of squamous cells; most common esophageal cancer worldwide</p>
<ol>
<li>Usually arises in upper or middle third of the esophagus; major risk factors include
i. Alcohol and tobacco (most common causes)
ii. Very hot tea
iii. Achalasia
iv. Esophageal web (e.g., Plummer-Vinson syndrome)
v. Esophageal injury (e.g., lye ingestion)
D. Esophageal carcinoma presents late (poor prognosis).</li>
<li>Symptoms include progressive dysphagia (solids to liquids), weight loss, pain, and hematemesis.</li>
<li>Squamous cell carcinoma may additionally present with hoarse voice (recurrent laryngeal nerve involvement) and cough (tracheal involvement).
E. Location of lymph node spread depends on the level of the esophagus that is involved.</li>
<li>Upper <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/3</span></span></span></span></span>-cervical nodes</li>
<li>Middle <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/3</span></span></span></span></span>-mediastinal or tracheobronchial nodes</li>
<li>Lower <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/3</span></span></span></span></span>-celiac and gastric nodes</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="stomach">STOMACH<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#stomach" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-gastroschisis">I. GASTROSCHISIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-gastroschisis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Congenital malformation of the anterior abdominal wall leading to exposure of abdominal contents (Fig. 10.9)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-omphalocele">II. OMPHALOCELE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-omphalocele" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Persistent herniation of bowel into umbilical cord
B. Due to failure of herniated intestines to return to the body cavity during development</p>
<ol>
<li>Contents are covered by peritoneum and amnion of the umbilical cord (Fig. 10.10).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-pyloric-stenosis">III. PYLORIC STENOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-pyloric-stenosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Congenital hypertrophy of pyloric smooth muscle; more common in males
B. Classically presents two weeks after birth as</p>
<ol>
<li>Projectile nonbilious vomiting</li>
<li>Visible peristalsis</li>
<li>Olive-like mass in the abdomen
C. Treatment is myotomy.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-d55474ba.jpeg" alt="img-115.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 10.9 Gastroschisis. (Courtesy of humpath. com)
Fig. 10.10 Omphalocele. (Courtesy of J.T. Stocker, MD)
Fig. 10.11 Intestinal metaplasia, chronic gastritis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-acute-gastritis">IV. ACUTE GASTRITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-acute-gastritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Acidic damage to the stomach mucosa
B. Due to imbalance between mucosal defenses and acidic environment</p>
<ol>
<li>Defenses include mucin layer produced by foveolar cells, bicarbonate secretion by surface epithelium, and normal blood supply (provides nutrients and picks up leaked acid).
C. Risk factors</li>
<li>Severe burn (Curling ulcer)—Hypovolemia leads to decreased blood supply.</li>
<li>NSAIDs (decreased <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">G</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{PGE}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PGE</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> )</li>
<li>Heavy alcohol consumption</li>
<li>Chemotherapy</li>
<li>Increased intracranial pressure (Cushing ulcer)—Increased stimulation of vagus nerve leads to increased acid production.</li>
<li>Shock—Multiple (stress) ulcers may be seen in ICU patients.
D. Acid damage results in superficial inflammation, erosion (loss of superficial epithelium), or ulcer (loss of mucosal layer).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-chronic-gastritis">V. CHRONIC GASTRITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-chronic-gastritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Chronic inflammation of stomach mucosa
B. Divided into two types based on underlying etiology: chronic autoimmune gastritis and chronic <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span></span></span></span></span> pylori gastritis
C. Chronic autoimmune gastritis is due to autoimmune destruction of gastric parietal cells, which are located in the stomach body and fundus.</p>
<ol>
<li>Associated with antibodies against parietal cells and/or intrinsic factor; useful for diagnosis, but pathogenesis is mediated by T cells (type IV hypersensitivity)</li>
<li>Clinical features
i. Atrophy of mucosa with intestinal metaplasia (Fig. 10.11)
ii. Achlorhydria with increased gastrin levels and antral G-cell hyperplasia
iii. Megaloblastic (pernicious) anemia due to lack of intrinsic factor
iv. Increased risk for gastric adenocarcinoma (intestinal type)
D.
