Chronic <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span></span></span></span></span> pylori gastritis is due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span></span></span></span></span> pylori-induced acute and chronic inflammation; most common form of gastritis ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> )</li>
<li>H pylori ureases and proteases along with inflammation weaken mucosal defenses; antrum is the most common site (Fig. 10.12).</li>
<li>Presents with epigastric abdominal pain; increased risk for ulceration (peptic ulcer disease), gastric adenocarcinoma (intestinal type), and MALT lymphoma</li>
<li>Treatment involves triple therapy.
i. Resolves gastritis/ulcer and reverses intestinal metaplasia
ii. Negative urea breath test and lack of stool antigen confirm eradication of H pylori.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-11667d2e.jpeg" alt="img-116.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 10.12 H pylori. (Courtesy of Ed Uthman, MD)
Fig. 10.13 Gastric ulcer. A, Peptic ulcer disease. B, Carcinoma. (Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vi-peptic-ulcer-disease">VI. PEPTIC ULCER DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-peptic-ulcer-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Solitary mucosal ulcer involving proximal duodenum ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> ) or distal stomach ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> )
B. Duodenal ulcer is almost always due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span></span></span></span></span> pylori ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>95</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;95 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">95%</span></span></span></span></span> ); rarely, may be due to ZE syndrome</p>
<ol>
<li>Presents with epigastric pain that improves with meals</li>
<li>Diagnostic endoscopic biopsy shows ulcer with hypertrophy of Brunner glands.</li>
<li>Usually arises in anterior duodenum; when present in posterior duodenum, rupture may lead to bleeding from the gastroduodenal artery or acute pancreatitis
C. Gastric ulcer is usually due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span></span></span></span></span> pylori ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>75</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">75 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">75%</span></span></span></span></span> ); other causes include NSAIDs and bile reflux.</li>
<li>Presents with epigastric pain that worsens with meals</li>
<li>Ulcer is usually located on the lesser curvature of the antrum.</li>
<li>Rupture carries risk of bleeding from left gastric artery.
D. Differential diagnosis of ulcers includes carcinoma.</li>
<li>Duodenal ulcers are almost never malignant (duodenal carcinoma is extremely rare).</li>
<li>Gastric ulcers can be caused by gastric carcinoma (intestinal subtype).
i. Benign peptic ulcers are usually small ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>3</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;3 \mathrm{~cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> ), sharply demarcated ("punched-out"), and surrounded by radiating folds of mucosa (Fig. 10.13A).
ii. Malignant ulcers are large and irregular with heaped up margins (Fig. 10.13B)
iii. Biopsy is required for definitive diagnosis.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-gastric-carcinoma">VII. GASTRIC CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-gastric-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of surface epithelial cells (adenocarcinoma)
B. Subclassified into intestinal and diffuse types
C. Intestinal type (more common) presents as a large, irregular ulcer with heaped up margins; most commonly involves the lesser curvature of the antrum (similar to gastric ulcer)</p>
<ol>
<li>Risk factors include intestinal metaplasia (e.g., due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span></span></span></span></span> pylori and autoimmune gastritis), nitrosamines in smoked foods (Japan), and blood type A.
D. Diffuse type is characterized by signet ring cells that diffusely infiltrate the gastric wall (Fig. 10.14B); desmoplasia results in thickening of stomach wall (linitis plastica, Fig. 10.14A).</li>
<li>Not associated with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span></span></span></span></span> pylori, intestinal metaplasia, or nitrosamines
E. Gastric carcinoma presents late with weight loss, abdominal pain, anemia, and early satiety; rarely presents as acanthosis nigricans or Leser-Trélat sign
F. Spread to lymph nodes can involve the left supraclavicular node (Virchow node).
G. Distant metastasis most commonly involves liver; other sites include</li>
<li>Periumbilical region (Sister Mary Joseph nodule); seen with intestinal type
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-9ddc6901.jpeg" alt="img-117.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 10.14 Gastric carcinoma, diffuse type. A, Linitis plastica. B, Signet-ring cells. (A, Courtesy of Ed Uthman, MD)</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Bilateral ovaries (Krukenberg tumor); seen with diffuse type</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="small-bowel">SMALL BOWEL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#small-bowel" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-duodenal-atresia">I. DUODENAL ATRESIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-duodenal-atresia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Congenital failure of duodenum to canalize; associated with Down syndrome
B. Clinical features</p>
<ol>
<li>Polyhydramnios</li>
<li>Distension of stomach and blind loop of duodenum ('double bubble' sign, Fig. 10.15)</li>
<li>Bilious vomiting</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-meckel-diverticulum">II. MECKEL DIVERTICULUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-meckel-diverticulum" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Outpouching of all three layers of the bowel wall (true diverticulum, Fig. 10.16)
B. Arises due to failure of the vitelline duct to involute
C. 'Rule of 2 s'</p>
<ol>
<li>Seen in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">2%</span></span></span></span></span> of the population (most common congenital anomaly of the GI tract)</li>
<li>2 inches long and located in the small bowel within 2 feet of the ileocecal valve</li>
<li>Can present during the first 2 years of life with bleeding (due to heterotopic gastric mucosa), volvulus, intussusception, or obstruction (mimics appendicitis); however, most cases are asymptomatic.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-volvulus">III. VOLVULUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-volvulus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Twisting of bowel along its mesentery
B. Results in obstruction and disruption of the blood supply with infarction (Fig. 10.17)
C. Most common locations are sigmoid colon (elderly) and cecum (young adults).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-intussusception">IV. INTUSSUSCEPTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-intussusception" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Telescoping of proximal segment of bowel forward into distal segment</p>
<ol>
<li>Telescoped segment is pulled forward by peristalsis, resulting in obstruction and disruption of blood supply with infarction.
B. Associated with a leading edge (focus of traction)</li>
<li>In children, the most common cause is lymphoid hyperplasia (e.g., due to rotavirus); usually arises in the terminal ileum, leading to intussusception into the cecum</li>
<li>In adults, the most common cause is tumor.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-small-bowel-infarction">V. SMALL BOWEL INFARCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-small-bowel-infarction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Small bowel is highly susceptible to ischemic injury.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-02fef12e.jpeg" alt="img-118.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 10.15 'Double bubble' sign, duodenal atresia. (Courtesy of Auckland District Health Board)</p>
<p>Fig. 10.16 Meckel diverticulum. (Courtesy of humpath.com)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1d518921.jpeg" alt="img-119.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 10.17 Infarction due to volvulus. (Courtesy of humpath.com)</p>
<ol>
<li>Transmural infarction occurs with thrombosis/embolism of the superior mesenteric artery or thrombosis of the mesenteric vein.</li>
<li>Mucosal infarction occurs with marked hypotension.
B. Clinical features include abdominal pain, bloody diarrhea, and decreased bowel sounds.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vi-lactose-intolerance">VI. LACTOSE INTOLERANCE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-lactose-intolerance" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Decreased function of the lactase enzyme found in the brush border of enterocytes 1. Lactase normally breaks down lactose into glucose and galactose.
B. Presents with abdominal distension and diarrhea upon consumption of milk products; undigested lactose is osmotically active.
C. Deficiency may be congenital (rare autosomal recessive disorder) or acquired (often develops in late childhood); temporary deficiency is seen after small bowel infection (lactase is highly susceptible to injury).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-celiac-disease">VII. CELIAC DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-celiac-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Immune-mediated damage of small bowel villi due to gluten exposure; associated with HLA-DQ2 and DQ8
B. Gluten is present in wheat and grains; its most pathogenic component is gliadin.</p>
<ol>
<li>Once absorbed, gliadin is deamidated by tissue transglutaminase (tTG).</li>
<li>Deamidated gliadin is presented by antigen presenting cells via MHC class II.</li>
<li>Helper T cells mediate tissue damage.
C. Clinical presentation</li>
<li>Children classically present with abdominal distension, diarrhea, and failure to thrive.</li>
<li>Adults classically present with chronic diarrhea and bloating.</li>
<li>Small, herpes-like vesicles may arise on skin (dermatitis herpetiformis). Due to IgA deposition at the tips of dermal papillae; resolves with gluten-free diet
D. Laboratory findings</li>
<li>IgA antibodies against endomysium, tTG, or gliadin; IgG antibodies are also present and are useful for diagnosis in individuals with IgA deficiency (increased incidence of IgA deficiency is seen in celiac disease).</li>
<li>Duodenal biopsy reveals flattening of villi, hyperplasia of crypts, and increased intraepithelial lymphocytes (Fig. 10.18). Damage is most prominent in the duodenum; jejunum and ileum are less involved.
E. Symptoms resolve with gluten-free diet.</li>
<li>Small bowel carcinoma and T-cell lymphoma are late complications that present as refractory disease despite good dietary control.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-81bc05fa.jpeg" alt="img-120.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 10.18 Celiac disease. A, Flattened villi. B, Normal villi for comparison.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="viii-tropical-sprue">VIII.TROPICAL SPRUE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-tropical-sprue" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Damage to small bowel villi due to an unknown organism resulting in malabsorption
B. Similar to celiac disease except</p>
<ol>
<li>Occurs in tropical regions (e.g., Caribbean)</li>
<li>Arises after infectious diarrhea and responds to antibiotics</li>
<li>Damage is most prominent in jejunum and ileum (secondary vitamin B12 or folate deficiency may ensue); duodenum is less commonly involved.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ix-whipple-disease">IX. WHIPPLE DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ix-whipple-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Systemic tissue damage characterized by macrophages loaded with Tropheryma whippelii organisms; partially destroyed organisms are present in macrophage lysosomes (positive for PAS).
B. Classic site of involvement is the small bowel lamina propria (Fig. 10.19).</p>
<ol>
<li>Macrophages compress lacteals.</li>
<li>Chylomicrons cannot be transferred from enterocytes to lymphatics.</li>
<li>Results in fat malabsorption and steatorrhea
C. Other common sites of involvement include synovium of joints (arthritis), cardiac valves, lymph nodes, and CNS.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="x-abetalipoproteinemia">X. ABETALIPOPROTEINEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#x-abetalipoproteinemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Autosomal recessive deficiency of apolipoprotein B-48 and B-100
B. Clinical features</p>
<ol>
<li>Malabsorption-due to defective chylomicron formation (requires B-48)</li>
<li>Absent plasma VLDL and LDL (require B-100)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="xi-carcinoid-tumor">XI. CARCINOID TUMOR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#xi-carcinoid-tumor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of neuroendocrine cells; low-grade malignancy</p>
<ol>
<li>Tumor cells contain neurosecretory granules that are positive for chromogranin.
B. Can arise anywhere along the gut; small bowel is the most common site.</li>
<li>Grows as a submucosal polyp-like nodule (Fig. 10.20)
C. Often secretes serotonin</li>
<li>Serotonin is released into the portal circulation and metabolized by liver monoamine oxidase (MAO) into 5-HIAA.</li>
<li>5-HIAA is excreted in the urine.
D. Metastasis of carcinoid tumor to the liver allows serotonin to bypass liver metabolism.</li>
<li>Serotonin is released into the hepatic vein and leaks into systemic circulation via hepato-systemic shunts, resulting in carcinoid syndrome and carcinoid heart disease.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-d70e0f6a.jpeg" alt="img-121.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 10.19 Whipple disease. A, Macrophages within lamina propria of small bowel villi. B, T whippelii organisms highlighted by PAS stain.
Fig. 10.20 Carcinoid tumor.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Carcinoid syndrome is characterized by bronchospasm, diarrhea, and flushing of skin; symptoms can be triggered by alcohol or emotional stress, which stimulate serotonin release from the tumor.</li>
<li>Carcinoid heart disease is characterized by right-sided valvular fibrosis (increased collagen) leading to tricuspid regurgitation and pulmonary valve stenosis; left-sided valvular lesions are not seen due to presence of monoamine oxidase (metabolizes serotonin) in the lung.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="appendix">APPENDIX<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#appendix" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I. ACUTE APPENDICITIS
A. Acute inflammation of the appendix; most common cause of acute abdomen
B. Related to obstruction of the appendix by lymphoid hyperplasia (children) or a fecalith (adults)
C. Clinical features include</p>
<ol>
<li>Periumbilical pain, fever, and nausea; pain eventually localizes to right lower quadrant (McBurney point).</li>
<li>Rupture results in peritonitis that presents with guarding and rebound tenderness.</li>
<li>Periappendiceal abscess is a common complication.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inflammatory-bowel-disease">INFLAMMATORY BOWEL DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inflammatory-bowel-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. BASIC PRINCIPLES
A. Chronic, relapsing inflammation of bowel
B. Possibly due to abnormal immune response to enteric flora
C. Classically presents in young women (teens to 30 s ) as recurrent bouts of bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain</p>
<ol>
<li>More prevalent in the West, particularly in Caucasians and Eastern European Jews
D. Diagnosis of exclusion; symptoms mimic other causes of bowel inflammation (e.g., infection).
E. Subclassified as ulcerative colitis or Crohn disease (Table 10.1)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="colon">COLON<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#colon" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. HIRSCHSPRUNG DISEASE
A. Defective relaxation and peristalsis of rectum and distal sigmoid colon</p>
<ol>
<li>Associated with Down syndrome
B. Due to congenital failure of ganglion cells (neural crest-derived) to descend into myenteric and submucosal plexus</li>
<li>Myenteric (Auerbach) plexus is located between the inner circular and outer longitudinal muscle layers of the muscularis propria and regulates motility.</li>
<li>Submucosal (Meissner) plexus is located in the submucosa and regulates blood flow, secretions, and absorption.
C. Clinical features are based on obstruction.</li>
<li>Failure to pass meconium</li>
<li>Empty rectal vault on digital rectal exam</li>
<li>Massive dilatation (megacolon) of bowel proximal to obstruction with risk for rupture
D. Rectal suction biopsy reveals lack of ganglion cells.
E. Treatment involves resection of the involved bowel; ganglion cells are present in the bowel proximal to the diseased segment.</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 10.1: Main Features of Ulcerative Colitis and Crohn Disease</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;"></th><th style="text-align: center;">ULCERATIVE COLITIS (UC)</th><th style="text-align: center;">CROHN DISEASE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Wall Involvement</td><td style="text-align: center;">Mucosal and submucosal ulcers</td><td style="text-align: center;">Full-thickness inflammation with knife-like fissures</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Location</td><td style="text-align: center;">Begins in rectum and can extend proximally up to the cecum (involvement is continuous, Fig. 10.21 A ); remainder of the GI tract is unaffected.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Anywhere from mouth to anus with skip lesions; terminal ileum is the most common site, rectum is least common.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Symptoms</td><td style="text-align: center;">Left lower quadrant pain (rectum) with bloody diarrhea</td><td style="text-align: center;">Right lower quadrant pain (ileum) with nonbloody diarrhea</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Inflammation</td><td style="text-align: center;">Crypt abscesses with neutrophils (Fig. 10.21B)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Lymphoid aggregates with granulomas ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">40%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Gross Appearance</td><td style="text-align: center;">Pseudopolyps; loss of haustra ('lead pipe' sign on imaging, Fig. 10.21C)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Cobblestone mucosa (Fig. 10.22A), creeping fat, and strictures ('string-sign' on imaging, Fig. 10.22B)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Complications</td><td style="text-align: center;">Toxic megacolon and carcinoma (risk is based on extent of colonic involvement and duration of disease; generally not a concern until <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;10</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span></span></span></span></span> years of disease)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Malabsorption with nutritional deficiency, calcium oxalate nephrolithiasis, fistula formation, and carcinoma, if colonic disease is present</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Extraintestinal Manifestations</td><td style="text-align: center;">Arthritis (peripheral joints, ankylosing spondylitis, sacroiliitis, migratory polyarthritis), uveitis, erythema nodosum (Fig. 10.22C), pyoderma gangrenosum, primary sclerosing cholangitis, and p-ANCA</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Smoking</td><td style="text-align: center;">Protects against UC</td><td style="text-align: center;">Increases risk for Crohn disease</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251213-cd1704f7.jpeg" alt="img-122.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 10.21 Ulcerative colitis. A, Gross appearance. B, Crypt abscess. C, 'Lead pipe' sign (A, Courtesy of Jamie Steinmetz, MD. C, Published with permission from LearningRadiology.com)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-39072b98.jpeg" alt="img-123.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 10.22 Crohn disease. A, Cobblestone mucosa with stricture. B, 'String' sign. (A, Courtesy of humpath.com. B, Published with permission from LearningRadiology.com)
Fig. 10.22C Erythema nodosum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-colonic-diverticula">II. COLONIC DIVERTICULA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-colonic-diverticula" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Outpouchings of mucosa and submucosa through the muscularis propria (Fig. 10.23, false diverticulum)
B. Related to wall stress</p>
<ol>
<li>Associated with constipation, straining, and low-fiber diet; commonly seen in older adults (risk increases with age)</li>
<li>Arise where the vasa recta traverse the muscularis propria (weak point in colonic wall); sigmoid colon is the most common location.
C. Usually asymptomatic; complications include</li>
<li>Rectal bleeding (hematochezia)</li>
<li>Diverticulitis—due to obstructing fecal material; presents with appendicitis-like symptoms in the left lower quadrant</li>
<li>Fistula-Inflamed diverticulum ruptures and attaches to a local structure. Colovesicular fistula presents with air (or stool) in urine.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-angiodysplasia">III. ANGIODYSPLASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-angiodysplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Acquired malformation of mucosal and submucosal capillary beds
B. Usually arises in the cecum and right colon due to high wall tension
C. Rupture classically presents as hematochezia in an older adult.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-hereditary-hemorrhagic-telangiectasia">IV. HEREDITARY HEMORRHAGIC TELANGIECTASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-hereditary-hemorrhagic-telangiectasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Autosomal dominant disorder resulting in thin-walled blood vessels, especially in the mouth and GI tract (Fig. 10.24)
B. Rupture presents as bleeding.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-ischemic-colitis">V. ISCHEMIC COLITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-ischemic-colitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Ischemic damage to the colon, usually at the splenic flexure (watershed area of superior mesenteric artery [SMA])
B. Atherosclerosis of SMA is the most common cause.
C. Presents with postprandial pain and weight loss; infarction results in pain and bloody diarrhea.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-irritable-bowel-syndrome">VI. IRRITABLE BOWEL SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-irritable-bowel-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Relapsing abdominal pain with bloating, flatulence, and change in bowel habits (diarrhea or constipation) that improves with defecation; classically seen in middleaged females
B. Related to disturbed intestinal motility; no identifiable pathologic changes
C. Increased dietary fiber may improve symptoms.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1476bc67.jpeg" alt="img-124.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 10.23 Colonic diverticula. A, Gross appearance. B, Microscopic appearance.</p>
<p>Fig. 10.24 Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. (Courtesy of Drs. H. Fred and H. van Dijk, Images of Memorable Cases)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vii-colonic-polyps">VII. COLONIC POLYPS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-colonic-polyps" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Raised protrusions of colonic mucosa
B. Most common types are hyperplastic and adenomatous polyps.</p>
<ol>
<li>Hyperplastic polyps are due to hyperplasia of glands; classically show a 'serrated' appearance on microscopy
i. Most common type of polyp; usually arise in the left colon (rectosigmoid)
ii. Benign, with no malignant potential</li>
<li>Adenomatous polyps are due to neoplastic proliferation of glands (Fig. 10.25); 2nd most common type of colonic polyp
i. Benign, but premalignant; may progress to adenocarcinoma via the adenoma-carcinoma sequence</li>
<li>Adenoma-carcinoma sequence describes the molecular progression from normal colonic mucosa to adenomatous polyp to carcinoma.
i. APC (adenomatous polyposis coli gene) mutations (sporadic or germline) increase risk for formation of polyp.
ii. K-ras mutation leads to formation of polyp.
iii. p53 mutation and increased expression of COX allow for progression to carcinoma; aspirin impedes progression from adenoma to carcinoma.
C. Screening for polyps is performed by colonoscopy and testing for fecal occult blood; polyps are usually clinically silent, but can bleed.</li>
<li>Goal is to remove adenomatous polyps before progression to carcinoma.
D. On colonoscopy, hyperplastic and adenomatous polyps look identical. Hence, all polyps are removed and examined microscopically.</li>
<li>Greatest risk for progression from adenoma to carcinoma is related to size <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span> cm , sessile growth, and villous histology.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-familial-adenomatous-polyposis-fap">VIII.FAMILIAL ADENOMATOUS POLYPOSIS (FAP)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-familial-adenomatous-polyposis-fap" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Autosomal dominant disorder characterized by 100 s to 1000 s of adenomatous colonic polyps (Fig. 10.26)
B. Due to inherited APC mutation (chromosome 5); increases propensity to develop adenomatous polyps throughout colon and rectum
C. Colon and rectum are removed prophylactically; otherwise, almost all patients develop carcinoma by 40 years of age.
D. Gardner syndrome is FAP with fibromatosis and osteomas.</p>
<ol>
<li>Fibromatosis is a non-neoplastic proliferation of fibroblasts; arises in retroperitoneum (desmoid) and locally destroys tissue</li>
<li>Osteoma is a benign tumor of bone that usually arises in the skull.
E. Turcot syndrome is FAP with CNS tumors (medulloblastoma and glial tumors).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-3a2fde58.jpeg" alt="img-125.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 10.25 Adenomatous polyp.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-7d2c7bee.jpeg" alt="img-126.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 10.26 Familial adenomatous polyposis. (Courtesy of humpath.com)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ix-juvenile-polyp">IX. JUVENILE POLYP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ix-juvenile-polyp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Sporadic, hamartomatous (benign) polyp that arises in children ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>5</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;5</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span></span></span></span></span> years)</p>
<ol>
<li>Usually presents as a solitary rectal polyp that prolapses and bleeds
B. Juvenile polyposis is characterized by multiple juvenile polyps in the stomach and colon; large numbers of juvenile polyps increase the risk of progression to carcinoma.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="x-peutz-jeghers-syndrome">X. PEUTZ-JEGHERS SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#x-peutz-jeghers-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Hamartomatous (benign) polyps throughout GI tract and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation (freckle-like spots) on lips, oral mucosa, and genital skin; autosomal dominant disorder
B. Increased risk for colorectal, breast, and gynecologic cancer</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="xi-colorectal-carcinoma">XI. COLORECTAL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#xi-colorectal-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Carcinoma arising from colonic or rectal mucosa; 3rd most common site of cancer and 3rd most common cause of cancer-related death</p>
<ol>
<li>Peak incidence is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>60</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>70</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">60-70</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span></span></span></span></span> years of age.
B. Most commonly arises from adenoma-carcinoma sequence; a second important molecular pathway is microsatellite instability (MSI).</li>
<li>Microsatellites are repeating sequences of noncoding DNA; integrity of sequence (stability) is maintained during cell division.</li>
<li>Instability indicates defective DNA copy mechanisms (e.g., DNA mismatch repair enzymes).</li>
<li>Hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal carcinoma (HNPCC) is due to inherited mutations in DNA mismatch repair enzymes.
i. Increased risk for colorectal, ovarian, and endometrial carcinoma
ii. Colorectal carcinoma arises de novo (not from adenomatous polyps) at a relatively early age; usually right-sided
C. Screening for colorectal carcinoma occurs via colonoscopy and fecal occult blood testing; begins at 50 years of age</li>
<li>Goal is to remove adenomatous polyps before carcinoma develops and to detect cancer early (before clinical symptoms arise).
D. Carcinoma can develop anywhere along entire length of colon.</li>
<li>Left-sided carcinoma usually grows as a 'napkin-ring' lesion; presents with decreased stool caliber, left lower quadrant pain, and blood-streaked stool</li>
<li>Right-sided carcinoma usually grows as a raised lesion; presents with irondeficiency anemia (occult bleeding) and vague pain. An older adult with iron deficiency anemia has colorectal carcinoma until proven otherwise.
E. Colonic carcinoma is associated with an increased risk for Streptococcus bovis endocarditis.
F. Staging</li>
<li>T-depth of invasion; tumors limited to the mucosa generally do not spread due to lack of lymphatics in the mucosa.</li>
<li>N-spread to regional lymph nodes</li>
<li>M-distant spread; most commonly involves the liver
G. CEA is a serum tumor marker that is useful for assessing treatment response and detecting recurrence; not useful for screening</li>
</ol>
<p>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="exocrine-pancreas-gallbladder-and-liver-pathology">Exocrine Pancreas, Gallbladder, and Liver Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exocrine-pancreas-gallbladder-and-liver-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="exocrine-pancreas">EXOCRINE PANCREAS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#exocrine-pancreas" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. ANNULAR PANCREAS
A. Developmental malformation in which the pancreas forms a ring around the duodenum; risk of duodenal obstruction</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-acute-pancreatitis">II. ACUTE PANCREATITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-acute-pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inflammation and hemorrhage of the pancreas
B. Due to autodigestion of pancreatic parenchyma by pancreatic enzymes</p>
<ol>
<li>Premature activation of trypsin leads to activation of other pancreatic enzymes.
C. Results in liquefactive hemorrhagic necrosis of the pancreas and fat necrosis of the peripancreatic fat (Fig. 11.1)
D. Most commonly due to alcohol and gallstones; other causes include trauma, hypercalcemia, hyperlipidemia, drugs, scorpion stings, mumps, and rupture of a posterior duodenal ulcer.
E. Clinical features</li>
<li>Epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back</li>
<li>Nausea and vomiting</li>
<li>Periumbilical and flank hemorrhage (necrosis spreads into the periumbilical soft tissue and retroperitoneum)</li>
<li>Elevated serum lipase and amylase; lipase is more specific for pancreatic damage.</li>
<li>Hypocalcemia (calcium is consumed during saponification in fat necrosis)
F. Complications</li>
<li>Shock-due to peripancreatic hemorrhage and fluid sequestration</li>
<li>Pancreatic pseudocyst-formed by fibrous tissue surrounding liquefactive necrosis and pancreatic enzymes
i. Presents as an abdominal mass with persistently elevated serum amylase
ii. Rupture is associated with release of enzymes into the abdominal cavity and hemorrhage.</li>
<li>Pancreatic abscess-often due to E coli; presents with abdominal pain, high fever, and persistently elevated amylase</li>
<li>DIC and ARDS</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-chronic-pancreatitis">III. CHRONIC PANCREATITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-chronic-pancreatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Fibrosis of pancreatic parenchyma, most often secondary to recurrent acute pancreatitis</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>Most commonly due to alcohol (adults) and cystic fibrosis (children); however, many cases are idiopathic.
B. Clinical features</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Epigastric abdominal pain that radiates to the back</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Pancreatic insufficiency-results in malabsorption with steatorrhea and fatsoluble vitamin deficiencies. Amylase and lipase are not useful serologic markers of chronic pancreatitis.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Dystrophic calcification of pancreatic parenchyma on imaging; contrast studies reveal a 'chain of lakes' pattern due to dilatation of pancreatic ducts.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Secondary diabetes mellitus-late complication due to destruction of islets</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased risk for pancreatic carcinoma</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-pancreatic-carcinoma">IV. PANCREATIC CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-pancreatic-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Adenocarcinoma arising from the pancreatic ducts</p>
<ol>
<li>Most commonly seen in the elderly (average age is 70 years)
B. Major risk factors are smoking and chronic pancreatitis.
C. Clinical features (usually occur late in disease)</li>
<li>Epigastric abdominal pain and weight loss</li>
<li>Obstructive jaundice with pale stools and palpable gallbladder; associated with tumors that arise in the head of the pancreas (most common location)</li>
<li>Secondary diabetes mellitus; associated with tumors that arise in the body or tail</li>
<li>Pancreatitis</li>
<li>Migratory thrombophlebitis (Trousseau syndrome); presents as swelling, erythema, and tenderness in the extremities (seen in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of patients)</li>
<li>Serum tumor marker is CA 19-9.
D. Surgical resection involves en bloc removal of the head and neck of pancreas, proximal duodenum, and gallbladder (Whipple procedure).
E. Very poor prognosis; 1-year survival is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gallbladder-and-biliary-tract">GALLBLADDER AND BILIARY TRACT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gallbladder-and-biliary-tract" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-biliary-atresia">I. BILIARY ATRESIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-biliary-atresia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Failure to form or early destruction of extrahepatic biliary tree
B. Leads to biliary obstruction within the first 2 months of life
C. Presents with jaundice and progresses to cirrhosis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-cholelithiasis-gallstones">II. CHOLELITHIASIS (GALLSTONES)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-cholelithiasis-gallstones" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Solid, round stones in the gallbladder
B. Due to precipitation of cholesterol (cholesterol stones) or bilirubin (bilirubin stones) in bile</p>
<ol>
<li>Arises with (1) supersaturation of cholesterol or bilirubin, (2) decreased phospholipids (e.g., lecithin) or bile acids (normally increase solubility), or (3) stasis
C. Cholesterol stones (yellow) are the most common type ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> ), especially in the West (Fig. 11.2A).</li>
<li>Usually radiolucent ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> are radiopaque due to associated calcium)</li>
<li>Risk factors include age (40s), estrogen (female gender, obesity, multiple pregnancies and oral contraceptives), clofibrate, Native American ethnicity, Crohn disease, and cirrhosis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-0901e1b0.jpeg" alt="img-127.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 11.1 Acute pancreatitis. (Courtesy of humpath.com)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-590410aa.jpeg" alt="img-128.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 11.2 Gallstones. A, Cholesterol stones. B, Bilirubin stones. (A, Courtesy of K.V. Santosh, MD. B, Courtesy of humpath.com)</p>
<p>D. Bilirubin stones (pigmented) are composed of bilirubin (Fig. 11.2B).</p>
<ol>
<li>Usually radiopaque</li>
<li>Risk factors include extravascular hemolysis (increased bilirubin in bile) and biliary tract infection (e.g., E coli, Ascaris lumbricoides, and Clonorchis sinensis).
i. Ascaris lumbricoides is a common roundworm that infects <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">25%</span></span></span></span></span> of the world's population, especially in areas with poor sanitation (fecal-oral transmission); infects the biliary tract, increasing the risk for gallstones
ii. Clonorchis sinensis is endemic in China, Korea, and Vietnam (Chinese liver fluke); infects the biliary tract, increasing the risk for gallstones, cholangitis, and cholangiocarcinoma
E. Gallstones are usually asymptomatic; complications include biliary colic, acute and chronic cholecystitis, ascending cholangitis, gallstone ileus, and gallbladder cancer.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-biliary-colic">III. BILIARY COLIC<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-biliary-colic" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Waxing and waning right upper quadrant pain
B. Due to the gallbladder contracting against a stone lodged in the cystic duct
C. Symptoms are relieved if the stone passes.
D. Common bile duct obstruction may result in acute pancreatitis or obstructive jaundice.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-acute-cholecystitis">IV. ACUTE CHOLECYSTITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-acute-cholecystitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Acute inflammation of the gallbladder wall
B. Impacted stone in the cystic duct results in dilatation with pressure ischemia, bacterial overgrowth (E coli), and inflammation.
C. Presents with right upper quadrant pain, often radiating to right scapula, fever with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> WBC count, nausea, vomiting, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> serum alkaline phosphatase (from duct damage)
D. Risk of rupture if left untreated</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-chronic-cholecystitis">V. CHRONIC CHOLECYSTITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-chronic-cholecystitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Chronic inflammation of the gallbladder
B. Due to chemical irritation from longstanding cholelithiasis, with or without superimposed bouts of acute cholecystitis
C. Characterized by herniation of gallbladder mucosa into the muscular wall (Rokitansky-Aschoff sinus, Fig. 11.3A)
D. Presents with vague right upper quadrant pain, especially after eating
E. Porcelain gallbladder is a late complication (Fig. 11.3B).</p>
<ol>
<li>Shrunken, hard gallbladder due to chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and dystrophic calcification
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-85d8cca1.jpeg" alt="img-129.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 11.3 Chronic cholecystitis. A, Rokitansky-Aschoff sinus. B, Porcelain gallbladder. (B, Courtesy of Drs. H. Fred and H. van Dijk, Images of Memorable Cases)</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Increased risk for carcinoma
F. Treatment is cholecystectomy, especially if porcelain gallbladder is present.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vi-ascending-cholangitis">VI. ASCENDING CHOLANGITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-ascending-cholangitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Bacterial infection of the bile ducts
B. Usually due to ascending infection with enteric gram-negative bacteria
C. Presents as sepsis (high fever and chills), jaundice, and abdominal pain
D. Increased incidence with choledocholithiasis (stone in biliary ducts)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-gallstone-ileus">VII. GALLSTONE ILEUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-gallstone-ileus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Gallstone enters and obstructs the small bowel
B. Due to cholecystitis with fistula formation between the gallbladder and small bowel</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-gallbladder-carcinoma">VIII. GALLBLADDER CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-gallbladder-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Adenocarcinoma arising from the glandular epithelium that lines the gallbladder wall (Fig. 11.4)
B. Gallstones are a major risk factor, especially when complicated by porcelain gallbladder.
C. Classically presents as cholecystitis in an elderly woman
D. Poor prognosis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="liver">LIVER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#liver" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-jaundice">I. JAUNDICE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-jaundice" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Yellow discoloration of the skin (Fig. 11.5); earliest sign is scleral icterus (yellow discoloration of the sclera).
B. Due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> serum bilirubin, usually <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">d</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;2.5 \mathrm{mg} / \mathrm{dL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">mg</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">dL</span></span></span></span></span></span>
C. Arises with disturbances in bilirubin metabolism (Table 11.1)
D. Normal bilirubin metabolism</p>
<ol>
<li>RBCs are consumed by macrophages of the reticuloendothelial system.</li>
<li>Protoporphyrin (from heme) is converted to unconjugated bilirubin (UCB).</li>
<li>Albumin carries UCB to the liver.</li>
<li>Uridine glucuronyl transferase (UGT) in hepatocytes conjugates bilirubin.</li>
<li>Conjugated bilirubin (CB) is transferred to bile canaliculi to form bile, which is stored in the gallbladder.</li>
<li>Bile is released into the small bowel to aid in digestion.</li>
<li>Intestinal flora convert CB to urobilinogen, which is oxidized to stercobilin (makes stool brown) and urobilin (partially reabsorbed into blood and filtered by kidney, making urine yellow).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-fbb06ef3.jpeg" alt="img-130.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 11.4 Gallbladder carcinoma. (Courtesy of K.V. Fig. 11.5 Jaundice. (Courtesy of James Heilman, MD, Wikipedia)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-f18b0c52.jpeg" alt="img-131.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 11.6 Acute hepatitis.</p>
<p>Table 11.1: Causes of Jaundice</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">DISEASE</th><th style="text-align: center;">ETIOLOGY</th><th style="text-align: center;">LABORATORY FINDINGS</th><th style="text-align: center;">CLINICAL FEATURES</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Extravascular hemolysis or Ineffective erythropoiesis</td><td style="text-align: center;">High levels of UCB overwhelm the conjugating ability of the liver.</td><td style="text-align: center;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> UCB</td><td style="text-align: center;">Dark urine due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> urine urobilinogen (UCB is not water soluble and, thus, is absent from urine) &lt;br&gt; Increased risk for pigmented bilirubin gallstones</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Physiologic jaundice of the newborn</td><td style="text-align: center;">Newborn liver has transiently low UGT activity.</td><td style="text-align: center;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> UCB</td><td style="text-align: center;">UCB is fat soluble and can deposit in the basal ganglia (kernicterus) leading to neurological deficits and death. &lt;br&gt; Treatment is phototherapy (makes UCB water soluble).</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Gilbert syndrome</td><td style="text-align: center;">Mildly low UGT activity; autosomal recessive</td><td style="text-align: center;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> UCB</td><td style="text-align: center;">Jaundice during stress (e.g., severe infection); otherwise, not clinically significant</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Crigler-Najjar syndrome</td><td style="text-align: center;">Absence of UGT</td><td style="text-align: center;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> UCB</td><td style="text-align: center;">Kernicterus; usually fatal</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Dubin-Johnson syndrome</td><td style="text-align: center;">Deficiency of bilirubin canalicular transport protein; autosomal recessive</td><td style="text-align: center;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em;
