vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> CB</td><td style="text-align: center;">Liver is dark; otherwise, not clinically significant &lt;br&gt; Rotor syndrome is similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome, but lacks liver discoloration.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Biliary tract obstruction (obstructive jaundice)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Associated with gallstones, pancreatic carcinoma, cholangiocarcinoma, parasites, and liver fluke (Clonorchis sinensis)</td><td style="text-align: center;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow><mo separator="true">,</mo><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \mathrm{CB}, \downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CB</span></span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> urine urobilinogen, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> alkaline phosphatase</td><td style="text-align: center;">Dark urine (due to bilirubinuria) and pale stool Pruritus due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> plasma bile acids Hypercholesterolemia with xanthomas Steatorrhea with malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Viral hepatitis</td><td style="text-align: center;">Inflammation disrupts hepatocytes and small bile ductules.</td><td style="text-align: center;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> in both CB and UCB</td><td style="text-align: center;">Dark urine due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> urine bilirubin; urine urobilinogen is normal or decreased.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Table 11.2: Important Features of Hepatitis Viruses</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">VIRUS</th><th style="text-align: center;">TRANSMISSION</th><th style="text-align: center;">COMMENTS</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Hepatitis A (HAV) and Hepatitis E (HEV)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Fecal-oral transmission &lt;br&gt; HAV is commonly acquired by travelers. &lt;br&gt; HEV is commonly acquired from contaminated water or undercooked seafood.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Acute hepatitis; no chronic state. &lt;br&gt; Anti-virus IgM marks active infection. Antivirus IgG is protective, and its presence indicates prior infection or immunization (immunization is available for HAV). &lt;br&gt; HEV infection in pregnant women is associated with fulminant hepatitis (liver failure with massive liver necrosis).</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Hepatitis B (HBV)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Parenteral transmission (e.g., childbirth, unprotected intercourse, intravenous drug abuse [IVDA], and needle stick)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Results in acute hepatitis; chronic disease occurs in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">20 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">20%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases (Table 11.3).</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Hepatitis C (HCV)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Parenteral transmission (e.g., IVDA, unprotected intercourse); risk from transfusion is almost nonexistent due to screening of the blood supply.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Results in acute hepatitis; chronic disease occurs in most cases. &lt;br&gt; HCV-RNA test confirms infection; decreased RNA levels indicate recovery; persistence indicates chronic disease.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Hepatitis D (HDV)</td><td style="text-align: center;"></td><td style="text-align: center;">Dependent on HBV for infection; superinfection upon existing HBV is more severe than coinfection (infection with HBV and HDV at the same time)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Table 11.3: Serologic Markers of Hepatitis B Virus</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">STAGE</th><th style="text-align: left;">HBsAG</th><th style="text-align: left;">HBeAG AND HBV &lt;br&gt; DNA</th><th style="text-align: left;">HBcAB</th><th style="text-align: left;">HBsAB</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Acute</td><td style="text-align: left;">+ (first serologic &lt;br&gt; marker to rise)</td><td style="text-align: left;">+</td><td style="text-align: left;">IgM</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Window</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td><td style="text-align: left;">IgM</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Resolved</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td><td style="text-align: left;">IgG</td><td style="text-align: left;">IgG (protective)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Chronic</td><td style="text-align: left;">+ (presence <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;6</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span></span></span></span></span> &lt;br&gt; months defines &lt;br&gt; chronic state)</td><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mo>−</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">+/-</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">+</span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord">−</span></span></span></span></span>; presence of &lt;br&gt; HBeAg or HBV DNA &lt;br&gt; indicates infectivity.</td><td style="text-align: left;">IgG</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Immunization</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td><td style="text-align: left;">-</td><td style="text-align: left;">IgG (protective)</td></tr></tbody></table>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-viral-hepatitis">II. VIRAL HEPATITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-viral-hepatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Inflammation of liver parenchyma, usually due to hepatitis virus (Table 11.2); other causes include EBV and CMV.
B. Hepatitis virus causes acute hepatitis, which may progress to chronic hepatitis.
C. Acute hepatitis presents as jaundice (mixed CB and UCB) with dark urine (due to CB), fever, malaise, nausea, and elevated liver enzymes (ALT &gt; AST).</p>
<ol>
<li>Inflammation involves lobules of the liver and portal tracts and is characterized by apoptosis of hepatocytes (Fig. 11.6).</li>
<li>Some cases may be asymptomatic with elevated liver enzymes.</li>
<li>Symptoms last <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;6</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span></span></span></span></span> months.
D. Chronic hepatitis is characterized by symptoms that last <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>6</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;6</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span></span></span></span></span> months.</li>
<li>Inflammation predominantly involves portal tract (Fig. 11.7)</li>
<li>Risk of progression to cirrhosis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-cirrhosis">III. CIRRHOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-cirrhosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. End-stage liver damage characterized by disruption of the normal hepatic parenchyma by bands of fibrosis and regenerative nodules of hepatocytes (Fig. 11.8)
B. Fibrosis is mediated by TGF- <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> from stellate cells which lie beneath the endothelial cells that line the sinusoids.
C. Clinical features</p>
<ol>
<li>Portal hypertension leads to
i. Ascites (fluid in the peritoneal cavity)
ii. Congestive splenomegaly/hypersplenism
iii. Portosystemic shunts (esophageal varices, hemorrhoids, and caput medusae)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-51cf3f05.jpeg" alt="img-132.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 11.7 Chronic hepatitis.
Fig. 11.8 Cirrhosis. A, Microscopic appearance. B, Gross appearance. (B, Courtesy of humpath.com)</p>
<p>iv. Hepatorenal syndrome (rapidly developing renal failure secondary to cirrhosis)
2. Decreased detoxification results in
i. Mental status changes, asterixis, and eventual coma (due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> serum ammonia); metabolic, hence reversible
ii. Gynecomastia, spider angiomata, and palmar erythema due to hyperestrinism iii. Jaundice
3. Decreased protein synthesis leads to
i. Hypoalbuminemia with edema
ii. Coagulopathy due to decreased synthesis of clotting factors; degree of deficiency is followed by PT.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-alcohol-related-liver-disease">IV. ALCOHOL-RELATED LIVER DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-alcohol-related-liver-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Damage to hepatic parenchyma due to consumption of alcohol</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common cause of liver disease in the West
B. Fatty liver is the accumulation of fat in hepatocytes (Fig. 11.9A).</li>
<li>Results in a heavy, greasy liver; resolves with abstinence (Fig. 11.9B)
C. Alcoholic hepatitis results from chemical injury to hepatocytes; generally seen with binge drinking</li>
<li>Acetaldehyde (metabolite of alcohol) mediates damage.</li>
<li>Characterized by swelling of hepatocytes with formation of Mallory bodies (damaged cytokeratin filaments, Fig. 11.10), necrosis, and acute inflammation</li>
<li>Presents with painful hepatomegaly and elevated liver enzymes (AST &gt; ALT); may result in death
D. Cirrhosis is a complication of long-term, chronic alcohol-induced liver damage; occurs in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>20</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10-20 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">20%</span></span></span></span></span> of alcoholics</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-nonalcoholic-fatty-liver-disease">V. NONALCOHOLIC FATTY LIVER DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-nonalcoholic-fatty-liver-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Fatty change, hepatitis, and/or cirrhosis that develop without exposure to alcohol (or other known insult)
B. Associated with obesity
C. Diagnosis of exclusion; ALT &gt; AST</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-hemochromatosis">VI. HEMOCHROMATOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-hemochromatosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Excess body iron leading to deposition in tissues (hemosiderosis) and organ damage (hemochromatosis)</p>
<ol>
<li>Tissue damage is mediated by generation of free radicals.
B. Due to autosomal recessive defect in iron absorption (primary) or chronic transfusions (secondary)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-b7d1370e.jpeg" alt="img-133.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 11.9 Fatty liver. A, Microscopic appearance. B, Gross appearance. (B, Courtesy of Jerome Taxy, MD)
Fig. 11.10 Mallory bodies, alcoholic hepatitis.</p>
<ol>
<li>Primary hemochromatosis is due to mutations in the HFE gene, usually C282Y (cysteine is replaced by tyrosine at amino acid 282).
C. Presents in late adulthood</li>
<li>Classic triad is cirrhosis, secondary diabetes mellitus, and bronze skin; other findings include dilated cardiomyopathy, cardiac arrhythmias and gonadal dysfunction (due to testicular atrophy).</li>
<li>Labs show <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> ferritin, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> TIBC, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> serum iron, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">%</span></span></span></span></span> saturation.</li>
<li>Liver biopsy reveals accumulation of brown pigment in hepatocytes (Fig. 11.11A); Prussian blue stain distinguishes iron (blue) from lipofuscin (Fig. 11.11B).
i. Lipofuscin is a brown pigment that is a by-product from the turnover ('wear and tear') of peroxidized lipids; it is commonly present in hepatocytes (Fig. 11.11C).
D. Increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma
E. Treatment is phlebotomy.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vii-wilson-disease">VII. WILSON DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-wilson-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Autosomal recessive defect (ATP7B gene) in ATP-mediated hepatocyte copper transport</p>
<ol>
<li>Results in lack of copper transport into bile and lack of copper incorporation into ceruloplasmin
B. Copper builds up in hepatocytes, leaks into serum, and deposits in tissues.</li>
<li>Copper-mediated production of hydroxyl free radicals leads to tissue damage.
C. Presents in childhood with</li>
<li>Cirrhosis</li>
<li>Neurologic manifestations (behavioral changes, dementia, chorea, and Parkinsonian symptoms due to deposition of copper in basal ganglia)</li>
<li>Kayser-Fleisher rings in the cornea
D. Labs show <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> urinary copper, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> serum ceruloplasmin, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> copper on liver biopsy.
E. Increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma
F. Treatment is D-penicillamine (chelates copper).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-primary-biliary-cirrhosis">VIII.PRIMARY BILIARY CIRRHOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-primary-biliary-cirrhosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Autoimmune granulomatous destruction of intrahepatic bile ducts</p>
<ol>
<li>Classically arises in women (average age is 40 years)</li>
<li>Associated with other autoimmune diseases
B. Etiology is unknown; antimitochondrial antibody is present.
C. Presents with features of obstructive jaundice
D. Cirrhosis is a late complication.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ix-primary-sclerosing-cholangitis">IX. PRIMARY SCLEROSING CHOLANGITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ix-primary-sclerosing-cholangitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inflammation and fibrosis of intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-88a5af3f.jpeg" alt="img-134.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 11.11 Hemochromatosis. A, Iron deposition in hepatocytes. B, Prussian blue stain. C, Lipofuscin in hepatocytes for comparison.</p>
<ol>
<li>Periductal fibrosis with an 'onion-skin' appearance (Fig. 11.12)</li>
<li>Uninvolved regions are dilated resulting in a "beaded" appearance on contrast imaging.
B. Etiology is unknown, but associated with ulcerative colitis; p-ANCA is often positive.
C. Presents with obstructive jaundice; cirrhosis is a late complication.
D. Increased risk for cholangiocarcinoma</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="x-reye-syndrome">X. REYE SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#x-reye-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Fulminant liver failure and encephalopathy in children with viral illness who take aspirin</p>
<ol>
<li>Likely related to mitochondrial damage of hepatocytes
B. Presents with hypoglycemia, elevated liver enzymes, and nausea with vomiting; may progress to coma and death</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="xi-hepatic-adenoma">XI. HEPATIC ADENOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#xi-hepatic-adenoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign tumor of hepatocytes
B. Associated with oral contraceptive use; regresses upon cessation of drug
C. Risk of rupture and intraperitoneal bleeding, especially during pregnancy</p>
<ol>
<li>Tumors are subcapsular and grow with exposure to estrogen.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="xii-hepatocellular-carcinoma">XII. HEPATOCELLULAR CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#xii-hepatocellular-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant tumor of hepatocytes
B. Risk factors include</p>
<ol>
<li>Chronic hepatitis (e.g., HBV and HCV)</li>
<li>Cirrhosis (e.g., alcohol, nonalcoholic fatty liver disease, hemochromatosis, Wilson disease, and A1AT deficiency)</li>
<li>Aflatoxins derived from Aspergillus (induce p53 mutations)
C. Increased risk for Budd-Chiari syndrome</li>
<li>Liver infarction secondary to hepatic vein obstruction</li>
<li>Presents with painful hepatomegaly and ascites
D. Tumors are often detected late because symptoms are masked by cirrhosis; poor prognosis
E. Serum tumor marker is alpha-fetoprotein.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="xiii-metastasis-to-liver">XIII.METASTASIS TO LIVER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#xiii-metastasis-to-liver" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. More common than primary liver tumors; most common sources include colon, pancreas, lung, and breast carcinomas.
B. Results in multiple nodules in the liver (Fig. 11.13)
C. Clinically may be detected as hepatomegaly with a nodular free edge of the liver
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-8d1dc746.jpeg" alt="img-135.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 11.12 'Onion-skin' fibrosis, primary sclerosing cholangitis.
Fig. 11.13 Metastatic carcinoma involving liver. (Courtesy of Jerome Taxy, MD)</p>
<p>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="kidney-and-urinary-tract-pathology">Kidney and Urinary Tract Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#kidney-and-urinary-tract-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="congenital">CONGENITAL<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#congenital" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-horseshoe-kidney">I. HORSESHOE KIDNEY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-horseshoe-kidney" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Conjoined kidneys usually connected at the lower pole (Fig. 12.1); most common congenital renal anomaly
B. Kidney is abnormally located in the lower abdomen; horseshoe kidney gets caught on the inferior mesenteric artery root during its ascent from the pelvis to the abdomen.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-renal-agenesis">II. RENAL AGENESIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-renal-agenesis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Absent kidney formation; may be unilateral or bilateral
B. Unilateral agenesis leads to hypertrophy of the existing kidney; hyperfiltration increases risk of renal failure later in life.
C. Bilateral agenesis leads to oligohydramnios with lung hypoplasia, flat face with low set ears, and developmental defects of the extremities (Potter sequence, Fig. 12.2); incompatible with life</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-dysplastic-kidney">III. DYSPLASTIC KIDNEY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-dysplastic-kidney" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Noninherited, congenital malformation of the renal parenchyma characterized by cysts and abnormal tissue (e.g., cartilage, Fig. 12.3)
B. Usually unilateral; when bilateral, must be distinguished from inherited polycystic kidney disease</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-polycystic-kidney-disease-pkd">IV. POLYCYSTIC KIDNEY DISEASE (PKD)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-polycystic-kidney-disease-pkd" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inherited defect leading to bilateral enlarged kidneys with cysts in the renal cortex and medulla (Fig. 12.4)
B. Autosomal recessive form presents in infants as worsening renal failure and hypertension; newborns may present with Potter sequence.</p>
<ol>
<li>Associated with congenital hepatic fibrosis (leads to portal hypertension) and hepatic cysts
C. Autosomal dominant form presents in young adults as hypertension (due to increased renin), hematuria, and worsening renal failure.</li>
<li>Due to mutation in the APKD1 or APKD2 gene; cysts develop over time.</li>
<li>Associated with berry aneurysm, hepatic cysts, and mitral valve prolapse</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-medullary-cystic-kidney-disease">V. MEDULLARY CYSTIC KIDNEY DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-medullary-cystic-kidney-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inherited (autosomal dominant) defect leading to cysts in the medullary collecting ducts
B. Parenchymal fibrosis results in shrunken kidneys and worsening renal failure.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="acute-renal-failure-arf">ACUTE RENAL FAILURE (ARF)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#acute-renal-failure-arf" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. BASIC PRINCIPLES
A. Acute, severe decrease in renal function (develops within days)
B. Hallmark is azotemia (increased BUN and creatinine [Cr]), often with oliguria.</p>
<p>C. Divided into prerenal, postrenal, and intrarenal azotemia based on etiology</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-prerenal-azotemia">II. PRERENAL AZOTEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-prerenal-azotemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Due to decreased blood flow to kidneys (e.g., cardiac failure); common cause of ARF
B. Decreased blood flow results in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> GFR, azotemia, and oliguria.
C. Reabsorption of fluid and BUN ensues (serum BUN:Cr ratio &gt; 15); tubular function remains intact (fractional excretion of sodium [FENa] <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;1 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span></span></span></span></span> and urine osmolality <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">o</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>500</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">[\mathrm{osm}]&gt;500 \mathrm{mOsm} / \mathrm{kg})</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">[</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">osm</span></span><span class="mclose">]</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mOsm</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kg</span></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-postrenal-azotemia">III. POSTRENAL AZOTEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-postrenal-azotemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Due to obstruction of urinary tract downstream from the kidney (e.g., ureters)
B. Decreased outflow results in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> GFR, azotemia, and oliguria.
C. During early stage of obstruction, increased tubular pressure "forces" BUN into the blood (serum BUN:Cr ratio &gt; 15); tubular function remains intact ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{FENa}&lt;1 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7224em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">FENa</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span></span></span></span></span> and urine osm <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>500</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;500 \mathrm{mOsm} / \mathrm{kg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mOsm</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kg</span></span></span></span></span></span> ).
D. With long-standing obstruction, tubular damage ensues, resulting in decreased reabsorption of BUN (serum BUN:Cr ratio &lt; 15), decreased reabsorption of sodium ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{FENa}&gt;2 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7224em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">FENa</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">2%</span></span></span></span></span> ), and inability to concentrate urine (urine osm <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>500</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;500 \mathrm{mOsm} / \mathrm{kg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mOsm</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kg</span></span></span></span></span></span> ).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-acute-tubular-necrosis">IV. ACUTE TUBULAR NECROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-acute-tubular-necrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Injury and necrosis of tubular epithelial cells (Fig. 12.5); most common cause of acute renal failure (intrarenal azotemia)
B. Necrotic cells plug tubules; obstruction decreases GFR.</p>
<ol>
<li>Brown, granular casts are seen in the urine.
C. Dysfunctional tubular epithelium results in decreased reabsorption of BUN (serum BUN:Cr ratio &lt; 15), decreased reabsorption of sodium ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">F</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">a</mi></mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{FENa}&gt;2 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7224em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">FENa</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">2%</span></span></span></span></span> ), and inability to concentrate urine (urine osm <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>500</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">k</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;500 \mathrm{mOsm} / \mathrm{kg}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">500</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mOsm</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">kg</span></span></span></span></span></span> ).
D. Etiology may be ischemic or nephrotoxic.</li>
<li>Ischemia-Decreased blood supply results in necrosis of tubules.
i. Often preceded by prerenal azotemia
ii. Proximal tubule and medullary segment of the thick ascending limb are particularly susceptible to ischemic damage.</li>
<li>Nephrotoxic-Toxic agents result in necrosis of tubules.
i. Proximal tubule is particularly susceptible.
ii. Causes include aminoglycosides (most common), heavy metals (e.g., lead), myoglobinuria (e.g., from crush injury to muscle), ethylene glycol (associated with oxalate crystals in urine), radiocontrast dye, and urate (e.g., tumor lysis syndrome).
iii. Hydration and allopurinol are used prior to initiation of chemotherapy to decrease risk of urate-induced ATN.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-9508e68c.jpeg" alt="img-136.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 12.1 Horseshoe kidney. (Courtesy of humpath.com)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-40f55fbf.jpeg" alt="img-137.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 12.2 Potter sequence. (Courtesy of humpath. com)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-c1f3b97a.jpeg" alt="img-138.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 12.3 Dysplastic kidney. (Courtesy of Aliya Husain, MD)</p>
<p>E. Clinical features</p>
<ol>
<li>Oliguria with brown, granular casts</li>
<li>Elevated BUN and creatinine</li>
<li>Hyperkalemia (due to decreased renal excretion) with metabolic acidosis
F. Reversible, but often requires supportive dialysis since electrolyte imbalances can be fatal</li>
<li>Oliguria can persist for <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2-3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span></span></span></span></span> weeks before recovery; tubular cells (stable cells) take time to reenter the cell cycle and regenerate.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="v-acute-interstitial-nephritis">V. ACUTE INTERSTITIAL NEPHRITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-acute-interstitial-nephritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Drug-induced hypersensitivity involving the interstitium and tubules (Fig. 12.6); results in acute renal failure (intrarenal azotemia)
B. Causes include NSAIDs, penicillin, and diuretics.
C. Presents as oliguria, fever, and rash days to weeks after starting a drug; eosinophils may be seen in urine.
D. Resolves with cessation of drug
E. May progress to renal papillary necrosis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-renal-papillary-necrosis">VI. RENAL PAPILLARY NECROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-renal-papillary-necrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Necrosis of renal papillae
B. Presents with gross hematuria and flank pain
C. Causes include</p>
<ol>
<li>Chronic analgesic abuse (e.g., long-term phenacetin or aspirin use)</li>
<li>Diabetes mellitus</li>
<li>Sickle cell trait or disease</li>
<li>Severe acute pyelonephritis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nephrotic-syndrome">NEPHROTIC SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nephrotic-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Glomerular disorders characterized by proteinuria ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;3.5 \mathrm{~g} /</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">3.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mord">/</span></span></span></span></span> day) resulting in</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypoalbuminemia-pitting edema</li>
<li>Hypogammaglobulinemia-increased risk of infection</li>
<li>Hypercoagulable state-due to loss of antithrombin III</li>
<li>Hyperlipidemia and hypercholesterolemia-may result in fatty casts in urine</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-minimal-change-disease-mcd">II. MINIMAL CHANGE DISEASE (MCD)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-minimal-change-disease-mcd" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children
B. Usually idiopathic; may be associated with Hodgkin lymphoma
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-8f9ffc13.jpeg" alt="img-139.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 12.4 Polycystic kidney disease. (Courtesy of Fig. 12.5 Acute tubular necrosis. Jamie Steinmetz, MD)</p>
<p>C. Normal glomeruli on H&amp;E stain (Fig. 12.7A); lipid may be seen in proximal tubule cells.
D. Effacement of foot processes on electron microscopy (EM, Fig. 12.7B)
E. No immune complex deposits; negative immunofluorescence (IF)
F. Selective proteinuria (loss of albumin, but not immunoglobulin)
G. Excellent response to steroids (damage is mediated by cytokines from T cells)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-focal-segmental-glomerulosclerosis-fsgs">III. FOCAL SEGMENTAL GLOMERULOSCLEROSIS (FSGS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-focal-segmental-glomerulosclerosis-fsgs" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in Hispanics and African Americans
B. Usually idiopathic; may be associated with HIV, heroin use, and sickle cell disease
C. Focal (some glomeruli) and segmental (involving only part of the glomerulus) sclerosis on H&amp;E stain (Fig. 12.8)
D. Effacement of foot processes on EM
E. No immune complex deposits; negative IF
F. Poor response to steroids; progresses to chronic renal failure</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-membranous-nephropathy">IV. MEMBRANOUS NEPHROPATHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-membranous-nephropathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in Caucasian adults
B. Usually idiopathic; may be associated with hepatitis B or C, solid tumors, SLE, or drugs (e.g., NSAIDs and penicillamine)
C. Thick glomerular basement membrane on H&amp;E (Fig. 12.9A)
D. Due to immune complex deposition (granular IF, Fig. 12.9B); subepithelial deposits with 'spike and dome' appearance on EM (Fig. 12.9C)
E. Poor response to steroids; progresses to chronic renal failure</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-membranoproliferative-glomerulonephritis">V. MEMBRANOPROLIFERATIVE GLOMERULONEPHRITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-membranoproliferative-glomerulonephritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Thick glomerular basement membrane on H&amp;E, often with 'tram-track' appearance
B. Due to immune complex deposition (granular IF)
C. Divided into two types based on location of deposits</p>
<ol>
<li>Type I-subendothelial (Fig. 12.10); associated with HBV and HCV</li>
<li>Type II (dense deposit disease)-intramembranous; associated with C3 nephritic factor (autoantibody that stabilizes C 3 convertase, leading to overactivation of complement, inflammation, and low levels of circulating C3)
D. Poor response to steroids; progresses to chronic renal failure</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-diabetes-mellitus">VI. DIABETES MELLITUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-diabetes-mellitus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. High serum glucose leads to nonenzymatic glycosylation of the vascular basement membrane resulting in hyaline arteriolosclerosis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-b204e8ce.jpeg" alt="img-140.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 12.7 Minimal change disease. A, Normal glomerulus. B, Effacement of foot processes on EM. (Courtesy of Tony Chang, MD)
Fig. 12.8 Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis.</p>
<p>B. Glomerular efferent arteriole is more affected than the afferent arteriole, leading to high glomerular filtration pressure.</p>
<ol>
<li>Hyperfiltration injury leads to microalbuminuria.
C. Eventually progresses to nephrotic syndrome</li>
<li>Characterized by sclerosis of the mesangium with formation of KimmelstielWilson nodules (Fig. 12.11)
D. ACE inhibitors slow progression of hyperfiltration-induced damage.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vii-systemic-amyloidosis">VII. SYSTEMIC AMYLOIDOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-systemic-amyloidosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Kidney is the most commonly involved organ in systemic amyloidosis.
B. Amyloid deposits in the mesangium, resulting in nephrotic syndrome.
C. Characterized by apple-green birefringence under polarized light after staining with Congo red</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nephritic-syndrome">NEPHRITIC SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nephritic-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Glomerular disorders characterized by glomerular inflammation and bleeding</p>
<ol>
<li>Limited proteinuria ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>3.5</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;3.5 \mathrm{~g} /</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">3.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">g</span></span><span class="mord">/</span></span></span></span></span> day <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>Oliguria and azotemia</li>
<li>Salt retention with periorbital edema and hypertension</li>
<li>RBC casts and dysmorphic RBCs in urine
B. Biopsy reveals hypercellular, inflamed glomeruli (Fig. 12.12).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-7438d95f.jpeg" alt="img-141.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 12.9 Membranous nephropathy. A, Thick glomerular basement membranes. B, Granular IF. C, Subepithelial deposits with 'spike and dome' appearance. (Courtesy of Tony Chang, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-ea4bfb79.jpeg" alt="img-142.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 12.10 Subendothelial deposits, membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (type I). (Courtesy of Tony Chang, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-0fa0284c.jpeg" alt="img-143.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 12.11 Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules, diabetic nephropathy.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-701cc037.jpeg" alt="img-144.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 12.12 Hypercellular, inflamed glomerulus, nephritic syndrome.</p>
<ol>
<li>Immune-complex deposition activates complement; C5a attracts neutrophils, which mediate damage.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-poststreptococcal-glomerulonephritis-psgn">II. POSTSTREPTOCOCCAL GLOMERULONEPHRITIS (PSGN)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-poststreptococcal-glomerulonephritis-psgn" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Nephritic syndrome that arises after group A <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hemolytic streptococcal infection of the skin (impetigo) or pharynx</p>
<ol>
<li>Occurs with nephritogenic strains</li>
<li>May occur after infection with nonstreptococcal organisms as well
B. Presents <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2-3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">3</span></span></span></span></span> weeks after infection as hematuria (cola-colored urine), oliguria, hypertension, and periorbital edema</li>
<li>Usually seen in children, but may occur in adults
C. Hypercellular, inflamed glomeruli on H&amp;E
D. Mediated by immune complex deposition (granular IF); subepithelial 'humps' on EM (Fig. 12.13)
E. Treatment is supportive.</li>
<li>Children rarely ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span></span></span></span></span> ) progress to renal failure.</li>
<li>Some adults ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">25%</span></span></span></span></span> ) develop rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-rapidly-progressive-glomerulonephritis">III. RAPIDLY PROGRESSIVE GLOMERULONEPHRITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-rapidly-progressive-glomerulonephritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Nephritic syndrome that progresses to renal failure in weeks to months</p>
<p>Table 12.1: Immunofluorescence Findings in Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">IMMUNOFLUORESCENCE &lt;br&gt; PATTERN</th><th style="text-align: center;">DISEASE</th><th style="text-align: center;">COMMENTS</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Linear (anti-basement membrane antibody, Fig. 12.15)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Goodpasture syndrome</td><td style="text-align: center;">Antibody against collagen in glomerular and alveolar basement membranes; presents as hematuria and hemoptysis, classically in young, adult males</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Granular (immune complex deposition)</td><td style="text-align: center;">PSGN (most common) or diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis</td><td style="text-align: center;">Diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis is due to diffuse antigen-antibody complex deposition, usually sub-endothelial; most common type of renal disease in SLE</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Negative IF (pauci-immune)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Wegener granulomatosis, microscopic polyangiitis, and Churg-Strauss syndrome</td><td style="text-align: center;">Wegener granulomatosis is associated with c-ANCA; microscopic polyangiitis and Churg-Strauss are associated with p-ANCA. Granulomatous inflammation, eosinophilia, and asthma distinguish Churg-Strauss from microscopic polyangitis.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251213-ac9a98fe.jpeg" alt="img-145.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 12.13 Subepithelial 'humps,' PSGN. (Courtesy of Tony Chang, MD)</p>
<p>Fig. 12.14 Crescent formation, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.</p>
<p>B. Characterized by crescents in Bowman space (of glomeruli) on H&amp;E stain; crescents are comprised of fibrin and macrophages (Fig. 12.14).
C. Clinical picture and IF help resolve etiology (Table 12.1).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-iga-nephropathy-berger-disease">IV. IgA NEPHROPATHY (BERGER DISEASE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-iga-nephropathy-berger-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. IgA immune complex deposition in mesangium of glomeruli; most common nephropathy worldwide
B. Presents during childhood as episodic gross or microscopic hematuria with RBC casts, usually following mucosal infections (e.g., gastroenteritis)</p>
<ol>
<li>IgA production is increased during infection.
C. IgA immune complex deposition in the mesangium is seen on IF (Fig. 12.16).
D. May slowly progress to renal failure</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-alport-syndrome">V. ALPORT SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-alport-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inherited defect in type IV collagen; most commonly X-linked
B. Results in thinning and splitting of the glomerular basement membrane
C. Presents as isolated hematuria, sensory hearing loss, and ocular disturbances</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="urinary-tract-infection">URINARY TRACT INFECTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#urinary-tract-infection" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. BASIC PRINCIPLES
A. Infection of urethra, bladder, or kidney
B. Most commonly arises due to ascending infection; increased incidence in females
C. Risk factors include sexual intercourse, urinary stasis, and catheters.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-cystitis">II. CYSTITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-cystitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Infection of the bladder
B. Presents as dysuria, urinary frequency, urgency, and suprapubic pain; systemic signs (e.g., fever) are usually absent.
C. Laboratory findings</p>
<ol>
