<li>Urinalysis-cloudy urine with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>10</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;10 \mathrm{WBCs} /</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">WBCs</span></span><span class="mord">/</span></span></span></span></span> high power field (hpf)</li>
<li>Dipstick-Positive leukocyte esterase (due to pyuria) and nitrites (bacteria convert nitrates to nitrites)</li>
<li>Culture-greater than 100,000 colony forming units (gold standard)
D. Etiology</li>
<li>E coli <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>80</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(80 \%)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">80%</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>Staphylococcus saprophyticus-increased incidence in young, sexually active women (but <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">E</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">E</span></span></span></span></span> coli is still more common in this population)</li>
<li>Klebsiella pneumoniae</li>
<li>Proteus mirabilis-alkaline urine with ammonia scent
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-738f2d8f.jpeg" alt="img-146.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 12.15 Linear IF, Goodpasture syndrome. (Courtesy of Tony Chang, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-3d14f671.jpeg" alt="img-147.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 12.16 IgA nephropathy. (Courtesy of Tony Chang, MD)</p>
<ol start="5">
<li>Enterococcus faecalis
E. Sterile pyuria is the presence of pyuria ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>10</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">W</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">h</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">f</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;10 \mathrm{WBCs} / \mathrm{hpf}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">WBCs</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.07778em;">hpf</span></span></span></span></span></span> and leukocyte esterase) with a negative urine culture.</li>
<li>Suggests urethritis due to Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae (dominant presenting sign of urethritis is dysuria)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-pyelonephritis">III. PYELONEPHRITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-pyelonephritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Infection of the kidney</p>
<ol>
<li>Usually due to ascending infection; increased risk with vesicoureteral reflux
B. Presents with fever, flank pain, WBC casts, and leukocytosis in addition to symptoms of cystitis
C. Most common pathogens are</li>
<li>E coli <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(90 \%)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">90%</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span></li>
<li>Enterococcus faecalis</li>
<li>Klebsiella species</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-chronic-pyelonephritis">IV. CHRONIC PYELONEPHRITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-chronic-pyelonephritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Interstitial fibrosis and atrophy of tubules due to multiple bouts of acute pyelonephritis
B. Due to vesicoureteral reflux (children) or obstruction (e.g., BPH or cervical carcinoma)
C. Leads to cortical scarring with blunted calyces; scarring at upper and lower poles is characteristic of vesicoureteral reflux.
D. Atrophic tubules containing eosinophilic proteinaceous material resemble thyroid follicles ('thyroidization' of the kidney, Fig. 12.17); waxy casts may be seen in urine.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="nephrolithiasis">NEPHROLITHIASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#nephrolithiasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. BASIC PRINCIPLES
A. Precipitation of a urinary solute as a stone (Table 12.2)
B. Risk factors include high concentration of solute in the urinary filtrate and low urine volume.
C. Presents as colicky pain with hematuria and unilateral flank tenderness</p>
<ol>
<li>Stone is usually passed within hours; if not, surgical intervention may be required.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="chronic-renal-failure">CHRONIC RENAL FAILURE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#chronic-renal-failure" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. BASIC PRINCIPLES
A. End-stage kidney failure</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>May result from glomerular, tubular, inflammatory, or vascular insults</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Most common causes are diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and glomerular disease.
B. Clinical features</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Uremia-Increased nitrogenous waste products in blood (azotemia) result in nausea, anorexia, pericarditis, platelet dysfunction, encephalopathy with asterixis, and deposition of urea crystals in skin.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Salt and water retention with resultant hypertension</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hyperkalemia with metabolic acidosis</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Anemia due to decreased erythropoietin production by renal peritubular interstitial cells</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Hypocalcemia due to decreased 1-alpha-hydroxylation of vitamin D by proximal renal tubule cells and hyperphosphatemia</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Renal osteodystrophy due to secondary hyperparathyroidism, osteomalacia, and osteoporosis
C. Treatment involves dialysis or renal transplant.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Cysts often develop within shrunken end-stage kidneys during dialysis, increasing risk for renal cell carcinoma.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="renal-neoplasia">RENAL NEOPLASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#renal-neoplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-angiomyolipoma">I. ANGIOMYOLIPOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-angiomyolipoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Hamartoma comprised of blood vessels, smooth muscle, and adipose tissue
B. Increased frequency in tuberous sclerosis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-renal-cell-carcinoma">II. RENAL CELL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-renal-cell-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant epithelial tumor arising from kidney tubules</p>
<p>Table 12.2: Features of Nephrolithiasis</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">COMPOSITION</th><th style="text-align: center;">FREQUENCY</th><th style="text-align: center;">CAUSES</th><th style="text-align: center;">TREATMENT</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Calcium oxalate and/ or calcium phosphate</td><td style="text-align: center;">Most common type; usually seen in adults</td><td style="text-align: center;">Most common cause is idiopathic hypercalciuria; hypercalcemia and its related causes must be excluded. Also seen with Crohn disease</td><td style="text-align: center;">Treatment is hydrochlorothiazide (calcium-sparing diuretic).</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Ammonium magnesium phosphate</td><td style="text-align: center;">Second most common type</td><td style="text-align: center;">Most common cause is infection with urease-positive organisms (e.g., Proteus vulgaris or Klebsiella); alkaline urine leads to formation of stone.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Classically, results in staghorn calculi in renal calyces (Fig. 12.18), which act as a nidus for urinary tract infections. Treatment involves surgical removal of stone (due to size) and eradication of pathogen (to prevent recurrence).</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Uric acid</td><td style="text-align: center;">Third most common stone (5%); radiolucent (as opposed to other types of stones which are radiopaque)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Risk factors include hot, arid climates, low urine volume, and acidic pH . Most common stone seen in patients with gout; hyperuricemia (e.g., in leukemia or myeloproliferative disorders) increases risk.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Treatment involves hydration and alkalinization of urine (potassium bicarbonate); allopurinol is also administered in patients with gout.</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Cystine</td><td style="text-align: center;">Rare cause of nephrolithiasis; most commonly seen in children</td><td style="text-align: center;">Associated with cystinuria (a genetic defect of tubules that results in decreased reabsorption of cysteine)</td><td style="text-align: center;">May form staghorn calculi; treatment involves hydration and alkalinization of urine.</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251213-bdd7aa8c.jpeg" alt="img-148.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 12.17 'Thyroidization' of kidney, chronic pyelonephritis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-43911c9c.jpeg" alt="img-149.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 12.18 Ammonium magnesium phosphate stone. (Courtesy of webpathology.com)</p>
<p>B. Presents with classic triad of hematuria, palpable mass, and flank pain</p>
<ol>
<li>All three symptoms rarely occur together; hematuria is the most common symptom.</li>
<li>Fever, weight loss, or paraneoplastic syndrome (e.g., EPO, renin, PTHrP, or ACTH) may also be present.</li>
<li>Rarely may present with left-sided varicocele
i. Involvement of the left renal vein by carcinoma blocks drainage of the left spermatic vein leading to varicocele.
ii. Right spermatic vein drains directly into the IVC; hence, right-sided varicocele is not seen.
C. Gross exam reveals a yellow mass (Fig. 12.19A); microscopically, the most common variant exhibits clear cytoplasm (clear cell type, Fig. 12.19B).
D. Pathogenesis involves loss of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>V</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>L</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>3</mn><mi>p</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">V H L(3 p)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">V</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord mathnormal">L</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">3</span><span class="mord mathnormal">p</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> tumor suppressor gene, which leads to increased IGF-1 (promotes growth) and increased HIF transcription factor (increases VEGF and PDGF).
E. Tumors may be hereditary or sporadic.</li>
<li>Sporadic tumors classically arise in adult males (average age is 60 years) as a single tumor in the upper pole of the kidney; major risk factor for sporadic tumors is cigarette smoke.</li>
<li>Hereditary tumors arise in younger adults and are often bilateral.
i. Von Hippel-Lindau disease is an autosomal dominant disorder associated with inactivation of the VHL gene leading to increased risk for hemangioblastoma of the cerebellum and renal cell carcinoma.
F. Staging</li>
<li>T-based on size and involvement of the renal vein (occurs commonly and increases risk of hematogenous spread to the lungs and bone)</li>
<li>N-spread to retroperitoneal lymph nodes</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-wilms-tumor">III. WILMS TUMOR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-wilms-tumor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Malignant kidney tumor comprised of blastema (immature kidney mesenchyme), primitive glomeruli and tubules, and stromal cells (Fig. 12.20)</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common malignant renal tumor in children; average age is 3 years.
B. Presents as a large, unilateral flank mass with hematuria and hypertension (due to renin secretion)
C. Most cases ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> ) are sporadic; syndromic tumors may be seen with</li>
<li>WAGR syndrome-Wilms tumor, Aniridia, Genital abnormalities, and mental and motor Retardation; associated with deletion of WT1 tumor suppressor gene (located at 11p13)</li>
<li>Denys-Drash syndrome-Wilms tumor, progressive renal (glomerular) disease, and male pseudohermaphroditism; associated with mutations of WT1
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-3c143e37.jpeg" alt="img-150.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 12.19 Renal cell carcinoma. A, Gross appearance. B, Microscopic appearance.
Fig. 12.20 Wilms tumor.</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome-Wilms tumor, neonatal hypoglycemia, muscular hemihypertrophy, and organomegaly (including tongue); associated with mutations in WT2 gene cluster (imprinted genes at 11p15.5), particularly IGF-2</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="lower-urinary-tract-carcinoma">LOWER URINARY TRACT CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#lower-urinary-tract-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-urothelial-transitional-cell-carcinoma">I. UROTHELIAL (TRANSITIONAL CELL) CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-urothelial-transitional-cell-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant tumor arising from the urothelial lining of the renal pelvis, ureter, bladder, or urethra</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common type of lower urinary tract cancer; usually arises in the bladder
B. Major risk factor is cigarette smoke; additional risk factors are naphthylamine, azo dyes, and long-term cyclophosphamide or phenacetin use.
C. Generally seen in older adults; classically presents with painless hematuria
D. Arises via two distinct pathways (Fig. 12.21)</li>
<li>Flat-develops as a high-grade flat tumor and then invades; associated with early p53 mutations</li>
<li>Papillary-develops as a low-grade papillary tumor that progresses to a highgrade papillary tumor and then invades; not associated with early p53 mutations
E. Tumors are often multifocal and recur ("field defect").</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-squamous-cell-carcinoma">II. SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-squamous-cell-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of squamous cells, usually involving the bladder
B. Arises in a background of squamous metaplasia (normal bladder surface is not lined by squamous epithelium)
C. Risk factors include chronic cystitis (older woman), Schistosoma haematobium infection (Egyptian male), and long-standing nephrolithiasis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-adenocarcinoma">III. ADENOCARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-adenocarcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of glands, usually involving bladder
B. Arises from a urachal remnant (tumor develops at the dome of the bladder), cystitis glandularis, or exstrophy (congenital failure to form the caudal portion of the anterior abdominal and bladder walls)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-82ef1878.jpeg" alt="img-151.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 12.21 Urothelial carcinoma. A, Flat. B, Papillary.</p>
<p>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="female-genital-system-and-gestational-pathology">Female Genital System and Gestational Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#female-genital-system-and-gestational-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vulva">VULVA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vulva" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Anatomically includes the skin and mucosa of the female genitalia external to the hymen (labia majora, labia minora, mons pubis, and vestibule)
B. Lined by squamous epithelium</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-bartholin-cyst">II. BARTHOLIN CYST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-bartholin-cyst" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Cystic dilation of the Bartholin gland</p>
<ol>
<li>One Bartholin gland is present on each side of the vaginal canal and produces mucus-like fluid that drains via ducts into the lower vestibule.
B. Arises due to inflammation and obstruction of gland</li>
<li>Usually occurs in women of reproductive age
C. Presents as a unilateral, painful cystic lesion at the lower vestibule adjacent to the vaginal canal</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-condyloma">III. CONDYLOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-condyloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Warty neoplasm of vulvar skin, often large
B. Most commonly due to HPV types 6 or 11 (condyloma acuminatum, Fig. 13.1A); secondary syphilis (condyloma latum) is a less common cause. Both are sexually transmitted.
C. Histologically, HPV-associated condylomas are characterized by koilocytes (hallmark of HPV-infected cells, Fig. 13.1B).
D. Condylomas rarely progress to carcinoma ( 6 and 11 are low-risk HPV types).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-lichen-sclerosis">IV. LICHEN SCLEROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-lichen-sclerosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Characterized by thinning of the epidermis and fibrosis (sclerosis) of the dermis
B. Presents as a white patch (leukoplakia) with parchment-like vulvar skin
C. Most commonly seen in postmenopausal women; possible autoimmune etiology
D. Benign, but associated with a slightly increased risk for squamous cell carcinoma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-lichen-simplex-chronicus">V. LICHEN SIMPLEX CHRONICUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-lichen-simplex-chronicus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Characterized by hyperplasia of the vulvar squamous epithelium
B. Presents as leukoplakia with thick, leathery vulvar skin
C. Associated with chronic irritation and scratching
D. Benign; no increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-vulvar-carcinoma">VI. VULVAR CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-vulvar-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Carcinoma arising from squamous epithelium lining the vulva
B. Relatively rare, accounting for only a small percentage of female genital cancers
C. Presents as leukoplakia; biopsy may be required to distinguish carcinoma from other causes of leukoplakia.
D. Etiology may be HPV related or non-HPV related.
E. HPV-related vulvar carcinoma is due to high-risk HPV types 16 and 18.</p>
<ol>
<li>Risk factors are related to HPV exposure and include multiple partners and early first age of intercourse; generally occurs in women of reproductive age</li>
<li>Arises from vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (VIN), a dysplastic precursor lesion characterized by koilocytic change, disordered cellular maturation, nuclear atypia, and increased mitotic activity
F. Non-HPV related vulvar carcinoma arises, most often, from long-standing lichen sclerosis.</li>
<li>Chronic inflammation and irritation eventually lead to carcinoma.</li>
<li>Generally seen in elderly women (average age is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>70</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;70</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span></span></span></span></span> years)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vii-extramammary-paget-disease">VII. EXTRAMAMMARY PAGET DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-extramammary-paget-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Characterized by malignant epithelial cells in the epidermis of the vulva (Fig. 13.2A)
B. Presents as erythematous, pruritic, ulcerated vulvar skin
C. Represents carcinoma in situ, usually with no underlying carcinoma</p>
<ol>
<li>Paget disease of the nipple is also characterized by malignant epithelial cells in the epidermis of the nipple, but it is almost always associated with an underlying carcinoma.
D. Must be distinguished from melanoma, which rarely can occur on the vulva</li>
<li>Paget cells are <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{PAS}^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PAS</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, keratin <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>100</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{S}-100^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">S</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>Melanoma is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{PAS}^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8446em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PAS</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, keratin, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">S</mi><mo>−</mo><msup><mn>100</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{S}-100^{+}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7667em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">S</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">0</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vagina">VAGINA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vagina" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Canal leading to the cervix
B. Mucosa is lined by non-keratinizing squamous epithelium</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-adenosis">II. ADENOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-adenosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Focal persistence of columnar epithelium in the upper vagina (Fig. 13.2B)</p>
<ol>
<li>During development, squamous epithelium from the lower <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/3</span></span></span></span></span> of the vagina (derived from the urogenital sinus) grows upward to replace the columnar epithelium lining of the upper <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2/3</span></span></span></span></span> of the vagina (derived from the Müllerian ducts).
B. Increased incidence in females who were exposed to diethylstilbestrol (DES) in utero</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-clear-cell-adenocarcinoma">III. CLEAR CELL ADENOCARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-clear-cell-adenocarcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of glands with clear cytoplasm
B. Rare, but feared, complication of DES-associated vaginal adenosis
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-bfef8198.jpeg" alt="img-152.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 13.1 Condyloma acuminata. A, Microscopic appearance. B, Koilocytic change.</p>
<p>Fig. 13.2A Extramammary Paget disease of the vulva. (Courtesy of webpathology.com)</p>
<p>C. Discovery of this complication (along with other DES-induced abnormalities of the gynecologic tract such as abnormal shape of the uterus) led to cessation of DES usage.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-embryonal-rhabdomyosarcoma">IV. EMBRYONAL RHABDOMYOSARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-embryonal-rhabdomyosarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Malignant mesenchymal proliferation of immature skeletal muscle; rare
B. Presents as bleeding and a grape-like mass protruding from the vagina or penis of a child (usually &lt; 5 yrs of age); also known as sarcoma botryoides (Fig. 13.3)
C. Rhabdomyoblast, the characteristic cell, exhibits cytoplasmic cross-striations and positive immunohistochemical staining for desmin and myogenin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-vaginal-carcinoma">V. VAGINAL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-vaginal-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Carcinoma arising from squamous epithelium lining the vaginal mucosa
B. Usually related to high-risk HPV
C. Precursor lesion is vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia (VAIN).
D. When spread to regional lymph nodes occurs, cancer from the lower <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/3</span></span></span></span></span> of vagina goes to inguinal nodes, and cancer from the upper <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2/3</span></span></span></span></span> goes to regional iliac nodes.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cervix">CERVIX<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cervix" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Anatomically, comprises the "neck" of the uterus
B. Divided into the exocervix (visible on vaginal exam) and endocervix</p>
<ol>
<li>Exocervix is lined by nonkeratinizing squamous epithelium.</li>
<li>Endocervix is lined by a single layer of columnar cells.</li>
<li>Junction between the exocervix and endocervix is called the transformation zone (Fig. 13.4A).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-hpv">II. HPV<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-hpv" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Sexually transmitted DNA virus that infects the lower genital tract, especially the cervix in the transformation zone
B. Infection is usually eradicated by acute inflammation; persistent infection leads to an increased risk for cervical dysplasia (cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, CIN).
C. Risk of CIN depends on HPV type, which is determined by DNA sequencing.</p>
<ol>
<li>High-risk-HPV types <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>16</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>18</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>31</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">16,18,31</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">16</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">18</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">31</span></span></span></span></span>, and 33</li>
<li>Low-risk-HPV types 6 and 11
D. High-risk HPV produce E6 and E7 proteins which result in increased destruction of p53 and Rb , respectively. Loss of these tumor suppressor proteins increases the risk for CIN.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-7083544b.jpeg" alt="img-153.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 13.2B Vaginal adenosis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-fffc5128.jpeg" alt="img-154.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 13.3 Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma. (Courtesy of humpath.com)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-cervical-intraepithelial-neoplasia">III. CERVICAL INTRAEPITHELIAL NEOPLASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-cervical-intraepithelial-neoplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Characterized by koilocytic change, disordered cellular maturation, nuclear atypia, and increased mitotic activity within the cervical epithelium.
B. Divided into grades based on the extent of epithelial involvement by immature dysplastic cells</p>
<ol>
<li>CIN I involves <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;1 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/3</span></span></span></span></span> of the thickness of the epithelium.</li>
<li>CIN II involves <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;2 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2/3</span></span></span></span></span> of the thickness of the epithelium.</li>
<li>CIN III involves slightly less than the entire thickness of the epithelium (Fig. 13.4B).</li>
<li>Carcinoma in situ (CIS) involves the entire thickness of the epithelium.
C. CIN classically progresses in a stepwise fashion through CIN I, CIN II, CIN III, and CIS to become invasive squamous cell carcinoma.</li>
<li>Progression is not inevitable (e.g., CIN I often regresses).</li>
<li>The higher the grade of dysplasia, the more likely it is to progress to carcinoma and the less likely it is to regress to normal.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-cervical-carcinoma">IV. CERVICAL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-cervical-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Invasive carcinoma that arises from the cervical epithelium
B. Most commonly seen in middle-aged women (average age is <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>50</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40-50</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">50</span></span></span></span></span> years)
C. Presents as vaginal bleeding, especially postcoital bleeding, or cervical discharge
D. Key risk factor is high-risk HPV infection; secondary risk factors include smoking and immunodeficiency (e.g., cervical carcinoma is an AIDS-defining illness).
E. Most common subtypes of cervical carcinoma are squamous cell carcinoma ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>80</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">80 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">80%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases) and adenocarcinoma ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases). Both types are related to HPV infection.
F. Advanced tumors often invade through the anterior uterine wall into the bladder, blocking the ureters. Hydronephrosis with postrenal failure is a common cause of death in advanced cervical carcinoma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-screening-and-prevention-of-cervical-carcinoma">V. SCREENING AND PREVENTION OF CERVICAL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-screening-and-prevention-of-cervical-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. The goal of screening is to catch dysplasia (CIN) before it develops into carcinoma.</p>
<ol>
<li>Progression from CIN to carcinoma, on average, takes <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>20</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10-20</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">20</span></span></span></span></span> years.</li>
<li>Screening begins at age 21 and is initially performed every three years.
B. Pap smear is the gold standard for screening.</li>
<li>Cells are scraped from the transformation zone using a brush and analyzed under a microscope.</li>
<li>Dysplastic cells are classified as low grade (CIN I) or high grade (CIN II and III).</li>
<li>High-grade dysplasia is characterized by cells with hyperchromatic (dark) nuclei and high nuclear to cytoplasmic ratios (Fig. 13.4C).
C. Pap smear is the most successful screening test developed to date.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-619f23aa.jpeg" alt="img-155.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 13.4 Cervix. A, Cervical transformation zone, normal. B, CIN III. C, High-grade dysplasia, Pap smear. (Courtesy of Ed Uthman, MD)</p>
<ol>
<li>It is responsible for a significant reduction in the morbidity and mortality of cervical carcinoma (cervical carcinoma went from being the most common to one of the least common types of gynecologic carcinoma in the US).</li>
<li>Women who develop invasive cervical carcinoma usually have not undergone screening.
D. An abnormal Pap smear is followed by confirmatory colposcopy (visualization of cervix with a magnifying glass) and biopsy.
E. Limitations of the Pap smear include inadequate sampling of the transformation zone (false negative screening) and limited efficacy in screening for adenocarcinoma.</li>
<li>Despite Pap smear screening, the incidence of adenocarcinoma has not decreased significantly.
F. Immunization is effective in preventing HPV infections.</li>
<li>The quadrivalent vaccine covers HPV types <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>6</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>11</mn><mo separator="true">,</mo><mn>16</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">6,11,16</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8389em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">11</span><span class="mpunct">,</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">16</span></span></span></span></span>, and 18 .</li>
<li>Antibodies generated against types 6 and 11 protect against condylomas.</li>
<li>Antibodies generated against types 16 and 18 protect against CIN and carcinoma.</li>
<li>Pap smears are still necessary due to the limited number of HPV types covered by the vaccine.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="endometrium-and-myometrium">ENDOMETRIUM AND MYOMETRIUM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endometrium-and-myometrium" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Endometrium is the mucosal lining of the uterine cavity.
B. Myometrium is the smooth muscle wall underlying the endometrium (Fig. 13.5).
C. Endometrium is hormonally sensitive.</p>
<ol>
<li>Growth of the endometrium is estrogen driven (proliferative phase).</li>
<li>Preparation of the endometrium for implantation is progesterone driven (secretory phase).</li>
<li>Shedding occurs with loss of progesterone support (menstrual phase).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-asherman-syndrome">II. ASHERMAN SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-asherman-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Secondary amenorrhea due to loss of the basalis and scarring
B. Result of overaggressive dilation and curettage (D&amp;C)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-anovulatory-cycle">III. ANOVULATORY CYCLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-anovulatory-cycle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Lack of ovulation
B. Results in an estrogen-driven proliferative phase without a subsequent progesteronedriven secretory phase</p>
<ol>
<li>Proliferative glands break down and shed resulting in uterine bleeding.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-54f485b7.jpeg" alt="img-156.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 13.5 Endometrium overlying myometrium, normal.
Fig. 13.6 Endometrial polyp.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Represents a common cause of dysfunctional uterine bleeding, especially during menarche and menopause</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-acute-endometritis">IV. ACUTE ENDOMETRITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-acute-endometritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Bacterial infection of the endometrium
B. Usually due to retained products of conception (e.g., after delivery or miscarriage); retained products act as a nidus for infection.
C. Presents as fever, abnormal uterine bleeding, and pelvic pain</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-chronic-endometritis">V. CHRONIC ENDOMETRITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-chronic-endometritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Chronic inflammation of the endometrium
B. Characterized by lymphocytes and plasma cells</p>
<ol>
<li>Plasma cells are necessary for the diagnosis of chronic endometritis given that lymphocytes are normally found in the endometrium.
C. Causes include retained products of conception, chronic pelvic inflammatory disease (e.g., Chlamydia), IUD, and TB.
D. Presents as abnormal uterine bleeding, pain, and infertility</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-endometrial-polyp">VI. ENDOMETRIAL POLYP<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-endometrial-polyp" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Hyperplastic protrusion of endometrium (Fig. 13.6)
B. Presents as abnormal uterine bleeding
C. Can arise as a side effect of tamoxifen, which has anti-estrogenic effects on the breast but weak pro-estrogenic effects on the endometrium</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-endometriosis">VII. ENDOMETRIOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-endometriosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Endometrial glands and stroma outside of the uterine endometrial lining</p>
<ol>
<li>Most likely due to retrograde menstruation with implantation at an ectopic site
B. Presents as dysmenorrhea (pain during menstruation) and pelvic pain; may cause infertility</li>
<li>Endometriosis cycles just like normal endometrium.
C. Most common site of involvement is the ovary, which classically results in formation of a 'chocolate' cyst (Fig. 13.7A).</li>
<li>Other sites of involvement include the uterine ligaments (pelvic pain), pouch of Douglas (pain with defecation), bladder wall (pain with urination), bowel serosa (abdominal pain and adhesions), and fallopian tube mucosa (scarring increases risk for ectopic tubal pregnancy); implants classically appear as yellow-brown 'gun-powder' nodules (Fig. 13.7B).</li>
<li>Involvement of the uterine myometrium is called adenomyosis.
D. There is an increased risk of carcinoma at the site of endometriosis, especially in the ovary.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-fbcabeb2.jpeg" alt="img-157.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 13.7 Endometriosis. A, 'Chocolate cyst' of ovary. B, 'Gun powder' nodules. (A, Courtesy of Bulent Celasun, MD. B, Courtesy of humpath.com)
Fig. 13.8 Endometrial hyperplasia. (Courtesy of Ed Uthman, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="viii-endometrial-hyperplasia">VIII.ENDOMETRIAL HYPERPLASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-endometrial-hyperplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Hyperplasia of endometrial glands relative to stroma (Fig. 13.8)
B. Occurs as a consequence of unopposed estrogen (e.g., obesity, polycystic ovary syndrome, and estrogen replacement)
C. Classically presents as postmenopausal uterine bleeding
D. Classified histologically based on architectural growth pattern (simple or complex) and the presence or absence of cellular atypia</p>
<ol>
<li>Most important predictor for progression to carcinoma (major complication) is the presence of cellular atypia; simple hyperplasia with atypia often progresses to cancer (30%); whereas, complex hyperplasia without atypia rarely does (&lt;5%).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ix-endometrial-carcinoma">IX. ENDOMETRIAL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ix-endometrial-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of endometrial glands (Fig. 13.9A)</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common invasive carcinoma of the female genital tract
B. Presents as postmenopausal bleeding
C. Arises via two distinct pathways: hyperplasia and sporadic
D. In the hyperplasia pathway ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>75</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">75 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">75%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases), carcinoma arises from endometrial hyperplasia.</li>
<li>Risk factors are related to estrogen exposure and include early menarche/late menopause, nulliparity, infertility with anovulatory cycles, and obesity.</li>
<li>Average age of presentation is 60 years.</li>
<li>Histology is endometrioid (i.e., normal endometrium-like, Fig. 13.9B).
E. In the sporadic pathway ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>25</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">25 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">25%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases), carcinoma arises in an atrophic endometrium with no evident precursor lesion.</li>
<li>Average age at presentation is 70 years.</li>
<li>Histology is usually serous and is characterized by papillary structures (Fig. 13.9C) with psammoma body formation; p53 mutation is common, and the tumor exhibits aggressive behavior.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="x-leiomyoma-fibroids">X. LEIOMYOMA (FIBROIDS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#x-leiomyoma-fibroids" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign neoplastic proliferation of smooth muscle arising from myometrium; most common tumor in females
B. Related to estrogen exposure</p>
<ol>
<li>Common in premenopausal women</li>
<li>Often multiple</li>
<li>Enlarge during pregnancy; shrink after menopause
C. Gross exam shows multiple, well-defined, white, whorled masses that may distort the uterus and impinge on pelvic structures (Fig. 13.10).
D. Usually asymptomatic; when present, symptoms include abnormal uterine bleeding, infertility, and a pelvic mass.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-4b880b50.jpeg" alt="img-158.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 13.9 Endometrial carcinoma. A, Gross appearance. B, Endometrioid type. C, Serous type. (A, Courtesy of <a href="http://www.anatomiapatologica.com.br" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">www.anatomiapatologica.com.br</a>)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="xi-leiomyosarcoma">XI. LEIOMYOSARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#xi-leiomyosarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of smooth muscle arising from the myometrium
B. Arises de novo; leiomyosarcomas do not arise from leiomyomas.
C. Usually seen in postmenopausal women
D. Gross exam often shows a single lesion with areas of necrosis and hemorrhage; histological features include necrosis, mitotic activity, and cellular atypia.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ovary">OVARY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ovary" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. The functional unit of the ovary is the follicle.
B. A follicle consists of an oocyte surrounded by granulosa and theca cells (Fig. 13.11A)</p>
<ol>
<li>LH acts on theca cells to induce androgen production.</li>
<li>FSH stimulates granulosa cells to convert androgen to estradiol (drives the proliferative phase of the endometrial cycle).</li>
<li>Estradiol surge induces an LH surge, which leads to ovulation (marking the beginning of the secretory phase of the endometrial cycle).
C. After ovulation, the residual follicle becomes a corpus luteum (Fig. 13.11B), which primarily secretes progesterone (drives the secretory phase which prepares the endometrium for a possible pregnancy).</li>
<li>Hemorrhage into a corpus luteum can result in a hemorrhagic corpus luteal cyst, especially during early pregnancy.
D. Degeneration of follicles results in follicular cysts. Small numbers of follicular cysts are common in women and have no clinical significance.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-polycystic-ovarian-disease-pcod">II. POLYCYSTIC OVARIAN DISEASE (PCOD)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-polycystic-ovarian-disease-pcod" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Multiple ovarian follicular cysts due to hormone imbalance</p>
<ol>
<li>Affects roughly <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">5%</span></span></span></span></span> of women of reproductive age
B. Characterized by increased LH and low FSH (LH:FSH &gt; 2)</li>
<li>Increased LH induces excess androgen production (from theca cells) resulting in hirsutism (excess hair in a male distribution).</li>
<li>Androgen is converted to estrone in adipose tissue.
i. Estrone feedback decreases FSH resulting in cystic degeneration of follicles.
ii. High levels of circulating estrone increase risk for endometrial carcinoma.
C.
