Classic presentation is an obese young woman with infertility, oligomenorrhea, and hirsutism; some patients have insulin resistance and may develop type 2 diabetes mellitus <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10-15</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">15</span></span></span></span></span> years later.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-cb89e8f2.jpeg" alt="img-159.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 13.10 Uterine leiomyomas. (Courtesy of Jamie Steinmetz, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-e2124ed5.jpeg" alt="img-160.jpeg">
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-9fee0bc5.jpeg" alt="img-161.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 13.11 Ovarian follicle. A, Normal. B, Corpus luteum. (B, Courtesy of Ed Uthman, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ovarian-tumors">OVARIAN TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ovarian-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Ovary is composed of three cell types: surface epithelium, germ cells, and sex cordstroma.
B. Tumor can arise from any of these cell types or from metastases.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-surface-epithelial-tumors">II. SURFACE EPITHELIAL TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-surface-epithelial-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Most common type of ovarian tumor ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">70%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases)
B. Derived from coelomic epithelium that lines the ovary; coelomic epithelium embryologically produces the epithelial lining of the fallopian tube (serous cells), endometrium, and endocervix (mucinous cells).
C. The two most common subtypes of surface epithelial tumors are serous and mucinous; both are usually cystic.</p>
<ol>
<li>Serous tumors are full of watery fluid.</li>
<li>Mucinous tumors are full of mucus-like fluid.
D. Mucinous and serous tumors can be benign, borderline, or malignant.</li>
<li>Benign tumors (cystadenomas) are composed of a single cyst with a simple, flat lining (Fig. 13.12); most commonly arise in premenopausal women (30-40 years old)</li>
<li>Malignant tumors (cystadenocarcinomas) are composed of complex cysts with a thick, shaggy lining; most commonly arise in postmenopausal women (60-70 years old)</li>
<li>Borderline tumors have features in between benign and malignant tumors.
i. Better prognosis than clearly malignant tumors, but still carry metastatic potential</li>
<li>BRCA1 mutation carriers have an increased risk for serous carcinoma of the ovary and fallopian tube.
i. BRCA1 carriers often elect to have a prophylactic salpingo-oophorectomy (along with prophylactic mastectomy due to the increased risk for breast cancer).
E. Less common subtypes of surface epithelial tumors include endometrioid and Brenner tumor.</li>
<li>Endometrioid tumors are composed of endometrial-like glands and are usually malignant.
i. May arise from endometriosis
ii. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> of endometrioid carcinomas of the ovary are associated with an independent endometrial carcinoma (endometrioid type).</li>
<li>Brenner tumors are composed of bladder-like epithelium and are usually benign.
F. Surface tumors clinically present late with vague abdominal symptoms (pain and fullness) or signs of compression (urinary frequency).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-2ef5632c.jpeg" alt="img-162.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 13.12 Ovarian cystadenoma.</p>
<ol>
<li>Prognosis is generally poor for surface epithelial carcinoma (worst prognosis of female genital tract cancers).</li>
<li>Epithelial carcinomas tend to spread locally, especially to the peritoneum.
G. CA-125 is a useful serum marker to monitor treatment response and screen for recurrence.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-germ-cell-tumors">III. GERM CELL TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-germ-cell-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. 2nd most common type of ovarian tumor ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases)
B. Usually occur in women of reproductive age
C. Tumor subtypes mimic tissues normally produced by germ cells.</p>
<ol>
<li>Fetal tissue-cystic teratoma and embryonal carcinoma</li>
<li>Oocytes-dysgerminoma</li>
<li>Yolk sac-endodermal sinus tumor</li>
<li>Placental tissue-choriocarcinoma
D. Cystic teratoma</li>
<li>Cystic tumor composed of fetal tissue derived from two or three embryologic layers (e.g., skin, hair, bone, cartilage, gut, and thyroid, Fig. 13.13)
i. Most common germ cell tumor in females; bilateral in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases</li>
<li>Benign, but presence of immature tissue (usually neural) or somatic malignancy (usually squamous cell carcinoma of skin) indicates malignant potential.</li>
<li>Struma ovarii is a teratoma composed primarily of thyroid tissue.
E. Dysgerminoma</li>
<li>Tumor composed of large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei (resemble oocytes, Fig. 13.14); most common malignant germ cell tumor</li>
<li>Testicular counterpart is called seminoma, which is a relatively common germ cell tumor in males.</li>
<li>Good prognosis; responds to radiotherapy</li>
<li>Serum LDH may be elevated.
F. Endodermal sinus tumor</li>
<li>Malignant tumor that mimics the yolk sac; most common germ cell tumor in children</li>
<li>Serum AFP is often elevated.</li>
<li>Schiller-Duval bodies (glomerulus-like structures) are classically seen on histology (Fig. 13.15).
G. Choriocarcinoma</li>
<li>Malignant tumor composed of cytotrophoblasts and syncytiotrophoblasts; mimics placental tissue, but villi are absent</li>
<li>Small, hemorrhagic tumor with early hematogenous spread</li>
<li>High <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hCG is characteristic (produced by syncytiotrophoblasts); may lead to thecal cysts in the ovary
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-f04d1577.jpeg" alt="img-163.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 13.13 Cystic teratoma.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-8e830924.jpeg" alt="img-164.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 13.14 Dysgerminoma.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-b514eba3.jpeg" alt="img-165.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 13.15 Schiller-Duval body. (Courtesy webpathology.com)</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Poor response to chemotherapy
H. Embryonal carcinoma</li>
<li>Malignant tumor composed of large primitive cells</li>
<li>Aggressive with early metastasis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-sex-cord-stromal-tumors">IV. SEX CORD-STROMAL TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-sex-cord-stromal-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Tumors that resemble sex cord-stromal tissues of the ovary
B. Granulosa-theca cell tumor</p>
<ol>
<li>Neoplastic proliferation of granulosa and theca cells</li>
<li>Often produces estrogen; presents with signs of estrogen excess
i. Prior to puberty—precocious puberty
ii. Reproductive age-menorrhagia or metrorrhagia
iii. Postmenopause (most common setting for granulosa-theca cell tumors)endometrial hyperplasia with postmenopausal uterine bleeding</li>
<li>Malignant, but minimal risk for metastasis
C. Sertoli-Leydig cell tumor</li>
<li>Composed of Sertoli cells that form tubules and Leydig cells (between tubules) with characteristic Reinke crystals</li>
<li>May produce androgen; associated with hirsutism and virilization
D. Fibroma</li>
<li>Benign tumor of fibroblasts (Fig. 13.16)</li>
<li>Associated with pleural effusions and ascites (Meigs syndrome); syndrome resolves with removal of tumor.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-metastasis">V. METASTASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-metastasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic mucinous tumor that involves both ovaries; most commonly due to metastatic gastric carcinoma (diffuse type)</p>
<ol>
<li>Bilaterality helps distinguish metastases from primary mucinous carcinoma of the ovary, which is usually unilateral.
B. Pseudomyxoma peritonei is massive amounts of mucus in the peritoneum.</li>
<li>Due to a mucinous tumor of the appendix, usually with metastasis to the ovary</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="gestational-pathology">GESTATIONAL PATHOLOGY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#gestational-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-ectopic-pregnancy">I. ECTOPIC PREGNANCY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-ectopic-pregnancy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Implantation of fertilized ovum at a site other than the uterine wall; most common site is the lumen of the fallopian tube (Fig. 13.17).
B. Key risk factor is scarring (e.g., secondary to pelvic inflammatory disease or endometriosis).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-63a00426.jpeg" alt="img-166.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 13.16 Ovarian fibroma.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-cec234bb.jpeg" alt="img-167.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 13.17 Ectopic tubal pregnancy. (Courtesy of humpath.com)</p>
<p>C. Classic presentation is lower quadrant abdominal pain a few weeks after a missed period.</p>
<ol>
<li>Surgical emergency; major complications are bleeding into fallopian tube (hematosalpinx) and rupture.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-spontaneous-abortion">II. SPONTANEOUS ABORTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-spontaneous-abortion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Miscarriage of fetus occurring before 20 weeks gestation (usually during first trimester)</p>
<ol>
<li>Common; occurs in up to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 / 4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">1/4</span></span></span></span></span> of recognizable pregnancies
B. Presents as vaginal bleeding, cramp-like pain, and passage of fetal tissues
C. Most often due to chromosomal anomalies (especially trisomy 16); other causes include hypercoagulable states (e.g., antiphospholipid syndrome), congenital infection, and exposure to teratogens (especially during the first 2 weeks of embryogenesis).</li>
<li>Effect of teratogens generally depends on the dose, agent, and time of exposure (Table 12.1).
i. First two weeks of gestation-spontaneous abortion
ii. Weeks 3-8—risk of organ malformation
iii. Months 3-9—risk of organ hypoplasia</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-placenta-previa">III. PLACENTA PREVIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-placenta-previa" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Implantation of the placenta in the lower uterine segment; placenta overlies cervical os (opening).
B. Presents as third-trimester bleeding
C. Often requires delivery of fetus by caesarian section</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-placental-abruption">IV. PLACENTAL ABRUPTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-placental-abruption" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Separation of placenta from the decidua prior to delivery of the fetus (Fig. 13.18)
B. Common cause of still birth
C. Presents with third-trimester bleeding and fetal insufficiency</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-placenta-accreta">V. PLACENTA ACCRETA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-placenta-accreta" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Improper implantation of placenta into the myometrium with little or no intervening decidua
B. Presents with difficult delivery of the placenta and postpartum bleeding</p>
<p>Table 12.1: Common Teratogens and Associated Effects</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;">TERATOGEN</th><th style="text-align: left;">EFFECT</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Alcohol</td><td style="text-align: left;">Most common cause of mental retardation; also leads to facial &lt;br&gt; abnormalities and microcephaly</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Cocaine</td><td style="text-align: left;">Intrauterine growth retardation and placental abruption</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Thalidomide</td><td style="text-align: left;">Limb defects</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Cigarette smoke</td><td style="text-align: left;">Intrauterine growth retardation</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Isotretinoin</td><td style="text-align: left;">Spontaneous abortion, hearing and visual impairment</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Tetracycline</td><td style="text-align: left;">Discolored teeth</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Warfarin</td><td style="text-align: left;">Fetal bleeding</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Phenytoin</td><td style="text-align: left;">Digit hypoplasia and cleft lip/palate</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>C. Often requires hysterectomy</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vi-preeclampsia">VI. PREECLAMPSIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-preeclampsia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Pregnancy-induced hypertension, proteinuria, and edema, usually arising in the third trimester; seen in approximately <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">5%</span></span></span></span></span> of pregnancies</p>
<ol>
<li>Hypertension may be severe, leading to headaches and visual abnormalities.
B. Due to abnormality of the maternal-fetal vascular interface in the placenta; resolves with delivery
C. Eclampsia is preeclampsia with seizures.
D. HELLP is preeclampsia with thrombotic microangiopathy involving the liver; characterized by Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelets
E. Both eclampsia and HELLP usually warrant immediate delivery.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-sudden-infant-death-syndrome">VII. SUDDEN INFANT DEATH SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-sudden-infant-death-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Death of a healthy infant ( 1 month to 1 year old) without obvious cause
B. Infants usually expire during sleep
C. Risk factors include sleeping on stomach, exposure to cigarette smoke, and prematurity.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-hydatidiform-mole">VIII.HYDATIDIFORM MOLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-hydatidiform-mole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Abnormal conception characterized by swollen and edematous villi with proliferation of trophoblasts</p>
<p>Table 12.2: Features of Complete and Partial Moles</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: left;"></th><th style="text-align: left;">PARTIAL MOLE</th><th style="text-align: left;">COMPLETE MOLE</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Genetics</td><td style="text-align: left;">Normal ovum fertilized by two &lt;br&gt; sperm (or one sperm that duplicates &lt;br&gt; chromosomes); 69 chromosomes</td><td style="text-align: left;">Empty ovum fertilized by two &lt;br&gt; sperm (or one sperm that duplicates &lt;br&gt; chromosomes); 46 chromosomes</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Fetal tissue</td><td style="text-align: left;">Present</td><td style="text-align: left;">Absent</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Villous edema</td><td style="text-align: left;">Some villi are hydropic, and some &lt;br&gt; are normal.</td><td style="text-align: left;">Most villi are hydropic (Fig. 13.19B).</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Trophoblastic &lt;br&gt; proliferation</td><td style="text-align: left;">Focal proliferation present around &lt;br&gt; hydropic villi</td><td style="text-align: left;">Diffuse, circumferential &lt;br&gt; proliferation around hydropic villi</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: left;">Risk for &lt;br&gt; choriocarcinoma</td><td style="text-align: left;">Minimal</td><td style="text-align: left;"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>3</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2-3 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">3%</span></span></span></span></span></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><img src="assets/images/image-20251213-0a1df49d.jpeg" alt="img-168.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 13.18 Placental abruption. (Courtesy of Jerome Taxy, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-b9d217c6.jpeg" alt="img-169.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 13.19 Complete mole. A, Swollen, 'grape-like' villi. B, Hydropic villi. (A, Courtesy of Steven O'Connor, MD)</p>
<p>B. Uterus expands as if a normal pregnancy is present, but the uterus is much larger and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hCG much higher than expected for date of gestation.
C. Classically presents in the second trimester as passage of grape-like masses through the vaginal canal (Fig. 13.19A).</p>
<ol>
<li>With prenatal care, moles are diagnosed by routine ultrasound in the early first trimester. Fetal heart sounds are absent, and a 'snowstorm' appearance is classically seen on ultrasound.
D. Classified as complete or partial (Table 12.2)
E. Treatment is suction curettage.</li>
<li>Subsequent <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hCG monitoring is important to ensure adequate mole removal and to screen for the development of choriocarcinoma.
i. Choriocarcinoma may arise as a complication of gestation (spontaneous abortion, normal pregnancy, or hydatidiform mole) or as a spontaneous germ cell tumor.
ii. Choriocarcinomas that arise from the gestational pathway respond well to chemotherapy; those that arise from the germ cell pathway do not.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="reminder">REMINDER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#reminder" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>Thank you for choosing Pathoma for your studies. We strive to provide the highest quality educational materials while keeping affordability in mind. A tremendous amount of time and effort has gone into developing these materials, so we appreciate your legitimate use of this program. It speaks to your integrity as a future physician and the high ethical standards that we all set forth for ourselves when taking the Hippocratic oath. Unauthorized use of Pathoma materials is contrary to the ethical standards of a training physician and is a violation of copyright. Pathoma videos are updated on a regular basis and the most current version, as well as a complete list of errata, can be accessed through your account at Pathoma.com.</p>
<p>Sincerely,
Dr. Sattar, MD</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="male-genital-system-pathology">Male Genital System Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#male-genital-system-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="penis">PENIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#penis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. HYPOSPADIAS
A. Opening of urethra on inferior surface of penis
B. Due to failure of the urethral folds to close
II. EPISPADIAS
A. Opening of urethra on superior surface of penis
B. Due to abnormal positioning of the genital tubercle
C. Associated with bladder exstrophy
III. CONDYLOMA ACUMINATUM
A. Benign warty growth on genital skin
B. Due to HPV type 6 or 11; characterized by koilocytic change (Fig. 14.1)
IV. LYMPHOGRANULOMA VENEREUM
A. Necrotizing granulomatous inflammation of the inguinal lymphatics and lymph nodes
B. Sexually transmitted disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes L1-L3)
C. Eventually heals with fibrosis; perianal involvement may result in rectal stricture.
V. SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA
A. Malignant proliferation of squamous cells of penile skin
B. Risk factors</p>
<ol>
<li>High risk HPV ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mn>3</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 / 3</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2/3</span></span></span></span></span> of cases)</li>
<li>Lack of circumcision-Foreskin acts as a nidus for inflammation and irritation if not properly maintained.
C. Precursor in situ lesions</li>
<li>Bowen disease-in situ carcinoma of the penile shaft or scrotum that presents as leukoplakia</li>
<li>Erythroplasia of Queyrat-in situ carcinoma on the glans that presents as erythroplakia</li>
<li>Bowenoid papulosis-in situ carcinoma that presents as multiple reddish papules
i. Seen in younger patients (40s) relative to Bowen disease and erythroplasia of Queyrat
ii. Does not progress to invasive carcinoma</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="testicle">TESTICLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#testicle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. CRYPTORCHIDISM
A. Failure of testicle to descend into the scrotal sac</p>
<ol>
<li>Testicles normally develop in the abdomen and then "descend" into the scrotal sac as the fetus grows.
B. Most common congenital male reproductive abnormality; seen in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span></span></span></span></span> of male infants</li>
</ol>
<p>C. Most cases resolve spontaneously; otherwise, orchiopexy is performed before 2 years of age.
D. Complications include testicular atrophy with infertility and increased risk for seminoma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-orchitis">II. ORCHITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-orchitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Inflammation of the testicle
B. Causes</p>
<ol>
<li>Chlamydia trachomatis (serotypes D-K) or Neisseria gonorrhoeae-Seen in young adults. Increased risk of sterility, but libido is not affected because Leydig cells are spared.</li>
<li>Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas-Seen in older adults; urinary tract infection pathogens spread into the reproductive tract.</li>
<li>Mumps virus (teenage males)-increased risk for infertility; testicular inflammation is usually not seen in children <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>10</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;10</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span></span></span></span></span> years old.</li>
<li>Autoimmune orchitis-characterized by granulomas involving the seminiferous tubules</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-testicular-torsion">III. TESTICULAR TORSION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-testicular-torsion" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Twisting of the spermatic cord; thin-walled veins become obstructed leading to congestion and hemorrhagic infarction (Fig. 14.2).
B. Usually due to congenital failure of testes to attach to the inner lining of the scrotum (via the processus vaginalis)
C. Presents in adolescents with sudden testicular pain and absent cremasteric reflex</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-varicocele">IV. VARICOCELE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-varicocele" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Dilation of the spermatic vein due to impaired drainage
B. Presents as scrotal swelling with a "bag of worms" appearance
C. Usually left sided; left testicular vein drains into the left renal vein, while the right testicular vein drains directly into the IVC.</p>
<ol>
<li>Associated with left-sided renal cell carcinoma; RCC often invades the renal vein.
D. Seen in a large percentage of infertile males</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-hydrocele">V. HYDROCELE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-hydrocele" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Fluid collection within the tunica vaginalis</p>
<ol>
<li>Tunica vaginalis is a serous membrane that covers the testicle as well as the internal surface of the scrotum.
B. Associated with incomplete closure of the processus vaginalis leading to communication with the peritoneal cavity (infants) or blockage of lymphatic drainage (adults)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-7ddcbba5.jpeg" alt="img-170.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 14.1 Koilocytic change.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-7b5eac12.jpeg" alt="img-171.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 14.2 Hemorrhagic infarction of testicle. (Courtesy of humpath.com)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-84e661f5.jpeg" alt="img-172.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 14.3 Hydrocele.</p>
<p>C. Presents as scrotal swelling that can be transilluminated (Fig. 14.3)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="testicular-tumors">TESTICULAR TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#testicular-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Arise from germ cells or sex cord-stroma
B. Present as a firm, painless testicular mass that cannot be transilluminated
C. Usually not biopsied due to risk of seeding the scrotum; removed via radical orchiectomy</p>
<ol>
<li>Most testicular tumors are malignant germ cell tumors.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-germ-cell-tumors">II. GERM CELL TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-germ-cell-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Most common type of testicular tumor ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>95</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;95 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">95%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases)
B. Usually occur between <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>40</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15-40</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">15</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span></span></span></span></span> years of age
C. Risk factors include cryptorchidism and Klinefelter syndrome.
D. Divided into seminoma and nonseminoma</p>
<ol>
<li>Seminomas ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>55</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">55 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">55%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases) are highly responsive to radiotherapy, metastasize late, and have an excellent prognosis.</li>
<li>Nonseminomas ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>45</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">45 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">45%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases) show variable response to treatment and often metastasize early.
E. Seminoma is a malignant tumor comprised of large cells with clear cytoplasm and central nuclei (resemble spermatogonia, Fig. 14.4A); forms a homogeneous mass with no hemorrhage or necrosis (Fig. 14.4B)</li>
<li>Most common testicular tumor; resembles ovarian dysgerminoma</li>
<li>Rare cases may produce <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hCG.</li>
<li>Good prognosis; responds to radiotherapy
F. Embryonal carcinoma is a malignant tumor comprised of immature, primitive cells that may produce glands (Fig. 14.5A); forms a hemorrhagic mass with necrosis (Fig. 14.5B)</li>
<li>Aggressive with early hematogenous spread</li>
<li>Chemotherapy may result in differentiation into another type of germ cell tumor (e.g., teratoma).</li>
<li>Increased AFP or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hCG may be present.
G. Yolk sac (endodermal sinus) tumor is a malignant tumor that resembles yolk sac elements.</li>
<li>Most common testicular tumor in children</li>
<li>Schiller-Duval bodies (glomerulus-like structures) are seen on histology (Fig. 14.6).</li>
<li>AFP is characteristically elevated.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-9dbee576.jpeg" alt="img-173.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 14.4 Seminoma. A, Microscopic appearance. B, Gross appearance. (A, Courtesy of Ed Uthman, MD)</p>
<p>H. Choriocarcinoma is a malignant tumor of syncytiotrophoblasts and cytotrophoblasts (placenta-like tissue, but villi are absent, Fig. 14.7).</p>
<ol>
<li>Spreads early via blood</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hCG is characteristically elevated; may lead to hyperthyroidism or gynecomastia ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>-subunit of hCG is similar to that of FSH, LH, and TSH)
I. Teratoma is a tumor composed of mature fetal tissue derived from two or three embryonic layers.</li>
<li>Malignant in males (as opposed to females)</li>
<li>AFP or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hCG may be increased.
J. Mixed germ cell tumors</li>
<li>Germ cell tumors are usually mixed.</li>
<li>Prognosis is based on the worst component.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-sex-cord-stromal-tumors">III. SEX CORD-STROMAL TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-sex-cord-stromal-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Tumors that resemble sex cord-stromal tissues of the testicle (Fig. 14.8); usually benign
B. Leydig cell tumor usually produces androgen, causing precocious puberty in children or gynecomastia in adults.</p>
<ol>
<li>Characteristic Reinke crystals may be seen on histology.
C. Sertoli cell tumor is comprised of tubules and is usually clinically silent.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-lymphoma">IV. LYMPHOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-lymphoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Most common cause of a testicular mass in males <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>60</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;60</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span></span></span></span></span> years old; often bilateral
B. Usually of diffuse large B-cell type
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6a9a65e6.jpeg" alt="img-174.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 14.5 Embryonal carcinoma. A, Microscopic appearance. B, Gross appearance. (Courtesy of webpathology.com)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-9604b8d7.jpeg" alt="img-175.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 14.6 Schiller-Duval body, yolk sac tumor. (Courtesy of webpathology.com)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-aa4d0951.jpeg" alt="img-176.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 14.7 Choriocarcinoma. (Courtesy of webpathology.com)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-b75eaf8f.jpeg" alt="img-177.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 14.8 Normal testicle, microscopic appearance.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="prostate">PROSTATE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#prostate" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Small, round organ that lies at the base of the bladder encircling the urethra
B. Sits anterior to the rectum; posterior aspect of prostate is palpable by digital rectal exam (DRE).
C. Consists of glands and stroma (Fig. 14.9)</p>
<ol>
<li>Glands are composed of an inner layer of luminal cells and an outer layer of basal cells; secrete alkaline, milky fluid that is added to sperm and seminal vesicle fluid to make semen.</li>
<li>Glands and stroma are maintained by androgens.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-acute-prostatitis">II. ACUTE PROSTATITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-acute-prostatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Acute inflammation of the prostate; usually due to bacteria</p>
<ol>
<li>Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae are common causes in young adults.</li>
<li>Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas are common causes in older adults.
B. Presents as dysuria with fever and chills
C. Prostate is tender and boggy on digital rectal exam.
D. Prostatic secretions show WBCs; culture reveals bacteria.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-chronic-prostatitis">III. CHRONIC PROSTATITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-chronic-prostatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Chronic inflammation of prostate
B. Presents as dysuria with pelvic or low back pain
C. Prostatic secretions show WBCs, but cultures are negative.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-benign-prostatic-hyperplasia-bph">IV. BENIGN PROSTATIC HYPERPLASIA (BPH)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-benign-prostatic-hyperplasia-bph" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Hyperplasia of prostatic stroma and glands
B. Age-related change (present in most men by the age of 60 years); no increased risk for cancer
C. Related to dihydrotestosterone (DHT)</p>
<ol>
<li>Testosterone is converted to DHT by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5 \alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>-reductase in stromal cells.</li>
<li>DHT acts on the androgen receptor of stromal and epithelial cells resulting in hyperplastic nodules.
D. Occurs in the central periurethral zone of the prostate
E. Clinical features include</li>
<li>Problems starting and stopping urine stream</li>
<li>Impaired bladder emptying with increased risk for infection and hydronephrosis (Fig. 14.10)</li>
<li>Dribbling
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-c0099e36.jpeg" alt="img-178.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 14.9 Normal prostate, microscopic appearance.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-0515f16f.jpeg" alt="img-179.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 14.10 Hydronephrosis.</p>
<ol start="4">
<li>Hypertrophy of bladder wall smooth muscle; increased risk for bladder diverticula</li>
<li>Microscopic hematuria may be present.</li>
<li>Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) is often slightly elevated (usually less than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \mathrm{ng} /</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">ng</span></span><span class="mord">/</span></span></span></span></span> mL ) due to the increased number of glands; PSA is made by prostatic glands and liquefies semen.
F. Treatment</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha_{1}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5806em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0037em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>-antagonist (e.g., terazosin) to relax smooth muscle
i. Also relaxes vascular smooth muscle lowering blood pressure
ii. Selective <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>α</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi>A</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha_{1 A}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5806em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0037em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight">A</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>-antagonists (e.g., tamsulosin) are used in normotensive individuals to avoid <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mi>α</mi><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi>B</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha_{1 B}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5806em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3283em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-left: -0.0037em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">1</span><span class="mord mathnormal mtight" style="margin-right: 0.05017em;">B</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> effects on blood vessels.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>5</mn><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">5 \alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">5</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>-reductase inhibitor
i. Blocks conversion of testosterone to DHT
ii. Takes months to produce results
iii. Also useful for male pattern baldness
iv. Side effects are gynecomastia and sexual dysfunction.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="v-prostate-adenocarcinoma">V. PROSTATE ADENOCARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-prostate-adenocarcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of prostatic glands
B. Most common cancer in men; 2nd most common cause of cancer-related death
C. Risk factors include age, race (African Americans &gt; Caucasians &gt; Asians), and diet high in saturated fats.
D. Prostatic carcinoma is most often clinically silent.</p>
<ol>
<li>Usually arises in the peripheral, posterior region of the prostate and, hence, does not produce urinary symptoms early on (Fig. 14.11A)</li>
<li>Screening begins at the age of 50 years with DRE and PSA.
i. Normal serum PSA increases with age due to BPH <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(2.5 \mathrm{ng} / \mathrm{mL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">2.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">ng</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span></span></span></span></span> for ages <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>40</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>49</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">40-49</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">49</span></span></span></span></span> years vs. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>7.5</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">7.5 \mathrm{ng} / \mathrm{mL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">7.5</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">ng</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span></span></span></span></span> for ages <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>79</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70-79</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7278em; vertical-align: -0.0833em;"></span><span class="mord">70</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">79</span></span></span></span></span> years)
ii. PSA <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>10</mn><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">n</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">g</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">/</mi><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;10 \mathrm{ng} / \mathrm{mL}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm" style="margin-right: 0.01389em;">ng</span></span><span class="mord">/</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">mL</span></span></span></span></span></span> is highly worrisome at any age.
iii. Decreased % free-PSA is suggestive of cancer (cancer makes bound PSA).
E. Prostatic biopsy is required to confirm the presence of carcinoma.</li>
<li>Shows small, invasive glands with prominent nucleoli (Fig. 14.11B)</li>
<li>Gleason grading system is based on architecture alone (and not nuclear atypia).
i. Multiple regions of the tumor are assessed because architecture varies from area to area.
ii. A score (1-5) is assigned for two distinct areas and then added to produce a final score (2-10).
iii. Higher score suggests worse prognosis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-d74842fc.jpeg" alt="img-180.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 14.11 Prostatic adenocarcinoma. A, Gross appearance. B, Microscopic appearance. C, Osteoblastic metastasis involving lumbar spine.</p>
<p>F. Spread to lumbar spine or pelvis is common (Fig. 14.11C); results in osteoblastic metastases that present as low back pain and increased serum alkaline phosphatase, PSA, and prostatic acid phosphatase (PAP)
G. Prostatectomy is performed for localized disease; advanced disease is treated with hormone suppression to reduce testosterone and DHT.</p>
<ol>
<li>Continuous GnRH analogs (e.g., leuprolide) shut down the anterior pituitary gonadotrophs (LH and FSH are reduced).</li>
<li>Flutamide acts as a competitive inhibitor at the androgen receptor.</li>
</ol>
<p>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="endocrine-pathology">Endocrine Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#endocrine-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. ENDOCRINE SYSTEM
A. Group of glands that maintain body homeostasis
B. Functions by release of hormones that travel via blood to distant organs
C. "Feedback" mechanisms control hormone release.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="anterior-pituitary-gland">ANTERIOR PITUITARY GLAND<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#anterior-pituitary-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. PITUITARY ADENOMA
A. Benign tumor of anterior pituitary cells
B. May be functional (hormone-producing) or nonfunctional (silent)</p>
<ol>
<li>Nonfunctional tumors often present with mass effect.
i. Bitemporal hemianopsia occurs due to compression of the optic chiasm.
ii. Hypopituitarism occurs due to compression of normal pituitary tissue.
iii. Headache</li>
<li>Functional tumors present with features based on the type of hormone produced.
C. Prolactinoma presents as galactorrhea and amenorrhea (females) or as decreased libido and headache (males); most common type of pituitary adenoma</li>
<li>Treatment is dopamine agonists (e.g., bromocriptine or cabergoline) to suppress prolactin production (shrinks tumor) or surgery for larger lesions.
D. Growth hormone cell adenoma</li>
<li>Gigantism in children-increased linear bone growth (epiphyses are not fused)</li>
<li>Acromegaly in adults
i. Enlarged bones of hands, feet, and jaw
ii. Growth of visceral organs leading to dysfunction (e.g., cardiac failure)
iii. Enlarged tongue</li>
<li>Secondary diabetes mellitus is often present (GH induces liver gluconeogenesis).</li>
<li>Diagnosed by elevated GH and insulin growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels along with lack of GH suppression by oral glucose</li>
<li>Treatment is octreotide (somatostatin analog that suppresses GH release), GH receptor antagonists, or surgery.
E. ACTH cell adenomas secrete ACTH leading to Cushing syndrome (see "Adrenal Cortex" below).
F. TSH cell, LH-producing, and FSH-producing adenomas occur, but are rare.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-hypopituitarism">II. HYPOPITUITARISM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-hypopituitarism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Insufficient production of hormones by the anterior pituitary gland; symptoms arise when <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>75</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;75 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">75%</span></span></span></span></span> of the pituitary parenchyma is lost.
B. Causes include</p>
<ol>
<li>Pituitary adenomas (adults) or craniopharyngioma (children)—due to mass effect or pituitary apoplexy (bleeding into an adenoma)</li>
<li>Sheehan syndrome-pregnancy-related infarction of the pituitary gland
i. Gland doubles in size during pregnancy, but blood supply does not increase significantly; blood loss during parturition precipitates infarction.</li>
</ol>
<p>ii. Presents as poor lactation, loss of pubic hair, and fatigue
3. Empty sella syndrome-congenital defect of the sella
i. Herniation of the arachnoid and CSF into the sella compresses and destroys the pituitary gland.
ii. Pituitary gland is "absent" (empty sella) on imaging.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="posterior-pituitary-gland">POSTERIOR PITUITARY GLAND<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#posterior-pituitary-gland" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I. BASIC PRINCIPLES
A. Antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and oxytocin are made in the hypothalamus and then transported via axons to the posterior pituitary for release.</p>
<ol>
<li>ADH acts on the distal tubules and collecting ducts of the kidney to promote free water retention.</li>
<li>Oxytocin mediates uterine contraction during labor and release of breast milk (let-down) in lactating mothers.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-central-diabetes-insipidus">II. CENTRAL DIABETES INSIPIDUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-central-diabetes-insipidus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. ADH deficiency
B. Due to hypothalamic or posterior pituitary pathology (e.g., tumor, trauma, infection, or inflammation)
C. Clinical features are based on loss of free water.</p>
<ol>
<li>Polyuria and polydipsia with risk of life-threatening dehydration</li>
<li>Hypernatremia and high serum osmolality</li>
<li>Low urine osmolality and specific gravity
D. Water deprivation test fails to increase urine osmolality (useful for diagnosis).
E. Treatment is desmopressin (ADH analog).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-nephrogenic-diabetes-insipidus">III.
