<li>Secondary is characterized by high renin; edema is often present.
F. Glucocorticoid-remediable aldosteronism (GRA) leads to familial hyperaldosteronism</li>
<li>Aberrant expression of aldosterone synthase in the fasciculata due to genetic mutation; autosomal dominant</li>
<li>Classically presents as child with HTN and hypokalemia; aldosterone is high and renin is low.</li>
<li>Responds to dexamethasone; confirmed with genetic testing
G. Liddle syndrome mimics hyperaldosteronism.</li>
<li>Decreased degradation of sodium channels in collecting tubules due to genetic mutation; autosomal dominant</li>
<li>Presents as child with HTN, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, but with low aldosterone and low renin</li>
<li>Diagnosed by genetic testing</li>
<li>Treatment is potassium-sparing diuretics (e.g., amiloride or triamterene), which block tubular sodium channels; spironolactone is not effective.
H. Syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess (SAME) also mimics hyperaldosteronism.</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>11</mn><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">11 \beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">11</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>11</mn><mi>β</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>H</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>D</mi><mn>2</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2(11 \beta-H S D 2)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">11</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span><span class="mbin">−</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2222em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.02778em;">D</span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> deficiency allows cortisol to activate renal aldosterone receptors; autosomal recessive</li>
<li>Presents as child with HTN, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis, but with low aldosterone and low renin</li>
<li>Diagnosed by low urinary free cortisone and genetic testing</li>
<li>May also arise with licorice (glycyrrhetinic acid), which blocks <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>11</mn><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">11 \beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord">11</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-HSD2</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-hypercortisolism-cushing-syndrome">III. HYPERCORTISOLISM (CUSHING SYNDROME)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-hypercortisolism-cushing-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Excess cortisol
B. Clinical features include</p>
<ol>
<li>Muscle weakness with thin extremities-Cortisol breaks down muscle to produce amino acids for gluconeogenesis.</li>
<li>Moon facies, buffalo hump, and truncal obesity-High insulin (due to high glucose) increases storage of fat centrally.</li>
<li>Abdominal striae-Impaired collagen synthesis results in thinning of skin</li>
<li>HTN often with hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis
i. High cortisol increases sensitivity of peripheral vessels to catecholamines.
ii. At very high levels, cortisol cross-reacts with mineralocorticoid receptors (aldosterone is not increased).</li>
<li>Osteoporosis</li>
<li>Immune suppression
C. Diagnosis is based on 24 -hour urine cortisol level (increased), late night salivary cortisol level (increased), and low-dose dexamethasone suppression test.</li>
<li>Low-dose dexamethasone suppresses cortisol in normal individuals but fails to suppress cortisol in all causes of Cushing syndrome.
D. Plasma ACTH distinguishes ACTH-dependent causes of Cushing syndrome from ACTH-independent causes (table 15.1).</li>
<li>If ACTH-independent, next step is CT to look for an adrenal lesion.</li>
<li>If ACTH-dependent, next step is high-dose dexamethasone test.
E. High-dose dexamethasone suppresses ACTH production by a pituitary adenoma (serum cortisol is lowered) but does not suppress ectopic ACTH production (serum cortisol remains high).</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 15.1 Cushing Syndrome</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">CAUSE</th><th style="text-align: center;">ACTH</th><th style="text-align: center;">HIGH-DOSE &lt;br&gt; DEXAMETHASONE</th><th style="text-align: center;">IMAGING</th><th style="text-align: center;">TREATMENT</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Exogenous glucocorticoids (most common iatrogenic cause)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Low</td><td style="text-align: center;">N/A</td><td style="text-align: center;">N/A</td><td style="text-align: center;">Tapering of steroids, if possible</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>70</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">70 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">70%</span></span></span></span></span>, Cushing disease)</td><td style="text-align: center;">High ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> ); androgen excess may be present.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Suppression</td><td style="text-align: center;">Pituitary adenoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Transsphenoidal resection of pituitary adenoma; bilateral adrenalectomy in refractory cases can lead to enlargement of pituitary adenoma, resulting in hyperpigmentation, headaches, and bitemporal hemianopsia (Nelson syndrome)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Ectopic ACTH secretion (15%)</td><td style="text-align: center;">High ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow \uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑↑</span></span></span></span></span> ); androgen excess and hyperpigmentation may be present.</td><td style="text-align: center;">No suppression</td><td style="text-align: center;">Ectopic source of ACTH (e.g., small cell carcinoma or carcinoid)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Resection of ectopic source</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Primary adrenal adenoma ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> ), hyperplasia, or carcinoma</td><td style="text-align: center;">Low</td><td style="text-align: center;">N/A</td><td style="text-align: center;">Adenoma/ carcinoma with contralateral atrophy or bilateral nodular hyperplasia</td><td style="text-align: center;">Resection of adenoma/carcinoma or bilateral resection of hyperplasia with hormone replacement</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>F. Treatment generally involves surgical resection</p>
<ol>
<li>Ketoconazole or metyrapone useful if surgery is not an option</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-congenital-adrenal-hyperplasia">IV. CONGENITAL ADRENAL HYPERPLASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-congenital-adrenal-hyperplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Due to enzymatic defects in cortisol production; autosomal recessive</p>
<ol>
<li>
<p>High ACTH (decreased negative feedback) leads to bilateral adrenal hyperplasia.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Mineralocorticoids and androgens may be increased or decreased depending on the enzyme defect.
B. 21-hydroxylase deficiency is the most common cause ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Aldosterone and cortisol are decreased; steroidogenesis is shunted towards androgens.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Classic form presents in neonates as hyponatremia and hyperkalemia with lifethreatening hypotension (salt-wasting type); females have clitoral enlargement (genital ambiguity).</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Nonclassic form presents later in life with androgen excess leading to precocious puberty (males) or hirsutism with menstrual irregularities (females).
C. 11-hydroxylase deficiency also leads to androgen excess, but weak mineralocorticoids (DOC) are increased.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Deoxycorticosterone (DOC) leads to HTN (sodium retention) with mild hypokalemia; renin and aldosterone are low.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Clitoral enlargement is seen in females
D. 17-hydroxylase deficiency leads to decreased cortisol and androgens.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Weak mineralocorticoids (DOC) are increased leading to HTN with mild hypokalemia; renin and aldosterone are low.</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decreased androgens lead to primary amenorrhea and lack of pubic hair (females) or ambiguous genitalia with undescended testes (males).
E. Newborn screening for CAH via serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone is routine</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Increased in 21- and 11-hydroxylase deficiency</p>
</li>
<li>
<p>Decreased in 17-hydroxylase deficiency
F. Treatment for CAH is glucocorticoids; mineralocorticoids (21-hydroxylase deficiency) or sex steroids (17-hydroxylase deficiency) given as necessary.</p>
</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="v-adrenal-insufficiency">V. ADRENAL INSUFFICIENCY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-adrenal-insufficiency" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Deficiency of adrenal hormones
B. Acute insufficiency presents as weakness and shock. Causes include</p>
<ol>
<li>Abrupt withdrawal of glucocorticoids</li>
<li>Treatment of Cushing syndrome</li>
<li>Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome-hemorrhagic necrosis of the adrenal glands (Fig. 15.17), classically due to sepsis and DIC in young children with Neisseria meningitidis infection
C. Chronic insufficiency (Addison disease) presents with vague, progressive symptoms such as hypotension, weakness, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.
D. Addison disease most often arises with progressive adrenal damage.</li>
<li>Common causes include autoimmune destruction (most common cause in the West), TB (most common cause in the developing world), and metastatic carcinoma (e.g., from lung).</li>
<li>Autoimmune adrenalitis can be a component of autoimmune polyendocrine syndromes
E. Addison disease may also arise with pituitary (secondary) or hypothalamic (tertiary) disease.</li>
<li>Hyperpigmentation (high ACTH) and hyperkalemia (low aldosterone) suggest primary adrenal insufficiency; secondary/tertiary insufficiency has no hyperpigmentation (low ACTH) and normal potassium (normal aldosterone).</li>
<li>Lack of ACTH response with metyrapone stimulation test supports a secondary or tertiary cause.</li>
<li>ACTH response with CRH stimulation test suggests hypothalamic (tertiary) disease.
F. Treatment is glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoids.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="adrenal-medulla">ADRENAL MEDULLA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#adrenal-medulla" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Composed of neural crest-derived chromaffin cells
B. Main physiologic source of catecholamines (epinephrine and norepinephrine)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-pheochromocytoma">II. PHEOCHROMOCYTOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-pheochromocytoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Tumor of chromaffin cells (Fig. 15.18)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6978711a.jpeg" alt="img-191.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 15.17 Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome. (Courtesy of humpath.com)
Fig. 15.18 Pheochromocytoma. (Courtesy of humpath.com)</p>
<p>B. Clinical features are due to episodic release of catecholamines.</p>
<ol>
<li>Episodic HTN, headaches, palpitations, tachycardia, and sweating
C. Diagnosed by increased metanephrines and catecholamines in serum and urine
D. Treatment is adrenalectomy.</li>
<li>Catecholamines may leak into the bloodstream upon manipulation of the tumor.</li>
<li>Phenoxybenzamine (irreversible <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>-blocker) followed by <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-blocker is administered preoperatively to prevent a hypertensive crisis.
E. Often follows the 'rule of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mrow><mo>:</mo><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \mathrm{~s}: 10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">10</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">s</span></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span><span class="mrel">:</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> bilateral, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> familial, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> malignant, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> located outside of the adrenal medulla (e.g., organ of Zuckerkandl at the inferior mesenteric artery root or bladder wall)</li>
<li>Malignancy is defined by metastatic spread; patients require long-term follow-up
F. Associated with MEN 2A and 2B (RET), von Hippel-Lindau disease, and neurofibromatosis type 1</li>
</ol>
<p>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="breast-pathology">Breast Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#breast-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-breast">I. BREAST<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-breast" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Modified sweat gland embryologically derived from the skin</p>
<ol>
<li>Breast tissue can develop anywhere along the milk line, which runs from the axilla to the vulva (e.g., supernumerary nipples).
B. The terminal duct lobular unit is the functional unit of the breast (Fig. 16.1); lobules make milk that drains via ducts to the nipple.
C. Lobules and ducts are lined by two layers of epithelium.</li>
<li>Luminal cell layer-inner cell layer lining the ducts and lobules; responsible for milk production in the lobules</li>
<li>Myoepithelial cell layer-outer cell layer lining ducts and lobules; contractile function propels milk towards the nipple.
D. Breast tissue is hormone sensitive.</li>
<li>Before puberty, male and female breast tissue primarily consists of large ducts under the nipple.</li>
<li>Development after menarche is primarily driven by estrogen and progesterone; lobules and small ducts form and are present in highest density in the upper outer quadrant.</li>
<li>Breast tenderness during the menstrual cycle is a common complaint, especially prior to menstruation.</li>
<li>During pregnancy, breast lobules undergo hyperplasia.
i. Hyperplasia is driven by estrogen and progesterone produced by the corpus luteum (early first trimester), fetus, and placenta (later in pregnancy)</li>
<li>After menopause, breast tissue undergoes atrophy.
E. Galactorrhea refers to milk production outside of lactation.</li>
<li>It is not a symptom of breast cancer.</li>
<li>Causes include nipple stimulation (common physiologic cause), prolactinoma of the anterior pituitary (common pathologic cause), and drugs.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inflammatory-conditions">INFLAMMATORY CONDITIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inflammatory-conditions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-acute-mastitis">I. ACUTE MASTITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-acute-mastitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Bacterial infection of the breast, usually due to Staphylococcus aureus
B. Associated with breast-feeding; fissures develop in the nipple providing a route of entry for microbes.
C. Presents as an erythematous breast with purulent nipple discharge; may progress to abscess formation
D. Treatment involves continued drainage (e.g., feeding) and antibiotics (e.g., dicloxacillin).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-periductal-mastitis">II. PERIDUCTAL MASTITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-periductal-mastitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inflammation of the subareolar ducts
B. Usually seen in smokers</p>
<ol>
<li>Relative vitamin A deficiency results in squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts, producing duct blockage and inflammation.
C. Clinically presents as a subareolar mass with nipple retraction</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-mammary-duct-ectasia">III. MAMMARY DUCT ECTASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-mammary-duct-ectasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Inflammation with dilation (ectasia) of the subareolar ducts</p>
<ol>
<li>Rare; classically arises in multiparous postmenopausal women
B. Presents as a periareolar mass with green-brown nipple discharge (inflammatory debris)</li>
<li>Chronic inflammation with plasma cells is seen on biopsy.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-fat-necrosis">IV. FAT NECROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-fat-necrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Necrosis of breast fat
B. Usually related to trauma; however, a history of trauma may not always be evident.
C. Presents as a mass on physical exam or abnormal calcification on mammography (due to saponification)
D. Biopsy shows necrotic fat with associated calcifications and giant cells.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="benign-tumors-and-fibrocystic-changes">BENIGN TUMORS AND FIBROCYSTIC CHANGES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#benign-tumors-and-fibrocystic-changes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-fibrocystic-change">I. FIBROCYSTIC CHANGE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-fibrocystic-change" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Development of fibrosis and cysts in the breast</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common change in the premenopausal breast; thought to be hormone mediated
B. Presents as vague irregularity of the breast tissue ('lumpy breast'), usually in the upper outer quadrant
C. Cysts have a blue-dome appearance on gross exam.
D. Benign, but some fibrocystic-related changes are associated with an increased risk for invasive carcinoma (increased risk applies to both breasts)</li>
<li>Fibrosis, cysts, and apocrine metaplasia (Fig. 16.2)—no increased risk</li>
<li>Ductal hyperplasia and sclerosing adenosis-2x increased risk</li>
<li>Atypical hyperplasia-5x increased risk</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-intraductal-papilloma">II. INTRADUCTAL PAPILLOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-intraductal-papilloma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Papillary growth, usually into a large duct
B. Characterized by fibrovascular projections lined by epithelial (luminal) and myoepithelial cells
C. Classically presents as bloody nipple discharge in a premenopausal woman
D. Must be distinguished from papillary carcinoma, which also presents as bloody nipple discharge
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6d91a645.jpeg" alt="img-192.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.1 Terminal duct lobular unit.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-99c14e86.jpeg" alt="img-193.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.2 Fibrocystic change with apocrine metaplasia.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-bd5e5bc7.jpeg" alt="img-194.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.3 Fibroadenoma.</p>
<ol>
<li>Papillary carcinoma is characterized by fibrovascular projections lined by epithelial cells without underlying myoepithelial cells.</li>
<li>Risk of papillary carcinoma increases with age; thus, it is more commonly seen in postmenopausal women.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-fibroadenoma">III. FIBROADENOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-fibroadenoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Tumor of fibrous tissue and glands (Fig. 16.3)
B. Most common benign neoplasm of the breast; usually seen in premenopausal women
C. Presents as a well-circumscribed, mobile marble-like mass
D. Estrogen sensitive-grows during pregnancy and may be painful during the menstrual cycle
E. Benign, with no increased risk of carcinoma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-phyllodes-tumor">IV. PHYLLODES TUMOR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-phyllodes-tumor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Fibroadenoma-like tumor with overgrowth of the fibrous component; characteristic 'leaf-like' projections are seen on biopsy (Fig. 16.4).
B. Most commonly seen in postmenopausal women
C. Can be malignant in some cases</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="breast-cancer">BREAST CANCER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#breast-cancer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Most common carcinoma in women by incidence (excluding skin cancer)
B. 2nd most common cause of cancer mortality in women
C. Risk factors are mostly related to estrogen exposure.</p>
<ol>
<li>Female gender</li>
<li>Age-Cancer usually arises in postmenopausal women, with the notable exception of hereditary breast cancer.</li>
<li>Early menarche/late menopause</li>
<li>Obesity</li>
<li>Atypical hyperplasia</li>
<li>First-degree relative (mother, sister, or daughter) with breast cancer</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-ductal-carcinoma-in-situ-dcis">II. DUCTAL CARCINOMA IN SITU (DCIS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-ductal-carcinoma-in-situ-dcis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of cells in ducts with no invasion of the basement membrane
B. Often detected as calcification on mammography; DCIS does not usually produce a mass.</p>
<ol>
<li>Mammographic calcifications can also be associated with benign conditions such as fibrocystic changes (especially sclerosing adenosis) and fat necrosis.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-c3f9ebf6.jpeg" alt="img-195.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 16.4 Phyllodes tumor.
Fig. 16.5 Ductal carcinoma in situ, comedo type.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Biopsy of calcifications is often necessary to distinguish between benign and malignant conditions.
C. Histologic subtypes are based on architecture; comedo type is characterized by high-grade cells with necrosis and dystrophic calcification in the center of ducts (Fig. 16.5).
D. Paget disease of the breast is DCIS that extends up the ducts to involve the skin of the nipple (Fig. 16.6).</li>
<li>Presents as nipple ulceration and erythema</li>
<li>Paget disease of the breast is almost always associated with an underlying carcinoma.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-invasive-ductal-carcinoma">III. INVASIVE DUCTAL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-invasive-ductal-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Invasive carcinoma that classically forms duct-like structures
B. Most common type of invasive carcinoma in the breast, accounting for <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>80</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;80 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">80%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases
C. Presents as a mass detected by physical exam or by mammography</p>
<ol>
<li>Clinically detected masses are usually 2 cm or greater.</li>
<li>Mammographically detected masses are usually 1 cm or greater.</li>
<li>Advanced tumors may result in dimpling of the skin or retraction of the nipple.
D. Biopsy usually shows duct-like structures in a desmoplastic stroma; special subtypes of invasive ductal carcinoma include</li>
<li>Tubular carcinoma-characterized by well-differentiated tubules that lack myoepithelial cells (Fig. 16.7A); relatively good prognosis</li>
<li>Mucinous carcinoma-characterized by carcinoma with abundant extracellular mucin ('tumor cells floating in a mucus pool', Fig. 16.7B)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6b159ecb.jpeg" alt="img-196.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 16.6 Paget disease of the nipple. A, Clinical appearance. B, Microscopic appearance. (A, Courtesy of Jerome Taxy, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-2fd7cfc3.jpeg" alt="img-197.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.7 Invasive ductal carcinoma. A, Tubular carcinoma. B, Mucinous carcinoma.</p>
<p>i. Tends to occur in older women (average age is 70 years)
ii. Relatively good prognosis
3. Medullary carcinoma-characterized by large, high-grade cells growing in sheets with associated lymphocytes and plasma cells
i. Grows as a well-circumscribed mass that can mimic fibroadenoma on mammography
ii. Relatively good prognosis
iii. Increased incidence in BRCA1 carriers
4. Inflammatory carcinoma-characterized by carcinoma in dermal lymphatics (Fig. 16.8)
i. Presents classically as an inflamed, swollen breast (tumor cells block drainage of lymphatics) with no discrete mass; can be mistaken for acute mastitis
ii. Poor prognosis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-lobular-carcinoma-in-situ-lcis">IV. LOBULAR CARCINOMA IN SITU (LCIS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-lobular-carcinoma-in-situ-lcis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of cells in lobules with no invasion of the basement membrane
B. LCIS does not produce a mass or calcifications and is usually discovered incidentally on biopsy.
C. Characterized by dyscohesive cells lacking E-cadherin adhesion protein
D. Often multifocal and bilateral
E. Treatment is tamoxifen (to reduce the risk of subsequent carcinoma) and close follow-up; low risk of progression to invasive carcinoma</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-invasive-lobular-carcinoma">V. INVASIVE LOBULAR CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-invasive-lobular-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Invasive carcinoma that characteristically grows in a single-file pattern (Fig. 16.9); cells may exhibit signet-ring morphology.</p>
<ol>
<li>No duct formation due to lack of E-cadherin.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-prognostic-and-predictive-factors">VI. PROGNOSTIC AND PREDICTIVE FACTORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-prognostic-and-predictive-factors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Prognosis in breast cancer is based on TNM staging.</p>
<ol>
<li>Metastasis is the most important factor, but most patients present before metastasis occurs.</li>
<li>Spread to axillary lymph nodes is the most useful prognostic factor (given that metastasis is not common at presentation); sentinel lymph node biopsy is used to assess axillary lymph nodes.
B. Predictive factors predict response to treatment.</li>
<li>Most important factors are estrogen receptor (ER), progesterone receptor (PR), and HER2/neu gene amplification (overexpression) status.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-b1d7eeb1.jpeg" alt="img-198.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 16.8 Inflammatory carcinoma. A, Microscopic appearance. B, Clinical appearance. (B, Courtesy of Fig. 16.9 Invasive lobular carcinoma. Jerome Taxy, MD)</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Presence of ER and PR is associated with response to antiestrogenic agents (e.g., tamoxifen); both receptors are located in the nucleus (Fig. 16.10).</li>
<li>HER2/neu amplification is associated with response to trastuzumab (Herceptin), a designer antibody directed against the HER2 receptor; HER2/neu is a growth factor receptor present on the cell surface (Fig. 16.11).</li>
<li>'Triple-negative' tumors are negative for ER, PR, and HER2/neu and have a poor prognosis; African American women have an increased propensity to develop triple-negative carcinoma.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vii-hereditary-breast-cancer">VII. HEREDITARY BREAST CANCER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-hereditary-breast-cancer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Represents <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of breast cancer cases
B. Clinical features that suggest hereditary breast cancer include multiple first-degree relatives with breast cancer, tumor at an early age (premenopausal), and multiple tumors in a single patient.
C. BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutations are the most important single gene mutations associated with hereditary breast cancer.</p>
<ol>
<li>BRCA1 mutation is associated with breast and ovarian carcinoma.</li>
<li>BRCA2 mutation is associated with breast carcinoma in males.
D. Women with a genetic propensity to develop breast cancer may choose to undergo removal of both breasts (bilateral mastectomy) to decrease the risk of developing carcinoma.</li>
<li>A small risk for cancer remains because breast tissue sometimes extends into the axilla or subcutaneous tissue of the chest wall.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-male-breast-cancer">VIII.MALE BREAST CANCER<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-male-breast-cancer" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Breast cancer is rare in males (represents <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span></span></span></span></span> of all breast cancers).
B. Usually presents as a subareolar mass in older males</p>
<ol>
<li>Highest density of breast tissue in males is underneath the nipple.</li>
<li>May produce nipple discharge
C. Most common histological subtype is invasive ductal carcinoma.</li>
<li>Lobular carcinoma is rare (the male breast develops very few lobules).
D. Associated with BRCA2 mutations and Klinefelter syndrome
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5e2cba56.jpeg" alt="img-199.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 16.10 Estrogen receptor, immunohistochemical stain.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-898af3cd.jpeg" alt="img-200.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 16.11 HER2/neu amplification, immunohistochemical stain.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="central-nervous-system-pathology">Central Nervous System Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#central-nervous-system-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="developmental-anomalies">DEVELOPMENTAL ANOMALIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#developmental-anomalies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-neural-tube-defects">I. NEURAL TUBE DEFECTS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-neural-tube-defects" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Arise from incomplete closure of the neural tube</p>
<ol>
<li>Neural plate invaginates early in gestation to form the neural tube, which runs along the cranial-caudal axis of the embryo.</li>
<li>The wall of the neural tube forms central nervous system tissue, the hollow lumen forms the ventricles and spinal cord canal, and the neural crest forms the peripheral nervous system.
B. Associated with low folate levels prior to conception
C. Detected during prenatal care by elevated alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) levels in the amniotic fluid and maternal blood
D. Anencephaly is absence of the skull and brain (disruption of the cranial end of the neural tube).</li>
<li>Leads to a 'frog-like' appearance of the fetus (Fig. 17.1)</li>
<li>Results in maternal polyhydramnios since fetal swallowing of amniotic fluid is impaired
E. Spina bifida is failure of the posterior vertebral arch to close, resulting in a vertebral defect (disruption of the caudal end of the neural tube).</li>
<li>Spina bifida occulta presents as a dimple or patch of hair overlying the vertebral defect.</li>
<li>Spina bifida presents with cystic protrusion of the underlying tissue through the vertebral defect.
i. Meningocele-protrusion of meninges
ii. Meningomyelocele-protrusion of meninges and spinal cord</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-cerebral-aqueduct-stenosis">II. CEREBRAL AQUEDUCT STENOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-cerebral-aqueduct-stenosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Congenital stenosis of the channel that drains cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the 3rd ventricle into the 4 th ventricle
B. Leads to accumulation of CSF in the ventricular space; most common cause of hydrocephalus in newborns</p>
<ol>
<li>CSF is produced by the choroid plexus lining the ventricles.</li>
<li>Flows from the lateral ventricles into the 3rd ventricle via the interventricular foramen of Monro</li>
<li>Flows from the 3rd ventricle into the 4th ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct</li>
<li>Flows from the 4th ventricle into the subarachnoid space via the foramina of Magendie and Luschka
C. Presents with enlarging head circumference due to dilation of the ventricles (cranial suture lines are not fused)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-dandy-walker-malformation">III. DANDY-WALKER MALFORMATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-dandy-walker-malformation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Congenital failure of the cerebellar vermis to develop
B. Presents as a massively dilated 4th ventricle (posterior fossa) with an absent cerebellum (Fig. 17.2); often accompanied by hydrocephalus</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-arnold-chiari-malformation-type-ii">IV. ARNOLD-CHIARI MALFORMATION (TYPE II)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-arnold-chiari-malformation-type-ii" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Congenital downward displacement of cerebellar vermis and tonsils through the foramen magnum
B. Obstruction of CSF flow commonly results in hydrocephalus.
C. Often associated with meningomyelocele</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="spinal-cord-lesions">SPINAL CORD LESIONS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#spinal-cord-lesions" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-syringomyelia">I. SYRINGOMYELIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-syringomyelia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Cystic degeneration of the spinal cord
B. Arises with trauma or in association with a type 1 Arnold-Chiari malformation
C. Usually occurs at C8-T1</p>
<ol>
<li>Presents as sensory loss of pain and temperature with sparing of fine touch and position sense in the upper extremities ("cape like" distribution)-due to involvement of the anterior white commissure of the spinothalamic tract with sparing of the dorsal column (Table 17.1)
D. Syrinx expansion results in involvement of other spinal tracts leading to</li>
<li>Muscle atrophy and weakness with decreased muscle tone and impaired reflexes-due to damage to lower motor neurons of the anterior horn</li>
<li>Horner syndrome with ptosis (droopy eyelid), miosis (constricted pupil), and anhidrosis (decreased sweating)-due to disruption of the lateral horn of the hypothalamospinal tract (Table 17.1)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-poliomyelitis">II. POLIOMYELITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-poliomyelitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Damage to the anterior motor horn due to poliovirus infection
B. Presents with lower motor neuron signs-flaccid paralysis with muscle atrophy, fasciculations, weakness with decreased muscle tone, impaired reflexes, and negative Babinski sign (downgoing toes)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-werdnig-hoffman-disease">III. WERDNIG-HOFFMAN DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-werdnig-hoffman-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inherited degeneration of the anterior motor horn; autosomal recessive
B. Presents as a "floppy baby;" death occurs within a few years after birth.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-amyotrophic-lateral-sclerosis-als">IV. AMYOTROPHIC LATERAL SCLEROSIS (ALS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-amyotrophic-lateral-sclerosis-als" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Degenerative disorder of upper and lower motor neurons of the corticospinal tract (Table 17.1)</p>
<ol>
<li>Anterior motor horn degeneration leads to lower motor neuron signs-flaccid paralysis with muscle atrophy, fasciculations, weakness with decreased muscle tone, impaired reflexes, and negative Babinski sign.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-23f192de.jpeg" alt="img-201.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 17.1 Anencephaly. (Courtesy of humpath. com)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-eb7cfb97.jpeg" alt="img-202.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17.2 Dandy-Walker malformation, MRI. (Courtesy of Robert Heng, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-63b09762.jpeg" alt="img-203.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17.3 Bacterial meningitis, gross appearance.</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Lateral corticospinal tract degeneration leads to upper motor neuron signsspastic paralysis with hyperreflexia, increased muscle tone, and positive Babinski sign.
B. Atrophy and weakness of hands is an early sign.</li>
<li>Lack of sensory impairment distinguishes ALS from syringomyelia.
C. Most cases are sporadic, arising in middle age adults.</li>
<li>Zinc-copper superoxide dismutase mutation (SOD1) is present in some familial cases; leads to free radical injury in neurons</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="v-friedreich-ataxia">V. FRIEDREICH ATAXIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-friedreich-ataxia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Degenerative disorder of the cerebellum and spinal cord</p>
<ol>
<li>Degeneration of the cerebellum leads to ataxia.</li>
<li>Degeneration of multiple spinal cord tracts leads to loss of vibratory sense and proprioception, muscle weakness in the lower extremities, and loss of deep tendon reflexes.
B. Autosomal recessive; due to expansion of an unstable trinucleotide repeat (GAA) in the frataxin gene</li>
<li>Frataxin is essential for mitochondrial iron regulation; loss results in iron buildup with free radical damage.
C. Presents in early childhood; patients are wheelchair bound within a few years.
D. Associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="meningitis">MENINGITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#meningitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inflammation of the leptomeninges (Fig. 17.3)</p>
<ol>
<li>Meninges consist of three layers (dura, arachnoid, and pia) that lie between the brain and the skull.</li>
<li>Pia and arachnoid together are termed leptomeninges.</li>
</ol>
<p>Table 17.1: Spinal Cord Tracts</p>
<table><thead><tr><th style="text-align: center;">TRACT</th><th style="text-align: center;">FIRST-ORDER NEURON</th><th style="text-align: center;">SECOND-ORDER NEURON</th><th style="text-align: center;">THIRD-ORDER NEURON</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Spinothalamic (pain and temperature sensation)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Peripheral nerves to posterior horn; cell body is in dorsal root ganglion.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Arises from posterior horn, immediately crosses over in anterior white commissure, and ascends via the spinothalamic tract to thalamus</td><td style="text-align: center;">Thalamus to cortex</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Dorsal column-medial lemniscus (pressure, touch, vibration, and proprioception)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Peripheral nerves to medulla via dorsal column; cell body is in dorsal root ganglion.</td><td style="text-align: center;">Arises from medulla, crosses over, and ascends via the medial lemniscus to thalamus</td><td style="text-align: center;">Thalamus to cortex</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Lateral corticospinal (voluntary movement)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Pyramidal neurons in cortex descend, cross over in medullary pyramids, and synapse on the anterior motor horn of the cord (upper motor neuron).</td><td style="text-align: center;">Arises from the anterior motor horn and synapses on muscle (lower motor neuron)</td><td style="text-align: center;">(None)</td></tr><tr><td style="text-align: center;">Hypothalamospinal (sympathetic input of the face)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Arises from the hypothalamus and synapses on the lateral horn at T 1</td><td style="text-align: center;">Arises from lateral horn at T1 and synapses on the superior cervical ganglion (sympathetic)</td><td style="text-align: center;">Superior cervical ganglion to eyelids, pupil, and skin of face</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>B. Most commonly due to an infectious agent</p>
<ol>
<li>Group B streptococci, E coli, and Listeria monocytogenes (neonates)</li>
<li>N meningitidis (children and teenagers), Streptococcus pneumoniae (adults and elderly), and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">H</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.08125em;">H</span></span></span></span></span> influenza (nonvaccinated infants)</li>
<li>Coxsackievirus (children; fecal-oral transmission)</li>
<li>Fungi (immunocompromised individuals)
C. Presents with classic triad of headache, nuchal rigidity, and fever; photophobia, vomiting, and altered mental status may also be present.
D. Diagnosis is made by lumbar puncture (sampling of CSF).</li>
<li>Performed by placing a needle between L4 and L5 (level of the iliac crest). Spinal cord ends at L2, but subarachnoid space and cauda equina continue to S2.</li>
<li>Layers crossed include skin, ligaments, epidural space, dura, and arachnoid.
E. CSF findings</li>
<li>Bacterial meningitis-neutrophils with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> CSF glucose; gram stain and culture often identify the causative organism.</li>
<li>Viral meningitis-lymphocytes with normal CSF glucose</li>
<li>Fungal meningitis-lymphocytes with <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> CSF glucose
F. Complications are usually seen with bacterial meningitis.</li>
<li>Death-herniation secondary to cerebral edema</li>
<li>Hydrocephalus, hearing loss, and seizures-sequelae related to fibrosis</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="cerebrovascular-disease">CEREBROVASCULAR DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cerebrovascular-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Neurologic deficit due to cerebrovascular compromise; major cause of morbidity and mortality
B. Due to ischemia ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>85</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">85 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">85%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases) or hemorrhage ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">15 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">15%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases)</p>
<ol>
<li>Neurons are dependent on serum glucose as an essential energy source and are particularly susceptible to ischemia (undergo necrosis within 3-5 minutes).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-global-cerebral-ischemia">II. GLOBAL CEREBRAL ISCHEMIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-global-cerebral-ischemia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Global ischemia to the brain
B. Major etiologies</p>
<ol>
<li>Low perfusion (e.g., atherosclerosis)</li>
<li>Acute decrease in blood flow (e.g., cardiogenic shock)</li>
<li>Chronic hypoxia (e.g., anemia)</li>
<li>Repeated episodes of hypoglycemia (e.g., insulinoma)
C. Clinical features are based on duration and magnitude of the insult.</li>
<li>Mild global ischemia results in transient confusion with prompt recovery.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-467a027c.jpeg" alt="img-204.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 17.4 Pale infarct, cortex. (Courtesy of Robert Wollmann, MD)
Fig. 17.5 Lacunar infarcts. (Courtesy of Robert Wollmann, MD)</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Severe global ischemia results in diffuse necrosis; survival leads to a 'vegetative state.'</li>
<li>Moderate global ischemia leads to infarcts in watershed areas (e.g., area lying between regions fed by the anterior and middle cerebral artery) and damage to highly vulnerable regions such as
i. Pyramidal neurons of the cerebral cortex (layers 3, 5, and 6)-leads to laminar necrosis
ii. Pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus (temporal lobe)-important in longterm memory
iii. Purkinje layer of the cerebellum-integrates sensory perception with motor control</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-ischemic-stroke">III. ISCHEMIC STROKE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-ischemic-stroke" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Regional ischemia to the brain that results in focal neurologic deficits lasting <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>24</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;24</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">24</span></span></span></span></span> hours</p>
<ol>
<li>If symptoms last <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>24</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;24</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">24</span></span></span></span></span> hours, the event is termed a transient ischemic attack (TIA).
B. Subtypes include thrombotic, embolic, and lacunar strokes.</li>
<li>Thrombotic stroke is due to rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque.
i. Atherosclerosis usually develops at branch points (e.g., bifurcation of internal carotid and middle cerebral artery in the circle of Willis).
ii. Results in a pale infarct at the periphery of the cortex (Fig. 17.4)</li>
<li>Embolic stroke is due to thromboemboli.
i. Most common source of emboli is the left side of the heart (e.g., atrial fibrillation).
ii. Usually involves the middle cerebral artery
iii. Results in a hemorrhagic infarct at the periphery of the cortex</li>
<li>Lacunar stroke occurs secondary to hyaline arteriolosclerosis, a complication of hypertension.
i. Most commonly involves lenticulostriate vessels, resulting in small cystic areas of infarction (Fig. 17.5)
ii. Involvement of the internal capsule leads to a pure motor stroke.
iii. Involvement of the thalamus leads to a pure sensory stroke.
C. Ischemic stroke results in liquefactive necrosis.</li>
<li>Eosinophilic change in the cytoplasm of neurons (red neurons, Fig. 17.6A) is an early microscopic finding ( 12 hours after infarction).</li>
<li>Necrosis ( 24 hours), infiltration by neutrophils (days 1-3) and microglial cells (days 4-7), and gliosis (weeks 2-3) then ensue.</li>
<li>Results in formation of a fluid-filled cystic space surrounded by gliosis (Fig. 17.6B)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-e899a784.jpeg" alt="img-205.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 17.6 Brain infarct. A, Red neurons. B, Cyst formation. (Courtesy of Robert Wollmann, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-intracerebral-hemorrhage">IV. INTRACEREBRAL HEMORRHAGE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-intracerebral-hemorrhage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Bleeding into brain parenchyma
B. Classically due to rupture of Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysms of the lenticulostriate vessels</p>
<ol>
<li>Complication of hypertension; treatment of hypertension reduces incidence by half.</li>
<li>Basal ganglia is the most common site (Fig. 17.7).
C. Presents as severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and eventual coma</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-subarachnoid-hemorrhage">V. SUBARACHNOID HEMORRHAGE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-subarachnoid-hemorrhage" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Bleeding into the subarachnoid space (Fig. 17.8)
B. Presents as a sudden headache ("worst headache of my life") with nuchal rigidity
C. Lumbar puncture shows xanthochromia (yellow hue due to bilirubin).
D.
