Most frequently ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>85</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">85 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">85%</span></span></span></span></span> ) due to rupture of a berry aneurysm; other causes include AV malformations and an anticoagulated state.</p>
<ol>
<li>Berry aneurysms are thin-walled saccular outpouchings that lack a media layer (Fig. 17.9), increasing the risk for rupture.</li>
<li>Most frequently located in the anterior circle of Willis at branch points of the anterior communicating artery</li>
<li>Associated with Marfan syndrome and autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="trauma">TRAUMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#trauma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-epidural-hematoma">I. EPIDURAL HEMATOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-epidural-hematoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Collection of blood between the dura and the skull
B. Classically due to fracture of the temporal bone with rupture of the middle meningeal artery; bleeding separates the dura from the skull.</p>
<ol>
<li>Lens-shaped lesion on CT</li>
<li>Lucid interval may precede neurologic signs.
C. Herniation is a lethal complication.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-subdural-hematoma">II. SUBDURAL HEMATOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-subdural-hematoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Collection of blood underneath the dura; blood covers the surface of the brain (Fig. 17.10).
B. Due to tearing of bridging veins that lie between the dura and arachnoid; usually arises with trauma</p>
<ol>
<li>Crescent-shaped lesion on CT</li>
<li>Presents with progressive neurologic signs
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-688815cf.jpeg" alt="img-206.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 17.7 Intracerebral hemorrhage, basal ganglia. (Courtesy of Robert Wollmann, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-57324a6f.jpeg" alt="img-207.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17.8 Subarachnoid hemorrhage. (Courtesy of Jerome Taxy, MD)</p>
<ol start="3">
<li>Increased rate of occurrence in the elderly due to age-related cerebral atrophy, which stretches the veins
C. Herniation is a lethal complication.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-herniation">III. HERNIATION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-herniation" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Displacement of brain tissue due to mass effect or increased intracranial pressure
B. Tonsillar herniation involves displacement of the cerebellar tonsils into the foramen magnum.</p>
<ol>
<li>Compression of the brain stem leads to cardiopulmonary arrest.
C. Subfalcine herniation involves displacement of the cingulate gyrus under the falx cerebri.</li>
<li>Compression of the anterior cerebral artery leads to infarction.
D. Uncal herniation involves displacement of the temporal lobe uncus under the tentorium cerebelli.</li>
<li>Compression of cranial nerve III (oculomotor) leads to the eye moving "down and out" and a dilated pupil.</li>
<li>Compression of posterior cerebral artery leads to infarction of occipital lobe (contralateral homonymous hemianopsia).</li>
<li>Rupture of the paramedian artery leads to Duret (brainstem) hemorrhage.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="demyelinating-disorders">DEMYELINATING DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#demyelinating-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Myelin insulates axons, improving the speed and efficiency of conduction.</p>
<ol>
<li>Oligodendrocytes myelinate the central nervous system.</li>
<li>Schwann cells myelinate the peripheral nervous system.
B. Demyelinating disorders are characterized by destruction of myelin or oligodendrocytes; axons are generally preserved.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-leukodystrophies">II. LEUKODYSTROPHIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-leukodystrophies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inherited mutations in enzymes necessary for production or maintenance of myelin
B. Metachromatic leukodystrophy is due to a deficiency of arylsulfatase (autosomal recessive); most common leukodystrophy</p>
<ol>
<li>Sulfatides cannot be degraded and accumulate in the lysosomes of oligodendrocytes (lysosomal storage disease).
C. Krabbe disease is due to a deficiency of galactocerebrosidase (autosomal recessive).</li>
<li>Galactocerebroside accumulates in macrophages.
D. Adrenoleukodystrophy is due to impaired addition of coenzyme A to long-chain fatty acids (X-linked defect).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6eaa512d.jpeg" alt="img-208.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 17.9 Berry aneurysm. (Courtesy of Jerome Taxy, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-32aaa549.jpeg" alt="img-209.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17.10 Subdural hematoma. (Courtesy of Robert Wollmann, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-dee443e2.jpeg" alt="img-210.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17.11 Gray plaque, multiple sclerosis. (Courtesy of Peter Pytel, MD)</p>
<ol>
<li>Accumulation of fatty acids damages adrenal glands and white matter of the brain.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-multiple-sclerosis">III. MULTIPLE SCLEROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-multiple-sclerosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Autoimmune destruction of CNS myelin and oligodendrocytes</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common chronic CNS disease of young adults (20-30 years of age); more commonly seen in women</li>
<li>Associated with HLA-DR2</li>
<li>More commonly seen in regions away from the equator
B. Presents with relapsing neurologic deficits with periods of remission (multiple lesions in time and space). Clinical features include</li>
<li>Blurred vision in one eye (optic nerve)</li>
<li>Vertigo and scanning speech mimicking alcohol intoxication (brainstem)</li>
<li>Internuclear ophthalmoplegia (medial longitudinal fasciculus)</li>
<li>Hemiparesis or unilateral loss of sensation (cerebral white matter, usually periventricular)</li>
<li>Lower extremity loss of sensation or weakness (spinal cord)</li>
<li>Bowel, bladder, and sexual dysfunction (autonomic nervous system)
C. Diagnosis is made by MRI and lumbar puncture.</li>
<li>MRI reveals plaques (areas of white matter demyelination).</li>
<li>Lumbar puncture shows increased lymphocytes, increased immunoglobulins with oligoclonal IgG bands on high resolution electrophoresis, and myelin basic protein.
D. Gross examination shows gray-appearing plaques in the white matter (Fig. 17.11).
E. Treatment of acute attacks includes high-dose steroids.</li>
<li>Long-term treatment with interferon beta slows progression of disease.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-subacute-sclerosing-panencephalitis">IV. SUBACUTE SCLEROSING PANENCEPHALITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-subacute-sclerosing-panencephalitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Progressive, debilitating encephalitis leading to death
B. Due to slowly progressing, persistent infection of the brain by measles virus.</p>
<ol>
<li>Infection occurs in infancy; neurologic signs arise years later (during childhood).
C. Characterized by viral inclusions within neurons (gray matter) and oligodendrocytes (white matter)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-progressive-multifocal-leukoencephalopathy">V. PROGRESSIVE MULTIFOCAL LEUKOENCEPHALOPATHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-progressive-multifocal-leukoencephalopathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. JC virus infection of oligodendrocytes (white matter)</p>
<ol>
<li>Immunosuppression (e.g., AIDS or leukemia) leads to reactivation of the latent virus.
B. Presents with rapidly progressive neurologic signs (visual loss, weakness, dementia) leading to death</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-central-pontine-myelinolysis">VI. CENTRAL PONTINE MYELINOLYSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-central-pontine-myelinolysis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Focal demyelination of the pons (anterior brain stem)
B. Due to rapid intravenous correction of hyponatremia</p>
<ol>
<li>Occurs in severely malnourished patients (e.g., alcoholics and patients with liver disease)
C. Classically presents as acute bilateral paralysis ("locked in" syndrome)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="dementia-and-degenerative-disorders">DEMENTIA AND DEGENERATIVE DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#dementia-and-degenerative-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. BASIC PRINCIPLES
A. Characterized by loss of neurons within the gray matter; often due to accumulation of protein which damages neurons</p>
<p>B. Degeneration of the cortex leads to dementia.
C. Degeneration of the brainstem and basal ganglia leads to movement disorders.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-alzheimer-disease-ad">II. ALZHEIMER DISEASE (AD)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-alzheimer-disease-ad" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Degenerative disease of cortex; most common cause of dementia
B. Clinical features</p>
<ol>
<li>Slow-onset memory loss (begins with short-term memory loss and progresses to long-term memory loss) and progressive disorientation</li>
<li>Loss of learned motor skills and language</li>
<li>Changes in behavior and personality</li>
<li>Patients become mute and bedridden; infection is a common cause of death.</li>
<li>Focal neurologic deficits are not seen in early disease.
C. Most cases ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>95</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">95 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">95%</span></span></span></span></span> ) are sporadic and seen in the elderly.</li>
<li>Risk increases with age (doubles every 5 years after the age of 60 ).</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mi>ε</mi><mn>4</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\quad \varepsilon 4</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ε</span><span class="mord">4</span></span></span></span></span> allele of apolipoprotein <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">E</mi><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>P</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>E</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{E}(A P O E)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mord mathrm">E</span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">POE</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> is associated with increased risk, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>ε</mi><mn>2</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\varepsilon 2</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">ε</span><span class="mord">2</span></span></span></span></span> allele with decreased risk.
D. Early-onset AD is seen in</li>
<li>Familial cases-associated with presenilin 1 and presenilin 2 mutations</li>
<li>Down syndrome-commonly occurs by 40 years of age
E. Morphologic features include</li>
<li>Cerebral atrophy with narrowing of the gyri, widening of the sulci, and dilation of the ventricles (Fig. 17.12A)</li>
<li>Neuritic plaques-extracellular core comprised of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">A \beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> amyloid with entangled neuritic processes (Fig. 17.12B)
i. <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mspace width="1em"></mspace><mi>A</mi><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\quad A \beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 1em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> amyloid is derived from amyloid precursor protein (APP), which is coded on chromosome 21. APP normally undergoes alpha cleavage; beta cleavage results in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>A</mi><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">A \beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal">A</span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span> amyloid.
ii. Amyloid may also deposit around vessels, increasing the risk of hemorrhage.</li>
<li>Neurofibrillary tangles-intracellular aggregates of fibers composed of hyperphosphorylated tau protein (Fig. 17.12C)
i. Tau is a microtubule-associated protein.</li>
<li>Loss of cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert
F. Diagnosis is made by clinical and pathological correlation.</li>
<li>Presumptive diagnosis is made clinically after excluding other causes.</li>
<li>Confirmed by histology at autopsy (when possible)</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-vascular-dementia">III. VASCULAR DEMENTIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-vascular-dementia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Multifocal infarction and injury due to hypertension, atherosclerosis, or vasculitis
B. 2nd most common cause of dementia
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5e8f5870.jpeg" alt="img-211.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17.12 Alzheimer disease. A, Cerebral atrophy. B, Neuritic plaque. C, Neurofibrillary tangle. (A, Courtesy of Jerome Taxy, MD, B and C, Courtesy of Peter Pytel, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-pick-disease">IV. PICK DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-pick-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Degenerative disease of the frontal and temporal cortex; spares the parietal and occipital lobes
B. Characterized by round aggregates of tau protein (Pick bodies) in neurons of the cortex
C. Behavioral and language symptoms arise early; eventually progresses to dementia</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-parkinson-disease">V. PARKINSON DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-parkinson-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Degenerative loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the basal ganglia (Fig. 17.13A,B)</p>
<ol>
<li>Nigrostriatal pathway of basal ganglia uses dopamine to initiate movement.
B. Common disorder related to aging; seen in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">2 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">2%</span></span></span></span></span> of older adults
C. Unknown etiology; historically, rare cases were related to MPTP exposure (a contaminant in illicit drugs).
D. Clinical features ('TRAP')</li>
<li>Tremor-pill rolling tremor at rest; disappears with movement</li>
<li>Rigidity-cogwheel rigidity in the extremities</li>
<li>Akinesia/bradykinesia-slowing of voluntary movement; expressionless face</li>
<li>Postural instability and shuffling gait
E. Histology reveals loss of pigmented neurons in the substantia nigra and round, eosinophilic inclusions of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>-synuclein (Lewy bodies, Fig. 17.13C) in affected neurons.
F. Dementia is a common feature of late disease.</li>
<li>Early-onset dementia is suggestive of Lewy body dementia, which is characterized by dementia, hallucinations and parkinsonian features; histology reveals cortical Lewy bodies.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-huntington-disease">VI. HUNTINGTON DISEASE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-huntington-disease" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Degeneration of GABAergic neurons in the caudate nucleus of the basal ganglia (Fig. 17.14)</p>
<ol>
<li>Autosomal dominant disorder (chromosome 4) characterized by expanded trinucleotide repeats (CAG) in the huntingtin gene</li>
<li>Further expansion of repeats during spermatogenesis leads to anticipation.
B. Presents with chorea that can progress to dementia and depression; average age at presentation is 40 years.
C. Suicide is a common cause of death.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-normal-pressure-hydrocephalus">VII. NORMAL PRESSURE HYDROCEPHALUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-normal-pressure-hydrocephalus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Increased CSF resulting in dilated ventricles
B. Can cause dementia in adults; usually idiopathic
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5d8d5d14.jpeg" alt="img-212.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17.13 Parkinson disease. A, Loss of pigmented neurons in substantia nigra. B, Normal substantia nigra for comparison. C, Lewy body. (A and B, Courtesy of Robert Wollmann, MD)</p>
<p>C. Presents as triad of urinary incontinence, gait instability, and dementia ("wet, wobbly, and wacky")
D. Lumbar puncture improves symptoms; treatment is ventriculoperitoneal shunting.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="viii-spongiform-encephalopathy">VIII.SPONGIFORM ENCEPHALOPATHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-spongiform-encephalopathy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Degenerative disease due to prion protein</p>
<ol>
<li>Prion protein is normally expressed in CNS neurons in an <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>α</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\alpha</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.4306em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.0037em;">α</span></span></span></span></span>-helical configuration <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{PrP}^{\mathrm{c}}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PrP</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7376em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">c</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>.
B. Disease arises with conversion to a <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>β</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\beta</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05278em;">β</span></span></span></span></span>-pleated conformation <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo fence="true">(</mo><msup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">r</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">P</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi></msup><mo fence="true">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\left(\mathrm{PrP}^{\mathrm{c}}\right)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="minner"><span class="mopen delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">(</span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">PrP</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7376em;"><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mathrm mtight">c</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mclose delimcenter" style="top: 0em;">)</span></span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>Conversion can be sporadic, inherited (familial forms of disease), or transmitted.
C. Pathologic protein is not degradable and converts normal protein into the pathologic form, resulting in a vicious cycle.</li>
<li>Damage to neurons and glial cells is characterized by intracellular vacuoles (spongy degeneration, Fig. 17.15).
D. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is the most common spongiform encephalopathy.</li>
<li>Usually sporadic; rarely can arise due to exposure to prion-infected human tissue (e.g., human growth hormone or corneal transplant)</li>
<li>Presents as rapidly progressive dementia associated with ataxia (cerebellar involvement) and startle myoclonus
i. Periodic sharp waves are seen on EEG.
ii. Results in death, usually in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> year</li>
<li>Variant CJD is a special form of disease that is related to exposure to bovine spongiform encephalopathy ('mad cow').
E. Familial fatal insomnia is an inherited form of prion disease characterized by severe insomnia and an exaggerated startle response.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="cns-tumors">CNS TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#cns-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Can be metastatic ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> ) or primary ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>50</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">50 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">50%</span></span></span></span></span> )
B. Metastatic tumors characteristically present as multiple, well-circumscribed lesions at the gray-white junction.</p>
<ol>
<li>Lung, breast, and kidney are common sources.
C. Primary tumors are classified according to cell type of origin (e.g., astrocytes, meningothelial cells, ependymal cells, oligodendrocytes, or neuroectoderm).
D. In adults, primary tumors are usually supratentorial.</li>
<li>Most common tumors in adults are glioblastoma multiforme, meningioma, and schwannoma.
E. In children, primary tumors are usually infratentorial.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-e2cba189.jpeg" alt="img-213.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 17.14 Huntington disease. A, Degeneration of caudate nucleus. B, Normal caudate nucleus for comparison. (Courtesy of Peter Pytel, MD)</p>
<p>Fig. 17.15 Spongiform encephalopathy. (Courtesy of Peter Pytel, MD)</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common tumors in children are pilocytic astrocytoma, ependymoma, and medulloblastoma.
F. Primary malignant CNS tumors are locally destructive, but rarely metastasize.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-glioblastoma-multiforme-gbm">II. GLIOBLASTOMA MULTIFORME (GBM)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-glioblastoma-multiforme-gbm" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Malignant, high-grade tumor of astrocytes
B. Most common primary malignant CNS tumor in adults
C. Usually arises in the cerebral hemisphere; characteristically crosses the corpus callosum ('butterfly' lesion, Fig. 17.16A)
D. Characterized by regions of necrosis surrounded by tumor cells (pseudopalisading, Fig. 17.16B) and endothelial cell proliferation; tumor cells are GFAP positive.
E. Poor prognosis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-meningioma">III. MENINGIOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-meningioma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign tumor of arachnoid cells
B. Most common benign CNS tumor in adults</p>
<ol>
<li>More commonly seen in women; rare in children
C. May present as seizures; tumor compresses, but does not invade, the cortex.
D. Imaging reveals a round mass attached to the dura.
E. Histology shows a whorled pattern (Fig. 17.17); psammoma bodies may be present.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-schwannoma">IV. SCHWANNOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-schwannoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign tumor of Schwann cells
B. Involves cranial or spinal nerves; within the cranium, most frequently involves cranial nerve VIII at the cerebellopontine angle (presents as loss of hearing and tinnitus)
C. Tumor cells are S-100*.
D. Bilateral tumors are seen in neurofibromatosis type 2.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-oligodendroglioma">V. OLIGODENDROGLIOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-oligodendroglioma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant tumor of oligodendrocytes
B. Imaging reveals a calcified tumor in the white matter, usually involving the frontal lobe; may present with seizures
C. 'Fried-egg' appearance of cells on biopsy (Fig. 17.18)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-pilocytic-astrocytoma">VI. PILOCYTIC ASTROCYTOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-pilocytic-astrocytoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign tumor of astrocytes
B. Most common CNS tumor in children; usually arises in the cerebellum
C. Imaging reveals a cystic lesion with a mural nodule (Fig. 17.19A).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-505f9767.jpeg" alt="img-214.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17.16 Glioblastoma multiforme. A, 'Butterfly' lesion. B, Pseudopalisading. (Courtesy of Peter Pytel, MD)</p>
<p>D. Biopsy shows Rosenthal fibers (thick eosinophilic processes of astrocytes, Fig. 17.19B) and eosinophilic granular bodies; tumor cells are GFAP positive.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vii-medulloblastoma">VII. MEDULLOBLASTOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-medulloblastoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Malignant tumor derived from the granular cells of the cerebellum (neuroectoderm)
B. Usually arises in children
C. Histology reveals small, round blue cells; Homer-Wright rosettes may be present.
D. Poor prognosis; tumor grows rapidly and spreads via CSF.</p>
<ol>
<li>Metastasis to the cauda equina is termed 'drop metastasis.'</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-ependymoma">VIII.EPENDYMOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-ependymoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant tumor of ependymal cells; usually seen in children
B. Most commonly arises in the 4th ventricle; may present with hydrocephalus
C. Perivascular pseudorosettes are a characteristic finding on biopsy (Fig. 17.20).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ix-craniopharyngioma">IX. CRANIOPHARYNGIOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ix-craniopharyngioma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Tumor that arises from epithelial remnants of Rathke's pouch
B. Presents as a supratentorial mass in a child or young adult; may compress the optic chiasm leading to bitemporal hemianopsia
C. Calcifications are commonly seen on imaging (derived from "tooth-like" tissue).
D. Benign, but tends to recur after resection
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-0bf15f45.jpeg" alt="img-215.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17.17 Meningioma.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-998a3475.jpeg" alt="img-216.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17.18 Oligodendroglioma. (Courtesy of Peter Pytel, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-a472e032.jpeg" alt="img-217.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17.19 Pilocytic astrocytoma. A, Cystic lesion with mural nodule. B, Rosenthal fibers. (A, Courtesy of Peter Pytel, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-59ecb87a.jpeg" alt="img-218.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 17.20 Ependymoma.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-d5feb4a9.jpeg" alt="img-219.jpeg"></p>
<p>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="musculoskeletal-pathology">Musculoskeletal Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#musculoskeletal-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="skeletal-system">SKELETAL SYSTEM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skeletal-system" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-achondroplasia">I. ACHONDROPLASIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-achondroplasia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Impaired cartilage proliferation in the growth plate; common cause of dwarfism
B. Due to an activating mutation in fibroblast growth factor receptor 3 (FGFR3); autosomal dominant</p>
<ol>
<li>Overexpression of FGFR3 inhibits growth.</li>
<li>Most mutations are sporadic and related to increased paternal age.
C. Clinical features</li>
<li>Short extremities with normal-sized head and chest-due to poor endochondral bone formation; intramembranous bone formation is not affected.
i. Endochondral bone formation is characterized by formation of a cartilage matrix, which is then replaced by bone; it is the mechanism by which long bones grow.
ii. Intramembranous bone formation is characterized by formation of bone without a preexisting cartilage matrix; it is the mechanism by which flat bones (e.g., skull and rib cage) develop.
D. Mental function, life span, and fertility are not affected.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-osteogenesis-imperfecta">II. OSTEOGENESIS IMPERFECTA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-osteogenesis-imperfecta" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Congenital defect of bone formation resulting in structurally weak bone
B. Most commonly due to an autosomal dominant defect in collagen type I synthesis
C. Clinical features</p>
<ol>
<li>Multiple fractures of bone (can mimic child abuse, but bruising is absent)</li>
<li>Blue sclera-Thinning of scleral collagen reveals underlying choroidal veins.</li>
<li>Hearing loss-Bones of the middle ear easily fracture.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-osteopetrosis">III. OSTEOPETROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-osteopetrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Inherited defect of bone resorption resulting in abnormally thick, heavy bone that fractures easily
B. Due to poor osteoclast function
C. Multiple genetic variants exist; carbonic anhydrase II mutation leads to loss of the acidic microenvironment required for bone resorption.
D. Clinical features include</p>
<ol>
<li>Bone fractures</li>
<li>Anemia, thrombocytopenia, and leukopenia with extramedullary hematopoiesis-due to bony replacement of the marrow (myelophthisic process, Fig. 18.1)</li>
<li>Vision and hearing impairment-due to impingement on cranial nerves</li>
<li>Hydrocephalus-due to narrowing of the foramen magnum</li>
<li>Renal tubular acidosis-seen with carbonic anhydrase II mutation
i. Lack of carbonic anhydrase results in decreased tubular reabsorption of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msubsup><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">H</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>3</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">−</mo></msubsup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{HCO}_{3}^{-}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1.0916em; vertical-align: -0.247em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">HCO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8446em;"><span style="top: -2.453em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">3</span></span></span></span><span style="top: -3.1362em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">−</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.247em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span>, leading to metabolic acidosis.
E. Treatment is bone marrow transplant; osteoclasts are derived from monocytes.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-rickets-osteomalacia">IV. RICKETS/OSTEOMALACIA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-rickets-osteomalacia" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Defective mineralization of osteoid</p>
<ol>
<li>Osteoblasts normally produce osteoid, which is then mineralized with calcium and phosphate to form bone.
B. Due to low levels of vitamin D, which results in low serum calcium and phosphate</li>
<li>Vitamin D is normally derived from the skin upon exposure to sunlight ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>85</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">85 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">85%</span></span></span></span></span> ) and from the diet <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>15</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(15 \%)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">15%</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span>.</li>
<li>Activation requires 25 -hydroxylation by the liver followed by 1-alphahydroxylation by the proximal tubule cells of the kidney.</li>
<li>Active vitamin D raises serum calcium and phosphate by acting on
i. Intestine-increases absorption of calcium and phosphate
ii. Kidney-increases reabsorption of calcium and phosphate
iii. Bone-increases resorption of calcium and phosphate</li>
<li>Vitamin D deficiency is seen with decreased sun exposure (e.g., northern latitudes), poor diet, malabsorption, liver failure, and renal failure.
C. Rickets is due to low vitamin D in children, resulting in abnormal bone mineralization.</li>
<li>Most commonly arises in children <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;1</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">1</span></span></span></span></span> year of age; presents with
i. Pigeon-breast deformity-inward bending of the ribs with anterior protrusion of the sternum
ii. Frontal bossing (enlarged forehead)-due to osteoid deposition on the skull iii. Rachitic rosary-due to osteoid deposition at the costochondral junction iv. Bowing of the legs may be seen in ambulating children.
D. Osteomalacia is due to low vitamin D in adults.</li>
<li>Inadequate mineralization results in weak bone with an increased risk for fracture.</li>
<li>Laboratory findings include <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> serum calcium, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↓</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\downarrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↓</span></span></span></span></span> serum phosphate, <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> PTH, and <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>↑</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\uparrow</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8889em; vertical-align: -0.1944em;"></span><span class="mrel">↑</span></span></span></span></span> alkaline phosphatase.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-osteoporosis">V. OSTEOPOROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-osteoporosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Reduction in trabecular bone mass
B. Results in porous bone with an increased risk for fracture
C. Risk of osteoporosis is based on peak bone mass (attained in early adulthood) and rate of bone loss that follows thereafter.</p>
<ol>
<li>Peak bone mass is achieved by 30 years of age and is based on (1) genetics (e.g., vitamin D receptor variants), (2) diet, and (3) exercise.</li>
<li>Thereafter, slightly less than <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>1</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">1 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">1%</span></span></span></span></span> of bone mass is lost each year; bone mass is lost more quickly with lack of weight-bearing exercise (e.g., space travel), poor diet, or decreased estrogen (e.g., menopause).
D. Most common forms of osteoporosis are senile and postmenopausal.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1be6f86f.jpeg" alt="img-220.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 18.1 Osteopetrosis. (Published with permission from LearningRadiology.com)
Fig. 18.2 Paget disease of bone.</p>
<p>E. Clinical features</p>
<ol>
<li>Bone pain and fractures in weight-bearing areas such as the vertebrae (leads to loss of height and kyphosis), hip, and distal radius</li>
<li>Bone density is measured using a DEXA scan.</li>
<li>Serum calcium, phosphate, PTH, and alkaline phosphatase are normal; labs help to exclude osteomalacia (which has a similar clinical presentation).
F. Treatment includes</li>
<li>Exercise, vitamin D, and calcium-limit bone loss</li>
<li>Bisphosphonates-induce apoptosis of osteoclasts</li>
<li>Estrogen replacement therapy is debated (currently not recommended).</li>
<li>Glucocorticoids are contraindicated (worsen osteoporosis).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="vi-paget-disease-of-bone">VI. PAGET DISEASE OF BONE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-paget-disease-of-bone" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Imbalance between osteoclast and osteoblast function</p>
<ol>
<li>Usually seen in late adulthood (average age <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>60</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;60</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">60</span></span></span></span></span> years)
B. Etiology is unknown; possibly viral
C. Localized process involving one or more bones; does not involve the entire skeleton
D. Three distinct stages are (1) osteoclastic, (2) mixed osteoblastic-osteoclastic, and (3) osteoblastic.</li>
<li>End result is thick, sclerotic bone that fractures easily.</li>
<li>Biopsy reveals a mosaic pattern of lamellar bone (Fig. 18.2).
E. Clinical features</li>
<li>Bone pain-due to microfractures</li>
<li>Increasing hat size-Skull is commonly affected.</li>
<li>Hearing loss-impingement on cranial nerve</li>
<li>Lion-like facies-involvement of craniofacial bones</li>
<li>Isolated elevated alkaline phosphatase-most common cause of isolated elevated alkaline phosphatase in patients <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>40</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;40</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">40</span></span></span></span></span> years old
F. Treatment includes</li>
<li>Calcitonin-inhibits osteoclast function</li>
<li>Bisphosphonates-induces apoptosis of osteoclasts
G. Complications include</li>
<li>High-output cardiac failure-due to formation of AV shunts in bone</li>
<li>Osteosarcoma</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-osteomyelitis">VII. OSTEOMYELITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-osteomyelitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Infection of marrow and bone</p>
<ol>
<li>Usually occurs in children
B. Most commonly bacterial; arises via hematogenous spread</li>
<li>Transient bacteremia (children) seeds metaphysis.</li>
<li>Open-wound bacteremia (adults) seeds epiphysis.
C. Causes include</li>
<li>Staphylococcus aureus-most common cause ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>90</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">90 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">90%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases)</li>
<li>N gonorrhoeae-sexually active young adults</li>
<li>Salmonella-sickle cell disease</li>
<li>Pseudomonas-diabetics or IV drug abusers</li>
<li>Pasteurella-associated with cat or dog bite/scratches</li>
<li>Mycobacterium tuberculosis-usually involves vertebrae (Pott disease)
D. Clinical features</li>
<li>Bone pain with systemic signs of infection (e.g., fever and leukocytosis)</li>
<li>Lytic focus (abscess) surrounded by sclerosis of bone on x-ray; lytic focus is called sequestrum, and sclerosis is called involucrum.
E. Diagnosis is made by blood culture.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="viii-avascular-aseptic-necrosis">VIII.AVASCULAR (ASEPTIC) NECROSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-avascular-aseptic-necrosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Ischemic necrosis of bone and bone marrow
B. Causes include trauma or fracture (most common), steroids, sickle cell anemia, and caisson disease.
C. Osteoarthritis and fracture are major complications.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="bone-tumors">BONE TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#bone-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. OSTEOMA
A. Benign tumor of bone
B. Most commonly arises on the surface of facial bones
C. Associated with Gardner syndrome
II. OSTEOID OSTEOMA
A. Benign tumor of osteoblasts (that produce osteoid) surrounded by a rim of reactive bone
B. Occurs in young adults <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>25</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;25</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">25</span></span></span></span></span> years of age (more common in males)
C. Arises in cortex of long bones (e.g., femur)
D. Presents as bone pain that resolves with aspirin
E. Imaging reveals a bony mass ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>2</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;2 \mathrm{~cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> ) with a radiolucent core (osteoid).
F. Osteoblastoma is similar to osteoid osteoma but is larger ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>2</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">c</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;2 \mathrm{~cm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">2</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">cm</span></span></span></span></span></span> ), arises in vertebrae, and presents as bone pain that does not respond to aspirin.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-osteochondroma">III. OSTEOCHONDROMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-osteochondroma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Tumor of bone with an overlying cartilage cap (Fig. 18.3); most common benign tumor of bone
B. Arises from a lateral projection of the growth plate (metaphysis); bone is continuous with the marrow space.
C. Overlying cartilage can transform (rarely) to chondrosarcoma.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-osteosarcoma">IV. OSTEOSARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-osteosarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of osteoblasts
B. Peak incidence is seen in teenagers; less commonly seen in the elderly</p>
<ol>
<li>Risk factors include familial retinoblastoma, Paget disease, and radiation exposure.</li>
<li>Arises in the metaphysis of long bones, usually the distal femur or proximal tibia (region of the knee)
C. Presents as a pathologic fracture or bone pain with swelling
D. Imaging reveals a destructive mass with a 'sunburst' appearance and lifting of the periosteum (Codman triangle, Fig. 18.4A).
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-3dab7c21.jpeg" alt="img-221.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 18.3 Osteochondroma. (Courtesy of humpath.com)
Fig. 18.4 Osteosarcoma. A, X-ray. B, Microscopic appearance. (A, Courtesy of Bulent Celasun, MD)</p>
<p>E. Biopsy reveals pleomorphic cells that produce osteoid (Fig. 18.4B).</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="v-giant-cell-tumor">V. GIANT CELL TUMOR<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-giant-cell-tumor" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Tumor comprised of multinucleated giant cells and stromal cells
B. Occurs in young adults
C. Arises in the epiphysis of long bones, usually the distal femur or proximal tibia (region of the knee)
D. 'Soap-bubble' appearance on x-ray
E. Locally aggressive tumor; may recur</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-ewing-sarcoma">VI. EWING SARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-ewing-sarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of poorly-differentiated cells derived from neuroectoderm
B. Arises in the diaphysis of long bones; usually in male children ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>15</mn></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;15</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">15</span></span></span></span></span> years of age)
C. 'Onion-skin' appearance on x-ray
D. Biopsy reveals small, round blue cells that resemble lymphocytes (Fig. 18.5).</p>
<ol>
<li>Can be confused with lymphoma or chronic osteomyelitis</li>
<li><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mn>11</mn><mo separator="true">;</mo><mn>22</mn><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">(11 ; 22)</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 1em; vertical-align: -0.25em;"></span><span class="mopen">(</span><span class="mord">11</span><span class="mpunct">;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.1667em;"></span><span class="mord">22</span><span class="mclose">)</span></span></span></span></span> translocation is characteristic.
E. Often presents with metastasis; responsive to chemotherapy</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-chondroma">VII. CHONDROMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-chondroma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign tumor of cartilage
B. Usually arises in the medulla of small bones of the hands and feet (Fig. 18.6)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="viii-chondrosarcoma">VIII. CHONDROSARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#viii-chondrosarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant cartilage-forming tumor
B. Arises in medulla of the pelvis or central skeleton</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ix-metastatic-tumors">IX. METASTATIC TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ix-metastatic-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. More common than primary tumors
B. Usually result in osteolytic (punched-out) lesions</p>
<ol>
<li>Prostatic carcinoma classically produces osteoblastic lesions.</li>
</ol>
