<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="joint">JOINT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#joint" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Connection between two bones
B. Solid joints are tightly connected to provide structural strength (e.g., cranial sutures).
C. Synovial joints have a joint space to allow for motion.</p>
<ol>
<li>Articular surface of adjoining bones is made of hyaline cartilage (type II collagen) that is surrounded by a joint capsule.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-753c0499.jpeg" alt="img-222.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 18.5 Ewing sarcoma.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1f824305.jpeg" alt="img-223.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 18.6 Chondroma. (Published with permission from LearningRadiology.com)</p>
<ol start="2">
<li>Synovium lining the joint capsule secretes fluid rich in hyaluronic acid to lubricate the joint and facilitate smooth motion.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-degenerative-joint-disease-osteoarthritis">II. DEGENERATIVE JOINT DISEASE (OSTEOARTHRITIS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-degenerative-joint-disease-osteoarthritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Progressive degeneration of articular cartilage; most common type of arthritis
B. Most often due to 'wear and tear'
C. Major risk factor is age (common after 60 years); additional risk factors include obesity and trauma.
D. Affects a limited number of joints (oligoarticular); hips, lower lumbar spine, knees, and the distal interphalangeal joints (DIP) and proximal interphalangeal joints (PIP) of fingers are common sites.
E. Classic presentation is joint stiffness in the morning that worsens during the day.
F. Pathologic features include</p>
<ol>
<li>Disruption of the cartilage that lines the articular surface (Fig. 18.7); fragments of cartilage floating in the joint space are called 'joint mice.'</li>
<li>Eburnation of the subchondral bone</li>
<li>Osteophyte formation (reactive bony outgrowths); classically arises in the DIP (Heberden nodes) and PIP (Bouchard nodes) joints of the fingers</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-rheumatoid-arthritis">III. RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-rheumatoid-arthritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Chronic, systemic autoimmune disease</p>
<ol>
<li>Classically arises in women of late childbearing age</li>
<li>Associated with HLA-DR4
B. Characterized by involvement of joints</li>
<li>Hallmark is synovitis leading to formation of a pannus (inflamed granulation tissue).</li>
<li>Leads to destruction of cartilage and ankylosis (fusion) of the joint
C. Clinical features</li>
<li>Arthritis with morning stiffness that improves with activity.
i. Symmetric involvement of PIP joints of the fingers (swan-neck deformity), wrists (radial deviation), elbows, ankles, and knees is characteristic (Fig. 18.8); DIP is usually spared (unlike osteoarthritis).
ii. Joint-space narrowing, loss of cartilage, and osteopenia are seen on x-ray.</li>
<li>Fever, malaise, weight loss, and myalgias</li>
<li>Rheumatoid nodules-central zone of necrosis surrounded by epithelioid histiocytes; arise in skin and visceral organs</li>
<li>Vasculitis-Multiple organs may be involved.</li>
<li>Baker cyst-swelling of bursa behind the knee</li>
<li>Pleural effusions, lymphadenopathy, and interstitial lung fibrosis
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-2a7b1c6a.jpeg" alt="img-224.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 18.7 Degenerative joint disease.
Fig. 18.8 Rheumatoid arthritis. (Courtesy of James Heilman, MD, Wikipedia)</p>
<p>D. Laboratory findings</p>
<ol>
<li>IgM autoantibody against Fc portion of IgG (rheumatoid factor); marker of tissue damage and disease activity</li>
<li>Neutrophils and high protein in synovial fluid
E. Complications include anemia of chronic disease and secondary amyloidosis.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-seronegative-spondyloarthropathies">IV. SERONEGATIVE SPONDYLOARTHROPATHIES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-seronegative-spondyloarthropathies" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Group of joint disorders characterized by</p>
<ol>
<li>Lack of rheumatoid factor</li>
<li>Axial skeleton involvement</li>
<li>HLA-B27 association
B. Ankylosing spondyloarthritis involves the sacroiliac joints and spine.</li>
<li>Arises in young adults, most often male</li>
<li>Presents with low back pain; involvement of vertebral bodies eventually arises, leading to fusion of the vertebrae ('bamboo spine').</li>
<li>Extra-articular manifestations include uveitis and aortitis (leading to aortic regurgitation).
C. Reactive arthritis is characterized by the triad of arthritis, urethritis, and conjunctivitis.</li>
<li>Arises in young adults (usually males) weeks after a GI or Chlamydia trachomatis infection
D. Psoriatic arthritis is seen in <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mn>10</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">%</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">10 \%</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8056em; vertical-align: -0.0556em;"></span><span class="mord">10%</span></span></span></span></span> of cases of psoriasis.</li>
<li>Involves axial and peripheral joints; DIP joints of the hands and feet are most commonly affected, leading to "sausage" fingers or toes.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-infectious-arthritis">V. INFECTIOUS ARTHRITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-infectious-arthritis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Arthritis due to an infectious agent, usually bacterial
B. Causes include</p>
<ol>
<li>N gonorrhoeae-young adults; most common cause</li>
<li>S aureus-older children and adults; 2nd most common cause
C. Classically involves a single joint, usually the knee
D. Presents as a warm joint with limited range of motion; fever, increased white count, and elevated ESR are often present.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-gout">VI. GOUT<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-gout" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Deposition of monosodium urate (MSU) crystals in tissues, especially the joints
B. Due to hyperuricemia; related to overproduction or decreased excretion of uric acid</p>
<ol>
<li>Uric acid is derived from purine metabolism and is excreted by the kidney.
C. Primary gout is the most common form; etiology of hyperuricemia is unknown.
D. Secondary gout is seen with</li>
<li>Leukemia and myeloproliferative disorders-Increased cell turnover leads to hyperuricemia.</li>
<li>Lesch-Nyhan syndrome-X-linked deficiency of hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT); presents with mental retardation and selfmutilation</li>
<li>Renal insufficiency-decreased renal excretion of uric acid
E. Acute gout presents as exquisitely painful arthritis of the great toe (podagra)</li>
<li>MSU crystals deposit in the joint, triggering an acute inflammatory reaction.</li>
<li>Alcohol or consumption of meat may precipitate arthritis.
F. Chronic gout leads to</li>
<li>Development of tophi-white, chalky aggregates of uric acid crystals with fibrosis and giant cell reaction in the soft tissue and joints (Fig. 18.9A)</li>
<li>Renal failure-Urate crystals may deposit in kidney tubules (urate nephropathy).</li>
</ol>
<p>G. Laboratory findings include hyperuricemia; synovial fluid shows needle-shaped crystals with negative birefringence under polarized light (Fig. 18.9B).
H. Pseudogout resembles gout clinically, but is due to deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate (CPPD); synovial fluid shows rhomboid-shaped crystals with weakly positive birefringence under polarized light.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skeletal-muscle">SKELETAL MUSCLE<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skeletal-muscle" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>I. DERMATOMYOSITIS
A. Inflammatory disorder of the skin and skeletal muscle
B. Unknown etiology; some cases are associated with carcinoma (e.g., gastric carcinoma).
C. Clinical features</p>
<ol>
<li>Bilateral proximal muscle weakness; distal involvement can develop late in disease.</li>
<li>Rash of the upper eyelids (heliotrope rash); malar rash may also be seen.</li>
<li>Red papules on the elbows, knuckles, and knees (Gottron papules)
D. Laboratory findings</li>
<li>Increased creatine kinase</li>
<li>Positive ANA and anti-Jo-1 antibody</li>
<li>Perimysial inflammation ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">D</mi></mrow><msup><mn>4</mn><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CD} 4^{+} \mathrm{T}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CD</span></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord">4</span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">T</span></span></span></span></span> cells) with perifascicular atrophy on biopsy (Fig. 18.10)
E. Treatment is corticosteroids.
II. POLYMYOSITIS
A. Inflammatory disorder of skeletal muscle
B. Resembles dermatomyositis clinically, but skin is not involved; endomysial inflammation (CD8 <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">+</mo></msup><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{+} \mathrm{T}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.7713em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.7713em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">+</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span><span class="mord mathrm">T</span></span></span></span></span> cells) with necrotic muscle fibers is seen on biopsy.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-x-linked-muscular-dystrophy">III. X-LINKED MUSCULAR DYSTROPHY<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-x-linked-muscular-dystrophy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Degenerative disorder characterized by muscle wasting and replacement of skeletal muscle by adipose tissue
B. Due to defects of dystrophin gene</p>
<ol>
<li>Dystrophin is important for anchoring the muscle cytoskeleton to the extracellular matrix.</li>
<li>Mutations are often spontaneous; large gene size predisposes to high rate of mutation.
C. Duchenne muscular dystrophy is due to deletion of dystrophin.</li>
<li>Presents as proximal muscle weakness at 1 year of age; progresses to involve distal muscles
i. Calf pseudohypertrophy is a characteristic finding.
ii. Serum creatine kinase is elevated.</li>
<li>Death results from cardiac or respiratory failure; myocardium is commonly involved.
D. Becker muscular dystrophy is due to mutated dystrophin; clinically results in milder disease</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="neuromuscular-junction">NEUROMUSCULAR JUNCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#neuromuscular-junction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. MYASTHENIA GRAVIS
A. Autoantibodies against the postsynaptic acetylcholine receptor at the neuromuscular junction
B. More commonly seen in women</p>
<p>C. Clinical features</p>
<ol>
<li>Muscle weakness that worsens with use and improves with rest; classically involves the eyes, leading to ptosis and diplopia</li>
<li>Symptoms improve with anticholinesterase agents.</li>
<li>Associated with thymic hyperplasia or thymoma; thymectomy improves symptoms.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-lambert-eaton-syndrome">II. LAMBERT-EATON SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-lambert-eaton-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Antibodies against presynaptic calcium channels of the neuromuscular junction
B. Arises as a paraneoplastic syndrome, most commonly due to small cell carcinoma of the lung
C. Leads to impaired acetylcholine release</p>
<ol>
<li>Firing of presynaptic calcium channels is required for acetylcholine release.
D. Clinical features</li>
<li>Proximal muscle weakness that improves with use; eyes are usually spared.</li>
<li>Anticholinesterase agents do not improve symptoms.</li>
<li>Resolves with resection of the cancer</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="soft-tissue-tumors">SOFT TISSUE TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#soft-tissue-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. LIPOMA
A. Benign tumor of adipose tissue
B. Most common benign soft tissue tumor in adults</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-liposarcoma">II. LIPOSARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-liposarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant tumor of adipose tissue
B. Most common malignant soft tissue tumor in adults
C. Lipoblast is the characteristic cell.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-rhabdomyoma">III. RHABDOMYOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-rhabdomyoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign tumor of skeletal muscle
B. Cardiac rhabdomyoma is associated with tuberous sclerosis.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-rhabdomyosarcoma">IV. RHABDOMYOSARCOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-rhabdomyosarcoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant tumor of skeletal muscle
B. Most common malignant soft tissue tumor in children
C. Rhabdomyoblast is the characteristic cell; desmin positive
D. Most common site is the head and neck; vagina is the classic site in young girls.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-ee18b41d.jpeg" alt="img-225.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 18.9 Gout. A, Tophi. B, Negative birefringence. (B, Courtesy of Ed Uthman, MD)
Fig. 18.10 Dermatomyositis. (Courtesy of Peter Pytel, MD)</p>
<p>.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="skin-pathology">Skin Pathology<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#skin-pathology" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="introduction">INTRODUCTION<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#introduction" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. SKIN
A. Functions as a barrier against environmental insults and fluid loss
B. Composed of an epidermis and dermis
C. Epidermis is comprised of keratinocytes and has four layers (Fig. 19.1).</p>
<ol>
<li>Stratum basalis-regenerative (stem cell) layer</li>
<li>Stratum spinosum-characterized by desmosomes between keratinocytes</li>
<li>Stratum granulosum-characterized by granules in keratinocytes</li>
<li>Stratum corneum-characterized by keratin in anucleate cells
D. Dermis consists of connective tissue, nerve endings, blood and lymphatic vessels, and adnexal structures (e.g., hair shafts, sweat glands, and sebaceous glands).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="inflammatory-dermatoses">INFLAMMATORY DERMATOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#inflammatory-dermatoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. ATOPIC (ECZEMATOUS) DERMATITIS
A. Pruritic, erythematous, oozing rash with vesicles and edema; often involves the face and flexor surfaces
B. Type I hypersensitivity reaction; associated with asthma and allergic rhinitis</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-contact-dermatitis">II. CONTACT DERMATITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-contact-dermatitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Pruritic, erythematous, oozing rash with vesicles and edema
B. Arises upon exposure to allergens such as</p>
<ol>
<li>Poison ivy and nickel jewelry (type IV hypersensitivity)</li>
<li>Irritant chemicals (e.g., detergents)</li>
<li>Drugs (e.g., penicillin)
C. Treatment involves removal of the offending agent and topical glucocorticoids, if needed.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-acne-vulgaris">III. ACNE VULGARIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-acne-vulgaris" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Comedones (whiteheads and blackheads), pustules (pimples), and nodules; extremely common, especially in adolescents
B. Due to chronic inflammation of hair follicles and associated sebaceous glands</p>
<ol>
<li>Hormone-associated increase in sebum production (sebaceous glands have androgen receptors) and excess keratin production block follicles, forming comedones.</li>
<li>Propionibacterium acnes infection produces lipases that break down sebum, releasing proinflammatory fatty acids; results in pustule or nodule formation
C. Treatment includes benzoyl peroxide (antimicrobial) and vitamin A derivatives (e.g., isotretinoin), which reduce keratin production.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-psoriasis">IV. PSORIASIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-psoriasis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Well-circumscribed, salmon-colored plaques with silvery scale, usually on extensor surfaces and the scalp (Fig. 19.2A); pitting of nails may also be present.
B. Due to excessive keratinocyte proliferation</p>
<p>C. Possible autoimmune etiology</p>
<ol>
<li>Associated with HLA-C</li>
<li>Lesions often arise in areas of trauma (environmental trigger).
D. Histology (Fig. 19.2B) shows</li>
<li>Acanthosis (epidermal hyperplasia)</li>
<li>Parakeratosis (hyperkeratosis with retention of keratinocyte nuclei in the stratum corneum)</li>
<li>Collections of neutrophils in the stratum corneum (Munro microabscesses)</li>
<li>Thinning of the epidermis above elongated dermal papillae; results in bleeding when scale is picked off (Auspitz sign)
E. Treatment involves corticosteroids, UV light with psoralen, or immune-modulating therapy.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="v-lichen-planus">V. LICHEN PLANUS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-lichen-planus" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Pruritic, planar, polygonal, purple papules (Fig. 19.3A), often with reticular white lines on their surface (Wickham striae); commonly involves wrists, elbows, and oral mucosa</p>
<ol>
<li>Oral involvement manifests as Wickham striae.
B. Histology shows inflammation of the dermal-epidermal junction with a 'saw-tooth' appearance (Fig. 19.3B).
C. Etiology is unknown; associated with chronic hepatitis <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>C</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">C</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.07153em;">C</span></span></span></span></span> virus infection</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="blistering-dermatoses">BLISTERING DERMATOSES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#blistering-dermatoses" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>I. PEMPHIGUS VULGARIS
A. Autoimmune destruction of desmosomes between keratinocytes
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5fa73884.jpeg" alt="img-226.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.1 Skin histology, normal.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-61c58464.jpeg" alt="img-227.jpeg">
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-d2430f83.jpeg" alt="img-228.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.2 Psoriasis. A, Clinical appearance. B, Microscopic appearance. (A, Courtesy of Vesna PetronicRosic, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6f2364aa.jpeg" alt="img-229.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.3 Lichen planus. A, Clinical appearance. B, Microscopic appearance. (A, Courtesy of Vesna Petronic-Rosic, MD)</p>
<p>B. Due to IgG antibody against desmoglein (type II hypersensitivity)
C. Presents as skin and oral mucosa bullae (Fig. 19.4A).</p>
<ol>
<li>Acantholysis (separation) of stratum spinosum keratinocytes (normally connected by desmosomes) results in suprabasal blisters.</li>
<li>Basal layer cells remain attached to basement membrane via hemidesmosomes ('tombstone' appearance, Fig. 19.4B).</li>
<li>Thin-walled bullae rupture easily (Nikolsky sign), leading to shallow erosions with dried crust.</li>
<li>Immunofluorescence highlights IgG surrounding keratinocytes in a 'fish net' pattern.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-bullous-pemphigoid">II. BULLOUS PEMPHIGOID<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-bullous-pemphigoid" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Autoimmune destruction of hemidesmosomes between basal cells and the underlying basement membrane
B. Due to IgG antibody against hemidesmosome components (BP180) of the basement membrane
C. Presents as blisters of the skin (Fig. 19.5A), usually in the elderly; oral mucosa is spared.</p>
<ol>
<li>Basal cell layer is detached from the basement membrane (Fig. 19.5B).</li>
<li>Tense bullae do not rupture easily; clinically milder than pemphigus vulgaris
D. Immunofluorescence highlights IgG along basement membrane (linear pattern).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-dermatitis-herpetiformis">III. DERMATITIS HERPETIFORMIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-dermatitis-herpetiformis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Autoimmune deposition of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae
B. Presents as pruritic vesicles and bullae that are grouped (herpetiform, Fig. 19.6)
C. Strong association with celiac disease; resolves with gluten-free diet
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-9d2dd54c.jpeg" alt="img-230.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.4 Pemphigus vulgaris. A, Clinical appearance. B, Microscopic appearance. (A, Courtesy of Vesna Petronic-Rosic, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-5f28e95f.jpeg" alt="img-231.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.5 Bullous pemphigoid. A, Clinical appearance. B, Microscopic appearance. (A, Courtesy of Vesna Petronic-Rosic, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iv-erythema-multiforme-em">IV. ERYTHEMA MULTIFORME (EM)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-erythema-multiforme-em" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Hypersensitivity reaction characterized by targetoid rash and bullae (Fig. 19.7)</p>
<ol>
<li>Targetoid appearance is due to central epidermal necrosis surrounded by erythema.
B. Most commonly associated with HSV infection; other associations include Mycoplasma infection, drugs (penicillin and sulfonamides), autoimmune disease (e.g., SLE), and malignancy.
C. EM with oral mucosa/lip involvement and fever is termed Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS).</li>
<li>Toxic epidermal necrolysis is a severe form of SJS characterized by diffuse sloughing of skin, resembling a large burn; most often due to an adverse drug reaction</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="epithelial-tumors">EPITHELIAL TUMORS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#epithelial-tumors" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-seborrheic-keratosis">I. SEBORRHEIC KERATOSIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-seborrheic-keratosis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign squamous proliferation; common tumor in the elderly
B. Presents as raised, discolored plaques on the extremities or face; often has a coinlike, waxy, 'stuck-on' appearance (Fig. 19.8A)</p>
<ol>
<li>Characterized by keratin pseudocysts on histology (Fig. 19.8B)
C. Leser-Trélat sign is the sudden onset of multiple seborrheic keratoses and suggests underlying carcinoma of the GI tract (Fig. 19.8C).</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-acanthosis-nigricans">II. ACANTHOSIS NIGRICANS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-acanthosis-nigricans" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Epidermal hyperplasia with darkening of the skin ('velvet-like' skin, Fig. 19.9); often involves the axilla or groin
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-6138e51d.jpeg" alt="img-232.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.6 Dermatitis herpetiformis. (Courtesy of Vesna Petronic-Rosic, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-eb2db486.jpeg" alt="img-233.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.7 Erythema multiforme. (Courtesy of James Heilman, MD, Wikipedia)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-eed33e73.jpeg" alt="img-234.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.8 Seborrheic keratosis. A, Clinical appearance. B, Microscopic appearance. C, Sign of Leser-Trélat. (A and C, Courtesy of Vesna Petronic-Rosic, MD)</p>
<p>B. Associated with insulin resistance (e.g., non-insulin-dependent diabetes) or malignancy (especially gastric carcinoma)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="iii-basal-cell-carcinoma">III. BASAL CELL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-basal-cell-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of the basal cells of the epidermis</p>
<ol>
<li>Most common cutaneous malignancy
B. Risk factors stem from UVB-induced DNA damage and include prolonged exposure to sunlight, albinism, and xeroderma pigmentosum.
C. Presents as an elevated nodule with a central, ulcerated crater surrounded by dilated (telangiectatic) vessels (Fig. 19.10A); 'pink, pearl-like papule'</li>
<li>Classic location is the upper lip.
D. Histology shows nodules of basal cells with peripheral palisading (Fig. 19.10B).
E. Treatment is surgical excision; metastasis is rare.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-squamous-cell-carcinoma">IV. SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-squamous-cell-carcinoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant proliferation of squamous cells characterized by formation of keratin pearls.
B. Risk factors stem from UVB-induced DNA damage and include prolonged exposure to sunlight, albinism, and xeroderma pigmentosum.</p>
<ol>
<li>Additional risk factors include immunosuppressive therapy, arsenic exposure, and chronic inflammation (e.g., scar from burn or draining sinus tract).
C. Presents as an ulcerated, nodular mass, usually on the face (classically involving the lower lip)
D. Treatment is excision; metastasis is uncommon.
E. Actinic keratosis is a precursor lesion of squamous cell carcinoma and presents as a hyperkeratotic, scaly plaque, often on the face, back, or neck.
F. Keratoacanthoma is well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma that develops rapidly and regresses spontaneously; presents as a cup-shaped tumor filled with keratin debris</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="disorders-of-pigmentation-and-melanocytes">DISORDERS OF PIGMENTATION AND MELANOCYTES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#disorders-of-pigmentation-and-melanocytes" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-basic-principles">I. BASIC PRINCIPLES<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-basic-principles" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Melanocytes are responsible for skin pigmentation and are present in the basal layer of the epidermis.</p>
<ol>
<li>Derived from the neural crest</li>
<li>Synthesize melanin in melanosomes using tyrosine as a precursor molecule</li>
<li>Pass melanosomes to keratinocytes
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-4eb1155a.jpeg" alt="img-235.jpeg"></li>
</ol>
<p>Fig. 19.9 Acanthosis nigricans. (Courtesy of Vesna Petronic-Rosic, MD)
Fig. 19.10 Basal cell carcinoma. A, Clinical appearance. B, Microscopic appearance. (A, Courtesy of Vesna Petronic-Rosic, MD)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="ii-vitiligo">II. VITILIGO<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-vitiligo" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<p>A. Localized loss of skin pigmentation (Fig. 19.11)
B. Due to autoimmune destruction of melanocytes</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-albinism">III. ALBINISM<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-albinism" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Congenital lack of pigmentation
B. Due to an enzyme defect (usually tyrosinase) that impairs melanin production
C. May involve the eyes (ocular form) or both the eyes and skin (oculocutaneous form)
D. Increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma, and melanoma due to reduced protection against UVB</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iv-freckle-ephelis">IV. FRECKLE (EPHELIS)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iv-freckle-ephelis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Small, tan to brown macule; darkens when exposed to sunlight
B. Due to increased number of melanosomes (melanocytes are not increased)</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="v-melasma">V. MELASMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#v-melasma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Mask-like hyperpigmentation of the cheeks
B. Associated with pregnancy and oral contraceptives</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vi-nevus-mole">VI. NEVUS (MOLE)<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vi-nevus-mole" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Benign neoplasm of melanocytes
B. Congenital nevus is present at birth; often associated with hair (Fig. 19.12)
C. Acquired nevus arises later in life.</p>
<ol>
<li>Begins as nests of melanocytes at the dermal-epidermal junction (junctional nevus); most common mole in children</li>
<li>Grows by extension into the dermis (compound nevus)</li>
<li>Junctional component is eventually lost resulting in an intradermal nevus, which is the most common mole in adults.
D. Characterized by a flat macule or raised papule with symmetry, sharp borders, evenly distributed color, and small diameter ( <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&lt;</mo><mn>6</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&lt;6 \mathrm{~mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&lt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span> )
E. Dysplasia may arise (dysplastic nevus), which is a precursor to melanoma.</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="vii-melanoma">VII. MELANOMA<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#vii-melanoma" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Malignant neoplasm of melanocytes; most common cause of death from skin cancer
B. Risk factors are based on UVB-induced DNA damage and include prolonged exposure to sunlight, albinism, and xeroderma pigmentosum; an additional risk factor is dysplastic nevus syndrome (autosomal dominant disorder characterized by formation of dysplastic nevi that may progress to melanoma).
C. Presents as a mole-like growth with "ABCD" (Fig. 19.13)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-587b2feb.jpeg" alt="img-236.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.11 Vitiligo. (Courtesy of James Hellman, MD, Wikipedia)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1f5d6ed7.jpeg" alt="img-237.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.12 Congenital nevus. (Courtesy of Vesna Petronic-Rosic, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-1ac86703.jpeg" alt="img-238.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.13 Melanoma. (Courtesy of Vesna Petronic-Rosic, MD)</p>
<ol>
<li>Asymmetry</li>
<li>Borders are irregular.</li>
<li>Color is not uniform.</li>
<li>Diameter <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mo>&gt;</mo><mn>6</mn><mrow><mtext>&nbsp;</mtext><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mrow></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">&gt;6 \mathrm{~mm}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.5782em; vertical-align: -0.0391em;"></span><span class="mrel">&gt;</span><span class="mspace" style="margin-right: 0.2778em;"></span></span><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6444em;"></span><span class="mord">6</span><span class="mord"><span class="mspace nobreak">&nbsp;</span><span class="mord mathrm">mm</span></span></span></span></span></span>
D. Characterized by two growth phases</li>
<li>Radial growth horizontally along the epidermis and superficial dermis; low risk of metastasis</li>
<li>Vertical growth into the deep dermis
i. Increased risk of metastasis; depth of extension (Breslow thickness) is the most important prognostic factor in predicting metastasis.
E. Variants include</li>
<li>Superficial spreading-most common subtype; dominant early radial growth results in good prognosis.</li>
<li>Lentigo maligna melanoma-lentiginous proliferation (radial growth); good prognosis</li>
<li>Nodular-early vertical growth; poor prognosis</li>
<li>Acral lentiginous-arises on the palms or soles, often in dark-skinned individuals; not related to UV light exposure</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="infectious-disorders">INFECTIOUS DISORDERS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#infectious-disorders" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="i-impetigo">I. IMPETIGO<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#i-impetigo" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Superficial bacterial skin infection, most often due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span></span> aureus or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span></span> pyogenes
B. Commonly affects children
C. Presents as erythematous macules that progress to pustules, usually on the face; rupture of pustules results in erosions and dry, crusted, honey-colored serum.</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="ii-cellulitis">II. CELLULITIS<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#ii-cellulitis" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Deeper (dermal and subcutaneous) infection, usually due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span></span> aureus or <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span></span> pyogenes
B. Presents as a red, tender, swollen rash with fever
C. Risk factors include recent surgery, trauma, or insect bite.
D. Can progress to necrotizing fasciitis with necrosis of subcutaneous tissues due to infection with anaerobic 'flesh-eating' bacteria</p>
<ol>
<li>Production of <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">O</mi></mrow><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">\mathrm{CO}_{2}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8333em; vertical-align: -0.15em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"><span class="mord mathrm">CO</span></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t vlist-t2"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.3011em;"><span style="top: -2.55em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord mtight">2</span></span></span></span></span><span class="vlist-s">​</span></span><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.15em;"><span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> leads to crepitus.</li>
<li>Surgical emergency</li>
</ol>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="iii-staphylococcal-scalded-skin-syndrome">III. STAPHYLOCOCCAL SCALDED SKIN SYNDROME<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#iii-staphylococcal-scalded-skin-syndrome" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>A. Sloughing of skin with erythematous rash and fever; leads to significant skin loss
B. Due to <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">S</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.05764em;">S</span></span></span></span></span> aureus infection; exfoliative A and B toxins result in epidermolysis of the stratum granulosum.
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-7991fb8c.jpeg" alt="img-239.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.14 Verruca. (Courtesy of Vesna PetronicRosic, MD)
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-95974f08.jpeg" alt="img-240.jpeg"></p>
<p>Fig. 19.15 Molluscum bodies.</p>
<p>C. Distinguished histologically from toxic epidermal necrolysis by level of skin separation; separation in TEN occurs at the dermal-epidermal junction.
IV. VERRUCA (WART)
A. Flesh-colored papules with a rough surface (Fig. 19.14)
B. Due to HPV infection of keratinocytes; characterized by koilocytic change
C. Hands and feet are common locations.
V. MOLLUSCUM CONTAGIOSUM
A. Firm, pink, umbilicated papules due to poxvirus; affected keratinocytes show cytoplasmic inclusions (molluscum bodies, Fig. 19.15)
B. Most often arise in children; also occur in sexually active adults and immunocompromised individuals</p>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="index">Index<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#index" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="x">X<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#x" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Xanthochromia, 186
Xanthoma, 119 t
Xeroderma pigmentosum, 209
Xerophthalmia, 2
Xerostomia, 19
X-linked agammaglobinemia, 16

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="yyy"><span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">Y</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.6833em;"></span><span class="mord mathnormal" style="margin-right: 0.22222em;">Y</span></span></span></span></span><span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#yyy" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>

<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h1 level="1" id="fundamentals-of-pathology-medical-course-and-step-1-review">FUNDAMENTALS OF PATHOLOGY MEDICAL COURSE AND STEP 1 REVIEW<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#fundamentals-of-pathology-medical-course-and-step-1-review" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h1></div>
<div data-testid="stHeadingWithActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-1p9ibxm e1icttdg2"><h2 level="2" id="master-the-subject-of-pathology-quickly-and-easily">MASTER THE SUBJECT OF PATHOLOGY QUICKLY AND EASILY.<span data-testid="stHeaderActionElements" class="st-emotion-cache-gi0tri e1icttdg3"><a href="#master-the-subject-of-pathology-quickly-and-easily" class="st-emotion-cache-yinll1 e1icttdg1"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" width="16" height="16" viewBox="0 0 24 24" fill="none" stroke="currentColor" stroke-width="2" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-linejoin="round"><path d="M15 7h3a5 5 0 0 1 5 5 5 5 0 0 1-5 5h-3m-6 0H6a5 5 0 0 1-5-5 5 5 0 0 1 5-5h3"></path><line x1="8" y1="12" x2="16" y2="12"></line></svg></a></span></h2></div>
<p>Fundamentals of Pathology is a unique text that combines Dr. Sattar's extensive teaching experience with his clear, principle-based, and engaging teaching style.</p>
<ul>
<li>Online videos by Dr. Sattar covering the entire text</li>
<li>High-yield outline format covering all major topics in pathology</li>
<li>Integrated review with key concepts from associated disciplines</li>
<li>Over 350 high-quality, full-color images</li>
<li>Focus on high-yield and highly tested material</li>
<li>Perfect for course examinations and board review</li>
</ul>
<p>Fundamentals of Pathology is your essential tool to exam success!
<img src="assets/images/image-20251213-45681c13.jpeg" alt="img-241.jpeg"></p>
<p>Husain Sattar, MD, is an Associate Professor of Pathology at the University of Chicago's Pritzker School of Medicine. He has been involved in medical education, including USMLE <span class="math math-inline"><span class="katex"><span class="katex-mathml"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><semantics><mrow><msup><mrow></mrow><mtext>TM&nbsp;</mtext></msup></mrow><annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{ }^{\text {TM }}</annotation></semantics></math></span><span class="katex-html" aria-hidden="true"><span class="base"><span class="strut" style="height: 0.8413em;"></span><span class="mord"><span class="mord"></span><span class="msupsub"><span class="vlist-t"><span class="vlist-r"><span class="vlist" style="height: 0.8413em;"><span style="top: -3.063em; margin-right: 0.05em;"><span class="pstrut" style="height: 2.7em;"></span><span class="sizing reset-size6 size3 mtight"><span class="mord mtight"><span class="mord text mtight"><span class="mord mtight">TM&nbsp;</span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span></span> Step 1 pathology review, for nearly a decade. His lucid style, big-idea approach, and ability to simplify difficult concepts have made him a favorite of medical students throughout the country and the world.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div data-testid="stAppIframeResizerAnchor" data-iframe-height="true" class="st-emotion-cache-1dumvfu eht7o1d9"></div></section></div></div></div><div data-testid="portal" id="portal" class="st-emotion-cache-1q6lfs0 e19n7mk11"></div></div><div class=""></div></div>
